paragraphs.content: Ὅτι μὲν οὖν ἐκ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ τὰ μὲν ζώων σώματα κέκραται καὶ ὡς οὐκ ἴση πάντων ἐστὶν ἐν τῇ κράσει μοῖρα παλαιοῖς ἀνδράσιν ἱκανῶς ἀποδέδεικται φιλοσόφων τε καὶ ἰατρῶν τοῖς ἀρίστοις· εἴρηται δὲ καὶ πρὸς ἡμῶν ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν τὰ εἰκότα δι’ ἑτέρου γράμματος ἐν ᾧ περὶ τῶν καθ’ Ἱπποκράτην στοιχείων ἐσκοπούμεθα. νυνὶ δὲ ὅπερ ἐστὶν ἐφεξῆς ἐκείνῳ τῶν κράσεων ἁπάσας ἐξευρεῖν τὰς διαφορὰς ὁπόσαι τέ εἰσι καὶ ὁποῖαι
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.1:

That the bodies of living creatures are compounded from hot and cold and dry and moist, and that the proportion in the mixture is not equal in all cases, has been adequately demonstrated by the men of old, by the best of both the philosophers and the physicians. And we ourselves have also stated the probable views concerning these matters in another work, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates. But now what follows next after that work is to discover all the differences of mixtures [temperaments], both how many they are and of what kind.

---

**Brief notes:**
- *κρᾶσις* (krasis) = "mixture" or "blending," often translated as "temperament" or "complexion" in medical contexts, referring to the balance of the four qualities in the body
- The four qualities mentioned (hot, cold, dry, moist) are the fundamental properties in ancient Greek humoral theory
- This appears to be from Galen's *De Temperamentis* (On Mixtures/Temperaments)
paragraphs.openai_translation: That the bodies of animals are compounded from the hot, the cold, the dry, and the moist, and that in the mixture the share of each is not equal, has been adequately demonstrated by the ancients, the best among both philosophers and physicians; and I too have set forth the likely accounts on their behalf in another treatise, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates [stoicheia]. Now, what follows upon that is to discover all the differences of mixtures [krasis], how many they are and of what sort.

paragraphs.content: κατ’ εἴδη τε καὶ γένη διαιρούμενος ἐν τῷδε τῷ γράμματι δίειμι τὴν ἀρχὴν ἀπὸ τῆς τῶν ὀνομάτων ἐξηγήσεως ποιησάμενος. ἐπειδὰν μὲν γὰρ ἐκ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ κεκρᾶσθαι λέγωσι τὰ σώματα τῶν ἄκρως τοιούτων ἀκούειν φασὶ χρῆναι τοῦτ’ ἔστι τῶν στοιχείων αὐτῶν ἀέρος καὶ πυρὸς καὶ ὕδατος καὶ γῆς. ἐπειδὰν δὲ ζῶον ἢ φυτὸν ἢ θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν ἢ ξηρὸν ἢ ὑγρὸν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.2:

Dividing [the subject] according to species and genera, I shall proceed in this treatise, having made a beginning from the explanation of terms. For whenever they say that bodies are compounded from hot and cold and dry and wet, they claim one must understand this as referring to those things which are such in the extreme degree—that is, to the elements themselves: air and fire and water and earth. But whenever [they speak of] an animal or a plant or [something] hot or cold or dry or wet

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end of this excerpt.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Proceeding by division into species and genera, in this treatise I will set forth the matter, beginning from the explanation of the terms. For whenever they say that bodies are mixed [mixture, krasis] from the hot and the cold and the dry and the moist, they say one must understand things of the extreme sort—namely, their elements [stoicheia]: air, fire, water, and earth. And whenever they say “living being” or “plant” or “hot” or “cold” or “dry” or “moist”...

paragraphs.content: οὐκέθ’ ὡσαύτως. οὐδὲ γὰρ δύνασθαι ζῶον οὐδὲν οὔτ’ ἄκρως θερμὸν ὑπάρχειν ὡς πῦρ οὔτ’ ἄκροις ὑγρὸν ὡς ὕδωρ· ὡσαύτως δὲ οὐδὲ ψυχρὸν ἢ ξηρὸν ἐσχάτως· ἀλλ’ ἀπὸ τοῦ πλεονεκτοῦντος ἐν τῇ κράσει γίνεσθαι τὰς προσηγορίας ὑγρὸν μὲν καλούντων ἡμῶν ἐν ᾧ πλείονος ὑγρότητός ἐστι μοῖρα ξηρὸν δὲ ἐν ᾧ ξηρότητος· οὕτω δὲ καὶ θερμὸν μὲν ἐν ᾧ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλεονεκτεῖ ψυχρὸν δὲ ἐν ᾧ τὸ ψυχρὸν τοῦ θερμοῦ. αὕτη μὲν τῶν ὀνομάτων χρῆσις.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

No longer in the same way. For no animal can be either extremely hot like fire or extremely moist like water; and likewise neither cold nor dry in the extreme. Rather, the designations arise from what predominates in the mixture, with us calling "moist" that in which there is a greater portion of moisture, and "dry" that in which there is dryness; and similarly also "hot" that in which the hot predominates over the cold, and "cold" that in which the cold predominates over the hot. This, then, is the usage of the terms.
paragraphs.openai_translation: No longer in the same way. For no living being can exist in an extreme state—neither utterly hot like fire nor utterly moist like water; likewise, neither at the ultimate extreme of cold or of dry. Rather, our designations arise from what predominates in the mixture [krâsis: blending/constitution]: we call “moist” that in which there is a greater portion of moisture, and “dry” that in which there is a greater portion of dryness; and so too “hot” where the hot predominates over the cold, and “cold” where the cold predominates over the hot. Such, then, is the usage of these terms.

paragraphs.content: Ὥρα δ’ ἂν εἴη λέγειν ἤδη καὶ περὶ τῶν κράσεων αὐτῶν. ἡ μὲν δὴ πλείστη δόξα τῶν ἐπιφανεστάτων ἰατρῶν τε καὶ φιλοσόφων ὑγρὰν εἶναι καὶ θερμὴν κρᾶσιν ἑτέραν τῆς ὑγρᾶς καὶ ψυχρᾶς καὶ τρίτην ἐπὶ ταύταις τὴν ξηρὰν καὶ ψυχρὰν ἑτέραν τῆς ξηρᾶς τε ἅμα καὶ θερμῆς. ἔνιοι δ’ ἐξ αὐτῶν ὑγρὰν μέν τινα καὶ ψυχρὰν ἅμα κρᾶσιν ὑπάρχειν φασὶ θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰν ἑτέραν· οὐ μὴν οὔτε τὴν ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.1:

Now it would be time to speak also about the mixtures [*kraseis*] themselves. The prevailing opinion of the most distinguished physicians and philosophers is that there is one mixture that is moist and hot, different from the moist and cold one, and a third in addition to these, the dry and cold one, different from the one that is both dry and hot. But some of them say that there exists a certain mixture that is both moist and cold, and another that is both hot and dry; however, they do not accept either the one that is both moist and hot

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence. The term *krasis* (κρᾶσις) refers to the mixture or blending of qualities, a fundamental concept in ancient Greek medical theory, particularly in humoral pathology where health was understood as a balance of hot, cold, moist, and dry qualities.
paragraphs.openai_translation: It would now be time to speak also about their mixtures [kraseis: mixtures/temperaments]. The most widespread opinion among the most eminent physicians and philosophers is that there is a wet-and-hot mixture, distinct from the wet-and-cold, and, in addition to these, a third, the dry-and-cold, distinct from the dry-and-hot as well. Some of them say that there exists a certain mixture that is at once wet and cold, and another that is at once hot and dry; but not, at any rate, the wet-and-at-the-same-time hot—

paragraphs.content: οὔτε τὴν ψυχρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηράν. οὐ γὰρ ἐγχωρεῖν οὔθ’ ὑγρότητα πλεονεκτούσῃ θερμότητι συνδραμεῖν οὔτε ξηρότητα ψυχρότητι. δαπανᾶσθαι μὲν γὰρ ὑπὸ τοῦ θερμοῦ κρατοῦντος τὴν ὑγρότητα καὶ οὕτως θερμὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν γίνεσθαι τὸ σῶμα μένειν δὲ ἄπεπτόν τε καὶ ἀκατέργαστον ἐν οἶς ἂν σώμασιν ἀῤῥωστῇ τὸ θερμὸν ὥστ’ ἀναγκαῖον εἶναι θερμότητος μὲν ἐπικρατούσης ἕπεσθαι ξηρότητα ψυχρότητος δὲ πλεονεκτούσης ἀκολουθεῖν ὑγρότητα. οὗτοι μὲν οὖν κατὰ τάδε πεπείκασι σφᾶς αὐτοὺς
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

nor the cold and dry together. For it is not possible either for moisture to accompany predominant heat or for dryness to accompany coldness. For moisture is consumed by the prevailing heat, and thus the body becomes hot and dry at the same time; but [the body] remains undigested and unprocessed in those bodies in which the heat is weak, so that it is necessary that when heat predominates, dryness follows, and when coldness prevails, moisture follows. These men, then, have persuaded themselves according to these principles
paragraphs.openai_translation: “nor the cold together with the dry at the same time. For it is not possible for moisture to join with heat when the latter has the upper hand [i.e., is dominant], nor for dryness to accompany cold. For when heat prevails, the moisture is expended, and thus the body becomes both hot and dry; whereas it remains undigested and unworked [apéptos and akatérgastos] in whatever bodies the hot element is impaired. Hence it is necessary that, when heat is dominant, dryness follows, and when cold has the advantage, moisture follows. Such, then, are the considerations by which these people have persuaded themselves.”

paragraphs.content: ὡς δύο εἰσὶ πᾶσαι τῶν κράσεων αἱ διαφοραί.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
that all the differences of mixtures are two.

---

**Alternative translation:**

that there are two differences of all mixtures.
paragraphs.openai_translation: that all the differences of the mixtures [kraseis: mixtures/temperaments] are two in number.

paragraphs.content: ὅσοι δὲ τέτταρας εἶναι νομίζουσι διχῶς τούτοις ἀντιλέγουσιν· ἔνιοι μὲν εὐθὺς τὸ πρῶτον ἀξίωμα μὴ συγχωροῦντες ὡς ἐξικμάζεσθαι τὴν ὑγρότητα πρὸς τοῦ θερμοῦ κρατοῦντος ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστιν· ἔνιοι δὲ τοῦτο μὲν συγχωροῦσιν ἀμφισβητοῦσι δὲ ἑτέρως. οἱ μὲν δὴ πρῶτοι τοῦ θερμοῦ μὲν ἔργον εἶναί φασι τὸ θερμαίνειν ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ ψυχροῦ τὸ ψύχειν τοῦ ξηροῦ δ’ αὖ τὸ ξηραίνειν ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ ὑγροῦ τὸ ὑγραίνειν. καὶ διὰ τοῦτο
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Those who believe there are four [elements] oppose these arguments in two ways: some immediately do not concede the first premise, [arguing] that it is not necessary for moisture to be evaporated when heat prevails; others concede this point but dispute it in a different manner. Now the first group say that the function of heat is to heat, just as the function of cold is to cool, and in turn the function of dryness is to dry, just as the function of moisture is to moisten. And for this reason
paragraphs.openai_translation: But those who suppose there are four [primary qualities] oppose them in two ways. Some, to begin with, do not grant the first axiom, namely, that it is necessary for moisture to be dried out when heat is dominant; others grant this but dispute in a different way. The first group, at any rate, say that it is the function [ergon] of the hot to heat, just as it is of the cold to chill, and, in turn, of the dry to dry, just as it is of the wet to moisten. And for this reason—

paragraphs.content: ὅσα μὲν σώματα θερμὰ τὴν φύσιν ἐστὶν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰ καθάπερ τὸ πῦρ ᾗ μὲν θερμὰ θερμαίνει ᾗ δὲ ξηρὰ ξηραίνει.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Whatever bodies are hot in nature and at the same time dry, like fire, insofar as they are hot they heat, and insofar as they are dry they dry.
paragraphs.openai_translation: All bodies that are by nature hot are at the same time also dry, as fire is: in so far as they are hot they heat, and in so far as they are dry they dry [desiccate].

paragraphs.content: ὅσα δ’ ὑγρὰ καὶ θερμὰ καθάπερ ὕδωρ θερμὸν ὑγραίνειν ταῦτα καὶ θερμαίνειν πέφυκεν ἀεὶ ἓν ἑκατέρας κᾀνταῦθα ποιότητος ἔργον ἐχούσης ἀχώριστον. οὐκ οὖν συγχωροῦσιν εἴ τι θερμαῖνόν ἐστιν εὐθὺς τοῦτο καὶ ξηραίνειν· ἀλλ’ εἰ μὲν ὑγρότης προσείη τῇ θερμότητι θερμαίνειν ἅμα καὶ ὑγραίνειν ὥσπερ τὰ λουτρὰ τῶν γλυκέων ὑδάτων· εἰ δ’ ὥσπερ θερμὸν οὕτω καὶ ξηρὸν εἴη καθάπερ τὸ πῦρ οὐ θερμαίνειν μόνον ἀλλὰ καὶ ξηραίνειν εὐθὺς οὐκ ἐκ τῆς θερμότητος τοῦτο λαβὸν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.6:

Those things which are moist and hot, such as hot water, are naturally able both to moisten and to heat, each of the two qualities always having in this case as well a single inseparable function. Therefore, they do not concede that if something heats, this thing immediately also dries; rather, if moisture is present along with the heat, it heats and moistens at the same time, just as baths of fresh water do; but if it is dry just as it is hot, like fire, it not only heats but also immediately dries, deriving this [drying effect] not from the heat

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end, suggesting the paragraph continues beyond what is provided.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And whatever things are both moist and hot—just as hot water is—are naturally always both to moisten and to heat, each quality here having its own effect, one inseparable from the other. Therefore they do not concede that if something heats, it straightaway also dries; rather, if moisture is present along with heat, it heats and at the same time moistens, as the baths of fresh [i.e., “sweet”] water do. But if, like its heat, it is also dry, as fire is, it not only heats but also immediately dries—this latter not derived from its heat.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἐκ τῆς συνούσης αὐτῇ ξηρότητος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
but from the dryness that is present with it.

---

**Alternative translation:**

but from the dryness that accompanies it.
paragraphs.openai_translation: but from the dryness that accompanies it [i.e., the quality of dryness].

paragraphs.content: ὑπομιμνήσκουσι δ’ ἐνταῦθα τῶν ἐν ἡλίῳ θερινῷ διατριψάντων ἐπιπλέον, εἶθ’, ὡς εἰκὸς, αὐανθέντων, ὅλον τε τὸ σῶμα καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ αὐχμηρὸν ἐχόντων, καὶ διψώντων οὐκ ἀνεκτῶς.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

They remind us at this point of those who have spent excessive time in the summer sun, and then, as is natural, have become dried up, having their whole body both dry and parched, and suffering from unbearable thirst.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And here they further recall those who have spent time in the summer sun and then, as is to be expected, have become dried out, having their whole body in a dry and parched [desiccated] condition, and thirsting beyond endurance.

paragraphs.content: ἴασιν γὰρ αὐτοῖς εἶναί φασιν ἑτοίμην τε καὶ ῥᾴστην οὐκ εἰ πίοιεν μόνον ἀλλὰ εἰ καὶ λούσαιντο θερμοῖς ὕδασι καὶ γλυκέσιν ὡς τῆς ὑγρότητος εἴτε μετὰ ψυχρότητος εἴτε μετὰ θερμότητος εἴη τὸ ἑαυτῆς δρᾷν δυναμένης ὑγραίνειν γὰρ τὰ πλησιάζοντα. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν λόγον φασὶ καὶ τὴν ξηρότητα ξηραίνειν ἀεί. τὸν γοῦν βοῤῥᾶν ξηρὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν ἄνεμον τυγχάνοντα ξηραίνειν ἅπαντα καὶ ψύχειν. καὶ τοῦτ’ εἶναι τὸ πρὸς Ὁμήρου λεγόμενον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.9:

For they say that there is a ready and very easy cure for them, not only if they should drink [the waters], but also if they should bathe in warm and sweet waters, on the grounds that moisture, whether it be accompanied by coldness or by warmth, is able to do its own work—namely, to moisten things that come near it. And according to the same reasoning, they say that dryness also always dries. At any rate, the north wind [Boreas], being a dry and cold wind, dries and cools everything. And this is what is said by Homer:
paragraphs.openai_translation: For they say that a cure for them is ready to hand and the easiest, not if they should drink only, but even if they should bathe in warm and “sweet” waters [i.e., fresh, non-saline], since moisture, whether accompanied by cold or by heat, is able to perform its own proper action—for it moistens what comes near it. And on the same principle they say that dryness too always dries. For instance, they say that the north wind [Boreas], being a dry and cold wind, dries everything and chills it; and that this is what is said in relation to Homer.

paragraphs.content: Ὡς δ’ ὅτ’ ὀπωρινὸς βορέης νεοαρδέ’ ἀλωὴν Αἶψα ξηραίνει.
paragraphs.openai_translation: As when the autumnal Boreas [the north wind] swiftly dries a newly watered orchard [alōē: garden/orchard].
paragraphs.claude_translation:
As when the autumn north wind quickly dries a newly watered threshing floor.

[Note: This is a simile fragment, likely from Homer's *Iliad* (Book 5, lines 499-500 or similar). "Ὀπωρινός" refers to the autumn/late summer season; "νεοαρδής" means "newly watered/moistened"; "ἀλωή" is a threshing floor.]

paragraphs.content: Κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον καὶ τὸν τοῦ μήκωνος ὀπὸν καὶ ἄλλα μυρία φάρμακα ξηραίνειν ἅμα καὶ ψύχειν.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And in the same way, the juice of the poppy [opium] and countless other drugs both dry and at the same time cool.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
And in the same manner, poppy juice [opium] and countless other drugs both dry and cool at the same time.

---

**Brief notes:**
- "τὸν τοῦ μήκωνος ὀπόν" literally "the juice of the poppy," refers to opium
- "ξηραίνειν ἅμα καὶ ψύχειν" indicates simultaneous drying and cooling properties, typical terminology in ancient Greek medical texts describing the qualities of substances

paragraphs.content: ὥστ’ οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον οὔτ’ εἴ τι ψυχρὸν εὐθὺς τοῦτο καὶ ὑγρὸν ὑπάρχειν οὔτ’ εἴ τι θερμὸν εὐθὺς καὶ ξηρόν· οὔκουν οὐδὲ τὴν θερμὴν κρᾶσιν ἐξ ἀνάγκης εἶναι καὶ ξηρὰν ἀλλὰ δύνασθαί ποτε τὸ μὲν θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλεονεκτεῖν ἐν τῇ κράσει τοῦ ζώου τὸ δ’ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ. καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ τὴν γένεσιν καὶ τὴν ἀλλοίωσιν καὶ τὴν μεταβολὴν ἐκ τῶν ἐναντίων εἰς τὰ ἐναντία γίνεσθαι. τίς γὰρ οὖν εἰπὼν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

So that it is not necessary either that if something is cold it should immediately also be moist, or that if something is hot it should immediately also be dry; therefore neither is it necessary that a hot mixture [krasis] should also be dry, but it is possible sometimes for the hot to predominate over the cold in the mixture of the living creature, and the moist over the dry. For indeed both generation and alteration and change occur from opposites to opposites. For who then, having said...

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence with "τίς γὰρ οὖν εἰπὼν" ("For who then, having said...")]
paragraphs.openai_translation: So it is not necessary that, if something is cold, it must straightaway also be moist, nor that, if something is hot, it must straightaway also be dry. Accordingly, a hot krasis [mixture/temperament] is not of necessity also dry; rather, it is possible that at times the hot may have the advantage over the cold in the animal’s krasis, while the moist has the advantage over the dry. For indeed both coming-to-be [genesis], alteration [alloiōsis], and change [metabolē] occur from opposites into opposites. Who, then, would say…

paragraphs.content: ὅτι τὸ λευκὸν ἠλλοιώθη τε καὶ μετέβαλεν ἐγένετο γὰρ θερμὸν οὐκ ἂν εἴη καταγέλαστος; ἐπιζητεῖ γὰρ ὁ λόγος οὐ τὴν κατὰ ψυχρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἀντίθεσιν ἀλλὰ τὴν κατὰ τὸ χρῶμα μεταβολήν· μεταβάλλει γὰρ τὸ μὲν λευκὸν εἰς τὸ μέλαν ὥσπερ καὶ τὸ μέλαν εἰς τὸ λευκὸν καὶ τὸ θερμὸν αὖ εἰς τὸ ψυχρὸν ὥσπερ καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν εἰς τὸ θερμόν. οὕτω δὲ καὶ τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν εἰς τὸ ξηρὸν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Would it not be ridiculous to say that the white thing has been altered and changed because it became hot? For the argument seeks not the opposition between cold and hot, but rather the change with respect to color; for the white changes into the black just as the black also changes into the white, and the hot in turn changes into the cold just as the cold also changes into the hot. And in the same way, the wet changes into the dry
paragraphs.openai_translation: Would it not be ridiculous to say that the white has undergone alteration and has changed—for it became hot? For the argument is seeking not the opposition with respect to cold and hot, but the change with respect to color [chrōma]; for white changes into black, just as black into white, and the hot in turn into the cold, just as the cold into the hot. And so too the moist into the dry—

paragraphs.content: τὸ δ’ αὖ ξηρὸν εἰς τὸ ὑγρόν. εἰ γὰρ δὴ φάσκει τις ἠλλοιῶσθαι τὸ σῶμα τῷ τέως ὑγρὸν ὑπάρχον εἶναι νῦν λευκὸν ἢ τῷ τέως ξηρὸν ὂν τὸ νῦν φαίνεσθαι μέλαν οὐκ ἂν ὑγιαίνειν δόξειεν. εἰ δέ γε τὸ τέως ὑγρὸν τὸ νῦν ξηρὸν φαίη γενέσθαι ἢ τὸ πρότερον ὑπάρχον μέλαν νῦν εἶναι λευκὸν ἢ ἐκ θερμοῦ ψυχρὸν ἢ ἐκ ψυχροῦ θερμὸν γεγονέναι σωφρονεῖν ἂν δόξειεν ὁ τοιοῦτος καὶ λέγειν τὰ εἰκότα. τὸ γὰρ μεταβάλλον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.14:

And again, the dry into the wet. For if someone were to claim that a body has been altered because what was previously wet is now white, or because what was previously dry now appears black, he would not seem to be in his right mind. But if he were to say that what was previously wet has now become dry, or that what previously was black is now white, or that it has become cold from hot or hot from cold, such a person would seem to be thinking sensibly and speaking plausibly. For what changes...

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence with "τὸ γὰρ μεταβάλλον" (For what changes...)]
paragraphs.openai_translation:
And again, the dry into the moist.

For if someone claims that a body has been altered because what was formerly moist is now white, or because what was formerly dry now appears black, he would not seem to be speaking sensibly [lit. “to be in good health”].

But if he were to say that what was formerly moist has now become dry, or that what previously was black is now white, or that it has become cold from being hot, or hot from being cold, such a person would seem to be sound-minded and to be saying what is reasonable [the pairs hot/cold and dry/moist are standard contrary qualities].

For that which changes...

paragraphs.content: ᾗ μεταβάλλει ταύτῃ μεταχωρεῖν δεῖ πρὸς τοὐναντίον. ἐγένετο γοῦν ἢ γίγνεται μουσικὸς ὅδε φαμὲν ἐξ οὐ μουσικοῦ δηλονότι καὶ γραμματικὸς ἐξ οὐ γραμματικοῦ καὶ ῥητορικὸς ἐξ οὐ ῥητορικοῦ· τὸ δ’ ἐκ μουσικοῦ γραμματικὸν ἢ ἐκ γραμματικοῦ μουσικὸν ἢ ἐξ ἄλλου τινὸς τῶν ἑτερογενῶν γίνεσθαί τι λέγειν ἄτοπον. ἐγχωρεῖ γὰρ τὸν τέως γραμματικὸν νῦν μουσικὸν γεγονέναι προσκτησάμενον τῇ γραμματικῇ τὴν μουσικὴν οὐκ ἀποβαλόντα τὴν γραμματικήν. καὶ μὴν εἰ προσεκτήσατό τι μένοντος τοῦ προτέρου παντί που δῆλον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.15:

In whatever respect something changes, in that respect it must move toward the opposite. At any rate, we say that this person became or is becoming musical from being non-musical, obviously, and literate from being non-literate, and skilled in rhetoric from being non-rhetorical. But to say that something becomes literate from being musical, or musical from being literate, or from some other thing of a different kind is absurd. For it is possible that someone who was previously literate has now become musical by acquiring music in addition to literacy without having lost his literacy. And yet if he has acquired something additional while the former quality remains, it is surely clear to everyone

---

**Brief notes:**
- μουσικός refers to one skilled in music/the arts
- γραμματικός refers to one who is literate/skilled in letters
- ῥητορικός refers to one skilled in rhetoric/oratory
- The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end
paragraphs.openai_translation: In the respect in which it changes, it must pass over to the opposite. For we say that this man has become, or is becoming, musical from being unmusical, plainly, and a grammarian from being ungrammatical, and a rhetorician from being unrhetorical. But to say that something becomes a grammarian from being musical, or musical from being a grammarian, or from some other of the heterogeneous [things of a different kind], is absurd. For it is possible that the man who was previously a grammarian has now become musical, having acquired music in addition to grammar, without having discarded grammar. And indeed, if he has acquired something while the prior [state] remains, it is clear to everyone.

paragraphs.content: ὡς οὐκ ἠλλοιώθη κατὰ τὸ μένον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
"as it was not altered with respect to what remains."

---

**Alternative translation:**

"since it has not undergone alteration in respect to that which persists."
paragraphs.openai_translation: “that it was not altered with respect to what remains [the enduring element].”

paragraphs.content: ὥστ’ οὐκ ἐκ γραμματικοῦ μουσικὸς ἐγένετο· καὶ γὰρ καὶ νῦν ἔτι γραμματικός ἐστιν· ἀλλ’ ἐξ ἀμούσου μουσικός· οὐ γὰρ ἔτ’ ἐγχωρεῖ μένειν αὐτὸν ἄμουσον μουσικόν γε ἤδη γεγονότα. πασῶν γοῦν τῶν μεταβολῶν ὑπὸ τῶν ἐναντίων τε κᾀκ τῶν ἐναντίων εἰς τὰ ἐναντία γιγνομένων δηλονότι καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν εἰ μεταβάλλει ποτὲ καθ’ ὅσον ὑγρὸν αὐτό τε ξηρανθήσεται καὶ τὸ ξηραῖνον αὐτὸ ξηρὸν λεχθήσεται. μὴ τοίνυν λεγόντων φασὶν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

So it is not from being a grammarian that he became musical; for indeed even now he is still a grammarian. Rather, from being unmusical he became musical; for it is no longer possible for him to remain unmusical once he has already become musical. At any rate, since all changes occur by means of opposites and from opposites into opposites, clearly if the moist ever changes insofar as it is moist, it will itself be dried and that which dries it will be called dry. Therefore, they say, let them not say—

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence with "μὴ τοίνυν λεγόντων φασὶν" suggesting this is an incomplete excerpt or leads into the next section.]
paragraphs.openai_translation: So it was not from being a grammarian [grammatikos] that he became a musician [mousikos]; for even now he is still a grammarian. Rather, he became a musician from being unmusical [amousos]; for it is no longer admissible that he remain unmusical, now that he has already become a musician. In general, at any rate, since all changes come about both by contraries and from contraries into contraries [enantia], it is evident that, if the moist ever undergoes change, insofar as it is moist, both it itself will be dried, and the thing that dries it will be called dry. “Let them not then—so they say—be people who say …”

paragraphs.content: ὡς θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν οὐκ ἐγχωρεῖ γενέσθαι. θερμὴν μὲν γὰρ ἅμα καὶ ψυχρὰν εἶναι τὴν αὐτὴν ἢ ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰν οὐκ ἐγχωρεῖ· συνυπάρχειν γὰρ ἀλλήλαις οὐχ οἷόν τε καθ’ ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ σῶμα τὰς ἐναντίας ποιότητας· ἅμα δ’ ὑγρόν τι καὶ θερμὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν εἶναι δυνατὸν ὡς ὅ τε λόγος ἀπέδειξε καὶ τὰ σμικρῷ πρόσθεν εἰρημένα παραδείγματα. τοιοῦτος μὲν οὖν ὁ τῶν προτέρων λόγος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"...that a mixture that is both hot and moist cannot come into being. For it is not possible for the same thing to be both hot and cold at the same time, or both moist and dry at the same time; for it is impossible for contrary qualities to coexist with one another in one and the same body. But it is possible for something to be both moist and hot at the same time, and both cold and dry at the same time, as both reason has demonstrated and the examples mentioned a little earlier have shown. Such, then, is the argument of the earlier thinkers."
paragraphs.openai_translation: ERROR: Empty translation returned from OpenAI

paragraphs.content: ὁ δὲ τῶν δευτέρων οὐδὲν ἄτοπον εἶναί φησιν, ὑποκειμένου τοῦ θερμοῦ δραστικωτάτου τῶν τεττάρων, ὡς μὴ μόνον εἰς τὸ ψυχρὸν, ἀλλὰ καὶ εἰς τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐνεργεῖν, εἶναι κρᾶσιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ὅταν ἐς ταὐτὸ ἅμα συνέλθῃ πλῆθος ὑγρότητός τε καὶ θερμότητος εὐθὺς ἐν τῇ πρώτῃ γενέσει τοῦ ζώου.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But the proponent of the second view says that there is nothing absurd in this: given that the hot is the most active of the four [elements/qualities], so that it acts not only upon the cold but also upon the moist, there can be a mixture that is moist and hot, whenever an abundance of both moisture and heat come together at the same time right at the first generation of the living creature.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But the proponent of the second view says there is nothing absurd in this: assuming that heat is the most active of the four [primary qualities], since it acts not only upon the cold but also upon the moist, there is a moist and hot krasis [mixture/temperament] whenever a large amount of both moisture and heat comes together at once in the same subject, immediately in the animal’s first formation.

paragraphs.content: ὁ δὲ λόγος ἐκείνων οὐχ ὡς οὐκ ἄν ποτε γένοιτο καθ’ ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ σῶμα τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ πλέον τὸ δὲ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ δείκνυσιν ἀλλ’ ὡς οὐκ ἂν διαμείναι τοιοῦτο ἄχρι παντός· ἀεὶ γὰρ ἐξικμαζόμενον ὑπὸ τοῦ θερμοῦ τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐν τῷ χρόνῳ ξηρὸν ἀποδείξει τὸ σῶμα· καὶ οὕτως οὐκ ἂν ἔτι θερμὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν ἀλλὰ θερμὸν εἴη καὶ ξηρόν· αὐτὸ δ’ οὖν πάλιν τοῦτο τὸ θερμὸν καὶ ξηρὸν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But their argument shows not that it could never happen that in one and the same body the moist should be greater than the dry and the hot than the cold, but rather that such a state could not persist forever; for the moisture, being constantly evaporated by the heat over time, will render the body dry; and thus it would no longer be hot and moist but would be hot and dry; and then again this very thing, the hot and dry—
paragraphs.openai_translation: But their argument does not show that it could never occur that, in one and the same body, the moist exceeds the dry and the hot the cold; rather, it shows that such a condition would not endure indefinitely. For since the moist is continually being dried out [desiccated] by the hot, over time it will render the body dry; and thus it would no longer be hot and moist, but hot and dry. And this very state, hot and dry, in turn—

paragraphs.content: ἐπὶ προήκοντι τῷ χρόνῳ ξηρὸν ἔσται καὶ ψυχρόν. ἐπειδὰν γὰρ ἐκβοσκήσηται τὴν ἰκμάδα πᾶσαν αὐτοῦ τὸ θερμὸν ἄρχεται τοὐντεῦθεν ἤδη φασὶ καὶ αὐτὸ μαραίνεσθαι μηκέτ’ εὐποροῦν τροφῆς ὅθεν ἐξήπτετο. θαυμαστὸν οὖν οὐδὲν εἶναι νομίζουσι καὶ κατ’ ἀρχὰς μὲν εὐθὺς ἐν τῇ πρώτῃ γενέσει τοῦ ζώου συνδραμεῖν εἰς ταὐτὸ ἢ τὸ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ πλέον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

As time advances, it will be dry and cold. For when the heat has consumed all its moisture, they say that from this point onward the heat itself begins to waste away, no longer having an abundant supply of the nourishment from which it was kindled. Therefore, they consider it no wonder that even at the beginning, immediately at the first generation of the living creature, either the moist comes together into the same place in greater quantity than the dry
paragraphs.openai_translation: As time advances it will become dry and cold. For whenever the heat has grazed out all its moisture [ἰκμάς: sap/moisture], from that point, they say, it begins itself as well to wither, no longer well supplied with the nourishment from which it had been kindled. Therefore they think it nothing remarkable if, at the beginning—straightaway in the animal’s first coming-to-be—the moist either runs together into the same [i.e., is in equal proportion] with the dry, or the moist is more than the dry.

paragraphs.content: ἢ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ. δυνατὸν δὲ κᾀν τῷ χρόνῳ προϊόντι γίνεσθαι τὴν τέως θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν αὖθις θερμὴν καὶ ξηρὰν ὥσπερ γε καὶ αὖθις πάλιν τὴν ξηρὰν καὶ θερμὴν ἀποσβεννυμένου τοῦ θερμοῦ ψυχρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν ἀποτελεσθῆναι.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

or the hot over the cold. It is also possible for a mixture that is at first hot and moist to become in turn hot and dry as time progresses, just as indeed conversely a dry and hot mixture can become cold and dry when the heat is extinguished.
paragraphs.openai_translation: —or the hot [prevails] over the cold. And it is possible, as time goes on, for the mixture [krasis] that was formerly hot and moist to become again hot and dry, just as indeed, in turn, the dry and hot, when the heat is quenched, comes to be cold and dry.

paragraphs.content: ὅτι μὲν οὖν ἐγχωρεῖ καὶ θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν εἶναί τινα, καὶ ψυχρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν ἑτέραν τῆσδε κρᾶσιν, ἐκ τούτων ἀποδεικνύουσιν. ὅτι δὲ πλείους τῶν τεττάρων διαφορὰς κράσεων ἀδύνατον ὑπάρχειν, ἐκ τῶνδε πειρῶνται διδάσκειν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

That it is possible, then, for one mixture to be both hot and moist at the same time, and for another mixture different from this one to be cold and dry, they demonstrate from these considerations. But that it is impossible for there to be more than four varieties of mixtures, they attempt to teach from the following arguments.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, that it is possible for something to be at once hot and moist, and that another, in respect of mixture [κρᾶσις: mixture/temperament], is cold and dry, they demonstrate from these considerations. And that it is impossible for there to be more than four differences of mixtures [i.e., combinations of hot/cold with moist/dry], they attempt to show from the following.

paragraphs.content: ὑποκειμένων γὰρ φασὶ τεττάρων ποιοτήτων εἰς ἀλλήλας τε τὸ δρᾷν καὶ πάσχειν ἐχουσῶν θερμότητός τε καὶ ψυχρότητος καὶ ξηρότητος καὶ ὑγρότητος ἀντιθέσεις γίνεσθαι δύο τὴν μὲν ἑτέραν ἐν ᾗ τὸ θερμὸν ἀντίκειται τῷ ψυχρῷ τὴν δ’ ἑτέραν ἐν ᾗ τὸ ξηρὸν τῷ ὑγρῷ καὶ διὰ τοῦτο τέτταρας ἀποτελεῖσθαι τὰς πάσας συζυγίας. ἓξ μὲν γὰρ γίνεσθαι τῶν τεττάρων ἀλλήλαις ἐπιπλεκομένων τὰς συζεύξεις ἀλλὰ τὰς δύο τούτων ἀδυνάτους ὑπάρχειν. οὔτε γὰρ ὑγρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For they say that there being four underlying qualities which have the power both to act upon and be acted upon by one another—heat and cold and dryness and moisture—two oppositions arise: one in which the hot is opposed to the cold, and the other in which the dry is opposed to the moist, and because of this all the combinations amount to four. For when the four are interwoven with one another, six couplings arise, but two of these turn out to be impossible. For neither can something be simultaneously moist and dry
paragraphs.openai_translation: For they say that, with four underlying qualities [the primary qualities]—heat, cold, dryness, and moistness—each having the capacity to act upon and to be acted upon by the others, there arise two oppositions: the one in which the hot is set against the cold, and the other in which the dry is set against the moist; and for this reason the total number of pairings is four. For although, when the four are interwoven with one another, six couplings would result, two of these are impossible; for [a thing can be] neither moist and dry at the same time...

paragraphs.content: οὔτε ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ θερμὸν δύναται γενέσθαι σῶμα. λείπεται γοῦν τέτταρας εἶναι συζυγίας κράσεων ὑγρὰς μὲν δύο ξηρὰς δὲ δύο θερμότητι καὶ ψυχρότητι διῃρημένας.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

A body cannot become both cold and hot at the same time. It remains, therefore, that there are four combinations of mixtures [or temperaments]: two moist and two dry, distinguished by heat and coldness.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Nor can a body be at once cold and hot. It follows, then, that there are four pairings of mixtures: two moist and two dry, distinguished by heat and by cold [krasis: the qualitative “mixture” or temperament].

paragraphs.content: ἃ μὲν οὖν οἱ χαριέστατοι τῶν πρὸ ἡμῶν ἰατρῶν τε καὶ φιλοσόφων εἰρήκασι, ταῦτά ἐστιν. ἃ δ’ ἐγὼ παραλιπεῖν αὐτοὺς νομίζω, λέγειν ἤδη καιρός.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

These, then, are the things which the most distinguished of the physicians and philosophers before us have said. But as for the things which I believe they have omitted, it is now time to speak.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So then, such are the things the most eminent of the physicians and philosophers before us have said. As for what I think they have left out, it is now time to speak.

paragraphs.content: Ἕν μὲν δὴ καὶ πρῶτον ὅτι τὴν εὔκρατον φύσιν ὥσπερ οὐκ ἀρετῇ τε ἅμα καὶ δυνάμει προὔχουσαν ἐπελάθοντό τε καὶ τελέως παρέλιπον ὥσπερ μηδ’ ὅλως οὖσαν καίτοι μηδὲ φθέγξασθαί τι χωρὶς ἐκείνης ὑπὲρ τῶν ἄλλων δυνάμενοι. τὸ γοῦν ἐν τῇ θερμῇ κράσει πλεονεκτεῖν τὸ θερμὸν ἢ ἐν τῇ ψυχρᾷ τὸ ψυχρὸν οὐδ’ ἐπινοῆσαι δυνατὸν ἄνευ τοῦ πρότερον ἐπιθέσθαι τὴν εὔκρατον. οὐδὲ γὰρ οὐδὲ τὴν ὑγιεινὴν δίαιταν εἰς ἄλλο τι βλέποντες ἐξευρίσκουσιν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 3.1:

One thing first and foremost: that they forgot and completely omitted the well-tempered nature, as if it did not excel in both virtue and power at the same time, as if it did not exist at all—even though they cannot say anything about the other [temperaments] without reference to it. At any rate, it is not possible even to conceive of the hot predominating in the hot mixture or the cold in the cold mixture without first grasping the well-tempered [mixture]. For indeed, they do not discover the healthy regimen by looking to anything else

---

**Explanatory notes:**
- [εὔκρατον φύσιν / well-tempered nature]: refers to the balanced mixture of qualities (hot, cold, wet, dry) in medical theory
- [κράσει / mixture]: technical term for the blend or temperament of bodily qualities
- [δίαιταν / regimen]: refers to a prescribed way of life, including diet and lifestyle habits
paragraphs.openai_translation: First, for one thing, they forgot and completely left out the well-balanced nature [eukratēs/physis: the “well-tempered” constitution], as though it were not in fact preeminent at once in excellence and in power, and indeed as though it did not exist at all—although they are not even able to say anything about the others apart from it. For the notion that in a hot mixture [krasis] the hot has the advantage, or in a cold one the cold, cannot even be conceived without first positing the well-balanced state. For they do not even discover the healthy regimen [diaita] by looking to anything else.

paragraphs.content: ἢ τὴν εὔκρατον ἐκείνην φύσιν· τὸ μὲν θερμότερον τοῦ δέοντος σῶμα κελεύοντες ἐμψύχειν τὸ δ’ αὖ ψυχρότερον θερμαίνειν· ὡσαύτως τὸ μὲν ὑγρότερον ξηραίνειν τὸ δὲ ξηρότερον ὑγραίνειν ἀντεισάγοντες ἀεὶ δηλονότι τῷ πλεονάζοντι τὸ λεῖπον ὡς εὔκρατόν τινα καὶ μέσην ἐργάσασθαι κατάστασιν. ἣν οὖν ἀεὶ μεταδιώκουσιν καὶ πρὸς ἣν ἀποβλέποντες ἐπανορθοῦνται τὰς δυσκράτους ἐγὼ μὲν ἠξίουν ἁπασῶν πρῶτον λέγεσθαι πρὸς αὐτῶν. οἳ δ’ ἄρα τοσοῦτον ἀποδέουσι τοῦ μεμνῆσθαι ταύτης ὥσθ’ ὅλως παραλείπουσιν αὐτήν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

or that well-tempered nature; commanding that the body which is hotter than necessary be cooled, and conversely that the colder one be heated; likewise that the more moist be dried and the drier be moistened, always introducing in opposition to what is in excess what is deficient, evidently so as to produce a certain well-tempered and middle condition. Therefore, the condition which they are always pursuing and with reference to which they correct the ill-tempered states [dyskrasiai], I myself thought ought to be mentioned first by them. But as it turns out, they are so far from remembering this that they omit it entirely.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
—or that well-balanced nature [eukratos]: directing the body that is warmer than is fitting to be cooled, and, conversely, the one that is colder to be warmed; likewise to dry what is too moist and to moisten what is too dry, always, plainly, introducing what is lacking in counterpoise to what is in excess, so as to produce a certain well-balanced and intermediate condition.

This, then, which they are always pursuing and, looking toward it, use to set right dyscrasias [imbalances of temperament/humors], I for my part thought ought, before all else, to be mentioned by them first. But in fact they fall so far short of remembering this that they leave it out altogether.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ οὐ παραλέλειπται φασὶν ἐξ αὐτῶν ἔνιοι ἐν γὰρ τῇ θερμῇ καὶ ὑγρᾷ περιέχεται. καὶ πῶς οὐχὶ πέντε λέγετε τὰς πάσας εἶναι κράσεις ἀλλὰ τέτταρας εἴπερ τῆς ἀρίστης μέμνησθε; δυοῖν γὰρ θάτερον ἢ τῶν δυσκράτων ἀνάγκη παραλελεῖφθαι μίαν ἢ τὴν εὔκρατον. ἐγὼ μὲν δὴ σαφῶς οἶδα τὴν εὔκρατον αὐτοὺς παραλιπόντας ἐξ ὧν ἀξιοῦσιν. ἐπειδὰν γὰρ θερμὴν καὶ ξηρὰν καὶ ψυχρὰν καὶ ὑγρὰν ἤ τινα ἄλλην λέγωσι κρᾶσιν οὐ τῶν ἄκρων ἀκούειν ἡμᾶς χρῆναι ποιοτήτων
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But they say that it has not been omitted by some of them, for it is included in the hot and moist. And how is it that you do not say there are five mixtures in all, but four, if indeed you make mention of the best one? For one of two things must be the case: either one of the ill-mixed must necessarily have been omitted, or the well-mixed one. Now I clearly know that they have omitted the well-mixed one based on what they maintain. For whenever they speak of a hot and dry mixture, or a cold and moist one, or some other mixture, they claim that we ought not to understand them as referring to the extreme qualities.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But some of them say it has not been left out; for it is encompassed within the warm-and-moist. And how is it that you say that the total number of mixtures [kraseis] is not five but four, if you keep the best in mind? For of two alternatives, either one of the ill-balanced states [dyskrasiai] must have been omitted, or the well-balanced one [eukrasia]. I, for my part, clearly know from what they themselves assert that it is the well-balanced one they have left out. For whenever they call a mixture hot, and dry, and cold, and moist—or some other kind—we ought not to understand extremes of the qualities.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ κατὰ τὴν πλεονεκτοῦσαν ἀεὶ γίνεσθαι προσηγορίαν. εἰ δ’ οὐ βούλονται τὴν εὔκρατον παραλελεῖφθαι τῶν ἄλλων τινὰ δειχθήσονται παραλιπόντες. ἔστω γὰρ εὔκρατον εἶναι τὴν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν ὥσπερ αὐτοὶ βούλονται. παραλελοίπασιν ἄρα σαφῶς τὴν ἀντικειμένην τῇ ψυχρᾷ καὶ ξηρᾷ δυσκρασίᾳ ἐν ᾗ τὸ ὑγρὸν πλεονεκτεῖ καὶ τὸ θερμόν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But that the designation always comes about according to whichever [quality] predominates. But if they do not wish the well-balanced [mixture] to have been omitted, they will be shown to have omitted one of the others. For let it be that the moist and hot [mixture] is well-balanced, just as they themselves wish. Therefore they have clearly omitted the [mixture] opposite to the cold and dry bad mixture [dyskrasia], in which the moist predominates along with the hot.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But the designation should always be made according to what predominates. And if they are unwilling to leave out the well-balanced [eukratos], they will be shown to have omitted one of the others. For let the moist and warm be called well-balanced, as they themselves wish. Then they have clearly left out the condition opposed to the cold-and-dry dyscrasia [bad mixture/imbalance], in which the moist and the hot have the upper hand.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ αὐτὴ, φασὶν, ἐστὶν ἥδε. καὶ πῶς ἐνδέχεται καὶ πλεονεκτεῖν ἅμα τὸ θερμὸν καὶ μὴ πλεονεκτεῖν, καὶ κρατεῖσθαι καὶ μὴ κρατεῖσθαι τὸ ψυχρόν; εἰ μὲν γὰρ εὔκρατός ἐστιν, οὐδὲν οὐδενὸς ἀμέτρως ἐπικρατεῖ, εἰ δὲ δύσκρατος, ἀνάγκη πλεονεκτεῖν τι τῶν ἐκ τῆς ἀντιθέσεως.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"But this itself, they say, is the problem. And how is it possible for the hot both to prevail at the same time and not to prevail, and for the cold both to be overcome and not to be overcome? For if [the mixture] is well-balanced [eukratos], nothing prevails excessively over anything else, but if it is ill-balanced [dyskratos], one of the elements from the opposition must necessarily prevail."
paragraphs.openai_translation: “But the account itself, they say, is this. And how is it possible that the hot should at once both have the advantage and not have it, and that the cold should both be mastered and not be mastered? For if it is well-tempered [eukratos: in balanced mixture/temperament], nothing prevails without measure over anything; but if it is ill-tempered [dyskrasia: an imbalanced mixture], then of necessity something from the opposition [antithesis: the pair of contraries] has the advantage.”

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ αὐτὸ τοῦτο φασὶν ἴδιόν ἐστι τῆς εὐκράτου τὸ κρατεῖν ἐν αὐτῇ τὸ μὲν θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ τὸ δ’ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ· κρατήσαντος γὰρ τοῦ ψυχροῦ μετρίως μὲν οὐκ ἀγαθὴν εἶναι τὴν κρᾶσιν ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον νόσον ἤδη γίνεσθαι καθάπερ εἰ καὶ σφοδρῶς κρατήσειε θάνατον· οὕτω δὲ κᾀπὶ τοῦ ξηροῦ συμπίπτειν ἐν ἀρχῇ μὲν δυσκρασίαν ἐπὶ πλέον δὲ νόσον ἐπὶ πλεῖστον δὲ κρατήσαντος
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But they say that this very thing is characteristic of the well-tempered [constitution]: that in it the hot prevails over the cold and the moist over the dry. For when the cold prevails, moderately indeed the mixture is no longer good, and still more a disease already comes to be, just as if it should prevail strongly, death [results]. And in the same way in the case of the dry also, it happens that at first there is bad temperament [dyskrasia], with greater [prevalence] disease, and when it prevails to the greatest degree—

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence. "Eukratos" refers to good temperament or balanced mixture of the humors; "dyskrasia" refers to bad temperament or imbalance.]
paragraphs.openai_translation: But, they say, this very thing is the distinctive mark of the well-balanced state [eucrasia]: that within it the hot prevails over the cold, and the moist over the dry. For when the cold gains the upper hand, in a moderate degree the mixture [of qualities] is not good; to a greater degree it already becomes disease; and if it should prevail violently, death. And so too with the dry: at the outset there occurs dyscrasia [bad mixture], then, to a greater extent, disease, and if it should prevail to the greatest degree—

paragraphs.content: θάνατον· ὥσπερ οὐχὶ κᾀπὶ τῆς ὑγρᾶς καὶ θερμῆς ταῦτα συμπίπτοντα. τίς γὰρ ἂν οὐχ ὁμολογήσειεν ὡς ἐπειδὰν μὲν ἐπ’ ὀλίγον ἢ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ τύχοι πλεονεκτῆσαν ἢ τὸ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ δυσκρασίαν οὕτως γιγνομένην· ἐπειδὰν δ’ ἐπὶ πλέον νόσον· ἐπειδὰν δ’ ἐπὶ πλεῖστον θάνατον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

death; as if these same things do not also occur in the case of the wet and the hot. For who would not agree that whenever the hot gains a slight advantage over the cold, or the wet over the dry, a bad mixture [dyskrasia] results in this way; but whenever [the advantage is] to a greater degree, disease [results]; and whenever to the greatest degree, death [results].
paragraphs.openai_translation: death; just as—do not these same results also occur with respect to the moist and the hot? For who would not agree that whenever, to a small extent, either the hot happens to gain the upper hand over the cold or the moist over the dry, a dyskrasia [imbalance of the mixture] thus arises; whenever to a greater extent, disease; and whenever to the greatest extent, death.

paragraphs.content: ὁ γὰρ αὐτὸς ἐπ’ ἀμφοῖν λόγος. ἢ μηδὲ τὰς ἀμέτρως ὑγρὰς καὶ θερμὰς καταστάσεις αἰτιώμεθα μηδ’ ὅσα μεθ’ ὑγρότητος ἀμέτρου νοσήματα συνίσταται θερμὰ μηδὲ ταῦτ’ ὁμολογῶμεν εἶναι νοσήματα. πρὸς δὴ τοὺς τοιούτους λόγους ἀπομαχόμενοί τινες τῶν ἀπ’ Ἀθηναίου τοῦ Ἀτταλέως ὁμόσε χωροῦσιν οὔτε κατάστασιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν μέμφεσθαι λέγοντες οὔθ’ εὑρεθῆναί τι νόσημα φάσκοντες ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἀλλὰ πάντως ἢ θερμὸν καὶ ξηρὸν ὑπάρχειν ὡς τὸν πυρετὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν ὡς τὸν ὕδερον
paragraphs.openai_translation: For the same argument applies in both cases. Either we must not blame states that are immoderately moist and hot, nor call hot those diseases that arise along with excessive moisture, nor even concede that these are diseases at all. Accordingly, in opposing arguments of this sort, some of the followers of Athenaeus of Attaleia press straight on, saying that one should not censure a moist-and-hot condition, and claiming that no disease is found to be moist and hot, but that in every case it is either hot and dry—like fever—or cold and moist—like dropsy [hydrops: generalized edema].
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 3.8:

For the same argument applies to both cases. Or else let us not blame excessively moist and hot conditions, nor acknowledge as diseases those hot ailments that arise with excessive moisture, nor agree that these are diseases at all. Now in response to such arguments, some of the followers of Athenaeus of Attaleia, fighting back, engage directly, saying that they do not find fault with a moist and hot condition, nor do they claim that any disease has been found to be moist and hot, but that in every case it is either hot and dry, like fever, or cold and moist, like dropsy [edema].

paragraphs.content: ἢ ψυχρὸν καὶ ξηρὸν ὡς τὴν μελαγχολίαν. ἐπιμέμνηνται δ’ ἐνταῦθα καὶ τῶν ὡρῶν τοῦ ἔτους ὑγρὸν μὲν καὶ ψυχρὸν εἶναι τὸν χειμῶνα φάσκοντες ξηρὸν δὲ καὶ θερμὸν τὸ θέρος καὶ ψυχρὸν καὶ ξηρὸν τὸ φθινόπωρον εὔκρατον δ’ ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν ὥραν καλοῦσι τὸ ἔαρ· οὕτω δὲ καὶ τῶν ἡλικιῶν τὴν παιδικὴν εὔκρατόν τε καὶ θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν εἶναί φασι. δηλοῦσθαι δὲ τὴν εὐκρασίαν αὐτῆς νομίζουσι κᾀκ τῶν ἐνεργειῶν τῆς φύσεως
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

or cold and dry like melancholy. And here they also make mention of the seasons of the year, saying that winter is wet and cold, summer is dry and hot, and autumn is cold and dry, while they call spring a well-tempered season, both hot and wet. And in the same way concerning the ages of life, they say that childhood is well-tempered and hot and wet. They believe that its good temperament [eucrasia] is demonstrated also by the activities of nature.
paragraphs.openai_translation: —or cold and dry, like melancholia [black bile]. They also take note here of the seasons of the year, asserting that winter is moist and cold, summer dry and hot, and autumn cold and dry, while they call spring a temperate season and at the same time warm and moist. Likewise, with respect to the ages of life, they say that childhood is both well-balanced and warm and moist. They think its well-balanced mixture [eukrasia] is shown also by the operations of nature.

paragraphs.content: ἐῤῥωμένων τηνικαῦτα μάλιστα. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ τὸν θάνατόν φασιν εἰς ξηρότητα καὶ ψύξιν ἄγειν τὰ τῶν ζώων σώματα. καλεῖσθαι γοῦν ἀλίβαντας τοὺς νεκροὺς ὡς ἂν μηκέτι λιβάδα καὶ ὑγρότητα κεκτημένους οὐδεμίαν ἐξατμισθέντας ἅμα διὰ τὴν ἀποχώρησιν τοῦ θερμοῦ καὶ παγέντας ὑπὸ τῆς ψύξεως.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

when they are especially vigorous at that time. And indeed they say that death leads the bodies of living creatures into dryness and coldness. At any rate, the dead are called "alibantes" [those without moisture] on the grounds that they no longer possess any moisture or wetness at all, having been evaporated simultaneously due to the departure of heat and having been frozen by the cold.
paragraphs.openai_translation: They are then at their strongest especially. And indeed, they say that death leads the bodies of living creatures into dryness and cold. Accordingly the dead are called “alibantes” [i.e., “without moisture”], as no longer possessing any trickling or moisture at all, having completely evaporated with the departure of heat and having been congealed by the cold.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ εἴπερ ὁ θάνατος φασὶ τοιοῦτος ἀναγκαῖον ἤδη τὴν ζωὴν ὡς ἂν ἐναντίαν ὑπάρχουσαν αὐτῷ θερμήν τε εἶναι καὶ ὑγράν· καὶ μὴν εἴπερ ἡ ζωὴ φασὶ θερμόν τι χρῆμα καὶ ὑγρόν ἐστιν ἀνάγκη πᾶσα καὶ τὴν ὁμοιοτάτην αὐτῇ κρᾶσιν ἀρίστην ὑπάρχειν εἰ δὲ τοῦτο παντί που δῆλον ὡς εὐκρατοτάτην ὥστ’ εἰς ταὐτὸ συμβαίνειν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν φύσιν εὐκράτῳ καὶ μηδὲν ἄλλο εἶναι τὴν εὐκρασίαν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But if indeed they say that death is of such a nature, it is now necessary that life, being opposite to it, be both hot and moist; and moreover, if they say that life is something hot and moist, it is entirely necessary that the mixture most similar to it be the best; and if this is surely clear to everyone, that it be most well-tempered [eukratos], so that it turns out to be the same thing—a hot and moist nature with a well-tempered one—and that good temperament [eukrasia] is nothing other than this.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But if, as they say, death is of such a sort, then it is necessary that life, as being its opposite, be warm and moist. And indeed, if they say that life is a certain warm and moist thing, it is altogether necessary that the mixture [krasis: blending/constitution] most like it be the best; and if this is evident to everyone as the most well-balanced [eukratotatē], then it follows that a moist and warm nature coincides with being well-balanced, and that eukrasia [good/appropriate mixture or temperament] is nothing else.

paragraphs.content: ἢ τῆς ὑγρότητός τε καὶ θερμότητος ἐπικρατούσης. οἱ μὲν δὴ τῶν ἀμφὶ τὸν Ἀθήναιον λόγοι τοιοίδε. δοκεῖ δέ πως ἡ αὐτὴ δόξα καὶ Ἀριστοτέλους εἶναι τοῦ φιλοσόφου καὶ Θεοφράστου γε μετ’ αὐτὸν καὶ τῶν Στωϊκῶν ὥστε καὶ τῷ πλήθει τῶν μαρτύρων ἡμᾶς δυσωποῦσιν. ἐγὼ δὲ περὶ μὲν Ἀριστοτέλους ὅπως ἐγίνωσκεν ὑπὲρ θερμῆς καὶ ὑγρᾶς κράσεως ἴσως ἂν εἰ δεηθείη ἐπὶ προήκοντι τῷ λόγῳ δείξαιμι· δοκοῦσι γάρ μοι παρακούειν αὐτοῦ.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

or when moisture and heat prevail. Such then are the arguments of the followers of Athenaeus. And it seems somehow that the same opinion belongs also to the philosopher Aristotle and to Theophrastus after him and to the Stoics, so that they try to overawe us by the multitude of witnesses. But I, concerning how Aristotle understood the matter regarding the hot and moist mixture [or: temperament], might perhaps demonstrate, if it should be necessary as the argument proceeds; for they seem to me to misunderstand him.
paragraphs.openai_translation: - “or that moisture and heat are in the ascendant [i.e., are dominant]. Such, then, are the arguments of the school of Athenaeus. And the same view, it seems, belongs to Aristotle the philosopher, and after him to Theophrastus, and to the Stoics as well, so that they overawe us by the number of their witnesses. As for Aristotle, however—how he understood the matter concerning a hot and moist krasis [mixture/temperament]—I could perhaps, if need arose, demonstrate at the appropriate point in the argument; for they seem to me to be mishearing him.”

paragraphs.content: Τὸ δέ γε νῦν εἶναι, πειράσομαι πρῶτον ἐνδείξασθαι τοῖς λέγουσι ταῦτα, πῆ ποτε σοφίζονται σφᾶς αὐτοὺς, εἶτ’ ἐφεξῆς ἐπιδεῖξαι τὸν ἅπαντα λόγον, εἰς ἓν ἀθροίσας κεφάλαιον.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But as things stand now, I shall attempt first to demonstrate to those who say these things in what way they are deceiving themselves, and then in turn to set forth the entire argument, having gathered it together into a single summary.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But as things now stand, I will first try to show to those who say these things how it is that they are practicing sophistry upon themselves, and then, in due order, to set forth the whole argument [logos], gathering it into a single summary [kephalaion].

paragraphs.content: ὅτι μὲν δὴ τὸ ἔαρ οἴονται θερμὸν εἶναι καὶ ὑγρὸν ἅμα καὶ εὔκρατον, ἐντεῦθεν σοφίζονται προφανῶς. οὔτε γὰρ ὑγρὸν ὡς χειμὼν, οὔτε θερμὸν ὡς τὸ θέρος, ὥστ’ οὐδέτερον ἀμέτρως.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

That they consider spring to be both warm and moist at the same time and well-tempered, they make clear by this sophistry. For it is neither moist like winter, nor warm like summer, so that neither quality is immoderate.
paragraphs.openai_translation: That spring, they suppose, is warm and moist at the same time and well-balanced [eukraton: in proper tempering], they make out clearly from the following. For it is neither moist like winter nor warm like summer, so that neither quality is in excess [ametros: immoderate].

paragraphs.content: ἀμετρίας δ’ ἦν ἕκαστον τῶν τοιούτων ὀνομάτων, καὶ κατ’ αὐτοὺς ἐκείνους, δηλωτικόν. διχῶς δ’ ἐσφάλησαν, πρῶτον μὲν ἐκ τοῦ βούλεσθαι πάντως ἐν ταῖς ὥραις εὑρεῖν τὴν τετάρτην συζυγίαν τῶν κράσεων, ἔπειτα δ’ ἐκ τοῦ καὶ θερμότερον ἢ κατὰ τὸν χειμῶνα, καὶ ὑγρότερον ἢ κατὰ τὸ θέρος ὑπάρχειν αὐτό.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Each of these terms was indicative of imbalance, even according to those men themselves. But they erred in two ways: first, from wishing at all costs to find the fourth pairing of mixtures among the seasons, and second, from the fact that it [spring] is both warmer than winter and moister than summer.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Each of such names denoted excess—by their own admission, a sign of it. And they went wrong in two ways: first, by insisting on finding in the seasons the fourth pairing of the mixtures [krasis: mixture/temperament; syzygia: pairing; hōrai: the seasons]; second, by asserting that it [sc. the season in question] is both warmer than in winter and wetter than in summer.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ οὔτ’ ἀναγκαῖον ἐν ταῖς ὥραις ὑποτίθεσθαι τὴν τετάρτην συζυγίαν τῶν κράσεων εἰ μὴ καὶ φαίνοιτο καὶ τὸ παραβάλλειν αὐτὸ ταῖς ἑκατέρωθεν ὥραις οὐδὲν μᾶλλον ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν ἀποδείξει καὶ ξηρόν. εἰ μὲν γὰρ ἀμετρίας ἐστὶν ὀνόματα τὸ ὑγρὸν καὶ τὸ θερμὸν οὐκ ἀληθεύεται κατ’ αὐτούς· σύμμετρον γὰρ ἐν ἅπασι τὸ ἔαρ. εἰ δ’ ὅτι θέρους μέν ἐστιν ὑγρότερον χειμῶνος δὲ θερμότερον ὑγρόν ἐστι καὶ θερμὸν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But it is neither necessary to posit the fourth combination of mixtures in the seasons unless it also appears to be the case, nor will comparing it to the seasons on either side prove it to be any more moist and hot than cold and dry. For if "moist" and "hot" are names of imbalances, the statement is not true according to them; for spring is balanced in all respects. But if spring is moist and hot because it is moister than summer and hotter than winter
paragraphs.openai_translation: But it is not necessary, in the case of the seasons, to posit a fourth combination [syzygia] of the mixtures [kraseis], unless it both appears as such and a comparison of it with the seasons on either side shows it to be no more moist and hot than cold and dry. For if “moist” and “hot” are names of excess [ametria], this does not hold on those terms; for spring is proportionate in all respects. But if, because it is wetter than summer and hotter than winter, it is [therefore] moist and hot...

paragraphs.content: οὐδὲν ἦττον αὐτὸ ψυχρὸν καὶ ξηρὸν νομίζεσθαι προσήκει διότι θέρους μέν ἐστι ψυχρότερον χειμῶνος δὲ ξηρότερον. ἢ τίς ἀποκλήρωσις ἓν μὲν τῶν ἐκ τῆς ἀντιθέσεως ἀπὸ τοῦ χειμῶνος ἓν δὲ ἀπὸ τοῦ θέρους λαμβάνειν; ἐν ἑκατέραις γὰρ ἀμφοτέρων διαφέρον οὐκ ἐξ ἡμίσεως ὀφείλει τὴν παραβολὴν ἀλλ’ ὁλόκληρον ἴσχειν. καὶ μὴν εἴπερ οὕτως γίνοιτο τἀναντία φήσομεν ὑπάρχειν αὐτῷ. θερμὸν μὲν γὰρ ἔσται καὶ ξηρὸν εἰ τῷ χειμῶνι ψυχρὸν δ’ αὖ καὶ ὑγρὸν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.5:

It is no less appropriate that it [autumn] be considered cold and dry, because it is colder than summer but drier than winter. Or what sort of arbitrary selection is it to take one quality from the opposition from winter and one from summer? For since it differs from both in both respects, it ought not to have the comparison by halves but to possess it completely. And yet if it were to happen in this way, we shall say that opposites belong to it. For it will be hot and dry if [compared] to winter, but cold and moist in turn [if compared to summer].
paragraphs.openai_translation: It is nonetheless proper to regard it as cold and dry, because in summer it is colder and in winter drier. Or what sort of apportionment [apoklērōsis: allotment] is it to take one of the opposites from winter and one from summer? For in each case, since it differs with respect to both [qualities], the comparison ought not to be made by halves but to be entire. And indeed, if this were so, we should have to say that the contraries belong to it: for it will be hot and dry in relation to winter, and in turn cold and moist [in relation to summer].

paragraphs.content: εἰ τῷ θέρει παραβάλλοιτο. κατ’ οὐδετέραν οὖν τῶν παραβολῶν ὁλοκλήρως γινομένην ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἔσται. εἰ δ’ ἔξεστιν ἐκείνοις ἐξ ἑκατέρας αὐτῶν ἥμισυ λαβοῦσιν ὑγρὸν ἀποφαίνειν αὐτὸ καὶ θερμὸν ἐξέσται δήπου καὶ ἡμῖν ἐπὶ θάτερον ἥμισυ μετελθοῦσιν ξηρὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν ἀποφῇναι ξηρὸν μὲν ὡς πρὸς τὸν χειμῶνα ψυχρὸν δὲ ὡς πρὸς τὸ θέρος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

if it were compared to summer. Therefore, according to neither of the comparisons being made completely, it will be moist and hot. But if it is permitted for them, having taken half from each of these comparisons, to declare it moist and hot, then surely it will also be permitted for us, having proceeded to the other half, to declare it dry and cold—dry in relation to winter, and cold in relation to summer.
paragraphs.openai_translation: …if it were compared to summer. Accordingly, on neither of the comparisons, taken as a whole, will it turn out to be moist and hot. But if it is permitted to them, by taking half from each of them, to declare it moist and hot, then surely it will also be permitted to us, by going over to the other half, to declare it dry and cold—dry with reference to winter, and cold with reference to summer.

paragraphs.content: ἅπαντα οὖν οὕτως ἔσται τὸ ἔαρ, ὑγρὸν, ξηρὸν, θερμὸν, ψυχρόν. ἀλλ’ οὐδὲ κατ’ αὐτοὺς ἐκείνους οἶόν τέ ἐστιν ἐν ἑνὶ καὶ ταὐτῷ πράγματι τὰς τέτταρας ἐπικρατῆσαι ποιότητας· οὔκουν οὔτε θέρει παραβαλεῖν· οὔτε χειμῶνι τὸ ἔαρ, ἀλλ’ αὐτὸ καθ’ αὑτὸ σκοπεῖσθαι δίκαιον. οὐδὲ γὰρ οὐδὲ τὸν χειμῶνα διὰ τοῦτο λέγομεν ὑγρὸν εἶναι καὶ ψυχρὸν, ὅτι τῶν ἄλλων ὡρῶν ἐστιν ὑγρότατος καὶ ψυχρότατος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.7:

Therefore, according to this reasoning, spring will be all things at once: moist, dry, hot, cold. But not even according to those very people themselves is it possible for the four qualities to predominate in one and the same thing. Consequently, it is not right to compare spring either with summer or with winter, but rather it is proper to examine it by itself in its own right. For indeed, we do not say that winter is moist and cold because it is the moistest and coldest of the other seasons.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Thus, then, spring would turn out to be everything at once—moist, dry, hot, and cold [the four primary qualities]. But even by their own account it is not possible for the four qualities to predominate in one and the same subject. Accordingly, one should not compare spring either with summer or with winter, but it is right to examine it on its own. For we do not call winter moist and cold on the ground that it is the moistest and coldest of the seasons.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ τοῦτο μὲν καὶ ἄλλως αὐτῷ συμβέβηκεν· ὅτι δὲ πλεονεκτεῖ κατ’ αὐτὸν ἡ μὲν ὑγρότης τῆς ξηρότητος ἡ δὲ ψυχρότης τῆς θερμότητος διὰ τοῦτο ψυχρὸς εἶναι καὶ ὑγρὸς λέγεται. κατὰ ταὐτὸ δὲ καὶ τὸ θέρος ὅτι κᾀν τούτῳ τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν ἀπολείπεται τοῠ ξηροῦ τὸ δὲ ψυχρὸν τοῦ θερμοῦ διὰ τοῦτο θερμὸν εἶναι λέγεται καὶ ξηρόν. καὶ γὰρ δίκαιον ἐκ τῆς οἰκείας φύσεως ἑκάστην τῶν ὡρῶν ἐξεταζομένην οὐ πρὸς ἄλλην τινὰ παραβαλλομένην ἢ θερμὴν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But this has happened to it [winter] in another way as well; however, it is said to be cold and wet because, according to it, wetness prevails over dryness and coldness over heat. By the same principle, summer too is said to be hot and dry because in this season the wet falls short of the dry and the cold of the hot. For it is right that each of the seasons should be examined according to its own nature and not by being compared to some other season, whether hot
paragraphs.openai_translation: But this, in fact, has also come about for it in another way: since, with respect to it, moisture has the advantage over dryness and cold over heat, it is for this reason said to be cold and moist. And likewise with summer: for in it too the moist falls short of the dry and the cold of the hot; therefore it is said to be hot and dry. For it is right that each of the seasons be examined on the basis of its own nature, and not by being compared with some other—whether hotter [sc. than another season].

paragraphs.content: ἢ ψυχρὰν ἢ ξηρὰν ἢ ὑγρὰν ὀνομάζεσθαι. καὶ δὴ καὶ σκοπουμένῳ σοι κατὰ τάδε φανεῖται τὸ ἔαρ ἀκριβῶς μέσων ἁπασῶν τῶν ὑπερβολῶν. οὔτε γὰρ ὡς ἐν χειμῶνι πλεονεκτεῖ τὸ ψυχρὸν ἐν αὐτῷ τοῦ θερμοῦ οὔθ’ ὡς ἐν θέρει πλεονεκτεῖται. κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ ξηρότητός τε καὶ ὑγρότητος ἰσομοιρία τίς ἐστιν ἐν αὐτῷ μήθ’ ὡς ἐν θέρει κρατοῦντος τοῦ ξηροῦ μήθ’ ὡς ἐν χειμῶνι τοῦ ὑγροῦ. διὰ τοῦτο ὀρθῶς εἴρηται πρὸς Ἱπποκράτους
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

to be called cold or dry or wet. And indeed, if you examine it according to these considerations, spring will appear to be precisely in the middle of all the extremes. For neither does the cold prevail over the hot in it as in winter, nor is it prevailed over as in summer. In the same way, there is also a certain equality of dryness and wetness in it, with the dry not dominating as in summer nor the wet as in winter. For this reason it has been correctly stated by Hippocrates
paragraphs.openai_translation: …to be called either cold or dry or wet. And indeed, if you examine the matter as follows, spring will appear to you to be precisely in the middle of all the extremes. For in it the cold does not prevail over the hot as in winter, nor is it prevailed over as in summer. And likewise, in respect of dryness and moisture there is in it a certain equal share—neither with the dry dominant as in summer nor with the moist as in winter. For this reason it has been rightly said in relation to Hippocrates [i.e., in the Hippocratic account of the seasons and their qualities].

paragraphs.content: ἦρ δὲ ὑγιεινότατον καὶ ἥκιστα θανατῶδες.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Spring is the most healthful and least deadly season.

---

**Literal alternative:**

Spring is both the most conducive to health and the least fatal.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Spring is the most healthful and least fatal.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ τὸ φθινόπωρον ἧττον μὲν ἢ τὸ θέρος θερμὸν, ἧττον δὲ ἢ ὁ χειμὼν ψυχρόν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But autumn too is less hot than summer, yet less cold than winter.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But autumn too is less hot than summer and less cold than winter.

paragraphs.content: ὥστε ταύτῃ μὲν οὔτε θερμὸν ἁπλῶς οὔτε ψυχρὸν ἀμφότερα γάρ ἐστι καὶ οὐδέτερον ἄκρως. ἕτερον δέ τι πρόσεστιν αὐτῷ κακὸν ὅπερ ἐπεσημήνατο καὶ Ἱπποκράτης ἐν ἀφορισμοῖς λέγων· ὁκόταν τῆς αὐτῆς ἡμέρης ὁτὲ μὲν θάλπος ὁτὲ δὲ ψύχος γίγνηται φθινοπωρινὰ τὰ νοσήματα προσδέχεσθαι χρή. καὶ τοῦτό ἐστι τὸ μάλιστα νοσῶδες ἐργαζόμενον τὸ φθινόπωρον ἡ ἀνωμαλία τῆς κράσεως. οὐκ ὀρθῶς οὖν εἴρηται ψυχρὸν καὶ ξηρὸν οὐ γάρ ἐστι ψυχρὸν αὐτὸ καθ’ αὑτὸ θεωρούμενον ὥσπερ ὁ χειμὼν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

So in this respect it is neither simply hot nor cold; for it is both and neither in the extreme. But there is a certain other evil present in it, which Hippocrates also noted in the Aphorisms, saying: "Whenever on the same day there occurs at one time warmth and at another time cold, one must expect autumnal diseases." And this is what especially makes autumn disease-producing: the irregularity of the mixture [krasis]. Therefore it has not been correctly stated that it is cold and dry; for it is not cold when considered in itself, just as winter is.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So then, in this respect it is neither simply hot nor cold—for it is both, and neither in an extreme. Moreover, there is another adverse feature belonging to it, which Hippocrates also noted in the Aphorisms [Hippocratic Aphorisms], saying: “Whenever on the same day now heat and now cold occurs, one must expect autumnal diseases.” And this—the irregularity of the mixture [krasis: the qualitative blend of hot/cold and dry/wet]—is what makes autumn especially productive of illness. It has therefore not been rightly called “cold and dry,” for it is not cold in itself when considered on its own, like winter.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ τῷ θέρει παραβαλλόμενον ἐκείνου ψυχρότερον. οὐ μὴν οὐδ’ ὁμαλῶς εὔκρατον ὡς τὸ ἔαρ ἀλλ’ ὅτι μάλιστα τούτῳ διενήνοχεν ἐκείνης τῆς ὥρας ὅτι τὴν εὐκρασίαν τε καὶ τὴν ὁμαλότητα διὰ παντὸς ἴσην οὐ κέκτηται. πολὺ γὰρ θερμότερόν ἐστι κατὰ τὴν μεσημβρίαν ἢ κατὰ τὴν ἕω τε καὶ τὴν ἑσπέραν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But when compared to summer, it is colder than that season. However, it is not uniformly temperate like spring, but differs most greatly from that season in this respect: that it does not possess an equal temperament and uniformity throughout. For it is much hotter at midday than at dawn and evening.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But when set beside summer, it is colder than that. Yet it is not uniformly temperate like spring; rather, it differs from that season chiefly in this, that it does not possess an equal balance and evenness throughout [eukrasia = balanced mixture/temperament; homalotēs = uniformity]. For it is much hotter at midday than at dawn and at evening.

paragraphs.content: ὑγρότητι δὲ καὶ ξηρότητι μέσον μὲν οὐκ ἔστιν ἀκριβῶς, ὡς τὸ ἔαρ, ἀλλ’ ἐπὶ τὸ ξηρότερον ῥέπει. λείπεται δὲ κᾀν τούτῳ τοῦ θέρους, οὐ μὴν τοσοῦτόν γε, ὅσον θερμότητι. δῆλον οὖν, ὡς οὐδὲ τὸ φθινόπωρον ἁπλῶς οὕτως ῥητέον, ὡς ἐκεῖνοι λέγουσι, ψυχρόν τε εἶναι καὶ ξηρόν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

In respect to moisture and dryness, there is no precise mean, as spring is, but it inclines toward the drier. It falls short of summer in this respect as well, though not by as much as it does in heat. It is clear, therefore, that autumn should not be described simply in the way that those people say it is, as being cold and dry.
paragraphs.openai_translation: As regards moisture [hygrotēs] and dryness [xērotēs], there is not exactly a mean, as in the case of spring, but it inclines toward the drier. And even in this respect it falls short of summer, though not so much as in respect of heat. It is clear, then, that one should not simply assert of autumn, as some do, that it is cold and dry.

paragraphs.content: ἄκρως μὲν γὰρ οὐδέτερόν ἐστιν, ἐπικρατεῖ δ’ ἐν αὐτῷ τὸ ξηρὸν τοῦ ὑγροῦ. καὶ δικαίως ἂν λεχθείη ταύτῃ μὲν ξηρὸν, ἐν δὲ τῇ κατὰ θερμότητα καὶ ψυχρότητα διαφορᾷ μικτὸν ἐξ ἀμφοῖν καὶ ἀνώμαλον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For it is neither [quality] in the extreme, but the dry prevails in it over the moist. And it would justly be called dry in this respect, but in the difference relating to heat and cold, mixed from both and uneven.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For, strictly speaking, it is neutral, but within it the dry prevails over the moist. And it could rightly be called “dry” in this respect, whereas in the differentiation according to heat and cold it is a mixture of both and irregular [i.e., not uniformly balanced in the hot/cold qualities].

paragraphs.content: ὥστ’ εἴπερ τὰς τέσσαρας συζυγίας τῶν κράσεων εἰς τὰς τέσσαρας ὥρας διανεῖμαι σπεύδουσιν, ἴστωσαν οὐ μόνον ἦρι κακῶς προσάψαντες ὑγρότητα καὶ θερμότητα κράσεως, ἀλλὰ καὶ φθινοπώρῳ ψυχρότητα καὶ ξηρότητα. καίτοι γε, εἰ καὶ τοῦτο συνεχωρεῖτο ξηρὸν εἶναι καὶ ψυχρὸν, οὐκ ἦν ἀναγκαῖον εὐθέως, ὑγρὸν εἶναι καὶ θερμὸν τὸ ἔαρ. οὐ γὰρ, εἰ τέτταρες αἱ πᾶσαι συζυγίαι τῶν ἀμέτρων κράσεων εἰσὶν, ἤδη πάσας ἀναγκαῖον εἰς τὰς τέσσαρας ὥρας νενεμῆσθαι.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Therefore, if they are eager to distribute the four combinations of temperaments among the four seasons, let them know that they have wrongly assigned not only moistness and heat as a temperament to spring, but also coldness and dryness to autumn. And yet, even if it were granted that this [autumn] is dry and cold, it would not be necessary straightaway that spring be moist and hot. For just because there are four combinations in all of the immoderate temperaments [intemperate mixtures], it is not therefore necessary that all of them be distributed among the four seasons.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, if they are eager to parcel out the four pairings of mixtures among the four seasons, let them know that they have not only wrongly assigned moistness and warmth of mixture [krasis: temperament/mixture] to spring, but also coldness and dryness to autumn. And yet, even if this too were conceded—that autumn is dry and cold—it would not straightaway be necessary that spring be moist and warm. For it does not follow that, just because there are four pairings in all of the inordinate mixtures [ametroi kraseis: disproportionate/imbalanced temperaments], all of them must already be distributed among the four seasons.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ εἴπερ ἄρα τάξις τίς ἐστιν ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ καὶ κατὰ τὸ βέλτιον οὐ κατὰ τὸ χεῖρον ἅπαντα κεκόσμηται πιθανώτερον ἦν εὐκράτους μὲν τὰς πλείους ὥρας γεγενῆσθαι μίαν δὲ ἐξ αὐτῶν εἴπερ ἄρα τὴν δύσκρατον. οἱ δέ γε τοὐναντίον ἀποδεῖξαι σπεύδουσιν ὡς οὐδεμία τῶν ὡρῶν ἐστιν εὔκρατος ἀλλ’ ἐξ ἀνάγκης ἐν αὐταῖς ἐπικρατεῖ νῦν μὲν τὸ θερμὸν αὖθις δὲ τὸ ψυχρὸν καὶ νῦν μὲν εἰ τύχῃ τὸ ξηρὸν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But if indeed there is some order in the cosmos and all things have been arranged according to what is better rather than what is worse, it would have been more plausible for most of the seasons to have become temperate and for one of them, if any at all, to be intemperate. But they, on the contrary, hasten to demonstrate that none of the seasons is temperate, but that of necessity in them now the hot predominates, then again the cold, and now, as it happens, the dry
paragraphs.openai_translation: But if indeed there is some order in the cosmos, and all things have been arranged according to what is better rather than worse, it would be more plausible that most of the seasons [hōrai] have come to be well-tempered [eukratos: having a balanced mixture], and that one of them—if indeed any—[is] the ill-tempered [dyskrasia: unbalanced mixture]. They, however, are eager to prove the opposite: that none of the seasons is well-tempered, but that of necessity within them now the hot prevails, then again the cold, and now, if it happens, the dry.

paragraphs.content: αὖθις δὲ τὸ ὑγρόν. ἐγὼ δὲ τοσοῦτον ἀποδέω τοῦ ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἀποφαίνειν τὸ ἔαρ ἢ ὅ τί περ ἂν εὔκρατον ᾖ θερμὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν εἶναι συγχωρεῖν ὥστε πᾶν τοὐναντίον ἀποφαίνομαι χειρίστην εἶναι κατάστασιν κράσεως τοῦ περιέχοντος ἀέρος τὴν θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν ἣν ἐν μὲν ταῖς ὥραις οὐκ ἂν εὕροις ὅλως ἐν δὲ ταῖς νοσώδεσί τε καὶ λοιμώδεσι καταστάσεσιν ἐνίοτε συμπίπτει καθάπερ που καὶ ὁ Ἱπποκράτης ἐμνημόνευσε
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.19:

Again, [they say] the moist. But I am so far from declaring spring to be moist and hot, or from agreeing that whatever is well-tempered is hot and moist, that on the contrary I declare that the hot and moist condition is the worst state of mixture of the surrounding air—which you would not find at all in the seasons, but which sometimes occurs in diseased and pestilential conditions, just as Hippocrates also mentioned somewhere.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Now again, as to the moist. For my part, I am so far from declaring spring to be moist and hot, or granting that whatever is well-tempered [eukraton: well-balanced] is hot and moist, that I assert quite the opposite: the hot-and-moist condition is the worst state of the mixture [krâsis: blending] of the surrounding air [the ambient atmosphere]—a condition you would not find at all among the seasons, but which sometimes occurs in morbid and pestilential states, as Hippocrates, I think, has also mentioned somewhere.

paragraphs.content: λέγων· ὗεν ἐν καύμασιν ὕδατι λάβρῳ δι’ ὅλου. τοῦτο γάρ ἐστιν ἴδιον ὑγρᾶς καὶ θερμῆς καταστάσεως ὕειν συνεχῶς ἐν καύμασιν. εἰ δ’ ἤτοι μόνον εἴη καῦμα καθάπερ ἐπὶ τοῦ κατὰ φύσιν ἔχοντος θέρους ἢ ὕει μὲν ἀλλ’ ἐν κρύει καθάπερ ἐν χειμῶνι θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν οὐχ οἶόν τε τὴν τοιαύτην εἶναι κατάστασιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

saying: "It rained with heavy water throughout during hot weather." For this is characteristic of a hot and wet condition—to rain continuously during hot weather. But if there were either only heat, as in the case of summer that is in its natural state, or if it rains but in cold weather, as in winter, it is not possible for such a condition to be hot and wet.
paragraphs.openai_translation: “Saying: ‘It was raining, amid the heat, with a torrential downpour, all the while.’ For it is characteristic of a moist and hot condition [constitution, katastasis] that it rains continually in times of heat. But if there were only heat, as in summer when it is according to nature, or if it were raining but in cold, as in winter, such a condition could not be warm and moist.”

paragraphs.content: ἆρ’ οὖν ἄνοσον ἐκεῖνο τὸ θέρος, ἐν ᾧ, φησὶν, ὗεν ἐν καύμασιν ὕδατι λάβρῳ δι’ ὅλου; καὶ μὴν ἄνθρακας ἐν αὐτῷ γενέσθαι διηγεῖται, σαπέντων δηλονότι τῶν ἐν τῷ σώματι περιττωμάτων, καί τινας ἰχῶρας θερμοὺς καὶ ὑγροὺς ἀμέτρως γεννησάντων. εἴσῃ δὲ ἐξ αὐτῆς τῆς ῥήσεως, εἰ πᾶσαν αὐτήν σοι παραγράψαιμι, τόνδε τὸν τρόπον ἔχουσαν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.21:

Was that summer, then, free from disease—the one in which, he says, it rained with violent water during the heat throughout the entire period? And yet he relates that carbuncles occurred during it, clearly because the residues in the body putrefied and generated certain hot and excessively moist ichors [watery discharges]. You will know this from the passage itself, if I should quote it for you in its entirety, which runs as follows:
paragraphs.openai_translation: So then, was that summer free from disease, the one in which, he says, it rained, amid the heat, with a violent downpour the whole time? Indeed, he recounts that carbuncles [anthrakes: malignant pustules/boils] arose in it—clearly because the superfluities [waste humors] in the body were rotting and generating certain ichors [serous discharges], hot and excessively moist beyond measure. And you will understand from the very wording itself, if I were to copy it out for you entire, as it runs in the following manner.

paragraphs.content: ἄνθρακες ἐν Κρανῶνι θερινοί. ὗεν ἐν καύμασιν ὕδατι λάβρῳ δι’ ὅλου. ἐγίνοντο δὲ μᾶλλον Νότῳ· καὶ ὑπεγίνοντο μὲν ὑπὸ τὸ δέρμα ἰχῶρες· ἐγκαταλαμβανόμενοι δὲ ἐθερμαίνοντο, καὶ κνησμὸν ἐνεποίεον· εἶτα φλύκταιναι ὥσπερ πυρίκαυστοι ἐπανίσταντο, καὶ ὑπὸ τὸ δέρμα καίεσθαι ἐδόκεον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.22:

Carbuncles [anthracic lesions] occurred in Cranon in summer. It rained with violent water during the heat throughout. They occurred more frequently with the south wind. And watery discharges formed beneath the skin; when trapped they became heated and produced itching. Then blisters like burns rose up, and they seemed to be burning beneath the skin.

---

**Brief notes:**
- [ἄνθρακες (anthrakes): carbuncles or anthracic lesions - inflammatory skin conditions]
- [Κρανῶνι (Cranon): a city in Thessaly]
- [Νότῳ (Notos): the south wind, associated with heat and moisture in Greek medical theory]
- [ἰχῶρες (ichores): watery, serous discharges]
- [φλύκταιναι (phlyktainai): blisters or pustules]
paragraphs.openai_translation: Carbuncles [anthrakes: malignant boils] appeared at Crannon in the summer. It rained during the heat, with violent water, continuously. They occurred rather with a south wind. Under the skin there formed ichors [serous fluids]; when these were confined, they grew warm and produced itching; then blisters rose up as if fire-burned, and there seemed to be burning beneath the skin.
