paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἐνταῦθα μὲν ὡς ἂν μιᾶς ὥρας μετακοσμηθείσης ἧττον τὸ κακόν· εἰ δὲ δύο ἢ τρεῖς ὑπαλλαχθεῖεν ἢ καὶ σύμπαν τὸ ἔτος ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν γένοιτο μέγιστον ἀνάγκη συμπεσεῖν οὕτω λοιμὸν οἶον ἐν τῷ τρίτῳ τῶν ἐπιδημιῶν διηγεῖται. παραγράψω δὲ πρῶτον μὲν ἅ περὶ τῆς τῶν ὡρῶν ἀκοσμίας εἶπεν ἐφεξῆς δὲ καὶ τὰ περὶ τῆς ἐπιγινομένης φθορᾶς τῶν ἀνθρώπων. ἐν ἅπασι δ’ αὐτοῖς προσέχειν σε τὸν νοῦν ἀκριβῶς ἀξιῶ καὶ σκοπεῖσθαι πρῶτον μὲν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But in this case, since only one season has been disordered, the harm is less; however, if two or three should be altered, or even the entire year should become wet and hot, it is necessary that a very great plague occur of the sort that he describes in the third book of the Epidemics. I shall quote first what he said concerning the disorder of the seasons, and then in sequence also what concerns the resulting destruction of people. In all these matters I ask you to pay attention carefully and to consider first...
paragraphs.openai_translation: But here, when only a single season [hōra: season] has been rearranged, the harm is less; whereas if two or three should be altered, or even if the whole year should turn moist and warm, it is necessary that a very great plague [loimos] ensue—such as is recounted in the third book of the Epidemics [the Hippocratic treatise]. I shall first transcribe what he said about the disorder of the seasons, and next what concerns the destruction that comes upon human beings. In all these matters I urge you to pay exact attention and to consider, first—

paragraphs.content: ὁποῖόν τι πρᾶγμα θερμὴ καὶ ὑγρὰ κρᾶσίς ἐστιν ὡς οὐδὲν ἦρι παρόμοιον εὐκράτῳ χρήματι· δεύτερον δὲ ὡς ἀναγκαῖον ἐν αὐτῇ σήπεσθαι πάντα.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

What sort of thing a hot and moist mixture is, as nothing is comparable to spring as a well-tempered condition; and secondly, that it is necessary for all things in it to putrefy.

---

**Alternative translation (preserving the Greek syntax more closely):**

What sort of thing a hot and moist mixture is—how nothing is comparable to spring as a well-balanced substance; and secondly, how it is necessary that all things within it decay.
paragraphs.openai_translation: What sort of thing a hot and moist krâsis [mixture/temperament] is: first, that in spring there is nothing similar to a well-balanced condition [eukraton chrêma]; secondly, that in it everything must putrefy.

paragraphs.content: ἄρχεται μὲν οὖν ὁ Ἱπποκράτης τῆς διηγήσεως ὧδε. ἔτος νότιον ἔπομβρον ἄπνοια διὰ τέλεος. εἶτα τούτοις ἐπιφέρει τὰ κατὰ μέρος ἁπάσης τῆς καταστάσεως ὄμβρους πολλοὺς ἐν θερμῇ καὶ νοτίᾳ καταστάσει γενέσθαι γράφων εἶτ’ αὖθις τὸν σύμπαντα λόγον εἰς ἕν ἐπὶ τέλει κεφάλαιον ἀγαγὼν οὕτως. γενομένου δὲ τοῦ ἔτεος ὅλου φησὶ νοτίου καὶ ὑγροῦ καὶ μαλακοῦ τάδε καὶ τάδε συνέπεσεν ἃ ξύμπαντα μὲν ἀναγράφειν ἐν τῷδε τῷ λόγῳ μακρόν· ἔνεστι δὲ τῷ βουλομένῳ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.26:

So then, Hippocrates begins his account in this way: "The year was southerly, rainy, with complete absence of wind." Then to these things he adds the details of the entire condition, writing that many rains occurred in a hot and southerly condition. Then again, bringing together the entire account into one summary at the end, thus: when the whole year, he says, had been southerly and wet and mild, such and such things occurred—which to record all of them in this account would be lengthy; but it is possible for anyone who wishes...

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end]
paragraphs.openai_translation: Hippocrates accordingly begins his account as follows. A southerly year, rainy, windless throughout. Then to these he adds, in detail, the particulars of the whole constitution [katastasis: the seasonal/meteorological “state”], writing that many showers occurred in a warm and moist condition; and then again he brings the entire discussion into a single concluding heading [kephalaion] as follows. When the whole year proved southerly and wet and mild, such-and-such events befell—things which, to record all of them in this discourse, would be lengthy; yet it is open to anyone who wishes [to do so].

paragraphs.content: λαβόντι τὸ τρίτον τῶν ἐπιδημιῶν ἀναγινώσκειν τὰ κατὰ μέρος εἰς ἕν ἅπαντα κεφάλαιον ἀναγόμενα σηπεδόνα μεγίστην ἧς καὶ αὐτῆς ὀνομαστὶ πολλάκις ὁ Ἱπποκράτης ἐπιμέμνηται ποτὲ μὲν ὡδί πως λέγων· ἦν δὲ καὶ τὸ ῥεῦμα τὸ συνιστάμενον οὐ πύῳ ἴκελον ἀλλὰ σηπεδών τις ἄλλη καὶ ῥεῦμα πολὺ καὶ ποικίλον· ὁτὲ δὲ πάλιν ὡδί· καὶ ἐν αἰδοίοισιν ἄνθρακες οἱ κατὰ θέρος καὶ ἄλλα ἃ σῆψις καλέεται
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.27:

When one takes up the third book of the Epidemics to read, all the particular cases taken together lead to one general conclusion: a very great putrefaction, which Hippocrates himself also mentions by name many times, sometimes speaking in this manner: "And the discharge that formed was not like pus, but some other putrefaction, and the discharge was abundant and varied"; and at other times again thus: "And carbuncles on the genitals during summer, and other things which are called sepsis [putrefaction]."
paragraphs.openai_translation: On taking up the third book of the Epidemics to read, and gathering the particulars into a single comprehensive heading, one may refer them to an exceedingly great putrefaction [sepsis], of which Hippocrates himself has often made express mention by name—sometimes speaking thus: “And the discharge that collected was not like pus, but some other sort of putrefaction, and there was much and varied discharge”; and at other times thus: “And in the genitals, carbuncles [anthrakes] occurring in summer, and other conditions that are called sepsis [putrefaction].”

paragraphs.content: καὶ ὡς ἐκ τῆς σήψεως ταύτης πολλοῖσι μὲν βραχίων καὶ πῆχυς ὅλως ἀπεῤῥύη πολλοῖσι δὲ μηρὸς ἢ τὰ περὶ τὴν κνήμην ἀπεψιλοῦτο καὶ ποῦς ὅλος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

And as a result of this putrefaction, in many cases the entire upper arm and forearm fell off completely, while in many others the thigh or the parts around the shin were stripped bare and the entire foot.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And as a result of this putrefaction [σήψις: gangrenous decay], in many the upper arm and forearm entirely sloughed off, while in many others the thigh or the parts about the shin were stripped away, and even the whole foot.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ ὀστῶν καὶ σαρκῶν καὶ νεύρων καὶ ἄρθρων ἐκπτώσεις ἐγίγνοντο μεγάλαι. καὶ ὅλως οὐδέν ἐστιν εὑρεῖν ὧν ἔγραψε παθημάτων ὃ μὴ σηπεδόνος ἔγγονον ὑπάρχει δεόντως. οὔτε γὰρ ὑπὸ τοῦ ξηροῦ τι σήπεσθαι πέφυκεν οὔθ’ ὑπὸ τοῦ ψυχροῦ. μάθοις δ’ ἂν εἰ θεάσαιο τά τε κρέα καὶ τὰ ἄλλα σύμπαντα τὰ πρὸς τῶν ἀνθρώπων ταριχευόμενα τὰ μὲν ἁλσὶ τὰ δ’ ἅλμῃ τὰ δ’ ὄξει
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.29:

But also great dislocations of bones and flesh and sinews and joints occurred. And in general, it is impossible to find any of the afflictions he described that is not properly the offspring of putrefaction. For nothing is naturally disposed to putrefy either by dryness or by cold. You would learn this if you were to observe both meats and all other things preserved by people—some with salt, some with brine, some with vinegar.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But there also occurred great sloughings-off of bones, flesh, sinews [tendons], and joints. And, in general, among the ailments he has written of, nothing can be found that is not, and rightly so, the offspring of putrefaction [rot]. For nothing is naturally subject to putrefy under the influence of what is dry, nor of what is cold. You would learn this if you observed the meats and all other things that people preserve—some with salt, some with brine, and some with vinegar.

paragraphs.content: τὰ δ’ ἄλλῳ τινὶ τῶν ξηραινόντων σκευαζόμενα καλῶς. μάθοις δὲ καὶ ὡς ἐν τῷ βοῤῥᾷ ξηρῷ καὶ ψυχρῷ τὴν φύσιν ὑπάρχοντι ἄσηπτα μέχρι πλεῖστον διαμένει πάντα· σήπεται δ’ ἑτοίμως ταῖς νοτίαις καταστάσεσιν. ἔστι γὰρ οὖν καὶ οὗτος ὁ ἄνεμος ὑγρὸς καὶ θερμός.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But things prepared with some other drying agent [are preserved] well. You may learn also how in the north wind, which is dry and cold by nature, all things remain free from decay for the longest time; but they decay readily in southerly conditions. For indeed this wind too [the south wind] is moist and warm.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And other items are suitably prepared with one or another of the desiccative agents [drying substances]. You would also learn that under the north wind [Boreas], whose nature is dry and cold, all things remain unspoiled for the longest time; whereas they readily putrefy in southerly conditions, for this wind [Notus] too is moist and warm.

paragraphs.content: ὥστε πᾶν τοὐναντίον ἡμεῖς ἀποφαινόμεθα τοῖς ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ὑπολαμβάνουσιν εἶναι τὸ ἔαρ. οὔτε γὰρ τοιοῦτό ἐστιν οὔθ’ ὑγιεινὸν ἂν ἦν εἴπερ ἦν τοιοῦτο. οἱ δὲ καὶ τοιοῦτο εἶναί φασιν αὐτὸ καὶ διὰ τοῦθ’ ὑγιεινὸν ὑπάρχειν ἐν ἀμφοτέροις ἁμαρτάνοντες ὅσα τε ταῖς αἰσθήσεσιν ἔνεστι διαγνῶναι καὶ ὅσα τῷ λόγῳ διασκέψασθαι. ταῖς μὲν γὰρ αἰσθήσεσιν ἔνεστιν ἐναργῶς μαθεῖν εὔκρατον ἀκριβῶς αὐτὸ τῷ λόγῳ δ’ ἐξευρεῖν ὡς διὰ τοῦτ’ ἔστιν ὑγιεινὸν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Therefore we declare the complete opposite to those who suppose that spring is moist and hot. For it is neither of such a nature, nor would it be healthful if it were of such a nature. But they say both that it is of such a nature and that for this reason it is healthful, erring in both respects—both in matters that can be discerned by the senses and in matters that can be examined by reason. For by the senses it is possible to learn clearly that it [spring] is precisely well-tempered [well-balanced in its mixture], and by reason to discover that it is for this reason that it is healthful.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, we assert quite the opposite of those who suppose spring to be moist and warm. For it is neither of such a kind, nor would it be healthful if indeed it were such. They claim both that it is of that sort and that on this account it is healthful, but they err in both respects—both in what can be discerned by the senses and in what can be examined by reason. For by the senses one can plainly learn that it is itself exactly of a well-balanced temperament [eukraton: a balanced mixture], and by reasoning discover how for this very reason it is healthful.

paragraphs.content: διότι μηδὲν ἐν αὐτῷ τῶν τεττάρων ἐπικρατεῖ. εἰ δέ γ’ ἤτοι τὸ θερμὸν ἐπεκράτει πολλῷ τοῦ ψυχροῦ ἢ τὸ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ σηπεδόνων τε ἂν ἦν εὔφορον οὕτω καὶ πασῶν τῶν ὡρῶν νοσωδέστατον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

because none of the four [elements/qualities] predominates in it. But if indeed either the hot greatly predominated over the cold or the moist over the dry, it would thus be prone to putrefactions and most disease-ridden in all seasons.
paragraphs.openai_translation: because none of the four [qualities] prevails in it. But if either the hot greatly prevailed over the cold or the moist over the dry, it would be well suited to putrefactions and thus the most disease-ridden of all the seasons.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἡ τῆς τῶν τεττάρων κράσεων ἰσομοιρία τῆς τε εὐκρασίας αὐτοῦ καὶ τῆς ὑγιείας αἰτία. πόθεν οὖν ἐπῆλθέ τισιν ἰατροῖς τε καὶ φιλοσόφοις ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἀποφῄνασθαι τὸ ἔαρ; ἐκ τοῦ βουληθῆναι δηλονότι τὰς τέτταρας συζυγίας τῶν κράσεων εἰς τὰς τέτταρας ὥρας διανεῖμαι. τοῦτο δ’ αὐτὸ πάλιν ἐκ τοῦ παραλιπεῖν τὴν πρώτην ἁπασῶν, τὴν εὔκρατον, ἐγένετο. καὶ γὰρ οὖν καὶ διαιτημάτων, καὶ φαρμάκων, ἁπάντων τε τῶν ὄντων, εἰς τὰς τέτταρας ταύτας συζυγίας ἀνάγουσι τὰς διαφοράς.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But the equal proportion of the mixture of the four [qualities] is the cause both of its good mixture [eucrasia] and of health. From where then did it occur to certain doctors and philosophers to declare that spring is moist and hot? From the fact that they wished, evidently, to distribute the four combinations of mixtures among the four seasons. And this itself in turn arose from their omitting the first of all [mixtures], the well-tempered one [eukratos]. For indeed they also reduce the differences of regimens, and of drugs, and of all existing things to these four combinations.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But it is the equal share of the four mixtures [kraseis] that is the cause both of its well-tempered condition [eukrasia] and of health. Whence, then, did it occur to certain physicians and philosophers to declare spring to be moist and warm? From their wish, plainly, to distribute the four pairings [syzygies] of the mixtures among the four seasons. And this very thing, in turn, came about from their having left out the first of them all—the well-tempered one. For they also refer the differences of regimens [diets], and of drugs, and indeed of all existing things, to these four pairings.

paragraphs.content: Ὧι καὶ δῆλον εἰς ὅσον οἱ περὶ φύσεως ἀνθρώπου λογισμοὶ σφαλέντες τῆς ἀληθείας εἰς τὰς ἰάσεις βλάπτουσι καὶ βέλτιόν ἐστι δυοῖν θάτερον ἢ μηδ’ ὅλως ἅπτεσθαι τῶν τοιούτων λόγων ἀλλ’ ἐπιτρέψαι τῇ πείρᾳ τὸ πᾶν ἢ πρότερον ἐν τῇ λογικῇ θεωρίᾳ γυμνάσασθαι. τὸ δὲ μήτε τῇ πείρᾳ προσέχειν τὸν νοῦν ἐπιχειρεῖν τε θεωρίᾳ φυσικῇ πρὸ τοῦ τὸν λογισμὸν ᾧ μέλλοιμεν εὑρίσκειν αὐτὴν ἀσκῆσαι πρεπόντως ἀναγκαῖον ἀπάγειν εἰς τὰ τοιαῦτα σοφίσματα
paragraphs.openai_translation: From this it is also clear how far reasonings about the nature of man, when they have gone astray from the truth, harm the cures [treatments]. And it is better, one of two things: either not to touch at all on such discussions, but to entrust everything to experience [empirical practice], or first to train oneself in logical theory [logic]. But to pay no attention to experience and to attempt natural theory [natural philosophy] before suitably exercising the reasoning by which we are to discover it is inevitably to be led into such sophistries.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 5.1:

From this it is also clear to what extent reasonings about the nature of man, when they have missed the truth, cause harm in treatments, and that it is better to choose one of two alternatives: either not to engage with such arguments at all but to entrust everything to experience, or first to train oneself in logical theory. But to neither pay attention to experience nor to attempt physical theory before having properly exercised the reasoning by which we would discover it necessarily leads to such sophistries.

---

**Brief notes:**
- "περὶ φύσεως ἀνθρώπου" = concerning the nature of man [a common topic in ancient medical and philosophical texts]
- "ἰάσεις" = treatments, healings [medical context]
- "πείρᾳ" = experience [empirical observation, a key concept in ancient medical methodology]
- "λογικῇ θεωρίᾳ" = logical theory [formal training in reasoning]
- "φυσικῇ θεωρίᾳ" = physical theory [natural philosophy, the study of nature]

paragraphs.content: καὶ περί γε τῶν φαινομένων ὡς ἀναισθήτους ἀναγκάζει διαλέγεσθαι μάρτυρά τε καλεῖν Ἀριστοτέλη παρακούοντας ὧν διδάσκει. πολλαχῶς γὰρ ἐκεῖνος οἶδε καὶ τὸ θερμὸν λεγόμενον καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν καὶ τὸ ξηρὸν καὶ τὸ ὑγρόν· οἱ δ’ οὐκ ἀκούουσιν αὐτοῦ πολλαχῶς ἀλλ’ ὡσαύτως ἀεί. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ ὡς οὐ ταὐτό ἐστιν ἢ οἰκείῳ τινὶ καὶ συμφύτῳ θερμῷ θερμὸν ὑπάρχειν ἢ ἐπικτήτῳ καὶ ἀλλοτρίῳ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 5.2:

And concerning the phenomena, he compels them to argue as if they were insensible, and to call upon Aristotle as a witness while mishearing what he teaches. For that man knows that "hot" is spoken of in many ways, as are "cold," "dry," and "wet"; but they do not hear him saying "in many ways" but rather "in the same way always." And indeed, they also fail to understand that it is not the same thing whether something is hot by means of some proper and innate heat or by means of an acquired and foreign heat.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And with respect to the phenomena, it even compels them to speak as though they were without perception, and to call Aristotle as a witness while mishearing what he teaches. For he recognizes that “hot,” “cold,” “dry,” and “wet” are said in many ways [i.e., have multiple senses], whereas they do not hear him as speaking in many ways, but always in one and the same way. And indeed he also holds that it is not the same thing for something to be hot by some proper and inborn heat as it is to be hot by an acquired and alien heat [the elemental qualities: hot/cold/dry/wet].

paragraphs.content: διῆλθεν Ἀριστοτέλης· οἱ δέ γε καὶ τούτου παρακούουσιν. ἔτι τε πρὸς τούτοις ὁ μὲν Ἀριστοτέλης ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ ὁ Θεόφραστος ἐς ὅ τι χρὴ βλέποντας ἢ εὔκρατον ἢ δύσκρατον ὑπολαμβάνειν εἶναι τὴν φύσιν ἀκριβῶς εἰρήκασιν. οἱ δ’ οὐδὲ τοῦτο γινώσκουσιν ἀλλ’ ὅταν ἀκούσωσι λεγόντων αὐτῶν ὑγρὸν εἶναι καὶ θερμὸν τὸ ζῶον ἢ τὴν τοῦ παιδὸς κρᾶσιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν οὔθ’ ὅπως εἴρηται ταῦτα συνίασιν ἐμπλήκτως τε μεταφέρουσι τὸν λόγον ἐπὶ τὰς ὥρας ὥσπερ ταὐτὸ ὂν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Aristotle discussed this; but they do not even understand this properly. Furthermore, in addition to these matters, Aristotle and likewise Theophrastus have stated precisely what one must look to in order to consider a nature to be well-tempered [eukratos] or ill-tempered [dyskratos]. But they do not even know this; rather, whenever they hear them saying that the animal is moist and hot, or that the temperament [krasis] of a child is moist and hot, they neither understand how these things have been stated, and they foolishly transfer the argument to the seasons as if it were the same thing.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Aristotle has dealt with this; yet they even fail to heed him. Moreover, Aristotle—and Theophrastus as well—have stated precisely, with a view to what one ought to consider, in calling “nature” either well-tempered or ill-tempered [eukraton/dyskra ton: a balanced or imbalanced mixture/constitution]. But these people do not even understand this; rather, when they hear them saying that the living creature is moist and warm, or that a child’s mixture [krasis: temperament/constitutional blend] is moist and warm, they neither grasp in what sense these things are said, and they foolishly transfer the account to the seasons, as though it were the same thing.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ οὐ μακρῷ διαφέρον ἢ τὴν οἰκείαν κρᾶσιν ὑγρὰν εἶναι καὶ θερμὴν ἢ τὴν τοῦ περιέχοντος ἡμᾶς ἀέρος. οὔτε γὰρ ταὐτό ἐστιν οὔθ’ ὁμοίως ὑγρὰ καὶ θερμὴ ζώου κρᾶσις ἀέρος ὑγρᾷ καὶ θερμῇ κράσει λέγεται. τί δ’ ἦν τὸ τούτων ἁπάντων αἴτιον ἤδη διηγήσομαι καὶ δείξω σαφῶς τοῖς προσέχειν τὸν νοῦν βουλομένοις ὡς μικρὰ πταίσματα τῶν ἐν ἀρχῇ τῆς λογικῆς θεωρίας διδασκομένων αἴτια μεγίστων ἁμαρτημάτων γίνεται
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But it makes no small difference whether one's own mixture is moist and hot or whether it is the mixture of the air surrounding us. For neither is the mixture of a living creature the same thing nor is it said to be moist and hot in the same way as a moist and hot mixture of air. Now I shall explain what was the cause of all these things and shall demonstrate clearly to those who wish to pay attention that small errors in what is taught at the beginning of logical theory become the causes of the greatest mistakes.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But it is no great matter whether the proper krasis [mixture/temperament] is moist and warm, or that of the air surrounding us. For neither is it the same, nor is the mixture of a living creature called moist and warm in the same way as the mixture of air is called moist and warm. And what was the cause of all these things I will now set forth, and I will show clearly, to those willing to pay attention, how small slips in what is taught at the outset of logical theory become the causes of the greatest errors.

paragraphs.content: καὶ κινδυνεύει πάντα τὰ κακῶς πραττόμενα κατά τε τὰς τέχνας ἁπάσας καὶ μέντοι καὶ κατὰ τὰς ἐν τῷ βίῳ πράξεις ἕπεσθαι σοφίσμασιν. ἕπεται τοιγαροῦν καὶ τάδε τὰ σοφίσματα τῷ μὴ διελέσθαι περὶ τῶν σημαινομένων ὀρθῶς.
paragraphs.claude_translation: And it is likely that all things that are done badly, both in all the arts and indeed also in the actions of life, follow from sophistries [fallacious arguments]. Therefore these sophistries too follow from not having distinguished correctly concerning the meanings.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And it is likely that all things poorly carried out—both in every art and, indeed, in the conduct of life—are attended by sophisms [fallacious arguments]. Accordingly, these sophisms too arise from a failure to make correct distinctions about what is signified [the meanings].

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ οἰηθῆναι τὸ θερμὸν λέγεσθαι διχῶς, τὸ μὲν ὡς ἄκρατον καὶ ἄμικτον καὶ ἁπλοῦν, τὸ δὲ ὡς ἐν τῇ πρὸς τὸ ἐναντίον ἐπιμιξίᾳ πλεονεκτοῦν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But one should understand that "the hot" is spoken of in two ways: on the one hand as unmixed and unblended and simple, on the other hand as prevailing in its mixture with its opposite.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But let us suppose that “the hot” is spoken of in two ways: on the one hand as undiluted, unmixed, and simple; on the other as preponderant within the admixture with its opposite [i.e., prevailing in a compound where the contrary is also present].

paragraphs.content: ὅτι δὲ καὶ παραβάλλοντες ἑτέρᾳ κράσει πολλάκις ἑτέραν ἀποφαινόμεθα τὴν ἑτέραν αὐτῶν εἶναι θερμὴν ἐπιλανθάνονται καὶ τοῦδε. καὶ μὴν οὕτω τὰ ζῶα θερμὰ καὶ ὑγρὰ λέγεται πρὸς τῶν παλαιῶν οὐ κατὰ τὴν ἰδίαν κρᾶσιν ἁπλῶς ἀλλὰ τοῖς γε φυτοῖς καὶ τοῖς τεθνεῶσι παραβαλλόμενα. καὶ γὰρ τῶν τεθνεώτων ζῶα καὶ τῶν φυτῶν ἐστι θερμότερα καὶ ὑγρότερα. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ τῶν ζώων αὐτῶν ἀλλήλοις κατ’ εἴδη παραβαλλομένων ξηρότερον μὲν ὁ κύων
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 5.7:

They also forget this point: that when we compare one mixture with another, we often declare that one of them is hot. And indeed, animals are called hot and moist by the ancients not simply according to their own mixture, but when compared to plants and to dead things. For animals are both hotter and moister than dead things and than plants. And furthermore, when animals themselves are compared with one another according to species, the dog is drier

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence at "the dog is drier" (ξηρότερον μὲν ὁ κύων), suggesting this is an incomplete excerpt from a larger discussion about the comparative qualities of different beings according to their mixture [κρᾶσις - the blending of elemental qualities].
paragraphs.openai_translation: But they also forget this: that by comparing with a different krasis [mixture/temperament], we often pronounce now the one, now the other of them to be hot. And indeed, in this way living creatures are called warm and moist by the ancients, not simply according to their own krasis, but in comparison with plants and with the dead. For animals are warmer and moister than corpses and than plants. And furthermore, when the animals themselves are compared with one another by species, the dog is drier...

paragraphs.content: ὑγρότερον δὲ ὁ ἄνθρωπος. εἰ δὲ μύρμηκι καὶ μελίττῃ παραβάλλοις τὸν κύνα ξηρότερα μὲν ἐκεῖνα τὸν κύνα δ’ ὑγρότερον εὑρήσεις.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But the human being is more moist. And if you were to compare the dog with an ant and a bee, you would find those creatures drier but the dog moister.
paragraphs.openai_translation: The human being, however, is wetter [i.e., more moist in humoral quality]. And if you were to compare the dog with the ant and the bee, you would find those creatures drier, but the dog wetter.

paragraphs.content: ὥστε ταὐτὸ ζῶον ξηρὸν μὲν ὡς πρὸς ἄνθρωπον ὑπάρχειν ὑγρὸν δ’ ὡς πρὸς μέλιτταν· οὕτω δὲ καὶ θερμὸν μὲν ὡς πρὸς ἄνθρωπον ψυχρὸν δ’ ὡς πρὸς λέοντα. καὶ θαυμαστὸν οὐδὲν εἰ τὸ πρὸς ἕτερόν τι λεγόμενον τὰς ἐναντίας ἅμα κατηγορίας ἐπιδέχεται. οὐ γὰρ τοῦτ’ ἄτοπον εἰ ταὐτὸ σῶμα θερμὸν ἅμα λέγεται καὶ ψυχρὸν ἀλλ’ εἰ καὶ πρὸς ταὐτό. οὐ γὰρ ὅτι δεξιὸς ἅμα καὶ ἀριστερὸς ὁ αὐτὸς ἄνθρωπος
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

So that the same animal is dry in relation to a human being but moist in relation to a bee; and likewise it is hot in relation to a human being but cold in relation to a lion. And it is not at all surprising if what is spoken of in relation to something else admits contrary predicates at the same time. For it is not absurd if the same body is called both hot and cold at the same time, but only if it is so in relation to the same thing. For [it is not absurd] that the same man is right and left at the same time
paragraphs.openai_translation: So the same animal is dry in relation to a human being, but moist in relation to a bee; and likewise hot in relation to a human being, but cold in relation to a lion. And there is nothing surprising if what is spoken of in relation to something else admits at the same time of contrary predications [i.e., opposed qualities said relatively]. For it is not absurd if the same body is said to be at once hot and cold—but it would be if it were so in relation to the same thing. For it is not that the same man is at once right and left—

paragraphs.content: ἄτοπον· εἰ δέ γε πρὸς ἄλλον μὲν δεξιὸς πρὸς ἄλλον δὲ ἀριστερὸς οὐδὲν ἄτοπον. οὕτως οὖν καὶ κύων ὑγρὸς ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸς καὶ θερμὸς ἅμα καὶ ψυχρὸς ἀλλ’ οὐ πρὸς ταὐτό· πρὸς μὲν γὰρ ἄνθρωπον ξηρὸς ὑγρὸς δ’ ὡς πρὸς μύρμηκα καὶ πρὸς μὲν ἄνθρωπον θερμὸς ψυχρὸς δ’ ὡς πρὸς λέοντα. καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ θερμὸς μὲν ὡς ζῶν· εἰ γάρ τι τέθνηκεν οὐ θερμόν· οὐ θερμὸς δ’ ὡς πρὸς ἕτερον εἰ οὕτως ἔτυχε
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

absurd. But if someone is right-handed in relation to one person and left-handed in relation to another, there is nothing absurd about that. So in this way also a dog is both moist and dry at the same time, and both hot and cold at the same time, but not in relation to the same thing: for in relation to a human being it is dry, but moist in relation to an ant, and in relation to a human being it is hot, but cold in relation to a lion. And indeed it is hot insofar as it is living; for if something is dead it is not hot; but it is not hot in relation to something else, if that happens to be the case.
paragraphs.openai_translation: That would be absurd; but if indeed one is right-handed in relation to one person and left-handed in relation to another, there is nothing absurd. So too a dog is at once wet and dry, and at once hot and cold, but not in relation to the same thing [pros to auto: relative to the same comparator]; for relative to a human being he is dry, but wet as compared to an ant, and relative to a human being he is warm, but cold as compared to a lion. Indeed, he is warm qua living [hōs zōn]; for if something has died, it is not warm; yet he is not warm in relation to something else, if that is how matters happen to stand.

paragraphs.content: κύνα. ταυτὶ μὲν οὖν ἅπαντα πρὸς ἄλληλα ἐκ παραβολῆς λέγεται τὰ δ’ ὡς ἐν ζώων γένει καθ’ ἕτερον τρόπον ὥσπερ αὖ καὶ κατ’ εἶδος ζώου. κύων γὰρ ὡς πρὸς μὲν μύρμηκα καὶ μέλιτταν ὑγρὸς ὡς δ’ ἐν ζώων γένει ξηρός. αὐτῶν δὲ τῶν κυνῶν κατ’ εἶδος ὁδὶ μὲν ξηρὸς ὁδὶ δὲ ὑγρὸς ἄλλος δέ τις ὡς κύων εὔκρατος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

a dog. Now all these things are spoken of in relation to one another by way of comparison, but as belonging to the class of animals [they are spoken of] in a different way, just as also according to the species of animal. For a dog is moist in relation to an ant and a bee, but as belonging to the class of animals it is dry. And among dogs themselves according to species, this one is dry, this one is moist, and another is well-tempered [balanced in mixture] as a dog.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Dog. Accordingly, all these things are said in relation to one another by way of comparison; but within the class of animals they are spoken of in another manner, and likewise by species of animal. For a dog, in comparison with an ant and a bee, is moist [ὑγρός], whereas within the genus of animals he is dry [ξηρός]. And among dogs themselves, by species, one is dry, another moist, and another, as a dog, well-balanced [εὔκρατος, i.e., of a well-mixed temperament].

paragraphs.content: Λέλεκται μὲν οὖν ἐπὶ πλεῖστον ἡμῖν ὑπὲρ ἁπάσης τῆς τοιαύτης χρήσεως τῶν ὀνομάτων ἐν δευτέρῳ περὶ διαγνώσεως σφυγμῶν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: We have therefore discussed at greatest length concerning all such usage of terms in the second book On the Diagnosis of Pulses.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, we have spoken at greatest length about the entire use of such names [i.e., technical terms] in the second book On the Diagnosis of Pulses.

paragraphs.content: ἀνάγκη δὲ, ὡς ἔοικεν, εἰπεῖν τι καὶ νῦν ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν διὰ κεφαλαίων, ὅσον εἰς τὰ παρόντα χρήσιμον. τὸ μὲν ἁπλῶς ξηρὸν, ὃ πρὸς μηδὲν ἕτερον λέγεται, μόνοις τοῖς στοιχείοις ὑπάρχει, πυρί τε καὶ γῇ· καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν ὕδατι καὶ ἀέρι. κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ περὶ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ χρὴ νοεῖν. οὐδὲν γὰρ τῶν ἄλλων σωμάτων ἀκριβῶς οὔτε θερμὸν οὔτε ψυχρόν ἐστιν, ἀλλ’ ἢ τὰ στοιχεῖα μόνον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.2:

It is necessary, it seems, to say something even now about these matters in summary form, insofar as it is useful for the present discussion. The absolutely dry, which is not spoken of in relation to anything else, belongs only to the elements, both to fire and to earth; and indeed the moist belongs to water and air. In the same way one must also think about the hot and the cold. For none of the other bodies is precisely either hot or cold, but only the elements.
paragraphs.openai_translation: It is necessary, as it seems, to say something now about them in outline [διὰ κεφαλαίων: “by headings”], so far as is useful for the present. What is simply dry—so called not in relation to anything else [i.e., absolutely]—belongs only to the elements [στοιχεῖα], namely to fire and earth; and likewise the wet to water and air. One must think the same regarding hot and cold; for none of the other bodies is strictly either hot or cold, but only the elements.

paragraphs.content: ὅ τι δ’ ἂν τῶν ἄλλων λάβῃς ἐκ τούτων κέκραται καὶ διὰ τοῦτο τὸ δεύτερον σημαινόμενον οὐκ ἔθ’ ἁπλῶς θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν ὡς ἄμικτόν τε καὶ εἰλικρινὲς ἀλλ’ ὡς ἤτοι πλέονος μὲν τοῦ θερμοῦ τοῦ ψυχροῦ δ’ ἐλάττονος ἢ τοῦ μὲν ψυχροῦ πλέονος ἐλάττονος δὲ τοῦ θερμοῦ μετέχον ἕκαστον τῶν ἄλλων ἢ θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν λέγεται. δύο μὲν δὴ ταῦτα σημαινόμενα τοῦ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ· τὸ μὲν ἁπλῶς λεγόντων ἡμῶν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Whatever else you take from these is mixed and for this reason in the second sense [of the terms] it is no longer simply hot or cold as unmixed and pure, but rather each of the other things is called either hot or cold as participating in either more of the hot and less of the cold, or more of the cold and less of the hot. So then there are these two senses of hot and cold and dry and moist: the one when we speak simply [i.e., of the pure qualities]...

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence with "when we speak simply," suggesting the continuation would contrast this first sense with the second sense already described.]
paragraphs.openai_translation: And whatever else you take from these is a mixture; and therefore, in the second signification, it is no longer called “hot” or “cold” simply, as though unmixed and pure [i.e., in a primary, unmixed state], but each of the other things is called either hot or cold in that it partakes either of more of the hot and less of the cold, or of more of the cold and less of the hot. There are, then, two meanings signified of the hot and the cold and the dry and the moist: the one when we speak simply [i.e., absolutely/unmixed]…

paragraphs.content: ἄμικτόν τε καὶ εἰλικρινές· ἕτερον δὲ μικτὸν μὲν ἐκ τῶν ἐναντίων ἀλλὰ τῷ τοῦ πλεονεκτοῦντος ὀνόματι προσαγορευόμενον. οὕτως μὲν οὖν ὑγρὸν αἷμα καὶ φλέγμα καὶ πιμελὴ καὶ οἶνος ἔλαιόν τε καὶ μέλι καὶ τῶν ἄλλων τῶν τοιούτων ἕκαστον λέγεται.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

unmixed and pure; but another kind is mixed from opposites but is named by the term of the predominant element. Thus, then, blood and phlegm and fat and wine and oil and honey and each of the other such things are called moist.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Unmixed and pure [i.e., simple]; and another kind, mixed from opposites, yet designated by the name of the one that predominates. Thus, then, “liquid blood,” and phlegm, and fat [suet], and wine, and oil, and honey, and each of the other things of this sort are so called.

paragraphs.content: ὀστᾶ δὲ καὶ χόνδροι καὶ ὄνυχες καὶ ὁπλαὶ καὶ κέρατα καὶ τρίχες καὶ λίθοι καὶ ξύλα καὶ ψάμμος καὶ κέραμος ἐλάττονα μὲν ὑγροῦ μοῖραν ἕχει πλείονα δὲ ξηροῦ καὶ διὰ τοῦτο πάλιν ἅπαντα τὰ τοιαῦτα ξηρὰ προσαγορεύεται. μύρμηξ δὲ ξηρὸν καὶ σκώληξ ὑγρὸν ὡς ζῶα. καὶ πάλιν ἐν αὐτοῖς τοῖς σκώληξιν ὁδὶ μὲν ξηρότερος ὁδὶ δὲ ὑγρότερος ἢ ἁπλῶς ὡς σκώληξ ἢ τῷδέ τινι παραβαλλόμενος ἑτέρῳ. αὐτὸ δὲ τοῦτο τί δή ποτέ ἐστιν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.5:

Bones and cartilage and nails and hooves and horns and hairs and stones and wood and sand and pottery have a smaller portion of the moist and a greater portion of the dry, and for this reason again all such things are called dry. An ant is dry and a worm is moist, as animals. And again among the worms themselves, this one is drier and that one is moister, either simply as a worm or being compared to some other particular one. But what exactly is this very thing itself?
paragraphs.openai_translation: Bones, cartilages, nails, hooves, horns, hairs, stones, wood, sand, and pottery [fired clay] possess a smaller share of the moist and a larger of the dry, and for this reason, again, all such things are called “dry.” The ant is [reckoned] dry and the worm moist, qua animals. And again, among the worms themselves, this one is drier, that one moister—either simply as “worm” [by kind] or when compared with this or that other [specimen]. But what, then, is this very thing?

paragraphs.content: ὅταν οὕτως λέγωμεν ὡς σκώληξ ξηρὸς ὡς ἄνθρωπος θερμὸς ὡς κύων ψυχρὸς εἰ μή τις ἀκριβῶς ἀκούσειέ τε καὶ νοήσειε πρότερον ἀνάγκη συγκεχύσθαι τὸν λόγον ἅπαντα. τὸ δ’ ἀκριβῶς ἐστιν ὃ κᾀν τῷ δευτέρῳ περὶ τῆς τῶν σφυγμῶν διαγνώσεως λέγεται τὸ κατὰ γένος ἢ εἶδος ὀνομάζεσθαι τηνικαῦθ’ ἕκαστον οὐ θερμὸν μόνον ἢ ψυχρὸν ἢ ξηρὸν ἢ ὑγρὸν ἀλλὰ καὶ μέγα καὶ μικρὸν καὶ βραδὺ καὶ ταχὺ καὶ τῶν τοιούτων ἕκαστον
paragraphs.claude_translation: When we speak in this way—"a worm is dry," "a human is hot," "a dog is cold"—unless someone listens and understands precisely, the entire argument must necessarily become confused. And the precise understanding is what is also stated in the second book on the diagnosis of pulses: that each thing is named according to genus or species at that time not only as hot or cold or dry or moist, but also as large and small and slow and fast and each of such qualities.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Whenever we speak in such a way—“the worm is dry, the human hot, the dog cold”—unless someone has first listened carefully and understood, it is inevitable that the whole account be thrown into confusion. Now “accurately” means what is also said in the second [book] On the Diagnosis of Pulses, namely that each thing should then be named according to its genus or species [genos/eidos], not only as hot or cold or dry or moist, but also as large and small and slow and swift, and each of the like qualities.

paragraphs.content: ὅταν ὑπὲρ τὸ σύμμετρόν τε καὶ μέσον ᾖ ἢ ζῶον θερμὸν ὅταν ὑπὲρ τὸ μέσον ᾖ τῇ κράσει ζῶον ἢ ἵππος θερμὸς ὅταν ὑπὲρ τὸν μέσον ἵππον ᾖ. τὰ δ’ ἐν ἑκάστῳ γένει τε καὶ εἴδει μέσα τὰ σύμμετρά ἐστιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

when it is beyond the proportionate and the mean, or an animal is hot when it is beyond the mean in its mixture [temperament], or a horse is hot when it is beyond the mean horse. And the means in each genus and species are what is proportionate.

---

**Brief explanatory notes:**
- "mixture" (κράσις/krasis) refers to the temperament or blend of elemental qualities in medical and philosophical contexts
- The text discusses degrees of qualities (like heat) relative to different standards of measurement: the absolute mean, the mean for animals generally, and the mean for a specific species
paragraphs.openai_translation: Whenever it is beyond what is proportionate and the mean; for example, an animal is “hot” whenever, in respect of its mixture [krāsis: the blend/constitution], it is beyond the mean animal, or a horse is “hot” whenever it is beyond the mean horse. And in each genus and species, the means are the proportionate cases [ta symmetra: well-proportioned/commensurate].

paragraphs.content: ἴσον γὰρ ἀπέχει τῶν ἄκρων ἐν ἐκείνῳ τῷ γένει τε καὶ εἴδει. γένος μὲν οὖν τὸ ζῶον ἵππος δὲ καὶ βοῦς καὶ κύων εἴδη. καὶ δὴ καὶ μέσον μέν ἐστι τῇ κράσει καθ’ ὅλον τὸ γένος τῶν ζώων ὁ ἄνθρωπος· ἐν γὰρ τοῖς ἐφεξῆς τοῦτο δειχθήσεται. μέσος δ’ ὡς ἐν ἀνθρώποις κατ’ εἶδος ὁ καλούμενος εὔσαρκος. οὗτος δ’ ἐστὶν ὃν οὔτε λεπτὸν οὔτε παχὺν ἔχομεν εἰπεῖν οὔτε θερμὸν οὔτε ψυχρὸν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.8:

For it is equally distant from the extremes in that genus and species. Now the genus is animal, while horse and ox and dog are species. And indeed, man is intermediate in mixture [temperament] with respect to the whole genus of animals; for this will be demonstrated in what follows. But as among humans, the one called well-fleshed is intermediate according to species. This is the one whom we can say is neither thin nor fat, neither hot nor cold.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For it is equally distant from the extremes within that genus and species. Thus, “animal” is the genus, while horse, ox, and dog are the species. And indeed, man is the mean in respect of krasis [mixture/temperament] across the whole genus of animals; for this will be shown in what follows. As for the mean within human beings by species, it is the so-called eúsarkos [“well-fleshed,” of moderate build]. This is the one whom we can call neither thin nor thick, neither hot nor cold.

paragraphs.content: οὔτ’ ἄλλῳ τινὶ τῶν τὴν ἀμετρίαν ἐνδεικνυμένων ὀνομάτων προσαγορεῦσαι.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"nor to designate [it] by any other of the terms that indicate excess [or lack of measure]."
paragraphs.openai_translation: "nor to call it by any other of the names that indicate lack of measure [ἀμετρία: imbalance/immoderation]."

paragraphs.content: ὅστις δ’ ἂν ὑπὲρ τοῦτον ᾖ, πάντως οὗτος ἢ θερμότερός ἐστιν, ἢ ψυχρότερος, ἢ ξηρότερος, ἢ ὑγρότερος. ὀνομάζεται δὲ πῇ μὲν ἁπλῶς ὁ τοιοῦτος, πῇ δ’ οὐχ ἁπλῶς.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
But whoever is beyond this point, this person is necessarily either hotter, or colder, or drier, or moister. Such a person is called in one respect simply [by these terms], but in another respect not simply.

---

**Brief note:** The phrase "ἁπλῶς" (haplōs) means "simply" or "absolutely," indicating that the terminology may be applied either in an absolute/unqualified sense or in a qualified/relative sense depending on the context.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Whoever goes beyond this [standard/mean], in any case is either hotter, or colder, or drier, or wetter [the four primary qualities]. And such a one is in one respect named without qualification, and in another respect not without qualification [haplôs = “without qualification”].

paragraphs.content: ἁπλῶς μὲν ὅτι θερμὸς ἢ ψυχρὸς ἢ ξηρὸς ἢ ὑγρὸς εἶναι λέγεται μηκέτι παραβαλλόμενος ἀφωρισμένως ἑνὶ τῷδε. καθ’ ἕτερον δὲ τρόπον οὐχ ἁπλῶς ὅτι τῷ συμμέτρῳ τε καὶ μέσῳ παντὸς τοῦ εἴδους παραβάλλεται. οὕτω δὲ καὶ κύων ζῶον ξηρὸν ἁπλῶς μὲν ὡς ἄν τῳ δόξειε λέγεται μηκέτι παραβαλλόμενος εἰ τύχῃ μύρμηκι καθ’ ἕτερον δὲ τρόπον οὐχ ἁπλῶς ὅτι τῷ συμμέτρῳ τε καὶ μέσῳ τῇ κράσει παντὸς τοῦ εἴδους τῶν ζώων ἁπάντων
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

In one sense, something is said to be hot or cold or dry or moist simply [i.e., absolutely] when it is no longer being compared in a definite way to this one particular thing. But in another sense, it is not simply [absolute] because it is being compared to what is proportionate and intermediate for the entire class. And in this way too, a dog is called a dry animal simply, as it might seem to someone, when it is no longer being compared, for instance, to an ant; but in another sense it is not simply [absolute] because [it is being compared] to what is proportionate and intermediate in mixture for the entire class of all animals.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Taken simply, a thing is said to be hot or cold or dry or moist when it is no longer being compared, in a determinate way, with some particular item. In another way, not simply, it is so called because it is compared with what is commensurate and the mean [symmetron: due proportion; meson: mean] of the whole kind. Thus too a dog is called a dry animal, simply—as someone might suppose—without any longer comparing it, say, with an ant; and in another way, not simply, because it is compared with what is commensurate and the mean, in respect of mixture [krâsis: blend/constitution], of the entire class of animals.

paragraphs.content: ὅ τί ποτ’ ἂν ᾖ τοῦτο παραβάλλεται. πρόδηλον οὖν ἤδη γέγονεν ὡς ἕκαστον τῶν οὕτω λεγομένων ἢ ἑνὶ παραβάλλοντες ὅτῳ δήποτε θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν ἢ ξηρὸν ἢ ὑγρὸν πρὸς ἐκεῖνο λέγομεν ἢ τῷ μέσῳ καθ’ ὅπερ ἂν εἶδος ἢ γένος ᾖ τὸ λεγόμενον· οἷον εἶδος μὲν ἵππον καὶ βοῦν καὶ κύνα καὶ πλάτανον καὶ κυπάριττον καὶ συκῆν γένος δὲ ζῶον ἢ φυτόν. ἐπὶ τούτοις τρίτον ἄλλο σημαινόμενον ἦν τῶν ἁπλῶς λεγομένων
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

whatever this may be, is compared. It has now become clear, therefore, that each of the things spoken of in this way we call hot or cold or dry or moist either by comparing it to some one thing, whatever it may be, in relation to that, or to the mean according to whatever species or genus the thing spoken of may be; for example, horse and ox and dog and plane tree and cypress and fig tree are species, while animal or plant is a genus. In addition to these there was a third different meaning of things spoken of in an absolute sense
paragraphs.openai_translation: Whatever it happens to be, that is what it is compared with. It has therefore now become clear that each of the things spoken of in this way we call hot or cold or dry or moist either by comparing it to some one particular thing—whatever it may be—or to the mean [to meson], according as the thing spoken of is a species [eidos] or a genus [genos]; for example, horse, ox, and dog, and plane-tree, cypress, and fig are species, whereas “animal” or “plant” is a genus. Besides these, there was a third meaning indicated among the things said without qualification [haplōs].

paragraphs.content: ἃ δὴ καὶ τὰς ἀμίκτους τε καὶ ἄκρας ἔφαμεν ἔχειν ποιότητας ὀνομάζεσθαί τε στοιχεῖα. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ τὰς ποιότητας αὐτὰς ὀνομάζομεν ἐνίοτε τοῖς ποιοῖς σώμασιν ὁμωνύμως.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

These are the very things which we said possess unmixed and extreme qualities and are called elements. And indeed we also sometimes name the qualities themselves homonymously with the qualified bodies.

[Note: "homonymously" (ὁμωνύμως) refers to using the same name for both the quality itself and the body possessing that quality]
paragraphs.openai_translation: Those things which we said possess unmixed and extreme qualities are also called “elements” [stoicheia]. And indeed, we sometimes also apply the very names of the qualities, homonymously, to the bodies that have them [i.e., we use the same name for a quality and for a body characterized by it].

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ περὶ μὲν τούτου μετ’ ὀλίγον ἐροῦμεν. εἰς δὲ τὰ παρόντα τῶν ποιῶν σωμάτων τριχῶς λεγομένων ἐπισκοπεῖσθαι προσήκει πῶς ἐν ἑκάστῃ ῥήσει κέχρηταί τις τῇ προσηγορίᾳ πότερον ὡς ἁπλοῦν τι καὶ ἄμικτον δηλῶν ἢ ὡς πρὸς τὸ σύμμετρον ὁμογενὲς ἢ ὁμοειδὲς παραβάλλων ἢ πρὸς ὁτιοῦν τὸ ἐπιτυχόν· οἷον ὅταν ὀστοῦν εἴπῃ τις ξηρὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν ἁπλῶς οὑτωσὶ μόνον ὀνομάσας ἄνευ τοῦ προσθεῖναι λέοντος ἢ κυνὸς ἢ ἀνθρώπου. δῆλον γὰρ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But concerning this matter we shall speak shortly. For present purposes, since qualified bodies are spoken of in three ways, it is appropriate to examine how someone has used the term in each statement—whether indicating something simple and unmixed, or comparing it to what is proportionate and homogeneous or uniform, or to just anything whatever that happens to be at hand. For example, when someone says that bone is dry or cold, naming it simply in this way alone without adding "of a lion" or "of a dog" or "of a human being." For it is clear

---

**Brief notes:**
- "qualified bodies" (τῶν ποιῶν σωμάτων) refers to bodies possessing certain qualities
- "homogeneous or uniform" (ὁμογενὲς ἢ ὁμοειδὲς) are technical terms indicating sameness of kind or form
- The text breaks off mid-sentence with "For it is clear" (δῆλον γὰρ)
paragraphs.openai_translation: But about this we shall speak shortly. For the present, since bodies as qualified [i.e., with respect to quality] are spoken of in three ways, it is proper to examine, in each statement, how someone uses the appellation [designation]: whether declaring something as simple and unmixed, or comparing it, with reference to what is commensurate, as homogeneous or of like form, or in relation to whatever happens to present itself; for example, when someone says that bone is dry or cold, simply naming it thus alone, without adding “of a lion” or “of a dog” or “of a human being.” For it is clear...

paragraphs.content: ὡς πρὸς τὴν ὅλην φύσιν ἀποβλέπων ἁπάντων τῶν ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ σωμάτων ἐπινοεῖ τι μέσον ᾧ παραβάλλων αὐτὸ ξηρὸν εἶναί φησι.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Looking at the whole of nature, he conceives of some middle point among all the bodies in the cosmos, and comparing it [the body in question] to this, he says that it is dry.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Looking to the whole of nature and to all the bodies in the cosmos, he conceives some mean [a standard or midpoint], and by comparing it with that he asserts that it is dry.

paragraphs.content: ἂν δέ γε τὸ τοῦ λέοντος ἢ τὸ τοῦ κυνὸς ἢ τὸ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου ὀστοῦν εἴπῃ ξηρὸν εἶναι δῆλον ὡς ἐν αὐτοῖς πάλιν τοῖς τῶν ζώων ὀστοῖς τῷ μέσῳ παραβάλλει. καὶ χρὴ κᾀνταῦθά τι νοῆσαι πάντων τῶν ζώων τῶν μὲν μᾶλλον τῶν δὲ ἧττον ἐχόντων ὀστᾶ ξηρὰ μέσον εἶναι τὴν κρᾶσιν ὀστοῦν ἔν τινι γένει ζώων οἷον ἀνθρώπου εἰ τύχοι καὶ τούτῳ τἄλλα παραβαλλόμενα τὰ μὲν ὑγρὰ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.17:

But if one should say that the bone of a lion or of a dog or of a human being is dry, it is clear that he is comparing it again to the middle [point] among the bones of animals themselves. And here too one must understand that, since all animals have bones that are more or less dry, there is a middle mixture [temperament] of bone within a certain class of animals—for example, of a human being, as it happens—and when the other [bones] are compared to this one, some are moist

---

**Brief notes:**
- "κρᾶσις" (krasis) refers to mixture or temperament, a technical term in ancient medical theory referring to the balance of qualities
- The text appears incomplete, breaking off mid-sentence with "some are moist"
paragraphs.openai_translation: If, however, he should say that the bone of a lion, or of a dog, or of a human being is dry, it is clear that he is again comparing, among the bones of animals, to the mean. And one must here too grasp this: that among all animals—some having drier bones more, others less—the mean of the mixture [krasis: proportioned blending] is the bone found in some particular kind of animal, say a human being, if it should happen so; and the others, when compared with this, are in some cases wetter…

paragraphs.content: τὰ δὲ ξηρὰ προσαγορεύεσθαι. καὶ μὲν δὴ κᾀν τοῖς ἀνθρώποις αὐτοῖς πάλιν ὁ μέν τις ξηρὸν ὁ δ’ ὑγρὸν ὀστοῦν ἔχειν λεχθήσεται τῷ μέσῳ παραβαλλόμενος ὡς ἐν ἀνθρώποις.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"and the dry things to be called [dry]. And indeed, even among human beings themselves in turn, one person will be said to have a dry bone and another a moist bone when compared to the middle [or mean] as [it exists] among human beings."
paragraphs.openai_translation: And the dry are so designated. And indeed, even among human beings themselves, again, one person will be said to have dry bone and another moist, when compared with the mean [to meson: the average condition], as within the class of human beings.

paragraphs.content: ὅτι δ’ ἐν ἅπασι τοῖς οὖσι τὸ μέσον τῶν ἄκρων ἐστὶ τὸ σύμμετρον καὶ κατ’ ἐκεῖνο τὸ γένος ἢ εἶδος εὔκρατον ἀεὶ χρὴ προσυπακούειν ἐν ἅπαντι τῷ λόγῳ κᾂν παρελθόντες ποτὲ τῇ λέξει τύχωμεν αὐτῇ. καὶ μὲν δὴ τούτων οὕτως ἐχόντων ὅταν ὑγρὰν εἶναί τις εἴπῃ τήνδε τὴν κρᾶσιν ἢ θερμὴν ἐρωτᾷν ὅπως εἴρηκεν ἆρά γε τῷδέ τινι παραβάλλων ἀφωρισμένως ἑνὶ καθάπερ εἰ τύχοι τῷ Πλάτωνι τὸν Θεόφραστον ἢ κατὰ γένος ὁτιοῦν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.19:

That in all existing things the mean between extremes is what is proportionate and well-tempered according to that particular genus or species, one must always understand implicitly throughout the entire argument, even if we happen at some point to omit this in the actual wording. And indeed, since these things are so, whenever someone says that this particular mixture is moist or hot, one must ask in what manner he has spoken—whether he is making a comparison with some one definite thing, as for instance comparing Theophrastus with Plato, or [speaking] according to some genus whatsoever.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And that in all existing things the middle between the extremes is what is proportionate [symmetron], and—relative to that genus or species—well-mixed [eukraton], one must always understand throughout the whole discussion, even if at times we happen to omit it in the wording. And since this is so, whenever someone says that this mixture [krasis, “blend”] is moist or hot, one should ask how he has said it: is he comparing it to some particular thing taken as a fixed standard—just as, for instance, Theophrastus to Plato—or according to some genus of any sort?

paragraphs.content: ἢ εἶδος. ἢ γὰρ ὡς ἄνθρωπον ἢ ὡς ζῶον ἢ ὡς οὐσίαν ἁπλῶς. τὸ γὰρ δὴ τρίτον σημαινόμενον ἑκάστῳ τῶν τοιούτων ὀνομάτων ὅπερ ἁπλοῦν ἐλέγομεν εἶναι καὶ ἄμικτον οὐκ ἔστιν ἐν τοῖς κεκραμένοις ἀλλ’ ἐν αὐτοῖς τοῖς πρώτοις ἃ δὴ καὶ στοιχεῖα προσαγορεύομεν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

or form. For either as man or as animal or as substance simply. For indeed the third meaning of each of such names, which we said was simple and unmixed, does not exist in mixed things but in those primary things themselves which we also call elements.
paragraphs.openai_translation: —or a form. For it is either as “man,” or as “living being,” or as “substance” without qualification. For the third thing signified by each of such names—the thing we said is simple and unmixed—is not found among the compounds, but in the first things themselves, which we also call elements [stoicheia].

paragraphs.content: ὥστε, τριχῶς ἑκάστου τῶν ποιῶν σωμάτων λεγομένου, τῶν δύο μόνων ἡμᾶς χρήζειν εἰς τὴν περὶ κράσεων πραγματείαν, ἢ πρὸς τὸ τυχὸν ὁτιοῦν παραβάλλοντας, ἢ πρὸς τὸ σύμμετρον ὁμογενές. ἐπεὶ δὲ πολλὰ τὰ γένη, καθάπερ οὖν καὶ τὰ ἄτομα, δυνήσεται ταὐτὸ σῶμα καὶ θερμὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν, καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν εἶναι κατὰ πολλοὺς τοὺς τρόπους.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Consequently, since each of the qualified bodies is spoken of in three ways, we need only two of these for the treatise on mixtures [or temperaments]: either comparing them to any random thing whatsoever, or to the well-proportioned thing of the same kind. But since the kinds are many, just as indeed the individuals are also, the same body will be able to be both hot and cold, and both dry and moist in many different ways.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, since each of the “qualitative” bodies [i.e., bodies characterized by active qualities] is spoken of in three ways, we need only two of these for the treatise on mixtures [kraseis]: either by comparing a thing to any chance standard whatsoever, or to a proportionate homogeneous one [symmetron homogenous: a well-balanced body of a single kind]. And since the kinds are many—as indeed are the individuals—the same body will be able to be both hot and cold, and dry and moist, in many different ways.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὅταν μὲν ἑνὶ τῷ τυχόντι παραβάλληται, πάνυ σαφές ἐστιν, ὡς ἐγχωρεῖ τἀναντία λέγεσθαι ταὐτὸν, οἷον Δίωνα Θέωνος μὲν καὶ Μέμνονος ξηρότερον, Ἀρίστωνος δὲ καὶ Γλαύκωνος ὑγρότερον.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But whenever it is compared to any single random person, it is very clear that it is possible for opposite things to be said about the same thing, for example that Dion is drier than Theon and Memnon, but moister than Ariston and Glaucon.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But whenever it is compared with some random individual, it is quite clear how it is possible for contraries to be predicated of the same thing—for example, Dion is drier than Theon and Memnon, but wetter than Ariston and Glaucon.

paragraphs.content: ὅταν δὲ πρὸς τὸ σύμμετρον, ὁμογενὲς ἢ ὁμοειδὲς, ἐνταῦθ’ ἤδη συγχεῖσθαί τε καὶ ταράττεσθαι συμβαίνει τοὺς ἀγυμνάστους.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
But when [it comes] to what is commensurate, whether homogeneous or of the same kind, at that point it then happens that the untrained become confused and disturbed.

---

**Alternative translation:**

But when [the matter concerns] the commensurate, whether of the same genus or the same form, then it already happens that those without training are confounded and thrown into confusion.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But whenever the discussion turns to what is commensurate [σύμμετρον: proportionate/commensurable], or to what is homogeneous [ὁμογενές: of the same kind] or of the same form [ὁμοειδές: of the same form/species], at that point the untrained already tend to become confused and unsettled.

paragraphs.content: ὁ γὰρ αὐτὸς ἄνθρωπός ὑγρὸς ἅμα καὶ θερμὸς εἷναι δύναται καὶ ξηρὸς καὶ ψυχρός· ξηρὸς μὲν καὶ ψυχρὸς ὡς πρὸς τὸν σύμμετρον ἄνθρωπον παραβαλλόμενος ὑγρὸς δὲ καὶ θερμὸς ὡς πρὸς ἄλλο τι ζῶον ἢ φυτὸν ἢ οὐσίαν ἡντιναοῦν· οἷον ὡς πρὸς μὲν ζῶον εἰ τύχοι μέλιττάν τε καὶ μύρμηκα πρὸς δὲ φυτὸν ἐλαίαν ἢ συκῆν ἢ δάφνην πρὸς οὐσίαν δὲ τινα ἑτέραν ἣ μήτε ζῶόν ἐστι μήτε φυτὸν οἷον λίθον ἢ σίδηρον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.24:

For the same human being can be both moist and hot at the same time, and also dry and cold: dry and cold when compared to the well-proportioned human being, but moist and hot when compared to some other living creature or plant or any substance whatsoever. For example, in relation to a living creature, it might be a bee or an ant; in relation to a plant, an olive tree or a fig tree or a laurel; and in relation to some other substance which is neither a living creature nor a plant, such as a stone or iron.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For the same human being can at once be moist and hot, and also dry and cold: dry and cold when compared with the “proportionate” man [symmetron, the standard or well-balanced human], but moist and hot when compared with some other animal, or plant, or any substance [ousia] whatsoever; for example, in relation to an animal, say a bee or an ant; in relation to a plant, an olive, a fig tree, or a laurel; and in relation to some other substance that is neither animal nor plant, such as stone or iron.

paragraphs.content: ἢ χαλκόν ἐν τούτοις δὲ τὸ μὲν πρὸς ἄνθρωπον παραβάλλειν πρὸς ὁμοειδές ἐστιν ἡ παραβολὴ τὸ δὲ πρὸς μέλιτταν ἢ μύρμηκα πρὸς ὁμογενὲς ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ πρὸς φυτὸν ὁτιοῦν. ἔστι γὰρ ἀνωτέρω τοῦ ζώου τοῦτο τὸ γένος ὥσπερ οὖν καὶ αὐτοῦ τούτου λίθος καὶ σίδηρος καὶ χαλκὸς ἐκ τῶν ἄνωθεν γενῶν. καλείσθω γοῦν ὁμογενὲς ἕνεκα συντόμου διδασκαλίας ἡ τοιαύτη σύμπασα παραβολή· τοσόνδε μόνον ἐν αὐτῇ διελομένων ἡμῶν ὡς ἐπειδὴ μὲν ἁπλῶς οὐσία τις εὔκρατος λέλεκται
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.25:

or bronze. Among these comparisons, the one comparing to a human being is a comparison to something of the same species [homoeidēs], while the one comparing to a bee or ant is to something of the same genus [homogenēs]; and likewise also to any plant whatsoever. For this genus is higher than the animal, just as indeed stone and iron and bronze are themselves from the higher genera. Let such a comparison in its entirety be called "of the same genus" [homogenēs] for the sake of concise instruction; with this one distinction being made by us in it: that since a certain well-tempered substance has been spoken of in simple terms...

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence. The terms homoeidēs and homogenēs are technical philosophical terms distinguishing between comparisons within the same species versus the same genus.]
paragraphs.openai_translation: …or bronze. In these cases, to compare something to a human is a comparison to what is of the same species [homoeidēs]; whereas to compare it to a bee or an ant is to what is of the same genus [homogenēs]—and likewise also to any plant whatever. For this genus stands higher than that of animal; and, similarly, stone and iron and bronze belong to the genera that are higher still. Let, then, for the sake of concise instruction, the whole of such comparison be called “homogenous” [same kind], only with this

paragraphs.content: καὶ ταύτης δέ τις ἑτέρα ξηροτέρα καὶ θερμοτέρα καὶ ψυχροτέρα καὶ ὑγροτέρα τὴν μὲν εὔκρατον ἐνταῦθα τὴν ἐκ τῶν ἐναντίων ἀκριβῶς ἴσων συνελθόντων ὀνομάζομεν ὅσον δ’ ἀπολείπεται τῆσδε καὶ πλεονεκτεῖ κατά τι τῷ τοῦ πλεονεκτοῦντος ὀνόματι προσαγορεύομεν· ἐπειδὰν δ’ ἤτοι φυτὸν ἢ ζῶον εὔκρατον ὁτιοῦν εἴπωμεν οὐκ ἔθ’ ἁπλῶς ἐν τῇ τοιαύτῃ τάξει τἀναντία παραβάλλομεν ἀλλήλοις ἀλλὰ πρὸς τὴν τοῦ φυτοῦ φύσιν ἢ τὴν τοῦ ζώου τὴν ἀναφορὰν ποιούμεθα συκῆν μὲν εὔκρατον εἰ τύχοι λέγοντες
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.26:

And of this [mixture] one is drier and hotter, another colder and moister; here we call "well-tempered" [eukratos] that which comes together from exactly equal opposites. But to the extent that something falls short of this or exceeds it in some respect, we designate it by the name of the quality that predominates. However, whenever we say that any plant or animal whatsoever is well-tempered, we no longer simply compare the opposites to one another in such a classification, but rather we make our reference in relation to the nature of the plant or the nature of the animal—saying, for instance, that a fig tree is well-tempered.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And besides this there is another—one that is drier, one hotter, one colder, and one wetter. Here we call “well-tempered” [eukraton] that which comes from the precisely equal conjunction of the opposites [hot/cold and dry/moist]; and whatever falls short of this and has an excess in some respect we designate by the name of that which predominates. But whenever we say that any plant or animal is “well-tempered,” we no longer simply set the opposites against one another in such an arrangement; rather, we make our reference relative to the nature of the plant or of the animal—for example, when we happen to call a fig tree well-tempered.

paragraphs.content: ὅταν οἵαν μάλιστα πρέπει τὴν φύσιν ὑπάρχειν συκῇ τοιαύτη τις ᾖ κύνα δ’ αὖ καὶ σῦν καὶ ἵππον καὶ ἄνθρωπον ἐπειδὰν καὶ τούτων ἕκαστον ἄριστα τῆς οἰκείας ἔχῃ φύσεως. αὐτὸ δὴ τοῦτο τὸ τῆς οἰκείας φύσεως ἔχειν ἄριστα ταῖς ἐνεργείαις κρίνεται καὶ γὰρ καὶ φυτὸν καὶ ζῶον ὁτιοῦν ἄριστα διακεῖσθαι τηνικαῦτά φαμεν ὅταν ἐνεργῇ κάλλιστα. συκῆς μὲν γὰρ ἀρετὴ βέλτιστά τε καὶ πλεῖστα τελεσφορεῖν σῦκα· κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ τῆς ἀμπέλου
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.27:

When a fig tree is of such a nature as especially befits it to have, and likewise a dog, and a pig, and a horse, and a human being—whenever each of these also possesses its own nature in the best way. This very thing, possessing one's own nature in the best way, is judged by activities; for indeed we say that any plant or animal whatsoever is in the best condition at that time when it performs its function most excellently. For the excellence of a fig tree is to bring forth figs in the best and most abundant way; and in the same manner also for the vine...
paragraphs.openai_translation: Whenever the nature that most befits a fig tree is present in it, such it is; and likewise a dog and a pig and a horse and a human being, whenever each of these has its own nature in the best condition. Now this very point—having one’s own nature in the best way—is determined by the activities [energeiai]; for we say that any plant or animal whatsoever is in its best state at the times when it is acting at its finest. For the excellence [aretē] of a fig tree is to bring figs to fruition in the best and most abundant way; and similarly in the case of the vine.

paragraphs.content: τὸ πλείστας τε καὶ καλλίστας εὐφορεῖν σταφυλὰς ἵππου δὲ τὸ θεῖν ὠκύτατα καὶ κυνὸς πρὸς μὲν θήρας καὶ φυλακὰς ἄκρως εἶναι θυμοειδῆ πρὸς δὲ τοὺς οἰκείους πραότατον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"to bear the most numerous and finest grapes; and of a horse, to run most swiftly; and of a dog, to be extremely spirited toward hunts and guard duties, but most gentle toward its household members."
paragraphs.openai_translation: For the vine, to bear the most and finest clusters of grapes; for the horse, to run with the greatest speed; and for the dog, in regard to hunting and guarding, to be exceedingly high‑spirited [thymoeidēs: spirited/bold], but toward its own people, the gentlest.

paragraphs.content: ἅπαντα οὖν ταῦτα, τά τε ζῶα λέγω καὶ τὰ φυτὰ, τὴν ἀρίστην τε καὶ μέσην ἐν τῷ σφετέρῳ γένει κρᾶσιν ἔχειν ἐροῦμεν οὐχ ἁπλῶς, ὅταν ἰσότης ἀκριβῶς ᾖ τῶν ἐναντίων, ἀλλ’ ὅταν ἡ κατὰ δύναμιν αὐτῆς ὑπάρχῃ συμμετρία. τοιοῦτο δέ τι καὶ τὴν δικαιοσύνην εἶναί φαμεν, οὐ σταθμῷ καὶ μέτρῳ τὸ ἴσον, ἀλλὰ τῷ προσήκοντί γε καὶ κατὰ τὴν ἀξίαν ἐξετάζοντες.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Therefore, we shall say that all these things—I mean both the animals and the plants—possess the best and middle mixture in their respective kind not simply when there is a precise equality of opposites, but when there exists a proportionality according to their capacity. We say that justice too is something of this sort, examining what is equal not by weight and measure, but rather by what is fitting and according to worth.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, we shall say that all these things—both animals and plants—possess the best and the middle blend [krâsis: mixture] within their own kind not simply when there is a precise equality of the contraries [opposing qualities], but when there is a symmetry proportionate to its capacity [kata dynamin]. And we say that justice too is something of this sort—not equality by scale and measure, but by examining what is fitting [to prosēkon] and according to worth [axia/desert].

paragraphs.content: ἰσότης οὖν κράσεως ἐν ἅπασι τοῖς εὐκράτοις ζώοις τε καὶ φυτοῖς ἐστιν οὐχ ἡ κατὰ τῶν κερασθέντων στοιχείων ὄγκον ἀλλ’ ἡ τῇ φύσει τοῦ τε ζώου καὶ τοῦ φυτοῦ πρέπουσα. πρέπει δ’ ἔσθ’ ὅτε τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ τὸ δὲ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλέον ὑπάρχειν. οὐ γὰρ ὁμοίαν χρὴ κρᾶσιν ἔχειν ἄνθρωπον καὶ λέοντα καὶ μέλιτταν καὶ κύνα. πρὸς δὲ τὸν ἐρόμενον ἧστινός ἐστι κράσεως ἄνθρωπος ἢ ἵππος ἢ βοῦς ἢ κύων
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.30:

The equality of mixture in all well-tempered animals and plants, therefore, is not according to the mass of the elements that have been mixed together, but rather that which is appropriate to the nature of both the animal and the plant. And it is appropriate at times for the moist to be greater than the dry, and the hot than the cold. For a human being and a lion and a bee and a dog must not have a similar mixture. And to the one who asks of what mixture a human being is, or a horse, or an ox, or a dog—

---

**Notes:**
- *krasis* (κρᾶσις/κράσεως) = "mixture" or "blend" [refers to the mixture of elemental qualities in Galenic/Hippocratic medical theory]
- *eukratos* (εὐκράτοις) = "well-tempered" or "well-mixed" [having a good balance of qualities]
- The four qualities referenced are the traditional hot, cold, moist, and dry of ancient Greek medical theory
paragraphs.openai_translation: Equality of mixture [krâsis: the blend/temperament of the elemental qualities] in all well-tempered animals and plants is not the equality in the bulk of the elements that have been mixed, but that which is fitting to the nature of the animal or the plant. At times, moreover, it is proper that the moist be present in greater measure than the dry, and the hot than the cold [i.e., among the four primary qualities: hot/cold, dry/moist]. For a human being, a lion, a bee, and a dog ought not to have the same mixture. And to one who asks of what mixture a human being or a horse or an ox or a dog is—

paragraphs.content: ἢ ὁτιοῦν ἄλλο τῶν πάντων οὐχ ἁπλῶς ἀποκριτέον. οὐ γὰρ ἐγχωρεῖ τὰ πολλαχῶς λεγόμενά τε καὶ κρινόμενα καθ’ ἕνα τρόπον ἀποκρινάμενον ἀνέγκλητον εἶναι. χρὴ τοίνυν δυοῖν θάτερον ἢ πάσας ἐπεξέρχεσθαι τὰς διαφορὰς ἢ περὶ τίνος ἤρετο πυθόμενον ἐκείνην μόνην εἰπεῖν. εἰ μὲν γὰρ ὡς ἐν ζώοις ἐπυνθάνετο τίνος εἴη κράσεως ἐπὶ τὸ μέσον ἁπάντων ζώων τῇ κράσει βλέποντα τὴν ἀπόκρισιν αὐτὴν ποιητέον· εἰ δ’ ἁπλῶς τε καὶ ὡς πρὸς ἅπασαν οὐσίαν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.31:

or any other thing among all things, one must not answer simply. For it is not possible for things that are spoken of and judged in many ways to be beyond reproach when one has answered in a single manner. Therefore, one must do one of two things: either go through all the distinctions, or, having learned about what he was asking, state that one alone. For if he was inquiring as one does concerning animals, what sort of mixture [krasis] it might be, one must make the answer looking toward the middle of all animals with respect to mixture; but if simply and in relation to all substance

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence. *Krasis* refers to mixture or blending, often used in medical and philosophical contexts to describe the combination or temperament of elements or qualities.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Or any other thing whatsoever among all things is not to be answered simply. For it is not possible that matters spoken of and judged in many ways should, when answered in a single way, remain without reproach. One must therefore do one of two things: either go through all the distinctions, or, after learning what the inquiry concerns, speak only to that. For if he was asking, as in the case of living creatures, of what [mixture/temperament: krâsis] it is, the answer must be given with an eye to the mean, in respect of [mixture/temperament], among all animals; but if he was asking simply and with reference to every substance…

paragraphs.content: οὕτως ἤδη παραβάλλειν τὰ ἐναντία τῶν ἐν αὐτῷ πρὸς ἄλληλα καὶ σκοπεῖσθαι μηκέτι πρὸς τὰς ἐνεργείας ἀναφέροντα τὴν κρᾶσιν ἀλλὰ πρὸς τοὺς ὄγκους τῶν στοιχείων. εἰ δ’ ἀφωρισμένως τῷδέ τινι παραβάλλων ἤρετο πρὸς ἐκεῖνο μόνον παραβλητέον. ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον εἴ τινος τῶν ἀτόμων οὐσιῶν οἷον εἰ τύχοι Δίωνος ἢ τοῦδέ τινος τοῦ κυνὸς ἐρωτηθείημεν ὁποία τις ἡ κρᾶσίς ἐστιν οὐχ ἁπλῶς ἀποκριτέον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation of Paragraph 6.32:

Thus one should now compare the opposites within it [the mixture] to one another and examine them no longer by referring the mixture to the activities but to the masses of the elements. But if someone were to ask by comparing it in a definite way to some particular thing, one should compare it only to that thing. And even more so, if we were asked about the mixture of any of the individual substances—for instance, if it happened to be Dion or some particular dog—what sort of mixture it is, one should not answer simply.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Thus one should now compare the contraries of the things present in it with one another, and examine the [krasis: mixture] no longer by referring it to the [energeiai: activities/functions] but to the [onkoi: masses/volumes] of the [stoicheia: elements]. But if the inquiry, making a determinate comparison with this particular thing, were posed, the comparison must be made with that alone. And even more so, if we were asked about some individual substance—say, Dion, or this particular dog—what sort of [krasis: mixture] it has, one must not give a simple answer.

paragraphs.content: ἀφορμὴ γὰρ οὐ σμικρὰ τοῖς σοφισταῖς ἐντεῦθεν εἰς τὸ συκοφαντεῖν. εἰ γὰρ εἴποις θερμῆς καὶ ξηρᾶς κράσεως εἶναι τὸν Δίων ῥᾷστον αὐτῷ προχειρισαμένῳ τῶν ξηροτέρων καὶ θερμοτέρων ἐκείνου τὴν κρᾶσιν ἄνθρωπον ὁντιναοῦν ὑγρὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν ὡς πρὸς ἐκεῖνον ἀποφῇναι τὸν Δίωνα· τοῦτο δ’ ἄλλο τι ζῶον ἢ φυτὸν οἷον εἰ τύχοι λέοντά τε καὶ κύνα καὶ τούτων ὑγρότερόν τινα καὶ ξηρότερον ἀποδεῖξαι τὸν Δίωνα. χρὴ τοίνυν ὃς μήθ’ ἑαυτὸν ἐξαπατῆσαι βούλεται μήθ’ ὑπ’ ἄλλου σοφισθῆναι
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For this provides no small opportunity for the sophists to engage in false accusation. For if you were to say that Dion is of a hot and dry mixture [temperament], it would be very easy for someone, having selected at hand any person whatsoever who is drier and hotter in mixture than that man, to declare that Dion is moist and cold in relation to him; and then to prove that Dion is moister and drier than some other animal or plant, such as, for instance, a lion and a dog, and someone moister or drier than these. Therefore, whoever wishes neither to deceive himself nor to be deceived by another through sophistry must...

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence. "Mixture" (κρᾶσις) refers to the medical theory of temperament or constitutional balance of bodily qualities.]
paragraphs.openai_translation: For from this there is no small occasion for the sophists to practice slander. For if you were to say that Dion has a hot and dry mixture [krasis: the temperament or blend of qualities], it would be easiest for him—having selected someone whose mixture is drier and hotter than Dion’s—to declare Dion moist and cold in comparison with that man; and then to take some other animal or plant—say, a lion and a dog—and show Dion to be wetter than one of these and drier than the other. One must therefore, if one does not wish either to deceive oneself or to be tricked by another’s sophistry...

paragraphs.content: τοῦτον ἀπὸ τῶν ἁπλῶς λεγομένων θερμῶν καὶ ψυχρῶν καὶ ξηρῶν καὶ ὑγρῶν οὐσιῶν ἀρξάμενον οὕτως ἐπὶ τὰς ἄλλας μετιέναι καὶ πρῶτον μὲν αὐτὸ δὴ τοῦτο ἐπ’ αὐτῶν διορίσασθαι τὸ μηδὲ ταύτας εἰ καὶ ὅτι μάλιστα δοκοῦσιν ἁπλῶς λέγεσθαι πεφευγέναι τὴν πρὸς τὸ σύμμετρον ὁμογενὲς παραβολήν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"[One must proceed] having begun from the substances that are called hot and cold and dry and wet in an absolute sense, and thus proceed to the others, and first to determine this very point concerning them: that not even these substances, even if they especially seem to be spoken of in an absolute sense, have escaped comparison with a commensurable standard of the same kind."
paragraphs.openai_translation: Beginning from the substances that are called, in a simple way, hot, cold, dry, and wet, and thus proceeding to the others, and first of all determining this point with respect to these themselves: that not even these—although they seem most of all to be spoken of simply—have escaped comparison to what is commensurate and homogeneous [i.e., like-with-like, measurable in the same terms].

paragraphs.content: ὥσπερ γὰρ κύνα μέσον ἁπάντων κυνῶν τῇ κράσει λέγομεν, ὅταν ἴσον ἀπέχῃ τῶν ἄκρων, οὕτω καὶ οὐσίαν ἐροῦμεν εἶναι μέσην τῇ κράσει τὴν ἴσον ἀπέχουσαν τῶν ἄκρων, ἅ δὴ καὶ πρῶτά τέ εἰσι πάντων καὶ στοιχεῖα.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For just as we say that a dog is intermediate among all dogs in its mixture [blend] when it is equally distant from the extremes, so too we shall say that a substance is intermediate in its mixture which is equally distant from the extremes, which are indeed both first of all things and elements.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For just as we call a dog the “middle” among all dogs in respect to its mixture [krasis: temperament/constitution] when it is equally distant from the extremes, so too we shall say that a substance is middle in its mixture when it is equally removed from the extremes—those which, indeed, are both the first of all things and the elements [stoicheia].

paragraphs.content: ἴσον δ’ ἀφέξει δηλονότι τῶν ἄκρων ἐξ ἴσου κερασθέντων ἁπάντων. τὴν οὖν ὑπερβάλλουσαν ἢ ἐλλείπουσαν τῆσδε θερμὴν ἢ ψυχρὰν ἢ ξηρὰν ἢ ὑγρὰν εἶναι φήσομεν ἅμα μὲν τῇ μέσῃ παραβάλλοντες ἅμα δὲ καὶ τῶν ἐναντίων στοιχείων ἐξέτασιν ἐπ’ αὐτῆς ποιούμενοι. καὶ δὴ καὶ κατὰ τοῦτο μὲν ἁπλῶς ἐροῦμεν αὐτὴν ἢ θερμὴν ἢ ξηρὰν ἢ ψυχρὰν ἢ ὑγράν ὑπάρχειν. ἐπειδὰν δὲ τῇ μέσῃ κράσει παραβάλλωμεν οὐχ ἁπλῶς
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

It will clearly stand at an equal distance from the extremes when all things have been mixed in equal proportion. Therefore, we shall say that the [mixture] which exceeds or falls short of this one is hot or cold or dry or moist, comparing it at once with the mean and at the same time making an examination of the contrary elements in it. And indeed in this respect we shall say simply that it is either hot or dry or cold or moist. But whenever we compare it with the mean mixture, not simply
paragraphs.openai_translation: And it will, of course, be equally distant when all the extremes have been mixed in equal proportion. Accordingly, whatever exceeds or falls short of this we shall call hot or cold or dry or moist, both by comparing it with the mean and also by making an examination of it in respect to the opposed elements [stoicheia]. And so, on this basis, we shall say simply that it is either hot or dry or cold or moist. But whenever we compare it with the mean mixture [krasis], not simply…

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὅτι πρὸς τὸ σύμμετρον ὁμογενὲς οὕτως ἔχει. γένος δ’ ἦν αὐτῶν ἡ οὐσία. πάντα γὰρ ὑπ’ αὐτὴν πέπτωκεν ὡς ἀνώτατον τὸ γένος ἔμψυχά τε καὶ ἄψυχα καὶ κοινόν ἐστιν ἥδε καὶ ἀνθρώπου καὶ κυνὸς καὶ πλατάνου καὶ συκῆς καὶ χαλκοῦ καὶ σιδήρου καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ἁπάντων γένος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But rather that it is related in this way to the commensurate as being of the same genus. And their genus was substance. For all things have fallen under it as the highest genus—both animate and inanimate things—and this is the common genus of both man and dog and plane-tree and fig-tree and bronze and iron and all other things.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But that, with respect to the commensurate [the proportionate], the homogeneous [what is of the same kind] stands thus. And their genus was substance. For everything falls under it as the highest genus, both animate and inanimate; and this is the common genus of human being and dog and plane tree and fig tree and bronze and iron and of all other things.

paragraphs.content: ὑπ’ αὐτῇ δ’ ἐστὶν ἕτερα γένη πολλά· τὸ μὲν ζῶον ὄρνιθός τε καὶ ἰχθύος, τὸ δὲ φυτὸν δένδρου τε καὶ βοτάνης· ἀετοῦ δὲ καὶ κόρακος ὄρνις, καὶ λάβρακος καὶ φωκίδος ἰχθύς.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Under it there are many other kinds: one is the animal of both bird and fish, another is the plant of both tree and herb; and eagle and crow are bird, and sea bass and seal are fish.

---

**Alternative translation with clearer logical structure:**

Under it there are many other genera: one genus is animal, which includes both bird and fish; another is plant, which includes both tree and herb. Eagle and crow belong to bird, and sea bass and seal belong to fish.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And under it there are many other genera: the animal, into bird and fish; the plant, into tree and herb; and the bird, into eagle and raven, and the fish, into labrax and phokis [labrax = sea-bass; phokis = a kind of fish].

paragraphs.content: ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ τὸ μὲν δένδρον ἐλαίας τε καὶ συκῆς γένος· ἡ βοτάνη δὲ ἀναγαλλίδος τε καὶ παιονίας. ἔσχατα δ’ ἤδη γένη ταῦτα· καὶ διὰ τοῦτο καὶ εἴδη προσαγορεύεται, κόραξ, καὶ φωκὶς, καὶ συκῆ, καὶ ἀναγαλλίς· οὕτω δὲ καὶ ἄνθρωπος, καὶ βοῦς, καὶ κύων.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Likewise, the tree is a genus of both olive and fig; and the plant is a genus of pimpernel and peony. These are now ultimate genera; and for this reason they are also called species: crow, and seal, and fig, and pimpernel; and similarly man, and ox, and dog.

---

**Alternative translation with slight variation:**

In the same way, tree is a genus of olive and fig; while plant is a genus of pimpernel and peony. But these are already the lowest genera; and because of this they are also designated as species: crow, seal, fig, and pimpernel; and likewise man, ox, and dog.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Likewise, “tree” is the genus [genus] of the olive and the fig, and “herb” is [the genus] of the pimpernel and the peony. These are already ultimate genera; and for this reason they are also called species [species]: raven, seal, fig tree, and pimpernel; and so too man, ox, and dog.

paragraphs.content: ἄνωθεν μὲν οὖν κατιόντων, ἔσχατα γένη ταῦτα, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο καὶ εἴδη προσαγορεύεται· κάτωθεν δ’ ἀνιόντων ἀπὸ τῶν ἀτόμων οὐσιῶν, πρῶτα. καὶ δέδεικται πρὸς ἑτέρου γράμματος, ὡς εὐλόγως οἱ παλαιοὶ ταῦτα ξύμπαντα τὰ μεταξὺ τῶν ἀτόμων τε καὶ τῶν πρώτων γενῶν εἴδη τε ἅμα καὶ γένη προσαγορεύουσιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.40:

Therefore, when descending from above, these are the lowest genera, and for this reason they are also called species; but when ascending from below from the individual substances, they are the first. And it has been demonstrated in another work that the ancients reasonably call all these things that are between the individuals and the primary genera both species and genera at the same time.

---

**Brief explanatory notes:**
- [ἄτομοι οὐσίαι = "individual substances" or "atomic substances" - referring to particular, indivisible entities in Aristotelian logic]
- [The text discusses the relative nature of logical categories: the same entities can be called "species" when viewed from above (from more general categories) or "genera" when viewed from below (from individual instances)]
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, when one descends from above, these are the last genera [lowest genera], and for this reason they are also designated as species; but when one ascends from below, starting from the atomic substances [individual substances], they are first. And it has been shown elsewhere [in another treatise] that it is reasonable for the ancients to call all the things lying between the individuals and the first genera [highest genera] both species and genera at once.
