paragraphs.content: Ὁπότ’ οὖν διῄρηται τὰ σημαινόμενα, καὶ ὡς οὐχ ἁπλῶς ἀποφαίνεσθαι χρὴ θερμόν τε καὶ ψυχρὸν, καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν σῶμα, σαφῶς ἀποδέδεικται, ζητητέον ἐφεξῆς αὐτῶν τὰ γνωρίσματα. καίτοι κᾷνταῦθα χρὴ πρότερον ὑπὲρ τῶν ὀνομάτων διελέσθαι τῶν ἐμπίπτειν ἐξ ἀνάγκης μελλόντων εἰς τὸν ἐφεξῆς λόγον, ἐξαπλῶσαί τέ τι πρᾶγμα, δυνάμει μὲν ἤδη προαποδεδειγμένον, οὐ μὴν ἐναργῶς γε πᾶσι τοῖς ἐντυγχάνουσι τῷδε τῷ γράμματι νοηθῆναι δυνάμενον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 7.1:

Since, therefore, the meanings have been distinguished, and it has been clearly demonstrated that one must not make simple declarations about hot and cold, and dry and moist body, we must investigate next their distinguishing characteristics. And yet here too it is necessary first to discuss the terms that will inevitably occur in the subsequent discourse, and to explain in detail a certain matter which has already been demonstrated in principle, but which nevertheless cannot be clearly understood by all those who encounter this treatise.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, since the things signified have been distinguished, and it has been clearly shown that one ought not simply to predicate “hot” and “cold,” and “dry” and “moist,” of a body, we must next inquire into their distinguishing marks [gnōrismata: diagnostic signs]. And yet, even here, it is first necessary to discuss the terms that will of necessity occur in the subsequent argument, and to unfold a certain point—already demonstrated in potential [i.e., implicitly], yet not capable of being clearly understood by all who encounter this writing.

paragraphs.content: ὑπὲρ τῶν ὀνομάτων οὖν πρῶτον εἰπὼν, οὕτως ἐπάνειμι ἐπὶ τὸ πρᾶγμα. τὸ θερμὸν, καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν, καὶ τὸ ξηρὸν, καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν, ὅτι μὲν οὐχ ἕν τι σημαίνει, ἐπειδὰν ἐπὶ σωμάτων λέγηται, δέδεικται πρόσθεν· ὅτι δὲ καὶ τὰς ἐν τοῖς σώμασι ποιότητας αὐτὰς μόνας, ἄνευ τῶν δεδεγμένων αὐτὰς οὐσιῶν, οὕτως ὀνομάζουσιν ἐνίοτε, τοῦτο μὲν οὔπω εἴρηται πρόσθεν, ἤδη δὲ αὐτὸ λέγεσθαι καιρός.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 7.2:

Having spoken first, then, concerning the terms, I shall return in this way to the matter at hand. That "the hot," "the cold," "the dry," and "the moist" do not signify any one thing when they are spoken of in reference to bodies has been demonstrated previously; but that people sometimes name in this way the qualities themselves in bodies alone, without the substances that have received them—this has not yet been said before, but now is the proper time for it to be said.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So then, having first spoken about the names, I shall thus return to the matter. As for “the hot,” “the cold,” “the dry,” and “the moist,” that they do not signify any one single thing when they are said of bodies [i.e., predicated of bodies] has been shown earlier; but that they sometimes use these names for the very qualities in bodies themselves, taken alone, apart from the substances that have received them [i.e., the underlying subjects], this has not yet been stated before— and now it is time to say it.

paragraphs.content: ὥσπερ οὖν τὸ λευκὸν ὄνομα κατά τε τοῦ χρώματος ἐπιφέρουσιν ἐπειδὰν οὕτω λέγωσιν ἐναντίον ἐστὶ τὸ λευκὸν χρῶμα τῷ μέλανι κατά τε τοῦ δεδεγμένου τὸ χρῶμα σώματος ἐπειδὰν τὸ τοῦ κύκνου σῶμα λευκὸν εἶναι φάσκωσιν οὕτω καὶ τὸ θερμὸν ὄνομα κατά τε τῆς ποιότητος ἐπιφέρουσιν ὡς εἰ καὶ θερμότητα προσηγόρευον ἀλλὰ καὶ κατὰ τοῦ σώματος
paragraphs.claude_translation: Just as, then, they apply the name "white" both to the color when they say in this way "the white color is opposite to the black," and to the body that has received the color when they assert that the body of the swan is white, so too they apply the name "hot" both to the quality, as if they were also calling it "heat," and also to the body.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Just as, then, they apply the name “white” both with reference to the color—when they say, “the white color is opposite to the black”—and with reference to the body that has taken on the color, when they assert that “the body of the swan is white,” so too they apply the name “hot” both with reference to the quality [i.e., the property of heat], as if they were naming “heat” itself, and also with reference to the body.

paragraphs.content: ὅ τὴν θερμότητα δέδεκται. τὴν γὰρ δὴ ποιότητα παρὰ τὸ δεδεγμένον αὐτὴν σῶμα ἑτέραν χρὴ νομίζειν εἶναί τινα φύσιν ἔχουσαν ἰδίαν ὡς ἐν τοῖς περὶ τῶν στοιχείων λόγοις δείκνυται. θερμότης μὲν οὖν ποιότης· ἡ δ’ αὐτὴ καὶ θερμὸν ὀνομάζεται καθάπερ λευκότης καὶ λευκόν. αὐτὸ δὲ σῶμα τὸ θερμὸν ἓν τοῦτο μόνον ὄνομα κέκτηται τὸ θερμὸν ὥσπερ τὸ λευκόν· οὐ μὴν οὔτε θερμότης
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

which has received the heat. For indeed one must consider the quality to be a certain nature having its own distinct character apart from the body that has received it, as is demonstrated in the discussions concerning the elements. Heat, then, is a quality; and the same thing is also called hot, just as whiteness is also called white. But the hot body itself has acquired only this one name, "hot," just as "white"; however, neither "heat"
paragraphs.openai_translation: which has received heat. For indeed one must consider the quality [poiotes] to be something other than the body that has received it, possessing its own peculiar nature, as is shown in the treatises concerning the elements. Heat, then, is a quality; and the same is also called “the hot,” just as “whiteness” and “white.” But the body itself, the hot body, has only this one name, “the hot,” just like “the white”; yet neither heat…

paragraphs.content: οὔτε λευκότης αὐτὸ τὸ σῶμά ποτε προσαγορεύεται. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν ὀνομάζεται αὐτό τε τὸ σῶμα καὶ ἡ ποιότης. οὐ μὴν ἡ ψυχρότης ἢ ξηρότης ἢ ὑγρότης ἔτι τὸ σῶμα καλεῖται καθάπερ ἡ ἐν αὐτῷ ποιότης. τούτων δ’ οὕτως ἐχόντων εὔλογον ἐπειδὰν μὲν ἤτοι θερμότητά τις ἢ ψυχρότητα διαλεγόμενος εἴπῃ μηδὲν γίνεσθαι σόφισμα· μόναι γὰρ ἐκ τῶν τοιούτων ὀνομάτων αἱ ποιότητες δηλοῦνται· θερμὸν δ’ εἰπόντος ἢ ψυχρὸν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 7.5:

Nor is whiteness ever called the body itself. But in the same manner, both the body itself and the quality are named dry and cold and moist. However, coldness or dryness or moistness is no longer called the body, just as the quality in it [is not]. Since these things are so, it is reasonable that whenever someone speaking of either heat or coldness says [something], no sophism arises; for only the qualities are indicated by such names. But when someone says hot or cold

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end of this paragraph, suggesting continuation in the next section.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Nor is “whiteness” ever itself called the body. And in the same way both the body and the quality are called “dry,” “cold,” and “wet.” Yet “coldness,” “dryness,” or “wetness” is not in turn called the body, as the quality [poiotes: quality] in it is. With things so, it is reasonable that, whenever someone in discussion says that neither heat [thermotes] nor coldness comes to be, this is a sophism; for by names of this sort only the qualities are indicated. But when one says “hot” or “cold”—

paragraphs.content: ἐπειδὴ καὶ ἡ ποιότης οὕτω καὶ τὸ σῶμα τὸ δεδεγμένον αὐτὴν ὀνομάζεται πρόχειρον γίνεσθαι τῷ κακουργεῖν ἐθέλοντι τὸ μὴ δηλούμενον ὑπὸ τοῦ λέγοντος ἀκούειν ἵν’ ἔχῃ σοφίζεσθαι. τοιοῦτο γάρ τοι δρῶσι καὶ πρὸς τὸν ἀφορισμὸν ἀντιλέγοντες ἐν ᾧ φησιν Ἱπποκράτης· τὰ αὐξανόμενα πλεῖστον ἔχει τὸ ἔμφυτον θερμόν. οὐ γὰρ σῶμά τι θερμὸν τὸ ἔμφυτον τῷ ζώῳ λέγεσθαι πρὸς Ἱπποκράτους ἀκούσαντες οὐδὲ ζητήσαντες ὅ τί ποτέ ἐστι τοῦτο κατὰ τῆς ποιότητος μόνης
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 7.6:

Since both the quality and the body that has received it are named in this way, it becomes easy for one who wishes to act maliciously to hear what is not being indicated by the speaker, so that he may have the means to quibble. For indeed they do such things when arguing against the aphorism in which Hippocrates says: "Growing things have the most innate heat." For they did not hear that Hippocrates was speaking of some hot body as innate to the living creature, nor did they investigate what this might actually be, but [they argue] against the quality alone.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Since both the quality in this way and the body that has received it are called by the same name, it becomes an easy pretext for someone who wants to play foul to hear what the speaker is not actually indicating, so that he may have something to sophize about. For they do just this, too, when they object to the Aphorism in which Hippocrates says: “Things that are growing possess the most innate heat [to emphuton thermon].” For, not having heard from Hippocrates that the innate [heat] in a living creature is said to be some hot body, nor having inquired what this is, they mount an attack against the quality [as such] alone.

paragraphs.content: ἣν δὴ καὶ θερμότητα καλοῦμεν εἰρῆσθαι τοὔνομα δεξάμενοι τὴν ἀντιλογίαν οὕτω ποιοῦνται. καίτοι φαίνεται σμικρὸν ὂν τὸ διαστέλλεσθαι τὰς ὁμωνυμίας ἐν τῇ χρείᾳ τῶν πραγμάτων ἱκανῶς ἀξιόλογον ὑπάρχον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"which indeed we also call heat, having accepted the name as it has been stated, they make their counter-argument in this way. And yet it appears that distinguishing homonymies [terms with the same name but different meanings], though being a small matter, is in the practical use of things sufficiently worthy of note."
paragraphs.openai_translation: “which indeed we also call ‘heat’: accepting the objection [antilogia: counter-argument] that the name has already been applied, they proceed in this way. And yet, although distinguishing homonyms [i.e., same name for different things] seems a small matter, it proves quite noteworthy enough in the practical use of things.”

paragraphs.content: Ἀλλ’ ἐπειδὴ καὶ τοῦτο σαφῶς ἤδη διώρισται ἐπὶ τὸ ὑπόλοιπον αὖθις ἐπανιτέον. οὔσης γάρ τινος ἀκράτου καὶ ἀμίκτου ποιότητος ὑγρότητός τε καὶ ξηρότητος καὶ θερμότητος καὶ ψυχρότητος ὅσα ταύτας διεδέξαντο σώματα θερμὰ δηλονότι καὶ ψυχρὰ καὶ ξηρὰ καὶ ὑγρὰ τελέως τε καὶ ἀκριβῶς ἔσται. ταυτὶ μὲν οὖν μοι νόει τὰ τῶν γινομένων τε καὶ φθειρομένων στοιχεῖα· τὰ δ’ ἄλλα σώματα τά τε τῶν ζώων καὶ τὰ τῶν φυτῶν καὶ τὰ τῶν ἀψύχων ἁπάντων οἷον χαλκοῦ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 8.1:

But since this too has now been clearly distinguished, we must return again to what remains. For since there exists some unmixed and pure quality of moistness and dryness and hotness and coldness, all those bodies that have received these qualities will obviously be hot and cold and dry and moist completely and precisely. These, then, you should understand as the elements of things that come to be and perish; but the other bodies—both those of animals and those of plants and those of all inanimate things, such as bronze

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence at "such as bronze" (χαλκοῦ), suggesting this is an incomplete excerpt from a larger work discussing the fundamental qualities and elements that constitute different types of bodies.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But since this too has already been clearly distinguished, we must return again to what remains. For since there exists a certain pure and unmixed quality of Moistness and Dryness and Heat and Cold, whatever bodies have received these will be hot, plainly, and cold and dry and moist, completely and precisely. Understand these, then, as the elements [stoicheia] of things that come to be and perish; but the other bodies—those of animals, of plants, and of all lifeless things, such as bronze—

paragraphs.content: καὶ σιδήρου καὶ λίθων καὶ ξύλων ἐν τῷ μεταξὺ τῶν πρώτων ἐκείνων τετάχθαι. οὐδὲν γὰρ αὐτῶν οὔτ’ ἄκρως θερμὸν οὔτ’ ἄκρως ψυχρὸν οὔτ’ ἄκρως ὑγρὸν οὔτ’ ἄκρως ξηρόν ἐστιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

and of iron and stones and wood to be arranged in the middle between those first elements. For none of them is either extremely hot or extremely cold or extremely wet or extremely dry.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And that iron, stones, and woods are set among the intermediates between those first [principles/elements]. For none of them is in the extreme—either hot, or cold, or moist, or dry.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἤτοι μέσον ἀκριβῶς ὑπάρχει τῶν ἐναντίων ὡς μηδὲν μᾶλλον εἶναι θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν ἢ ξηρὸν ἢ ὑγρὸν ἢ θατέρῳ τῶν ἄκρων προσκεχώρηκεν ὡς μᾶλλον εἶναι θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν ἢ μᾶλλον ὑγρὸν ἢ ξηρόν. εἰ μὲν δὴ μέσον ἀκριβῶς εἴη καθ’ ἑκατέραν τῶν ἐναντιώσεων ὡς μηδὲν μᾶλλον εἶναι θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν ἢ ξηρὸν ἢ ὑγρὸν εὔκρατον ἁπλῶς τοῦτο λεχθήσεται. θατέρου δὲ πλεονεκτήσαντος ἤτοι κατὰ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν ἢ κατ’ ἀμφοτέραν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But either it exists precisely in the middle of the opposites so that it is in no way more hot than cold or dry than moist, or it has inclined toward one of the extremes so that it is more hot than cold or more moist than dry. Now if it should be precisely in the middle with respect to each of the oppositions so that it is in no way more hot than cold or dry than moist, this will be called well-tempered [eukraton] in the absolute sense. But when one has prevailed, either with respect to one opposition or with respect to both—

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence. "Eukraton" refers to a balanced mixture or good temperament, a technical term in ancient Greek medical and philosophical theory regarding the balance of qualities or humors.]
paragraphs.openai_translation: But either it stands exactly in the middle of the contraries, so as to be no more hot than cold, or dry than moist; or else it has inclined toward one of the extremes, so as to be more hot than cold, or more moist than dry. If, then, it is exactly intermediate with respect to each pair of opposites, so as to be in no way more hot than cold or dry than moist, this will be called simply “well-tempered” [eukraton: a balanced mixture]. But if one of the two has the advantage, either with respect to the one opposition or with respect to both—

paragraphs.content: οὐκ ἔτ’ εὔκρατον. εἰ μὲν δὴ θερμὸν εἴη μᾶλλον ἢ ψυχρὸν ὃ μᾶλλόν ἐστι τοῦτο λεχθήσεται· ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ ὑγρόν· κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ εἰ ψυχρὸν εἴη μᾶλλον ὀνομασθήσεται ψυχρόν. εἰ δ’ ἐξ ἑκατέρας τῆς ἀντιθέσεως ἐπικρατοίη θάτερον ἤτοι θερμὸν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὸν ἢ θερμὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν ὀνομασθήσεται τὸ σῶμα κατὰ τὸ ἐπικρατοῦν. ταύτας μὲν οὖν τὰς τέτταρας δυσκρασίας
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

no longer well-tempered. Now if it should be more hot than cold, it will be called by whichever is more; and likewise both dry and moist; and in the same way even if it should be more cold, it will be named cold. But if from each of the oppositions one should prevail—either hot and moist together, or hot and dry together, or cold and moist together, or cold and dry together—the body will be named according to what prevails. These four dyskrasias [imbalances of temperament], then,
paragraphs.openai_translation: It is no longer well-balanced [eukraton: in proper temperament]. If, then, it is more hot than cold, it will be called by whichever it is more—hot; and likewise with dry and moist. And similarly, if it is more cold, it will be called cold. But if, from each pair of opposites, one should prevail—either hot together with moist, or hot together with dry, or cold together with moist, or cold together with dry—the body will be named according to what predominates. These, then, are the four dyskrasias [imbalanced temperaments].

paragraphs.content: ὡς καὶ πρόσθεν εἴπομεν οἱ πλεῖστοι γινώσκουσιν ἰατροί τε καὶ φιλόσοφοι. τὰς δ’ ἄλλας τέτταρας ἐξ ἡμίσεως τούτων γιγνομένας οὐκ οἶδ’ ὅπως παραλείπουσιν ὥσπερ καὶ τὴν πρώτην ἁπασῶν κρᾶσιν τὴν ἀρίστην.
paragraphs.claude_translation: As we said before, most physicians and philosophers recognize [these]. But the other four [mixtures] that arise from half of these, I do not know how they overlook, just as [they overlook] also the first mixture of all, the best one.
paragraphs.openai_translation: As we said before, the majority recognize this—both physicians and philosophers. But the other four, which come to be from the halves of these [i.e., the intermediate combinations formed by half-portions of the extremes], I do not know how they overlook, just as they also overlook the first mixture of all, the best.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὅτι γε δυνατὸν ἐπικρατοῦντος τοῦ θερμοῦ μηδὲν μᾶλλον ὑγρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν εἶναι τὴν κρᾶσιν ὅσον ἐπὶ ταύτῃ τῇ συζυγίᾳ πρόδηλον μὲν οἶμαι κᾀκ τῶν ἤδη προειρημένων εἶναι. ῥᾷστον δὲ κᾂν εἰ μηδὲν προείρητο συλλογίσασθαι συγχωρησάντων γε ἅπαξ αὐτῶν ἑτέραν μὲν εἶναι κρᾶσιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν ἑτέραν δὲ ξηρὰν καὶ θερμήν. εἰ γὰρ οὐκ ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστι πάντως εἶναι ξηρὰν τὴν θερμὴν ἀλλ’ ἐγχωρεῖ καὶ ὑγρὰν ὑπάρχειν αὐτὴν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation of Paragraph 8.6:

But that it is indeed possible, when the hot predominates, for the mixture to be no more moist than dry, at least with respect to this pairing [of qualities], I think is clear even from what has already been stated. But it would be very easy to deduce this even if nothing had been stated previously, provided that they once agree that one mixture is moist and hot, while another is dry and hot. For if it is not necessary that what is hot must in every case be dry, but it is possible for it to be moist as well—
paragraphs.openai_translation: But that, when the hot predominates, it is possible for the mixture [krasis: the qualitative “blend” or temperament] to be no more moist than dry, so far as this pairing [syzygia: the pair of opposed qualities] is concerned, is, I think, evident also from what has already been said. Yet it is easiest to infer even if nothing had been said beforehand, provided only that they once concede that there is one mixture that is moist and hot, and another that is dry and hot. For if it is not in every case necessary that what is hot be dry, but it is also admissible for it to be moist, then...

paragraphs.content: ἐγχωρήσει δηλονότι καὶ μέσην· ἐγγυτέρω γάρ ἐστιν ἡ μέση τῆς ξηρᾶς κράσεως ἤπερ ἡ ὑγρά. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον ἐστί τις ἑτέρα ψυχρὰ κρᾶσις ἐφ’ ἧς ἐστιν ἰσχυρότερον τὸ ψυχρόν· οὐ μὴν οὔθ’ ὑγρὰν οὔτε ξηρὰν ὑπάρχειν αὐτὴν ἀνάγκη ἀλλ’ ἐγχωρεῖ καὶ μέσην γενέσθαι· πάλιν γὰρ κᾀνταῦθα τὸν αὐτὸν ἐπάξεις λόγον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

It will be possible, clearly, for it to be intermediate as well; for the intermediate is closer to the dry mixture than the moist is. And in the same way there is another cold mixture in which the cold is stronger; however, it is not necessary for it to be either moist or dry, but it is possible for it to become intermediate as well; for again in this case too you will apply the same argument.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Evidently a mean [state] will also be admissible; for the mean is closer to the dry mixture [krâsis: blend/temperament] than the moist is. And in the same way there is another cold mixture in which the cold is stronger; yet it need not be either moist or dry, but may also be a mean, for once again in this case you will apply the same argument.

paragraphs.content: ὥστ’, εἴπερ οὐκ ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστιν ὑγρὰν εἶναι τὴν ψυχρὰν, ἀλλ’ , χωρεῖ καὶ ξηρὰν γενέσθαι, πρόδηλον, ὡς καὶ τὴν μέσην ἐγχωρήσει, ἐγγυτέρω γάρ ἐστιν αὕτη τῆς ὑγρᾶς, ἤπερ ἡ ξηρά.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Therefore, if it is not necessary for the cold to be moist, but it is possible for it to become dry as well, it is clear that the intermediate will also be possible, for this is closer to the moist than the dry is.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So then, if indeed it is not necessary for the cold to be moist, but it also admits of becoming dry, it is evident that it will admit the intermediate [i.e., the mean state] as well; for this is nearer to the moist than the dry is.

paragraphs.content: ὡς οὖν αὗται αἱ δύο δυσκρασίαι κατὰ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν ἐδείχθησαν ἡ μὲν θερμὴ μόνον ἡ δὲ ψυχρά· κατὰ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον ἕτεραι δύο γενήσονται κατὰ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν ἡ μὲν ξηρὰ μόνον ἡ δ’ ὑγρὰ συμμέτρως ἐχόντων πρὸς ἄλληλα τοῦ θερμοῦ καὶ τοῦ ψυχροῦ. πάλιν γὰρ κᾀνταῦθα φήσομεν ὥσπερ οὐκ ἔστιν ἀναγκαῖον ἥ τίς ἐστι ξηρὰ κρᾶσις εὐθὺς ταύτην εἶναι καὶ θερμὴν ἀλλ’ ἐνδέχεται καὶ ψυχρὰν ὑπάρχειν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 8.9:

Therefore, just as these two dyskrasias [imbalances] were shown to exist according to one opposition—the one being hot only, the other cold—in the same way two others will arise according to the other opposition, the one being dry only, the other moist, with the hot and the cold being in moderate relation to one another. For again in this case too we shall say, just as it is not necessary that whatever mixture is dry must immediately also be hot, but it is possible for it to be cold as well—
paragraphs.openai_translation: As, then, these two dyscrasias [imbalances] were shown according to the one opposition—the one solely hot, the other cold—so in the same manner two others will arise according to the other opposition: the one solely dry, the other moist, with hot and cold standing in a proportionate relation to one another. For again here too we shall say, as before, that it is not necessary that whatever krasis [mixture/constitution] is dry should straightaway be hot as well; it can also be cold.

paragraphs.content: οὐκ ἀδύνατον ἔσται καὶ τὸ μήτε ψυχρὰν εἶναί τινα μήτε θερμὴν ἀλλ’ εὔκρατον μὲν κατὰ τοῦτο ξηρὰν δὲ κατὰ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

It will not be impossible for something to be neither cold nor hot but rather well-tempered [eukratos] in this respect, yet dry in the other opposition [of qualities].

---

**Brief notes:**
- [eukratos: literally "well-mixed" or "well-balanced," a technical term in Greek medical and natural philosophical texts referring to a balanced mixture of qualities]
- [the other opposition: referring to the second pair of elemental qualities, wet-dry, as opposed to the hot-cold pair]
paragraphs.openai_translation: It will not be impossible, moreover, for something to be neither cold nor hot, but temperate [well-balanced] in this respect, and dry with regard to the other opposition.

paragraphs.content: ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ τὴν ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον οὔτε θερμὴν, οὔτε ψυχρὰν ὑπάρχειν, ἀλλ’ ἐνδέχεται μέσην ἀμφοῖν εἶναι κατά γε ταύτην τὴν ἀντίθεσιν. εἰ τοίνυν οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον, οὔτε τῇ κατὰ τὸ ψυχρὸν καὶ θερμὸν δυσκρασίᾳ τὴν ἐκ τῆς ἑτέρας ἀντιθέσεως ἕπεσθαι, οὔτ’ ἐκείνῃ τὴν ἐκ ταύτης, ἐνδέχεταί ποτε καὶ τὴν εὔκρατον ὅσον ἐπὶ θερμότητι καὶ ψυχρότητι φύσιν ἤτοι ξηρὰν ἢ ὑγρὰν γενέσθαι, καὶ τὴν ἐν τούτοις πάλιν εὔκρατον ἤτοι θερμὴν ἢ ψυχράν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Likewise, a moist mixture is not necessarily either hot or cold, but it is possible for it to be intermediate between both, at least with respect to this opposition. If, therefore, it is not necessary either for the dyskrasia [imbalance] in respect to cold and hot to accompany the one from the other opposition, nor for that one to accompany the one from this, it is possible sometimes both for a nature that is eukratic [well-balanced] with respect to heat and coldness to become either dry or moist, and for one that is again eukratic in these respects to become either hot or cold.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Likewise, it is not necessary for a moist mixture [krasis: blend/temperament] to be either hot or cold; rather, it may be intermediate between both with respect to this opposition. If, then, it is not necessary that the dyscrasia [imbalance] in terms of cold and hot be accompanied by that arising from the other opposition, nor that that one be accompanied by this one, it is sometimes possible for a nature [physis] that is well-balanced [eukraton] as regards heat and cold to become either dry or moist, and, conversely, for one that is well-balanced in respect to these [i.e., dry and moist] to be either hot or cold.

paragraphs.content: ὥστ’ εἶναι καὶ ταύτας τέτταρας ἑτέρας ἐκείνων δυσκρασίας ὡς οἱ πρόσθεν ἰατροί τε καὶ φιλόσοφοι παρέδοσαν ἡμῖν καὶ μέσας γε ταύτας τετάχθαι τῶν εὐκράτων ἕξεων καὶ τῶν κατ’ ἀμφοτέρας τὰς ἀντιθέσεις δυσκράτων. ἡ μὲν γὰρ ἄκρως εὔκρατος οὐδετέραν ἀντίθεσιν ἔχει πλεονεκτοῦσαν ἡ δ’ ἐξ ὑπεναντίου τῆσδε δύσκρατος ἀμφοτέρας μοχθηράς. ἐν μέσῳ δ’ ἐστὶν ἡ κατὰ μὲν τὴν ἑτέραν εὔκρατος κατὰ δὲ τὴν ἑτέραν δύσκρατος ὑπάρχουσα ἥτις ἐξ ἡμίσεως μὲν εὔκρατος ἐξ ἡμίσεως δὲ δύσκρατος οὖσα
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

So that these too are four other dyskrasias [imbalances] distinct from those previous ones, as the earlier physicians and philosophers handed down to us, and indeed these have been arranged as intermediate between the well-balanced states and those that are dyskratic [imbalanced] in both oppositions. For the perfectly well-balanced state has neither opposition predominating, while the dyskratic state opposite to this has both in a bad condition. In between is that which is well-balanced in one opposition but dyskratic in the other, which, being half well-balanced and half dyskratic,
paragraphs.openai_translation: So that there are also these four other dyscrasias [faulty-mixture states], distinct from those, as the earlier physicians and philosophers handed down to us; and these are placed in the middle between the eukratic dispositions [well-balanced mixtures] and the dyscratic ones with respect to both pairs of opposites [e.g., hot/cold and dry/moist]. For the state that is perfectly eukratic has neither of the opposed qualities predominating, whereas the dyscratic state opposite to this has both in a bad condition. In between is the state which, with respect to the one is eukratic and with respect to the other is dyscratic, being half eukratic and half dyscratic.

paragraphs.content: μέση δεόντως ἂν εἶναι λέγοιτο τῆς ὅλης εὐκράτου τε καὶ δυσκράτου. καὶ εἴπερ ταῦθ’ οὕτως ἔχει ὥσπερ οὖν καὶ ἔχει θαῤῥούντως ἤδη λέγομεν ἐννέα τὰς πάσας εἶναι τῶν κράσεων διαφορὰς εὔκρατον μὲν μίαν οὐκ εὐκράτους δὲ τὰς ὀκτὼ τέτταρας μὲν ἁπλᾶς ὑγρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν καὶ θερμὴν καὶ ψυχρὰν ἄλλας δὲ τέτταρας συνθέτους ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν καὶ ξηρὰν ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν καὶ ψυχρὰν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν καὶ ψυχρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηράν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

It would properly be said to be intermediate between the whole well-tempered and ill-tempered [constitutions]. And if these things are so—as indeed they are, and we now say confidently—there are nine differences of temperaments in all: one well-tempered, and eight not well-tempered, four simple ones—moist and dry and hot and cold—and four other compound ones—moist and hot at the same time, and dry and hot at the same time, and cold and moist at the same time, and cold and dry at the same time.
paragraphs.openai_translation: The mean would properly be said to be that of the whole—of both the well-balanced and the ill-balanced. And if things stand thus—as indeed they do—we may now confidently say that the total number of differences of mixtures [kraseis] is nine: one that is well-balanced [eucratic], and eight that are not well-balanced [dyscratic]—four simple, namely moist, dry, hot, and cold; and four composite, namely moist and hot together, dry and hot together, cold and moist together, and cold and dry together.

paragraphs.content: Ἐν ἑκάστῃ δὲ τῶν εἰρημένων κράσεων τὸ μᾶλλόν τε καὶ τὸ ἦττον πάμπολυ κατά τε τὰς ἁπλᾶς λεγομένας κράσεις ἐπί τε τῆς ὅλης οὐσίας ἤδη δὲ καὶ καθ’ ἕν ὁτιοῦν γένος. εἰ δή τις βούλεται διαγνωστικὸς εἶναι κράσεων ἄρχεσθαι τούτῳ προσήκει τῆς γυμνασίας ἀπὸ τῶν καθ’ ἕκαστον γένος εὐκράτων τε καὶ μέσων φύσεων. ἐκείναις γὰρ τὰς ἄλλας παραβάλλων
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 9.1:

In each of the aforementioned mixtures [kraseis], there is a very great degree of the more and the less, both in the so-called simple mixtures and in the whole substance, and indeed also in any single class whatsoever. If, therefore, someone wishes to be skilled in diagnosing mixtures, it is appropriate for him to begin his training from the well-mixed [eukratoi] and middle natures in each class. For by comparing the others to those,

---

**Notes:**
- *kraseis* (κράσεις): mixtures or blendings, particularly referring to temperaments or constitutions in medical contexts
- *eukratoi* (εὐκράτων): well-balanced or well-tempered mixtures, representing the ideal or moderate state
- The text appears to break off mid-sentence with "παραβάλλων" (comparing)
paragraphs.openai_translation: And in each of the temperaments [kraseis: mixtures/constitutions] just mentioned, the “more” and the “less” vary enormously, both with respect to the so‑called simple temperaments [of the basic qualities, e.g., hot/cold, dry/moist] and with respect to the whole substance [overall constitution], and indeed also in each particular kind whatsoever. If someone wishes to be skilled in diagnosing temperaments, it is proper that he begin his training from the well‑tempered and mean natures [eukratos and meson] in each several kind; for by comparing the others with those—

paragraphs.content: ῥᾳδίως ἐξευρήσει τὸ πλεονάζον ἢ τὸ λεῖπον ἐν ἑκάστῃ. περὶ πρώτων οὖν ῥητέον τῶν ἁπλῶς λεγομένων εὐκράτων τε καὶ δυσκράτων ἅς ἐπὶ πάσης οὐσίας γεννητῆς οὐκ ἐπὶ ζώων μόνον ἢ φυτῶν ἔφαμεν ἐξετάζεσθαι. πάλιν δὲ κᾀνταῦθα τό γε τοσοῦτο χρὴ διαστείλασθαι περὶ ὀνομάτων ὡς θερμὴ κρᾶσις ἄλλη μέν ἐστιν ἐνεργείᾳ δυνάμει δ’ ἄλλη καὶ ὡς δυνάμει ταῦτ’ εἶναι λέγομεν ὅσα μήπω μέν ἐστιν ὃ λέγεται ῥᾷστον δ’ αὐτοῖς γενέσθαι
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

He will easily discover what is excessive or what is deficient in each case. First, then, we must speak about those things called simply well-tempered and ill-tempered, which we said are examined in relation to every generated substance, not only in animals or plants. But again, even here, it is necessary to make at least this much distinction concerning terms: that a hot mixture [krasis] is one thing in actuality but another in potentiality, and that we say those things exist in potentiality which are not yet what they are said to be, but for which it is easiest to become so.
paragraphs.openai_translation: He will easily discover in each case what is in excess or what is lacking. So first we must speak about those that are called simply “well-balanced” and “ill-balanced” [eukratic and dyscratic, i.e., possessing a proper or improper mixture of qualities], which we said are to be examined in every generated substance, not only in animals or plants. Again, even here, we must at least make this distinction in regard to the terms: a “hot mixture” [thermê krasis] is one thing in actuality and another in potentiality; and we say that things are “in potentiality” when they are not yet what they are so called, but it is easiest for them to become so.

paragraphs.content: φυσικήν τινα ἐπιτηδειότητα κεκτημένοις εἰς τὸ γενέσθαι. περὶ πρώτων οὖν διέλθωμεν τῶν ἐνεργείᾳ θερμῶν καὶ ψυχρῶν καὶ ξηρῶν καὶ ὑγρῶν ἀπὸ τῆς συμπάσης οὐσίας ἀρξάμενοι κᾄπειτα μεταβῶμεν ἐπί τε τὰ ζῶα καὶ τὰ φυτά. τελέως γὰρ ἂν οὕτως ἡμῖν ἀπειργασμένον εἴη τὸ προτεθέν. ἐπειδὴ τοίνυν τὸ μέσον ἐν ἅπαντι γένει καὶ μάλιστα κατὰ τὰς συμπάσας οὐσίας ἐκ τῆς τῶν ἄκρων μίξεως γίνεται
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"possessing a certain natural suitability for coming into being. Let us therefore discuss first those things that are actually hot and cold and dry and moist, beginning from all substance in general, and then let us proceed to both animals and plants. For in this way our proposed subject would be completely worked out for us. Since, therefore, the intermediate in every genus, and especially in the case of all substances, comes into being from the mixture of the extremes"
paragraphs.openai_translation: for things that possess a certain natural aptitude for coming-to-be. Let us then first go through the primary items that are in actuality hot, cold, dry, and moist, beginning from the entire substance [the whole] and thereafter pass on to animals and plants. For in this way the aim proposed would be completely worked out for us. Since, then, the mean [meson] in every kind—and especially with respect to entire substances—comes to be from the mixture of the extremes [akra].

paragraphs.content: χρὴ καὶ τὴν νόησιν αὐτοῦ καὶ τὴν διάγνωσιν ἐξ ἐκείνων συνίστασθαι. τὸ μὲν δὴ τῆς νοήσεως ῥᾶστον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"It is necessary that both the conception of it and the diagnosis be established from those things. Now the matter of conception is easiest."

---

Alternative translation:

"One must establish both its understanding and its discernment from those things. The matter of understanding, then, is the easiest."
paragraphs.openai_translation: It is necessary that both its understanding [νόησις: intellectual apprehension] and its discernment [διάγνωσις: discrimination/diagnosis] be constituted from those [considerations]. As for the understanding, at any rate, that is the easier part.

paragraphs.content: ἀπὸ γὰρ τοῦ θερμοτάτου πάντων τῶν εἰς αἴσθησιν ἡκόντων, οἷον ἤτοι πυρὸς, ἤ τινος ὕδατος ἄκρως ζέοντος, ἐπὶ τὸ ψυχρότατον κατελθόντες ἁπάντων ὧν ἴσμεν, οἶον κρύσταλλον, ἢ χιόνα, νοήσαντές τι διάστημα, μέσον ἀκριβῶς τοῦτο τέμνομεν. οὕτω γὰρ ἐξευρήσομεν τῇ νοήσει τὸ σύμμετρον, ὅπερ ἑκατέρου τῶν ἄκρων ἴσον ἀπέχει.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 9.5:

For starting from the hottest of all things that come within perception—such as either fire or some water boiling intensely—and descending to the coldest of all things we know, such as ice or snow, having conceived of a certain interval, we divide this precisely in the middle. For in this way we shall discover by thought the moderate [mean], which is equally distant from each of the extremes.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For starting from the hottest of all things that come within perception—such as fire, or water boiling at the utmost—and going down to the coldest of all that we know—such as crystal or snow—having conceived a certain interval, we cut this exactly in the middle. For in this way we shall discover by intellect the symmetron [the well-measured mean], which is equally distant from each of the extremes.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ κατασκευάσαι πως αὐτὸ δυνάμεθα τὸν ἴσον ὄγκον κρυστάλλου μίξαντες ὕδατι ζέοντι. τὸ γὰρ ἐξ ἀμφοῖν κραθὲν ἴσον ἑκατέρου τῶν ἄκρων ἀφέξει τοῦ τε καίοντος καὶ τοῦ ναρκοῦντος διὰ ψύξιν. οὔκουν οὐδὲν ἔτι χαλεπόν ἐστι τοῦ κραθέντος οὕτως ἁψαμένους ἔχειν τὸ μέσον ἁπάσης οὐσίας ἐν τῇ κατὰ τὸ θερμόν τε καὶ ψυχρὸν ἀντιθέσει καὶ μεμνῆσθαι τούτου καὶ κρίνειν ἅπαντα τἄλλα καθάπερ τινὶ κανόνι παραβάλλοντας. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ ξηρὰν γῆν ἢ τέφραν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 9.6:

But we can also somehow construct this very thing by mixing an equal volume of ice with boiling water. For the mixture blended from both will stand at an equal distance from each of the extremes—both from that which burns and from that which numbs through cold. Therefore it is no longer at all difficult, having touched what has been mixed in this way, to possess the middle point of all substance in the opposition between hot and cold, and to remember this and to judge all other things by comparing them as if to some standard. And indeed also dry earth or ash

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end, suggesting this is an incomplete excerpt from a larger work discussing the establishment of a mean or standard point between hot and cold extremes for purposes of measurement or judgment.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But we can also in a way contrive this by mixing an equal volume of crystal [ice] with boiling water. For what is blended from both, being equal to each of the extremes, will be free from both the burning and the numbing, through cooling. Accordingly, once we have in this way touched the mixture, there is no longer anything difficult about possessing the mean of the whole substance with respect to the opposition of hot and cold, and remembering this and judging all other things by comparing them to it as to a kind of rule. And indeed even dry earth or ash—

paragraphs.content: ἤ τι τοιοῦτο ἕτερον ἀκριβῶς αὐχμηρὸν ἀναδεύσας ὕδατι κατὰ τὸν ὄγκον ἴσῳ τὸ μέσον ἐργάσῃ σῶμα τῆς κατὰ τὸν ξηρόν τε καὶ ὑγρὸν ἀντιθέσεως. οὔκουν οὐδὲ ἐνταῦθα χαλεπὸν οὐδὲν ὄψει τε ἅμα καὶ ἁφῇ τὸ τοιοῦτο σῶμα διαγνόντας παραθέσθαι τῇ μνήμῃ καὶ τούτῳ κανόνι τε καὶ κριτηρίῳ χρῆσθαι πρὸς τὴν τῶν ἐλλειπόντων ἢ πλεοναζόντων ὑγρῶν καὶ ξηρῶν διάγνωσιν. ἔστω δὲ δηλονότι τὸ κρινόμενον σῶμα συμμέτρως θερμόν. εἰ γὰρ εἰς ἄκρον ἤτοι θερμότητος ἢ ψύξεως ἄγοιτο
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

or some other such thing, precisely dry, mixing it with water equal in volume, you may produce a body that is the middle point of the opposition between dry and wet. Therefore, neither in this case will you see any difficulty in discerning such a body by both sight and touch at the same time, committing it to memory, and using this as both a standard and criterion for the diagnosis of deficient or excessive wet and dry [qualities]. And let the body being judged be, of course, moderately warm. For if it should be brought to an extreme of either heat or cold
paragraphs.openai_translation: Or, by moistening some other such precisely parched substance with water in an equal volume, you would produce a middle-state body with respect to the opposition of dry and moist [i.e., the mean between dryness and moisture]. Accordingly, here too nothing is difficult: once you have discerned such a body by both sight and touch, lay it up in your memory and use it as a rule and criterion for diagnosing deficiencies or excesses of moist and dry. But let it be understood that the body under judgment is proportionately warm; for if it were brought to the extreme either of heat or of cold—

paragraphs.content: τουτὶ τὸ μέσον ὑγροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ σῶμα φαντασίαν ἐνίοτε παρέξει ψευδῆ καὶ δόξει ποτὲ μὲν ὑγρότερον εἶναι τοῦ συμμέτρου ποτὲ δὲ ξηρότερον. εἰ μὲν γὰρ θερμανθείη πλέον ἢ δεῖ τηκόμενόν τε καὶ ῥέον ὑγροτέρου φαντασίαν ἑαυτοῦ παρέξει. ψυχόμενον δὲ περαιτέρω τοῦ προσήκοντος ἵσταταί τε καὶ πήγνυται καὶ ἀκίνητον γίνεται καὶ σκληρὸν ἁπτομένοις φαίνεται κᾀκ τούτου φαντασίαν προβάλλει ψευδῆ ξηρότητος. εἰ δ’ ὥσπερ ὑγροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ μετέσχεν ἴσον οὕτω καὶ θερμότητός τε καὶ ψύξεως εἴη μέσον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 9.8:

This body, which is intermediate between wet and dry, will sometimes present a false appearance and will at times seem to be wetter than the proper measure and at times drier. For if it should be heated more than necessary, melting and flowing, it will present an appearance of itself as wetter. But when cooled beyond what is appropriate, it stands still and solidifies and becomes immobile and appears hard to those touching it, and from this it projects a false appearance of dryness. But if, just as it partook equally of wet and dry, so too it were intermediate in both heat and cold—

[Note: The sentence appears to break off, suggesting the text continues beyond this excerpt.]
paragraphs.openai_translation: This body that is the mean [meson] between wet and dry will at times present a false appearance [phantasia] and will seem now to be wetter than is proportionate, now drier. For if it is heated more than it should be, melting and flowing, it will present of itself the appearance of something wetter. But when it is cooled beyond what is appropriate, it both sets and congeals, becomes motionless, and seems hard to the touch, and from this it projects a deceptive appearance of dryness. Yet if, just as it partakes equally of the wet and the dry, it were likewise a mean between heat and cold...

paragraphs.content: οὔτε σκληρὸν οὔτε μαλακὸν ἁπτομένῳ φαίνεται τὸ τοιοῦτο σῶμα. τὸ μὲν οὖν ὅλα δι’ ὅλων αὐτὰ κεράσαι τὸ θερμὸν λέγω καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν καὶ τὸ ξηρὸν καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν ἀδύνατον ἀνθρώπῳ. γῆ γὰρ ὑγρῷ φυραθεῖσα μέμικται μὲν ὡς ἄν τῳ δόξειε καὶ οὕτω κέκραται πᾶσα παντὶ παράθεσις μήν ἐστι τὸ τοιοῦτο κατὰ σμικρὰ καὶ οὐ δι’ ὅλων κρᾶσις ἀλλὰ τὸ δι’ ὅλων ἄμφω κεράσαι θεοῦ καὶ φύσεως ἔργον. ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 9.9:

Such a body appears to one touching it neither hard nor soft. Now then, to blend them completely through and through—I mean the hot and the cold and the dry and the moist—is impossible for a human being. For earth kneaded with moisture is mixed, as it might seem to someone, and in this way it has been blended throughout; yet such a thing is juxtaposition in small particles and not a blending through and through, but to blend both completely through and through is the work of god and nature. And even more—

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence at "ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον" (And even more—), suggesting this is an incomplete excerpt from a larger work discussing the theory of mixture [*krasis*] and the elements.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Neither hard nor soft does such a body seem to the touch. Now, to mix them entirely, through and through—I mean the hot and the cold and the dry and the moist—is impossible for a human being. For earth kneaded with moisture is indeed mingled, as it might appear to someone, and in this way every juxtaposition is a “mixture”; yet such a thing is a mixture “by small parts” [kata smikra: particlewise] and not a mixture “through-and-through” [krasis di’ holōn]. But to blend the opposites through-and-through is the work of god and of nature. And even more so…

paragraphs.content: εἰ τὸ θερμὸν καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν ὅλα δι’ ὅλων ἀλλήλοις κεραννύοιτο. τὸ μέντοι παράθεσιν ἐργάσασθαι τοιαύτην ὡς ἐκφεύγειν τὴν αἴσθησιν ἕκαστον τῶν ἁπλῶν σωμάτων οὐ φύσεως τοῦτό γε μόνης ἢ θεοῦ τὸ ἔργον ἀλλὰ καὶ ἡμέτερόν ἐστιν. οὐδὲ γὰρ χαλεπὸν ὑγροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ μέσον ἐργάσασθαι πηλὸν ἐκ τῆς τοιαύτης μίξεως· ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ. καί σοι φανεῖται τὸ τοιοῦτο σῶμα καὶ τῇ θερμότητι μὲν καὶ τῇ ψυχρότητι εὔκρατον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

If the hot and the cold were to be mixed with each other completely throughout their whole substance. However, to produce such a juxtaposition that each of the simple bodies escapes perception is not the work of nature alone or of god, but is also ours. For it is not difficult to produce mud, a mean between wet and dry, from such a mixture; and likewise also [a mean] between hot and cold. And such a body will appear to you to be well-tempered [eucraton] both in heat and in coldness
paragraphs.openai_translation: If the hot and the cold were mixed with one another wholly through and through. However, to produce such a juxtaposition [paráthesis: side-by-side combination] as to make each of the simple bodies [i.e., the elements] escape perception is not the work of nature alone or of god, but also ours. For it is not difficult to produce, from such a mixture, a middle between the moist and the dry—namely clay; and likewise between the hot and the cold. And such a body will appear to you well-balanced [eûkraton: in a good mixture] with respect to both its heat and its cold.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ σκληρότητός τε καὶ μαλακότητος ἐν τῷ μέσῳ. τοιοῦτο δ’ ἐστὶ καὶ τὸ τῶν ἀνθρώπων δέρμα μέσον ἀκριβῶς ἁπάντων τῶν ἐσχάτων θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ σκληροῦ καὶ μαλακοῦ καὶ τούτου μάλιστα τὸ κατὰ τὴν χεῖρα. γνώμων γὰρ αὕτη πάντων ἔμελλεν ἔσεσθαι τῶν αἰσθητῶν ὄργανον ἁπτικὸν ὑπὸ τῆς φύσεως ἀπεργασθεῖσα τῷ φρονιμωτάτῳ τῶν ζώων οἰκεῖον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But also in the middle between hardness and softness. Such too is the skin of human beings, precisely in the middle of all the extremes—of hot and cold, and of hard and soft—and especially that which is on the hand. For this was destined to be the judge of all sensible things, having been fashioned by nature as an organ of touch suitable for the most intelligent of living creatures.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And also with respect to hardness and softness it is in the mean [the middle between extremes]. Such, too, is the skin of human beings—precisely in the middle of all the extremes of hot and cold, and of hard and soft—and this is especially true of that on the hand. For this was to be the judge [gnomon: standard/measure] of all the perceptibles [objects of sense], a tactile organ fashioned by nature as proper to the most intelligent of animals.

paragraphs.content: ἴσον οὖν ἀπέχειν αὐτὴν ἐχρῆν ἁπάντων τῶν ἄκρων, θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ, καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ. καὶ δὴ καὶ γέγονεν ἐκ τῆς τούτων ἁπάντων ἰσομοιρίας, οὐ μιχθέντων μόνον, ἀλλὰ καὶ δι’ ὅλων ἀλλήλοις κερασθέντων, ὅπερ οὐκ ἔτ’ οὐδεὶς ἡμῶν ἐργάσασθαι δυνατός ἐστιν, ἀλλὰ φύσεως τὸ ἔργον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Therefore it was necessary for it to be equally distant from all the extremes—hot and cold, and dry and moist. And indeed it has come into being from an equal proportion of all these, not merely mixed together, but also thoroughly blended with one another throughout, which none of us is any longer capable of accomplishing, but is the work of nature.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, it had to be at an equal remove from all the extremes—hot and cold, and dry and wet. And indeed it came to be from an equal share of all these, not merely mixed, but blended through and through with one another—a thing that none of us is any longer able to accomplish, but is the work of nature. [“extremes” = the four primary qualities; “equal share” = isomoiria, an equal proportion; “blended through and through” implies complete interpenetration, not a mere juxtaposition]

paragraphs.content: ὅσα μὲν οὖν σκληρότερα τοῦ δέρματός ἐστι μόρια καθάπερ ὀστᾶ καὶ χόνδροι καὶ κέρατα καὶ τρίχες ὄνυχές τε καὶ σύνδεσμοι καὶ ὁπλαὶ καὶ πλῆκτρα πλέον ἐν τούτοις ἐστὶ τὸ ξηρόν· ὅσα δὲ μαλακώτερα καθάπερ αἷμα καὶ φλέγμα καὶ πιμελὴ καὶ στέαρ καὶ μυελὸς ἐγκέφαλός τε καὶ νωτιαῖος ὑγροῦ πλέον ἐν τούτοις ἐστὶν ἢ ξηροῦ. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ ὅσῳ τὸ πάντων ξηρότατον ἐν ἀνθρώπῳ μόριον ὑπερβάλλει ξηρότητι τοῦ δέρματος
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Therefore, all those parts that are harder than the skin, such as bones and cartilages and horns and hairs and nails and ligaments and hooves and spurs—in these the dry element predominates; but all those that are softer, such as blood and phlegm and fat and suet and marrow and brain and spinal cord—in these there is more of the moist than the dry. And indeed, the driest of all parts in a human being surpasses the skin in dryness
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, all the parts that are harder than the skin—such as bones and cartilages, and horns, and hairs and nails, and ligaments, and armors [protective plates/shells], and striking-instruments [spurs/stings]—contain more of the dry. But the parts that are softer—such as blood and phlegm, and fat [subcutaneous fat] and suet [hard fat/tallow], and marrow, and the brain and spinal marrow—contain more of the moist than of the dry. And indeed, by just so much as the driest part in a human being surpasses the skin in dryness...

paragraphs.content: τοσούτῳ πάλιν ἀπολείπεται τὸ ὑγρότατον. ἔοικε δέ πως ὁ λόγος ἤδη τῶν χρησιμωτάτων αὐτῶν ἐφάπτεσθαι καὶ διδάσκειν ἅμα μὲν ὡς οὐχὶ ζώων μόνον ἀλλὰ καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ἁπάντων σωμάτων εὐκρατότατός ἐστιν ὁ ἄνθρωπος ἅμα δ’ ὡς τῶν ἐν αὐτῷ μορίων τὸ τῆς χειρὸς δέρμα τὸ ἔσωθεν ἁπάσας ἐκπέφευγεν ἀκριβῶς τὰς ὑπερβολάς. ἐπιστήσαντες οὖν πάλιν ἐνταῦθα τὸν λόγον ἐπισκεψώμεθα τίς ἄριστα πάντων κέκραται ἄνθρωπος ὃν καὶ τῆς ὅλης μὲν οὐσίας
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 9.14:

By so much again does the most moist fall short. And somehow the argument now seems to be touching upon the most useful matters themselves and teaching at once both that man is the most well-tempered not only of living creatures but also of all other bodies whatsoever, and at the same time that of the parts within him, the skin of the hand on the inside has precisely escaped all excesses. Therefore, pausing the argument again at this point, let us examine which human being is best tempered of all, whom indeed of his whole substance...

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence at "ὃν καὶ τῆς ὅλης μὲν οὐσίας"]
paragraphs.openai_translation: By so much, again, the very moist [i.e., the extreme of moisture] falls short. And the account now seems somehow to be touching upon their most useful points and at the same time to be teaching, first, that the human being is the most well-balanced in temperament [eukratotatos] not only of animals but also of all other bodies, and, second, that among the parts within him, the inner skin of the hand has precisely escaped all the excesses. Let us then, bringing our discussion to a halt here again, examine which human being is mixed best of all [i.e., composed in the best proportion], whom also, with respect to his whole constitution [overall substance]—

paragraphs.content: ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον ἀνθρώπων καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ζώων ἐν τῷ μέσῳ χρὴ τάξαντας καθάπερ τινὰ κανόνα καὶ γνώμονα τοὺς ἄλλους ἅπαντας τούτῳ παραβάλλοντας θερμοὺς καὶ ψυχροὺς καὶ ξηροὺς καὶ ὑγροὺς ὀνομάζειν. δεῖ δὲ συνδραμεῖν ἐς ταὐτὸν ἐπὶ τοῦδε πολλὰ γνωρίσματα. καὶ γὰρ ὡς πρὸς τὴν ὅλην οὐσίαν ἐξετάζοντι μέσον φαίνεσθαι χρὴ τὸν τοιοῦτον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 9.15:

Furthermore, it is even more necessary to position humans and other animals in the middle, as it were, like a standard and measuring rod, and by comparing all the others to this, to call them hot and cold and dry and wet. Many distinguishing marks must converge together in the case of this [standard]. For indeed, when one examines it in relation to its whole substance, such a thing must appear to be in the middle.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And further, one ought to set human beings and the other animals in the middle [the mean], as a kind of rule and gnomon [measuring standard], and by comparing all the rest to this, to designate them as hot, cold, dry, or moist. Many marks [signs/criteria] must converge upon the same point for this purpose. For to one who examines with respect to the whole ousia [overall constitution/nature], such a thing must appear to be in the mean.

paragraphs.content: ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον ὡς πρὸς ἀνθρώπους τε καὶ ζῶα. τὰ μὲν οὖν ἁπάσης τῆς οὐσίας γνωρίσματα κοινὰ προείρηται· τὰ δ’ ὡς ἐν ζώων εἴδεσιν ἐνεργείας τελειότητι κρίνεται τῆς ἑκάστῳ πρεπούσης. πρέπει δ’ ἀνθρώπῳ μὲν εἶναι σοφωτάτῳ κυνὶ δὲ πρᾳοτάτῳ τε ἅμα καὶ ἀλκιμωτάτῳ λέοντι δὲ ἀλκιμωτάτῳ μόνον ὥσπερ γε καὶ προβάτῳ πρᾳοτάτω. καὶ μέν με καὶ ὡς τὰς τοῦ σώματος ἐνεργείας οἰκείας εἶναι χρὴ τῷ τῆς ψυχῆς ἤθει
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 9.16:

And even more so in relation to humans and animals. Now then, the characteristics common to all substance have been stated previously; but as regards the species of animals, [excellence] is judged by the perfection of the activity appropriate to each one. It is appropriate for a human to be most wise, for a dog to be both most gentle and most courageous, for a lion to be most courageous only, just as indeed for a sheep to be most gentle. And moreover, the activities of the body must be proper to the character of the soul.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Further, and more specifically, with reference to human beings and animals. The common marks of the whole substance [ousia: essence/substance] have already been stated; but those that, as found in the kinds of animals, are judged by the perfection of activity [energeia: actualized function] appropriate to each. It befits a human being to be most wise, a dog to be at once most gentle and most courageous, a lion to be only most courageous, just as, indeed, a sheep to be most gentle. And indeed, too, the activities of the body ought to be appropriate to the character [ēthos: disposition] of the soul.

paragraphs.content: δέδεικται μὲν καὶ πρὸς Ἀριστοτέλους ἐν τοῖς περὶ ζώων μορίων· λέλεκται δὲ καὶ πρὸς ἡμῶν ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν οὐδὲν ἦττον. ἡ μὲν δὴ μέθοδος ἥδε. τὸ δ’ ἀσκῆσαι γνωρίζειν ἑτοίμως ἐν ἑκάστῳ γένει ζώου καὶ κατὰ τὰ σύμπαντα τὸ μέσον οὐ τοῦ τυχόντος ἀνδρὸς ἀλλ’ ἐσχάτως ἐστὶ φιλοπόνου καὶ διὰ μακρᾶς ἐμπειρίας καὶ πολλῆς γνώσεως ἁπάντων τῶν κατὰ μέρος ἐξευρίσκειν δυναμένου τὸ μέσον. οὕτω γοῦν καὶ πλάσται καὶ γραφεῖς
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 9.17:

This has been demonstrated both by Aristotle in his works on the parts of animals; and it has been discussed by us concerning these matters no less thoroughly. This, then, is the method. But to train oneself to recognize readily in each kind of animal and in all things collectively what is the mean [or "the middle/moderate"] is not the work of just any man, but of one who is extremely industrious and capable of discovering the mean through long experience and extensive knowledge of all the particulars. Thus indeed both sculptors and painters

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end, suggesting this is part of a longer passage. The term "τὸ μέσον" (to meson) refers to "the mean" or "the middle/moderate state," a concept important in Greek philosophy and medicine for understanding proper proportion and balance.
paragraphs.openai_translation: It has been shown also by Aristotle in the Parts of Animals; and it has been stated by us on their behalf no less. The method, then, is this. To be trained to recognize readily, in each kind of animal and in general, the mean [to meson: the typical or middle form], is not the task of just any man, but belongs supremely to one who is exceedingly industrious and, through long experience and much knowledge of all the particulars, is able to discover the mean. Thus, at any rate, sculptors and painters…

paragraphs.content: ἀνδριαντοποιοί τε καὶ ὅλως ἀγαλματοποιοὶ τὰ κάλλιστα γράφουσί τε καὶ πλάττουσι καθ’ ἕκαστον εἶδος οἶον ἄνθρωπον εὐμορφότατον ἢ ἵππον ἢ βοῦν ἢ λέοντα τὸ μέσον ἐν ἐκείνῳ τῷ γένει σκοποῦντες. καί πού τις ἀνδριὰς ἐπαινεῖται Πολυκλείτου κανὼν ὀνομαζόμενος ἐκ τοῦ πάντων τῶν μορίων ἀκριβῆ τὴν πρὸς ἄλληλα συμμετρίαν ἔχειν ὀνόματος τοιούτου τυχών. ἔστι μὲν οὖν ἐπιπλέον ὃν νῦν ἡμεῖς ἐζητοῦμεν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 9.18:

Statue-makers and sculptors in general paint and model the most beautiful forms according to each type—for example, the most well-proportioned human being or horse or ox or lion—aiming at the mean within that particular class. And indeed a certain statue by Polyclitus is praised, called the Canon [literally "rule" or "standard"], having received such a name from the fact that all its parts have precise symmetry [proportional relationship] with one another. Therefore, what we have been seeking is something beyond this.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Statue-makers and, in general, makers of images produce and model the most beautiful examples in each species—for instance, the most well-formed human being, or horse, or ox, or lion—by looking to the mean within that kind. And there is, somewhere, a certain statue that is praised, called the Canon of Polycleitus [the “Canon”: a standard of proportion], which has obtained such a name from the fact that it possesses the precise symmetry [symmetria: proportional commensurability] of all the parts in relation to one another. There is, then, in addition, the very thing we were just now seeking.

paragraphs.content: ἢ ὁ κανὼν οὗτος. οὐ μόνον γὰρ ὑγρότητός τε καὶ ξηρότητος ἐν τῷ μέσῳ καθέστηκεν ὁ οὕτως εὔσαρκος ἄνθρωπος ἀλλὰ καὶ διαπλάσεως ἀρίστης τετύχηκεν ἴσως μὲν ἑπομένης τῇ τῶν τεσσάρων στοιχείων εὐκρασίᾳ τάχα δέ τινα θειοτέραν ἀρχὴν ἑτέραν ἐχούσης ἄνωθεν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Or this is the standard. For a person who is well-fleshed in this way stands not only in the middle between moisture and dryness, but has also obtained the best formation, perhaps following upon the good mixture of the four elements, but perhaps having some other more divine principle from above.

[Note: "well-fleshed" (εὔσαρκος) refers to having good, healthy flesh in proper proportion; "good mixture" (εὐκρασία) is the technical term for proper balance of bodily humors or elements; "the four elements" refers to earth, water, air, and fire in ancient Greek natural philosophy]
paragraphs.openai_translation: Or let this be the rule. For the well-fleshed man is set in the middle not only with respect to moisture and dryness, but has also obtained the best formation—perhaps as following upon the well-tempered mixture [eukrasia: balanced blending] of the four elements, or else as having from above some other, more divine principle.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ τό γε πάντως εὔκρατον εἶναι τὸν τοιοῦτον ἐξ ἀνάγκης ὑπάρχει· τὸ γὰρ ἐν εὐσαρκίᾳ σύμμετρον εὐκρασίας ἐστὶν ἔγγονον. εὐθὺς δ’ ὑπάρχει τῷ τοιούτῳ σώματι καὶ ταῖς ἐνεργείαις ἄριστα διακεῖσθαι καὶ σκληρότητός τε καὶ μαλακότητος ἔχειν μετρίως θερμότητός τε καὶ ψυχρότητος· καὶ ταῦθ’ ὑπάρχειν ἅπαντα τῷ δέρματι καὶ τούτῳ μάλιστα τῷ τῆς χειρὸς ἐντὸς ὅταν μηδένα τύλον ἔχῃ τοιοῦτον οἷον τοῖς ἐρέττουσί τε καὶ σκάπτουσι γίνεται. διττῆς γὰρ ἕνεκα χρείας τῶν χειρῶν γεγενημένων
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 9.20:

But at any rate, it is necessarily the case that such a person is well-tempered [eukratos]; for the moderate condition in good flesh is the offspring of good temperament [eukrasia]. And immediately such a body possesses the best disposition for its functions, and has a moderate degree of both hardness and softness, and of both heat and cold; and all these qualities belong to the skin, and especially to the inner part of the hand, whenever it does not have such a callus as develops in those who row and dig. For since the hands have come into being for a twofold use—

---

**Notes:**
- [eukratos/eukrasia]: terms referring to good mixture or balance of bodily humors/qualities
- The text breaks off mid-sentence at the end, suggesting continuation in the next paragraph
paragraphs.openai_translation: But that such a person is in every way well-balanced [in humoral mixture: eukrasia] follows of necessity; for the proportionate condition in good fleshiness [eusarkia] is the offspring of eukrasia. And straightaway it belongs to such a body both to be in the best condition for its functions and to possess a measured degree of hardness and softness and of heat and cold. And all these qualities pertain to the skin—and especially to the inner part of the hand—whenever it has no callus such as arises in those who row and those who dig. For since the hands have come to be for a twofold use...

paragraphs.content: ἁφῆς καὶ ἀντιλήψεως αἱ μαλακαὶ μὲν εἰς τὴν τῆς ἁφῆς ἀκρίβειαν αἱ σκληραὶ δὲ εἰς τὴν τῆς ἀντιλήψεως ἰσχὺν ἐπιτηδειότεραι. καὶ δὴ καὶ τὸ δέρμα τὸ μέσον οὐ μόνον ἁπάντων ἀνθρωπίνων μορίων ἀλλὰ καὶ τῆς ὅλης οὐσίας καὶ πάντων τῶν ἐν γενέσει καὶ φθορᾷ σωμάτων οὐ τὸ τετυλωμένον ἐστὶ καὶ σκληρὸν καὶ λιθῶδες ἀλλὰ τὸ κατὰ φύσιν ἔχον ᾧ δὴ καὶ μάλιστά φαμεν ἀκριβοῦσθαι τὴν ἁφήν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Of touch and grasping, soft [hands] are more suitable for the precision of touch, while hard ones are more suitable for the strength of grasping. And indeed the skin that is intermediate—not only of all human parts but also of the entire substance and all bodies subject to generation and corruption—is not that which is calloused and hard and stone-like, but that which is in its natural state, by which we say that touch is most precisely exercised.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Soft [parts] are better suited to the precision of touch [haphē], whereas hard [parts] are better suited to the strength of grasp [antilēpsis, prehension]. And indeed the skin, in its mean condition, not only among all the parts of a human being but in regard to the whole substance and to all bodies subject to coming-to-be and decay, is not that which is calloused, hard, and stony, but that which is in its natural state—in which, as we say, touch is most exact.

paragraphs.content: ὅτι μὲν οὖν σκληρότητός τε καὶ μαλακότητος ἐν τῷ μέσῳ καθέστηκεν ἁπάντων μορίων, ἱκανῶς ἐναργές· ὅτι δὲ καὶ θερμότητος καὶ ψυχρότητος, ἐκ τῆς οὐσίας ἂν αὐτοῦ μάλιστα καταμάθοις. ἔστι γὰρ οἷον ἔναιμόν τι νεῦρον, ἀκριβῶς μέσον ὑπάρχον νεύρου τε καὶ σαρκὸς, ὡς εἰ καὶ κραθέντων ἀμφοῖν ἐγένετο.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

That it [the arterial vessel] stands in the middle between hardness and softness of all parts is sufficiently clear; but that it also stands between heat and cold, you would best understand from its substance itself. For it is like a certain blood-containing sinew, being precisely intermediate between sinew and flesh, as if it had come to be from a mixture of both.
paragraphs.openai_translation: That, then, it stands midway between hardness and softness among all the parts is sufficiently evident; and that it does so also in respect of heat and cold, you would most clearly learn from its substance. For it is, as it were, a blood-bearing sinew [neuron: tendon/nerve], precisely occupying a middle position between tendon and flesh, as though it had come into being from a mixture of the two.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ νεῦρον μὲν ἅπαν ἄναιμόν τε καὶ ψυχρόν· σὰρξ δὲ πολύαιμός τε καὶ θερμή· μέσον δ’ ἀμφοῖν τὸ δέρμα μήτ’ ἄναιμον τὸ πάμπαν ὡς νεῦρον ἀλλὰ μηδὲ πολύαιμον ὡς ἡ σὰρξ γενόμενον. εἰ δὴ τοῦτο κανόνα τε καὶ οἷον κριτήριον ἁπάντων τῶν τοῦ ζώου μορίων προστησάμενος ἐξετάζεις τε καὶ παραβάλλεις αὐτῷ τἄλλα
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But every sinew is both bloodless and cold; flesh, on the other hand, is both rich in blood and warm; and skin is intermediate between both, being neither completely bloodless like sinew, nor rich in blood like flesh. If therefore you establish this as a standard and as it were a criterion of all the parts of the animal, and you examine and compare the other parts to it
paragraphs.openai_translation: But every neûron [sinew/nerve/tendon] is bloodless and cold, whereas flesh is very full of blood and warm; and the skin is intermediate between the two, being neither utterly bloodless like the neûron nor yet very full of blood like the flesh. If, then, taking this as a rule and, as it were, a criterion for all the parts of the living creature, you proceed to examine and compare the others with it…

paragraphs.content: τὰς ὀκτὼ διαφορὰς εὑρήσεις τῆς δυσκρασίας ἐν αὐτοῖς. καὶ δὴ καὶ κατὰ μέρος δίειμί σοι περὶ πάντων ἑξῆς. φλέγμα μὲν οὖν ὑγρότατόν ἐστι καὶ ψυχρότατον αἷμα δὲ θερμότατον ἀλλ’ οὐχ οὕτως ὑγρὸν ὡς τὸ φλέγμα. θρὶξ δὲ ξηροτάτη τε καὶ ψυχροτάτη· ἧττον δὲ αὐτῆς ὀστοῦν ψυχρόν ἐστι καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ τοῦδε χόνδρος ἧττον ξηρός. ἐφεξῆς δὲ χόνδρῳ σύνδεσμος καὶ ὃν χονδροσύνδεσμον ὀνομάζουσιν ἔπειτα τένων εἶθ’ ὑμὴν καὶ ἀρτηρία καὶ φλὲψ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

You will find the eight differences of dyscrasia [imbalance of qualities] in them. And indeed I shall go through all of them for you in order, part by part. Phlegm, then, is most moist and most cold, while blood is most hot but not as moist as phlegm. Hair is most dry and most cold; but bone is less cold and dry than it. And cartilage is less dry than this. Next after cartilage comes ligament and what they call chondroligament [cartilaginous ligament], then tendon, then membrane and artery and vein.
paragraphs.openai_translation: You will find the eight varieties of dyscrasia among these. Indeed, I will also go through each of them for you in order. Phlegm is the most moist and the coldest; blood is the hottest, but not as moist as phlegm. Hair is the driest and the coldest; less so than it, bone is cold and dry, and less dry than bone is cartilage. Next after cartilage comes the ligament, and what they call the chondrosyndesmos [a cartilaginous ligament]; then the tendon, and after that the membrane [hymen], and the artery and the vein.

paragraphs.content: αὐτὰ δηλονότι τὰ σώματα τῶν ἀγγείων εἶθ’ ὅσα νεῦρα σκληρά. τὰ δὲ μαλακὰ νεῦρα κατὰ τὴν τοῦ δέρματος ὑπάρχει φύσιν ἐν τῇ καθ’ ὑγρότητά τε καὶ ξηρότητα μεσότητι. κατὰ γὰρ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν οὐκ ἔτι μέσον θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ τὸ νεῦρον μαλακὸν ἀλλὰ τοσοῦτον ἀπολείπεται θερμότητος ὅσον καὶ αἵματος. οὕτω δὲ καὶ τἄλλα σύμπαντα τὰ πρόσθεν εἰρημένα τοσούτῳ ψυχρότερα δέρματος ὅσῳ καὶ ἀναιμότερα. καὶ οἵ γε χιτῶνες αὐτοὶ τῶν ἐναιμοτάτων ἀγγείων ἀρτηρίας λέγω καὶ φλεβὸς
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Obviously the bodies of the vessels themselves, and then all the hard sinews. But the soft sinews exist according to the nature of skin in the middle state between moisture and dryness. For according to the other opposition, the soft sinew is no longer intermediate between hot and cold, but falls short of heat by as much as it also falls short of blood. And in the same way all the other parts mentioned previously are colder than skin by as much as they are more bloodless. And indeed the coats themselves of the most blood-filled vessels—I mean the artery and the vein—
paragraphs.openai_translation: Plainly, the very bodies of the vessels, and then all the sinews that are hard. But the soft sinews [νεῦρα: sinews/tendons] partake of the nature of the skin, occupying a mean with respect to moisture and dryness. For with regard to the other opposition [i.e., hot vs. cold], the soft sinew is no longer a mean between hot and cold, but falls short of heat by as much as it does of blood. And thus all the other parts previously mentioned are colder than the skin by precisely the degree to which they are also more bloodless. And even the very coats [χιτῶνες: coats/membranes] of the most blood-filled vessels—I mean the artery and the vein—

paragraphs.content: ἄναιμοί τέ εἰσι καὶ ψυχροὶ τῇ φύσει· τῇ γειτνιάσει δὲ τοῦ αἵματος θερμαίνονται καὶ εἰς μέσην ἀφικνοῦνται κατάστασιν κράσεως. τὸ δὲ αἷμα πάλιν αὐτὸ παρὰ τῆς καρδίας ἔχει τὴν θερμασίαν. φύσει γὰρ ἐκεῖνο τὸ σπλάγχνον ἁπάντων ἐστὶ τῶν τοῦ ζώου μορίων ἐναιμότατόν τε ἅμα καὶ θερμότατον· ἐφεξῆς δ’ αὐτῷ τὸ ἧπαρ.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

They are bloodless and cold by nature; but by proximity to the blood they are warmed and arrive at a middle state of mixture. The blood itself, in turn, has its heat from the heart. For that organ is by nature the most full of blood and at the same time the hottest of all the parts of the animal; and next to it is the liver.
paragraphs.openai_translation: They are bloodless and cold by nature; yet by their proximity to the blood they are warmed and attain a middling condition of mixture [krâsis, “temperament”]. The blood, in turn, derives its heating from the heart. For by nature that organ [the heart] is, of all the animal’s parts, at once the most full of blood and the hottest; next to it is the liver.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἡ μὲν καρδία βραχὺ δέρματος ἀποδεῖ σκληρότητι τὸ δ’ ἧπαρ πολύ. καὶ τοίνυν ὑγροτέρα τοσούτῳ δέρματός ἐστιν ὅσῳ μαλακωτέρα. καὶ μὴν δὴ καὶ σὰρξ ὑγροτέρα δέρματος· ἀλλ’ αὕτη μὲν καὶ θερμοτέρα. νωτιαῖος δὲ ὑγρότερος μὲν ἀλλὰ καὶ ψυχρότερος· καὶ τοῦδε μᾶλλον ἐγκέφαλος υγρότερος ἔτι δὲ τούτου μᾶλλον πιμελή καὶ ἡ πῆξις αὐτῆς διὰ τὴν τῶν ὑμένων γειτνίασιν· ἐλαίῳ γὰρ ἔοικε παχεῖ καὶ διὰ τοῦτο πήγνυται
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 9.27:

But the heart falls short of skin in hardness by only a little, whereas the liver falls short by much. And indeed, it is moister than skin by as much as it is softer. And moreover, flesh is moister than skin; but this [flesh] is also warmer. The spinal marrow is moister but also colder; and more than this, the brain is moister, and still more than this is fat, and its solidification [occurs] because of the proximity of the membranes; for it resembles thick oil and because of this it solidifies.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But the heart falls short of the skin in hardness by a little, while the liver by much. And accordingly, it is wetter than the skin in just the degree that it is softer. And indeed flesh is wetter than skin—and this [flesh] is also hotter. The spinal marrow is wetter, but also colder; and the brain is wetter still than this; and fat [suet] even more than that. As for its setting [coagulation], this is due to the nearness of the membranes [meninges], for it [the brain] resembles thick oil, and for this reason it congeals.

paragraphs.content: ψυχροῖς καὶ ἀναίμοις ὁμιλοῦσα μορίοις. οὔτε δ’ ἥπατι περιπήγνυσθαι πιμελὴν οὔτ’ ἀρτηρίαις καὶ φλεψὶν οὔτε καρδίᾳ δυνατὸν ἀλλ’ οὐδ’ ἄλλῳ τινὶ θερμῷ πάνυ μορίῳ. διότι δὲ πέπηγε πάνυ ψυχρῷ διὰ τοῦτο χεῖται θερμαινομένη τοῖς ἄλλοις ὁμοίως πεπηγόσιν. οὐ μὴν ἐγκέφαλός γε θερμαινόμενος χεῖται καὶ διὰ τοῦτο ἦττον ὑγρός ἐστι πιμελῆς. ἧττον δ’ ὑγρὰ πιμελῆς ἐστι καὶ ἡ τοῦ πνεύμονος σὰρξ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 9.28:

when it associates with cold and bloodless parts. Nor is it possible for fat to solidify around the liver, nor around the arteries and veins, nor around the heart, nor indeed around any other very hot part. But because it has solidified when very cold, for this reason it melts when heated, just like other solidified substances. However, the brain does not melt when heated, and for this reason it is less moist than fat. And the flesh of the lung is also less moist than fat.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Consorting with parts that are cold and bloodless. And it is not possible for fat [pimelē: suet/fat] to congeal around the liver, or around the arteries and veins, or around the heart, nor indeed around any other very hot part. And because it has congealed about something very cold, for this reason it liquefies when warmed, like other things that have similarly congealed. The brain, however, does not liquefy when heated, and for this reason it is less moist with fat. And the flesh of the lung is also less moist with fat.

paragraphs.content: οὐδὲ γὰρ αὕτη χεῖται θερμαινομένη. πολὺ δ’ ἔτι μᾶλλον ἡ τοῦ σπληνός τε καὶ τῶν νεφρῶν ἧττόν ἐστιν ὑγρὰ πιμελῆς.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For neither does this [fat] melt when heated. But even much more so, the [fat] of the spleen and of the kidneys is less moist than suet [pimele].
paragraphs.openai_translation: For not even this liquefies when heated. And that of the spleen and the kidneys is, to an even greater degree, much less a liquid fat [pimelē = suet-like fat].

paragraphs.content: ἅπαντα μέντοι ταῦτα δέρματός ἐστιν ὑγρότερα. τὰς δὲ τούτων ἀποδείξεις ἐν τῷ μεταξὺ λόγῳ διέξειμι· καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ ὅσα λείπει τῇ συμπάσῃ περὶ κράσεων πραγματείᾳ διὰ τῶν ἐφεξῆς δυοῖν ὑπομνημάτων εἰρήσεται.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

All these things, however, are moister than skin. I shall go through the demonstrations of these matters in the intervening treatise; and indeed whatever remains for the entire work on mixtures [or temperaments] will be discussed in the next two books.
paragraphs.openai_translation: All these things, however, are moister than the skin. The demonstrations of these I shall set out in the intervening discussion; and indeed, whatever is lacking in the entire treatise on Mixtures will be stated in the next two hypomnemata [“memoranda” or short supplementary treatises].

paragraphs.content: ΓΑΛΗΝΟΥ ΠΕΡΙ ΚΡΑΣΕΩΝ ΒΙΒΛΙΟΝ ΔΕΥΤΕΡΟΝ.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Galen, On the Temperaments [Mixtures], Book Two.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
GALEN'S ON MIXTURES, BOOK TWO.

---

**Alternative translation:**

GALEN'S ON TEMPERAMENTS, BOOK TWO.

---

[Note: The Greek word ΚΡΑΣΕΩΝ (kraseon) can be translated as either "mixtures" or "temperaments," referring to Galen's theory of the balance of bodily humors and qualities. "On Temperaments" is the more commonly used English title for this work.]

paragraphs.content: Ὅτι μὲν δὴ τῶν πολλαχῶς λεγομένων ἐστὶν ὑγρόν τε καὶ ξηρὸν σῶμα καὶ θερμὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν ἐν τῷ πρὸ τοῦδε λόγῳ διῄρηται. δέδεικται δὲ ὡς ἐννέα διαφοραὶ τῶν κράσεών εἰσι μία μὲν ἡ σύμμετρός τε καὶ εὔκρατος αἱ λοιπαὶ δὲ πᾶσαι δύσκρατοι τέτταρες μὲν ἁπλαῖ μιᾶς ἐν ἑκάστῃ πλεονεκτούσης ποιότητος ἤτοι θερμότητος ἢ ψυχρότητος ἢ ξηρότητος ἢ ὑγρότητος ἕτεραι δὲ τέτταρες ἐπειδὰν ἐξ ἑκατέρας ἀντιθέσεως ἡ ἑτέρα κρατήσῃ δύναμις. λέγω δ’ ἀντιθέσεις δύο
paragraphs.openai_translation: That “moist” and “dry” as applied to body, and likewise “hot” and “cold,” are among the terms said in many ways has been set out in the preceding discourse. And it has been shown that there are nine differences of mixtures [kraseis]: one is proportionate and well-mixed [eucrasia], while all the others are ill-mixed [dyscrasias]—four simple, in each of which one quality prevails, namely heat or cold or dryness or moisture; and another four arise whenever, in each opposition, the one power prevails. I speak of two oppositions [sc. hot vs. cold, dry vs. moist].
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.1:

Now then, that wet and dry body, and hot and cold, are among the things spoken of in many ways was distinguished in the preceding discussion. And it has been demonstrated that there are nine differences of temperaments [krasis]: one is the well-proportioned and well-tempered [eukratos], while all the rest are ill-tempered [dyskratos]—four are simple, with one quality predominating in each, namely either heat or coldness or dryness or wetness; and four others [arise] whenever one of the two powers prevails from each pair of opposites. And I mean two pairs of opposites—

paragraphs.content: μίαν μὲν τὴν κατὰ τὸ θερμόν τε καὶ ψυχρὸν ἑτέραν δὲ τὴν κατὰ τὸ ξηρόν τε καὶ ὑγρόν. ἐφεξῆς δὲ τούτων ἐπὶ τὰ γνωρίσματα μεταβάντες ὑπὲρ τῆς εὐκράτου φύσεως ἐσκοπούμεθα διότι πρώτη πασῶν ἥδε καὶ ἀρετῇ καὶ δυνάμει καὶ τάξει νοήσεώς ἐστιν. ἐπεὶ δ’ εὔκρατον ἄλλο μὲν ἁπλῶς εὑρίσκεται λεγόμενον ἐν πάσῃ τῇ τῶν ὄντων φύσει
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

one [classification] according to the hot and cold, and another according to the dry and moist. After these matters, proceeding to the distinguishing signs, we examined the well-tempered nature, because this is first of all in excellence, in power, and in order of understanding. But since "well-tempered" is found to be spoken of in one sense absolutely throughout all the nature of existing things,

---

**Brief notes:**
- "εὔκρατον/well-tempered" refers to a balanced mixture of qualities (εὐκρασία), a key concept in ancient Greek medical theory
- The text appears to be discussing classifications of bodily temperaments or qualities, likely from a medical or natural philosophical treatise
paragraphs.openai_translation: One classification is according to the hot and the cold, and another according to the dry and the moist. Next, after these, passing on to the distinguishing marks [gnōrismata: diagnostic signs], we examined the eucratic nature [well-tempered/balanced mixture], because this is first of all in excellence, in power, and in the order of understanding [taxis noēseōs: conceptual priority]. And since “eucratic” is found, on the one hand, to be said simply throughout the whole nature of things…

paragraphs.content: καθ’ ἕκαστον δὲ γένος ἄλλο· περὶ πρώτου δεῖν ἐδόκει σκοπεῖσθαι τοῦ κοινῇ κατὰ πάσης φύσεως ἐξεταζομένου. κανὼν δ’ ἦν αὐτοῦ καὶ κρίσις ἡ τῶν στοιχείων ἰσομοιρία δι’ ἣν καὶ τὸ τῶν ἐσχάτων ἁπάντων ἀκριβῶς μέσον ἀποτελεσθὲν εὔκρατόν τε καὶ σύμμετρον ὀνομάζεται. τὰ δὲ ἄλλα τὰ καθ’ ἕκαστον γένος εὔκρατα ταῖς οἰκείαις τῶν σωμάτων ἐνεργείαις τε καὶ χρείαις κρίνεται. καὶ διὰ τοῦτο ταὐτὸ σῶμα ζώου τινὸς ἢ φυτοῦ μέσον μὲν εἶναι δύναται τῶν ὁμογενῶν ἁπάντων
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.3:

But different according to each kind; it seemed necessary to examine first that which is investigated commonly in relation to all nature. And its standard and criterion was the equal proportion of the elements, through which also what has been made precisely the middle of all extremes is called well-tempered and well-proportioned. But the other things that are well-tempered according to each kind are judged by the proper activities and functions of their bodies. And because of this, the same body of some animal or plant can be the middle of all things of the same kind

---

**Brief contextual notes:**
- [εὔκρατον] "well-tempered" refers to a proper balance or mixture, a key concept in ancient Greek medical and philosophical thought
- [σύμμετρον] "well-proportioned" indicates proper measure or commensurability
- [ἰσομοιρία] "equal proportion" literally means "equal share" or "equal distribution"
paragraphs.openai_translation: And for each particular kind, another [standard applies]; but it seemed necessary first to consider that which is examined in common with respect to every nature. Its rule and criterion was the equal apportionment of the elements [isomoiria of the stoicheia], by which that which has been brought to be precisely the mean of all extremes is called both well-tempered and proportionate [eukratos and symmetros]. The other well-tempered states, those belonging to each particular kind, are judged by the activities and needs proper to the bodies. And for this reason the same body of some animal or plant can be in the middle among all its congeners [homogeneous cases].

paragraphs.content: τοῦτ’ ἔστιν εὔκρατόν τε καὶ σύμμετρον ἐν ἐκείνῳ τῷ γένει δύσκρατον δ’ ἑτέρῳ τινὶ παραβαλλόμενον ἢ φυτῶν ἢ ζώων ἢ ἀψύχων γένει. τὸ μὲν γὰρ τοῦ ζῶντος σῶμα τῷ τοῦ νεκροῦ παραβαλλόμενον ὑγρότερόν ἐστι καὶ θερμότερον. οἷον εἰ τύχοι λέων ζῶν λέοντος τεθνεῶτος ἢ αὐτὸς ἑαυτοῦ τις ἢ ἕτερος ἑτέρου θερμότερός ἐστι καὶ ὑγρότερος. καὶ διὰ τοῦτ’ εἴρηται πρὸς τῶν παλαιῶν ὑγρόν τε εἶναι καὶ θερμὸν τὸ ζῶον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

This is well-tempered and proportionate within that particular class, but ill-tempered when compared to some other class, whether of plants or animals or inanimate things. For the body of a living creature compared to that of a dead one is more moist and hotter. For example, if it should happen that a living lion compared to a dead lion, or one individual compared to himself, or one compared to another, is hotter and more moist. And for this reason it has been said by the ancients that the living creature is moist and hot.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
That is, it is well-tempered and proportionate in that kind, but ill-tempered when set beside some other kind—whether the kind of plants, of animals, or of inanimate things. For the body of a living creature, when compared with that of a dead one, is moister and warmer. For example, if it should happen that a living lion is compared with a dead lion—either the same individual with himself [alive versus dead] or one individual with another—he is warmer and moister. And for this reason it has been said by the ancients that the living creature is moist and warm.

[Notes: “well-tempered” renders εὔκρατον, “ill-tempered” δύσκρατον, terms of mixture/temperament in humoral physiology.]

paragraphs.content: οὐχ ὡς ἢ τῆς ὑγρότητος ἐν αὐτῷ πλεονεκτούσης ἁπλῶς ἢ τῆς θερμότητος. οὕτως μὲν γὰρ εὑρεθήσεται πάμπολλα ζῶα ψυχρὰ καὶ ξηρὰ καθάπερ ἐμπίδες τε καὶ κώνωπες καὶ μυῖαι καὶ μέλιτται καὶ μύρμηκες ἀλλ’ ὡς τοῖς τεθνεῶσι παραβαλλόμενα. καὶ γὰρ μέλιττα ζῶσα τεθνεώσης μελίττης ὑγροτέρα τέ ἐστι καὶ θερμοτέρα καὶ μύρμηξ μύρμηκος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.5:

Not in the sense that either moisture or heat simply predominates in it. For in this way very many animals will be found to be cold and dry, such as gnats and mosquitoes and flies and bees and ants, but rather in the sense of being compared to dead ones.
