For indeed a living bee is both moister and hotter than a dead bee, and an ant than an ant [i.e., a living ant compared to a dead ant].
paragraphs.openai_translation: Not on the grounds that either moisture or heat simply predominates in it. For on that view one would find very many animals to be cold and dry—gnats and mosquitoes and flies and bees and ants—but rather by comparison with the dead. For a living bee is both moister and warmer than a dead bee, and so too an ant than a dead ant.

paragraphs.content: ἀνθρώπῳ μέντοι παραβαλλόμενα, καὶ ἵππῳ, καὶ βοῒ, καὶ τοῖς ἄλλοις ζώοις τοῖς ἐναίμοις, ἅπαντα τὰ τοιαῦτα ψυχρὰ καὶ ξηρὰ τὴν κρᾶσίν ἐστιν. καὶ μὲν δὴ κᾂν εἰ πρὸς τὴν ὅλην οὐσίαν ἀποβλέπων ἐξετάζοις, οὐδ’ οὕτως ἐκπέπτωκε τοῦ ξηρά τε εἶναι ταῦτα καὶ ψυχρά.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.6:

However, when compared to a human being, and to a horse, and to an ox, and to the other blooded animals, all such things are cold and dry in their mixture [krasis]. And indeed, even if you were to examine them with regard to their entire substance, not even in this way have they fallen outside of being both dry and cold.

---

**Brief notes:**
- [krasis]: the mixture or blending of qualities; a technical term in ancient Greek medical and philosophical texts referring to the balance of elemental qualities
- [blooded animals]: animals possessing blood (enaima), a standard Aristotelian classification
paragraphs.openai_translation: Nevertheless, when set beside a human being, and a horse, and an ox, and the other blooded animals, all such things are cold and dry in their mixture [krasis, “temperamental blend”]. And indeed, even if you were to examine them with reference to their whole substance [ousia], not even then would they have departed from being dry and cold.

paragraphs.content: ὥσπερ γὰρ καθ’ ἕκαστον γένος ὅταν ἐξίστηταί τι τῆς μεσότητος ἀπὸ τοῦ πλεονεκτοῦντος ὀνομάζεται κατὰ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον ἐπὶ τῆς συμπάσης οὐσίας ὅταν ὑπερβάλλῃ τι τῷ μέσῳ οὐκέτι εὔκρατον ἀλλ’ ἤτοι ψυχρὸν ἢ ξηρὸν ἢ θερμὸν ἢ ὑγρὸν ὀνομασθήσεται. δέδεικται γὰρ δὴ πρόσθεν ὡς ἄνθρωπός ἐστιν οὐ τῶν ζώων μόνον ἢ φυτῶν ἀλλὰ καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ἁπάντων εὐκρατότατον. ἐπεὶ δὲ ἐκ πολλῶν καὶ διαφερόντων σύγκειται μορίων εὔδηλον ὡς τὸ μέσον ἁπάντων τῇ κράσει
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.7:

For just as in each individual genus, whenever something departs from the mean, it is named according to the predominant element, in the same way with regard to the entire substance, whenever something exceeds the mean, it will no longer be called well-tempered [eukraton] but will be named either cold or dry or hot or moist. For it has been demonstrated previously that man is the most well-tempered not only of animals or plants but also of all other things. But since he is composed of many and different parts, it is clear that the mean of all in mixture

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence. The term *eukraton* refers to a proper balance or tempering of qualities, a key concept in ancient Greek medical theory regarding the mixture of elemental qualities in bodies.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For just as in each particular kind, whenever something departs from the mean, it is named from that which predominates, so too with respect to the entire substance: whenever something exceeds the mean, it will no longer be called well-tempered [eúkraton, well-balanced in mixture], but will be named either cold or dry or hot or moist. For it has already been shown that the human being is the most well-tempered, not only among animals or plants, but among all other things as well. And since he is composed of many and diverse parts, it is evident that the mean of them all in respect of mixture [krâsis, blending of qualities]…

paragraphs.content: τοῦτο καὶ ἁπλῶς ἐστιν εὐκρατότατον. τὸ γὰρ τοῦ μέσου τῇ κράσει ζώου μέσον μόριον ἁπάντων ἐστὶν ἁπλῶς εὐκρατότατον. ἐδείχθη δὲ τοῦτ’ ἐν ἀνθρώπῳ τὸ καλούμενον δέρμα καὶ μάλιστα τοῦ δέρματος τὸ τῶν χειρῶν ἐντὸς ἐὰν οἶον ὑπὸ τῆς φύσεως ἀπεργασθῇ τοιοῦτο φυλάττηται. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ ὡς οὐ παντὸς ἀνθρώπου τὸ δέρμα μέσον ἁπλῶς ἐστιν ἁπάσης οὐσίας ἐλέχθη πρόσθεν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.8:

This is also the most well-tempered in an absolute sense. For the middle part of an animal that is middle in its mixture is the most well-tempered of all things in an absolute sense. It has been shown that this in the case of man is what is called the skin, and especially the inner surface of the skin of the hands, provided that it has been fashioned by nature in such a way and is preserved as such. And indeed it was also stated previously that the skin of not every human being is middle in an absolute sense of every substance.

---

**Notes:**
- εὐκρατότατον [eukretataton]: "most well-tempered" or "most well-balanced" - refers to the optimal balance of qualities or humors in medical/physiological theory
- κράσις [krasis]: "mixture" or "temperament" - a technical term referring to the blending of elemental qualities
- μέσον [meson]: "middle" or "intermediate" - referring to a balanced state between extremes
paragraphs.openai_translation: This, moreover, is in the unqualified sense most well-tempered. For the part that is middle with respect to an animal’s krāsis [mixture/temperament]—the middle part among all—is, simply, the most well-tempered. And this was shown in the human being: the so-called skin, and especially—of the skin—the inside of the hands, provided that, as if fashioned by nature, it is preserved in such a state. And indeed it was said earlier as well that the skin is not, in every human being, simply at the midpoint of the whole ousia [substance].

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὅστις ἂν εὐκρατότατος ᾖ· πολλὴν γὰρ εἶναι καὶ αὐτοῖς τοῖς ἀνθρώποις πρὸς ἀλλήλους τὴν διαφοράν. εὐκρατότατος δ’ ἐστὶν ὃς ἂν τῷ μὲν σώματι φαίνηται μέσος ἀκριβῶς τῶν ἄκρων ἰσχνότητός τε καὶ παχύτητος μαλακότητός τε καὶ σκληρότητος ἔτι δὲ θερμότητός τε καὶ ψυχρότητος. ἔστι γὰρ εὑρεῖν ἁψάμενον ἑκάστου τῶν ἀνθρωπίνων σωμάτων ἢ χρηστὴν καὶ ἀτμώδη θερμασίαν ἢ πυρώδη καὶ δριμεῖαν ἢ τούτων μὲν οὐδετέραν ἐπικρατοῦσαν δέ τινα ψύξιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But rather whoever may be most well-balanced; for there is great difference even among human beings themselves in relation to one another. The most well-balanced person is one who appears in body to be precisely midway between the extremes of thinness and thickness, softness and hardness, and furthermore of heat and coldness. For it is possible to find by touching each of the human bodies either a wholesome and vaporous warmth, or a fiery and sharp one, or neither of these but rather some prevailing coldness.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But rather, whoever is most well-balanced [eukratotatos: possessing the best-balanced bodily mixture/temperament]. For there is great difference even among human beings in relation to one another. And the most well-balanced is the one who, in body, appears precisely in the middle between the extremes of leanness and corpulence, softness and hardness, and further, warmth and cold. For by touching each human body one can discover either a sound and vaporous warmth [a gentle, moist heat], or a fiery and sharp heat, or neither of these predominating, but instead some chill prevailing.

paragraphs.content: ἀκούειν δὲ χρὴ ψύξιν ἐπικρατοῦσαν, ὡς ἐν ζώου σώματι, καὶ ταῦτα ἐναίμου τε καὶ ὑγροῦ ὄντος. τῷ μὲν οὖν δὴ σώματι τοιοῦτος ὁ εὔκρατος ἄνθρωπος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
One must understand "cooling prevailing" as it applies to the body of a living creature, and particularly one that is both blooded and moist. Therefore, such is the well-tempered person with respect to the body.

---

**Alternative translation:**

One must understand that cooling predominates, as in the body of an animal, and moreover one that is both blooded and fluid. Such, then, is the well-balanced [eukratos] person in terms of the body.
paragraphs.openai_translation: One must understand “a predominance of cooling” as it occurs in the body of a living creature, and indeed one that is blooded and moist. With respect to the body, then, such is the well-tempered [eukratic, of balanced temperament] human being.

paragraphs.content: ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ τῇ ψυχῇ μέσος ἀκριβῶς ἐστι θρασύτητός τε καὶ δειλίας μελλησμοῦ τε καὶ προπετείας ἐλέους τε καὶ φθόνου. εἴη δ’ ἂν ὁ τοιοῦτος εὔθυμος φιλόστοργος φιλάνθρωπος συνετός. ἐκ τούτων μὲν ὁ εὐκρατότατος ἄνθρωπος γνωρίζεται πρώτως καὶ μάλιστα. προσέρχεται δ’ αὐτοῖς οὐκ ὀλίγα τῶν ἐξ ἀνάγκης ἑπομένων. καὶ γὰρ ἐσθίει καὶ πίνει σύμμετρα καὶ πέττει καλῶς τὰς τροφὰς οὐκ ἐν γαστρὶ μόνον ἀλλὰ κἀν ταῖς φλεψὶ καὶ καθ’ ὅλην τὴν ἕξιν τοῦ σώματος
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.11:

Likewise also in respect to the soul, he is precisely midway between rashness and cowardice, between hesitation and impetuosity, between pity and envy. Such a person would be cheerful, affectionate, humane, and intelligent. From these qualities the most well-balanced person is recognized primarily and especially. And there accompany these no small number of necessarily consequent attributes. For he both eats and drinks in moderation and digests his food well, not only in the stomach but also in the veins and throughout the entire condition of the body.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Likewise, in the soul there is precisely a mean between rashness and cowardice, between dilatoriness [mellēsmos: undue delay] and precipitancy [propeteia: rash impetuosity], and between pity and envy. Such a person would be cheerful, affectionate, humane, and sensible. From these traits the man of the best temperament [eukrasia: well-balanced mixture] is recognized first and most of all. And in addition to these there come not a few things that follow of necessity. For he eats and drinks in due measure, and he digests [pettei: “cooks” internally] his foods well, not only in the stomach but also in the veins and throughout the entire condition [hexis] of the body.

paragraphs.content: ἁπάσας τε συνελόντι φάναι τάς τε καλουμένας φυσικὰς ἐνεργείας καὶ τὰς ψυχικὰς ἀμέμπτους ἔχει. καὶ γὰρ καὶ ταῖς αἰσθήσεσιν ἄριστα διάκειται καὶ ταῖς τῶν κώλων κινήσεσιν εὔχρους τ’ ἐστὶ καὶ εὔπνους ἀεὶ καὶ μέσος ὑπνώδους τε καὶ ἀγρύπνου καὶ ψιλοῦ τριχῶν καὶ δασέος καὶ μέλανος τὴν χρόαν καὶ λευκοῦ· καὶ τρίχας ἔχει παῖς μὲν ὢν πυῤῥοτέρας μᾶλλον ἢ μελαντέρας ἀκμάζων δ’ ἔμπαλιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.12:

To speak comprehensively, he possesses all the so-called physical functions and the psychic ones without fault. For indeed he is in the best condition with respect to his senses and the movements of his limbs, and he is always of good complexion and breathes well, and he is intermediate between sleepy and wakeful, and between hairless and hairy, and between dark in color and pale; and as a child he has hair that is more reddish than dark, but in his prime the opposite.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And, to sum up, one may say that he has unimpaired both the so‑called natural functions [physikai energeiai: bodily/physiological functions] and the psychic ones [mental faculties]. For he is excellently disposed both in his senses and in the movements of his limbs; he is of good complexion and always easy in breathing, and he is in the mean between drowsy and wakeful, between scant of hair and shaggy, and in complexion between dark and fair. As for his hair, when a child it is rather more reddish than blackish, but in his prime the reverse.

paragraphs.content: Ἐπεὶ δὲ καὶ τῆς κατὰ τὰς ἡλικίας αὐτοῦ διαφορᾶς ἐπεμνήσθημεν, οὐδὲν ἂν εἴη χεῖρον ἤδη τι καὶ περὶ τούτων εἰπεῖν. ἐβουλόμην μὲν οὖν πρότερον ἑκάστου τῶν εἰρημένων γνωρισμάτων ἐπελθεῖν τὰς αἰτίας, ἀλλ’ ἐπεὶ πρὸς τὰ παρόντα μᾶλλον ἡ περὶ τῶν ἡλικιῶν ἐπείγει σκέψις, εὐπορωτάτους τε ἡμᾶς πρὸς τὴν τῶν αἰτιῶν εὕρεσιν ἀπεργάζεται, ταύτην νῦν ἐνστησόμεθα.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Since we have also made mention of the difference in him according to ages, it would be no worse to say something now about these matters as well. Now I would have preferred to go through the causes of each of the characteristics that have been mentioned first, but since the examination concerning ages is more pressing for present purposes and renders us most well-equipped for the discovery of causes, we shall undertake this now.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Since we have also made mention of its differences according to the stages of life, it would be no bad thing now to say something about these as well. I did indeed wish first to go through the causes of each of the aforesaid marks [gnōrismata: diagnostic signs], but since, in view of what lies before us, the inquiry concerning the ages [life stages] presses more urgently and moreover renders us most well supplied for the discovery of the causes, this inquiry we shall now undertake.

paragraphs.content: Νοήσωμεν οὖν ἄρτι διαπλαττόμενον ἐν ταῖς μήτραις τῶν τικτουσῶν τὸ ζῶον, ἵνα γνῶμεν, ὅπως ὑγρότατόν ἐστι καὶ θερμότατον. ἡ μὲν γὰρ πρώτη σύστασις ἐξ αἵματος αὐτῷ καὶ σπέρματος, ὑγρῶν καὶ θερμῶν χρημάτων.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Let us therefore consider the living creature just now being formed in the wombs of those giving birth, so that we may know how it is most moist and most hot. For its first composition is from blood and seed, which are moist and hot substances.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Let us then consider the living creature as it is just now being formed in the wombs of those who give birth, so that we may know how it is at its most moist and most hot. For its first constitution [σύστασις: initial formation/composition] is from blood and seed [σπέρμα: semen], substances [χρήματα: materials] that are moist and warm.

paragraphs.content: ἀεὶ δὲ καὶ μᾶλλον τούτων ξηρῶν γινομένων ὑμένες μὲν πρῶτον διαπλάττονται καὶ χιτῶνες καὶ σπλάγχνα καὶ ἀγγεῖα τελευταῖα δὲ ὀστᾶ καὶ ὄνυχες καὶ χόνδροι πηγνυμένης ἀποτελοῦνται τῆς οὐσίας· πρὶν γὰρ ἤτοι δύνασθαι τείνεσθαι τὴν ὑποβεβλημένην οὐσίαν ἢ πήγνυσθαι τῶν εἰρημένων οὐδὲν ἐγχωρεῖ γενέσθαι. χιτῶνες μὲν οὖν καὶ ὑμένες ἀρτηρίαι τε καὶ νεῦρα καὶ φλέβες τεινομένης αὐτῆς ὀστᾶ δὲ καὶ χόνδροι καὶ ὄνυχες καὶ ὁπλαὶ καὶ σπλάγχνα πηγνυμένης ἀποτελοῦνται. τελειωθέντων δ’ οὕτω
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.3:

And as these things continually become drier, membranes are first formed, along with tunics [outer coverings], internal organs, and vessels; and finally bones, nails, and cartilages are completed as the substance solidifies. For before the underlying substance is able either to be stretched or to solidify, it is not possible for any of the aforementioned things to come into being. Now tunics and membranes, arteries and sinews and veins are completed when it [the substance] is stretched; but bones and cartilages and nails and hooves and internal organs are completed when it solidifies. And when these have been perfected in this way...
paragraphs.openai_translation: Always, and all the more as these [parts] become drier, first membranes are molded, and tunics [coats], and the viscera, and the vessels; but bones and nails and cartilages are brought to completion as the substance congeals. For before the underlying substance is either able to be stretched or to congeal, none of the aforesaid can come to be. Thus, as it is being stretched, tunics and membranes and the arteries and sinews [neura: tendons/ligaments] and veins are produced; but as it congeals, bones and cartilages and nails and armored plates [hoplai: protective coverings] and viscera are brought to completion. And when these have been completed thus—

paragraphs.content: τίκτεται μὲν ἐφεξῆς ἐν τῇ κυήσει. ἔτι δ’ ὑγρὸν ἐσχάτως ἐστὶν ὥσπερ βρύον οὐκ ἀγγείοις μόνον καὶ σπλάγχνοις καὶ σαρξὶν ἀλλὰ καὶ αὐτοῖς τοῖς ὀστοῖς ἃ δὴ ξηρότατα τῶν ἐν ἡμῖν ὑπάρχει μορίων.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

It is born successively during gestation. Moreover, it is extremely moist like moss, not only in its blood vessels and internal organs and flesh, but also in the very bones themselves, which are indeed the driest of the parts within us.
paragraphs.openai_translation: It is produced in succession during gestation. And it is still exceedingly moist, like bryon [moss], not only in the vessels, the viscera, and the flesh, but even in the very bones, which in fact are the driest of the parts within us.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὅμως καὶ ταῦτα καὶ ὅλα σὺν αὐτοῖς τὰ κῶλα διαπλάττουσιν αἱ τροφοὶ τῶν βρεφῶν, ὥσπερ κήρινα. τοσαύτη τις ὑγρότης ἐστὶν ἐν ἅπαντι τῷ σώματι τῶν παιδίων.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But nevertheless, the nurses of infants mold both these parts and indeed entire limbs along with them, as if they were made of wax. So great is the moisture present in the whole body of children.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But nevertheless the nurses of infants mold these things too, and along with them all the limbs [κῶλα], as if they were of wax; so great is the moisture [ὑγρότης: yielding dampness/softness] in the whole body of children.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ εἰ νέον ἱερεῖον εἴτ’ ἐσθίειν ἐθέλοις εἴτ’ ἀνατεμὼν σκοπεῖσθαι μυξώδη μὲν καὶ πλαδαρὰν εὑρήσεις τὴν σάρκα τὸ δὲ ὀστῶδες γένος ἅπαν ἄρτι πηγνυμένῳ τυρῷ ἐμφερὲς ὥστε μηδὲ φαγεῖν ἡδέα δι’ ὑπερβάλλουσαν ὑγρότητα τῶν νεογνῶν ζώων εἶναι τὰ σώματα. καὶ μάλιστά γε τοῦτο πέπονθε τὰ ὕεια καὶ τὰ πρόβατα διότι καὶ μάλιστ’ ἐστὶν ὑγρότερα. τὰ δ’ αἴγεια διότι ξηρότερα
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.6:

But even if you should wish either to eat a young sacrificial animal or to dissect it and examine it, you will find the flesh slimy and flabby, while the entire bony structure is similar to cheese that has just been curdled, so that the bodies of newborn animals are not even pleasant to eat on account of their excessive moisture. And pigs and sheep are especially affected by this condition because they are also especially moist. But goats, because they are drier...

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end]
paragraphs.openai_translation: But even if you should wish either to eat a young sacrificial animal [hierion] or to cut it open and examine it [i.e., dissect it], you will find the flesh slimy and flabby, and the whole bony part resembling cheese that has only just curdled; so that the bodies of newborn animals are not even pleasant to eat, on account of their excessive moisture. And this is especially the case with pigs and sheep, because they are the moistest; whereas those of goats are less so, because they are drier.

paragraphs.content: βελτίω τέ ἐστι καὶ ἡδίω φαγεῖν. ἔμπαλιν δὲ τοῖς νέοις ἱερείοις τὰ γεγηρακότα ξηρὰ μὲν ἱκανῶς καὶ ἄνικμα καὶ ἄχυμα τά τ’ ὀστᾶ σύμπαντα καὶ τοὺς σύμπαντας συνδέσμους αὐτῶν ἔχει νευρώδη δὲ καὶ σκληρὰν τὴν σάρκα καὶ τὰς ἀρτηρίας καὶ τὰς φλέβας καὶ τὰ νεῦρα διὰ τὴν ἡλικίαν δίκην ἱμάντων ἀηδῆ καὶ ἄχυμα. τὰ δ’ ἐν τῷ μέσῳ τούτων καὶ τῶν ἄρτι γεγενημένων ὅσα μὲν ἤδη προβέβηκε ταῖς ἡλικίαις ὅσον ἀπολείπεται τοῦ γήρως
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

They are both better and more pleasant to eat. Conversely, in contrast to young sacrificial animals, aged ones have bones that are quite dry, lacking moisture and juice throughout, as well as all their ligaments entirely; and they have flesh, arteries, veins, and sinews that are sinewy and tough on account of their age, like leather straps, unpleasant and lacking juice. Those that are between these and the newly born—as many as have already advanced in age to the extent that they fall short of old age
paragraphs.openai_translation: It is also better and more pleasant to eat. Conversely, as compared with young sacrificial animals, the old ones are quite dry, juiceless, and chaff-like; all their bones and all their ligaments are such, and the flesh, the arteries [arteries], the veins [veins], and the sinews [tendons] are sinewy and hard because of age, like straps—unpleasant and insipid. Those that are between these and the newborns, in proportion as they have already advanced in years, by just so much fall short of old age.

paragraphs.content: τοσοῦτον καὶ τῆς ἐσχάτης ξηρότητος· ὅσα δὲ νεώτερα καὶ ἔτ’ αὐξανόμενα τοσοῦτον καὶ ταῦτα τῆς τῶν ἐμβρύων ὑγρότητος ἀπεχώρησεν ὅσον καὶ ταῖς ἡλικίαις προελήλυθεν. ἡ δ’ ἀκμὴ μάλιστα πάντων τῶν ζώων ἐν τῷ μέσῳ καθέστηκε τῶν ἀκροτήτων οὔτ’ εἰς ἔσχατον ἥκουσα ξηρότητος ὡς τὸ γῆρας οὔτ’ ἐν ὑγρότητι καὶ πλάδῳ πολλῷ καθεστῶσα
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

...so far also from extreme dryness; but those that are younger and still growing have departed from the moisture of embryos to the same extent that they have advanced in their ages. The prime of life of all animals is established most of all in the middle between the extremes, neither having reached the extreme of dryness as old age has, nor being established in great moisture and softness [as the young are].
paragraphs.openai_translation: to that extent also toward the uttermost dryness; and whatever are younger and still growing have withdrawn from the moisture of embryos by just as much as they have advanced in age. The akmē [prime of life] in all animals is set in the middle between the extremes, having reached neither the extreme of dryness, as in old age, nor being situated in much moisture and flaccidity [plados: limp softness].

paragraphs.content: καθάπερ ἡ τῶν βρεφῶν ἡλικία. τί δὴ οὖν ἔνιοι τῶν ἐλλογίμων ἰατρῶν ὑγρὸν ἀπεφήναντο τὸ γῆρας; ἢ δηλονότι τῷ πλήθει τῶν περιττωμάτων ἀπατηθέντες; οἵ τε γὰρ ὀφθαλμοὶ δακρύουσιν αὐτοῖς αἵ τε ῥῖνες ἀναπίμπλανται κορύζης ἔν τε τῷ στόματι σιέλου πλῆθος ἀθροίζεται ἀλλὰ καὶ βήττουσι καὶ ἀναπτύουσι φλέγμα δηλοῦντες ἄρα καὶ τὸν πνεύμονα μεστὸν εἶναι τοιούτου χυμοῦ· καὶ ἡ γαστὴρ δὲ αὐτοῖς πεπλήρωται φλέγματος ἕκαστόν τε τῶν ἄρθρων ὑπόμυξον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

like the age of infants. Why then have some of the distinguished physicians declared old age to be moist? Or clearly because they were deceived by the abundance of residues? For their eyes water and their nostrils fill up with mucus, and in the mouth a quantity of saliva collects; but they also cough and expectorate phlegm, thus showing that the lung too is full of such humor; and their stomach is filled with phlegm, and each of the joints is full of mucus.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Just like the age of infants. Why then did some of the reputable physicians declare old age to be moist? Or, plainly, were they deceived by the abundance of excretions [perittōmata: waste products]? For their eyes water, their noses are filled with coryza [nasal catarrh], and in the mouth a quantity of saliva [sialon] gathers; they also cough and bring up phlegm, thereby indicating that the lung is full of such a humor. And their stomach too is filled with phlegm, and each of their joints is rheumy [rheum: mucous discharge].

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ οὐδὲν τούτων ἐναντιοῦται τῷ ξηρὰ τὰ τῶν γηρώντων εἶναι σώματα. τὰ μὲν γὰρ νεῦρα, καὶ τὰς ἀρτηρίας, καὶ τὰς φλέβας, καὶ τοὺς ὑμένας, καὶ τοὺς χιτῶνας ἁπάντων τῶν ὀργάνων ξηρότερα μὲν εὑρήσεις τῶν πρόσθεν πολὺ, περιπεπλασμένον δ’ αὐτοῖς ἔνδοθέν τε καὶ ἔξωθεν ἤτοι φλεγματώδη τινὰ χυμὸν, ἢ ὑγρότητα μυξώδη.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But none of these things contradicts the fact that the bodies of the elderly are dry. For you will find that the sinews, and the arteries, and the veins, and the membranes, and the coats of all the organs are much drier than before, but that there is plastered around them, both inside and outside, either some phlegmatic humor [watery fluid], or a mucous-like moisture.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But none of this is at odds with the fact that the bodies of the elderly are dry. For you will find the sinews [neura: nerves/tendons], the arteries, the veins, the membranes, and the tunics of all the organs much drier than formerly, and enwrapped around them, both within and without, either a certain phlegmatic humor [phlegm, in humoral theory] or a mucous moisture.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ τοσούτου δεῖ τὰ τοιαῦτα σύμπαντα γνωρίσματα τὸ γῆρας ὑγρὸν ἀποφαίνειν, ὥστε καὶ μαρτυρεῖν μοι δοκεῖ τῇ ξηρότητι. δι’ αὐτὸ γάρ τοι τοῦθ’ ἕκαστον τῶν μορίων ξηρότερον γίνεται, ὅτι μηκέθ’ ὁμοίως τρέφεται νῦν ὑπ’ ἀῤῥωστίας τοῦ θερμοῦ. πλῆθος μὲν γὰρ ἔξωθεν αὐτοῦ περιττωμάτων ὑγρῶν ἐπικλύζει, τὸ βάθος δ’ αὐτὸ τοῦ σώματος ἑκάστου ξηρόν ἐστι, μήθ’ ἕλκειν εἴσω τὴν τροφὴν δυναμένου, μήτ’ ἀπολαύειν ἱκανῶς.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But so far are all such signs from demonstrating that old age is moist, that they even seem to me to bear witness to its dryness. For it is precisely because of this that each of the parts becomes drier—because it is no longer nourished in the same way now due to the weakness of the heat. For a quantity of moist residues floods over it from the outside, but the depth itself of each body is dry, since it is neither able to draw the nourishment inward nor to benefit from it sufficiently.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But such signs as these are so far from showing that old age is moist that they even seem to testify to its dryness. For it is for this reason that each of the parts becomes drier—namely, because it is no longer nourished in the same way now, owing to the weakness [arrhōstia: impairment] of the heat. A mass of moist superfluities [perittōmata: excess residues] indeed floods it from without, but the inner depth of each body is dry, being unable either to draw the nourishment inward or to profit from it sufficiently.

paragraphs.content: ὑγρὸς οὖν ὁ γέρων ἐστὶν, οὐ τοῖς οἰκείοις μορίοις, ἀλλὰ τοῖς περιττώμασι, καὶ ξηρὸς, οὐ τοῖς περιττώμασιν, ἀλλὰ τοῖς μορίοις αὐτοῖς, ὥστ’ ἄλλῳ μὲν ξηρὸς, ἄλλῳ δ’ ὑγρός.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Therefore, the old man is moist, not in his own parts, but in his waste products, and dry, not in his waste products, but in the parts themselves; consequently, he is dry in one respect, but moist in another.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, the old man is moist, not in his proper parts [i.e., the body’s own tissues], but in his residues [perittōmata: superfluities/excrements], and dry, not in the residues, but in the parts themselves; so that in one respect he is dry, in another moist.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ οὐ περὶ τῶν περιττωμάτων αὐτῶν νῦν ὁ λόγος ἀλλὰ τῶν οἰκείων μορίων ἐστίν· ὧν αἱ κατὰ φύσιν ἐνέργειαι συμπληροῦσι τὴν ζωήν. τούτοις οὖν ξηρός ἐστιν ὁ γέρων οἷς ὁ παῖς ἦν ὑγρὸς αὐτοῖς τοῖς στερεοῖς μέρεσι τοῦ σώματος ὀστοῖς καὶ ὑμέσι καὶ συνδέσμοις καὶ ἀρτηρίαις καὶ φλεψὶ καὶ νεύροις καὶ χιτῶσι καὶ σαρξί. καὶ δικαίως Ἀριστοτέλης εἰκάζει τὸ γῆρας αὐαινομένῳ φυτῷ. καὶ γὰρ οὖν καὶ τὰ φυτὰ νέα μὲν ὄντα
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.13:

But the discussion now is not about the waste products themselves but about the proper parts of the body, whose natural activities complete life. In these parts, then, the old man is dry in the same respects that the child was moist—in the very solid parts of the body: bones and membranes and ligaments and arteries and veins and sinews and tunics [coverings/sheaths] and flesh. And Aristotle rightly compares old age to a withering plant. For indeed plants too, when they are young

---

**Brief notes:**
- [χιτῶσι (chitōsi)] refers to membrane-like coverings or sheaths around organs and tissues
- The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end
paragraphs.openai_translation: But our discussion now is not about their excrements [perittōmata: wastes/residuals], but about their own proper parts [oikeia moria], whose activities in accordance with nature [energeiai kata physin] complete life. In respect to these, the old person is dry in those parts in which the child was moist—namely, the solid parts of the body [sterea merē]: bones, membranes [hymenes], ligaments, arteries, veins, nerves/sinews [neura], tunics/coats [chitōnes], and flesh. And Aristotle rightly likens old age to a withering plant. For indeed plants too, when they are young...

paragraphs.content: μαλακά τ’ ἐστὶ καὶ ὑγρά· γηρῶντα δὲ ἀεὶ καὶ μᾶλλον φαίνεται ξηραινόμενα· τελευτῶντα δὲ τελέως ἀποξηραίνεται καὶ τοῦτ’ ἔστιν αὐτοῖς ὁ θάνατος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"they are soft and moist; but as they grow old they are seen to become increasingly dry; and when they are dying they dry out completely, and this is death for them."
paragraphs.openai_translation: They are soft and moist; but as they grow old they always appear to be drying out more and more; and when they come to their end they are completely dried out, and this is for them death.

paragraphs.content: ὅτι μὲν οὖν ξηρόταταν ὡς ἐν ἡλικίαις τὸ γῆρας, ἐκ τῶν εἰρημένων εὔδηλον· ὅτι δὲ καὶ ψυχρότατόν ἐστιν, ἔτ’ ἐναργέστερον, ὥστ’ οὐδ’ ἀμφισβητήσειεν οὐδεὶς ὑπέρ γε τούτου. καὶ γὰρ ἁπτομένοις οἱ γέροντες ψυχροὶ φαίνονται, καὶ ῥᾳδίως ἀποψύχονται, καὶ μελαίνονται, καὶ πελιδνοῦνται, καὶ τοῖς ψυχροῖς ἑτοίμως ἁλίσκονται νοσήμασιν, ἀποπληξίαις, παραλύσεσι, νάρκαις, τρόμοις, σπασμοῖς, κορύζαις, βρόγχοις.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.15:

That old age is the driest of the stages of life, then, is clear from what has been said; but that it is also the coldest is even more evident, so that no one would dispute this point at least. For indeed old people appear cold to the touch, and they easily grow cold, and they turn dark, and they become livid, and they are readily seized by cold diseases—apoplexies [strokes], paralyses, numbnesses, tremblings, spasms, head colds, and hoarseness.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, that old age is the driest of the life stages is clear from what has been said; and that it is also the coldest is even more evident, so that no one would even dispute this point. For to the touch the old appear cold, and they are easily chilled; they grow dark and livid, and they are readily seized by cold diseases—apoplexies, paralyses, numbnesses [nárkai: torpor/numbing], tremors, spasms, coryzas [head colds], and bronchial affections [bronchitis/catarrh].

paragraphs.content: ἀπόλωλε δ’ αὐτῶν ὀλίγου δεῖν ἅπαν τὸ αἷμα, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο συναπόλωλε καὶ ἡ τῆς χρόας ἐρυθρότης. ἀλλὰ καὶ πέψις αὐτοῖς, καὶ ἀνάδοσις, ἐξαιμάτωσίς τε, καὶ πρόσθεσις, καὶ θρέψις, ὄρεξίς τε, καὶ αἴσθησις, καὶ κίνησις, ἀμυδρὰ πάντα καὶ κακῶς διακείμενα. καὶ τί γὰρ ἄλλο ἢ ὁδὸς ἐπὶ θάνατόν ἐστι τὸ γῆρας;
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.16:

Nearly all of their blood has perished, and because of this the redness of their complexion has perished along with it. But also their digestion, distribution [of nutrients], blood-formation, assimilation, nourishment, appetite, sensation, and movement—all these things are feeble and in a poor condition. And what else is old age but a road to death?

---

**Brief notes:**
- [distribution] refers to *anádosis*, the distribution or conveyance of nutrients throughout the body
- [blood-formation] translates *exaimátōsis*, the process of converting nutrients into blood
- [assimilation] renders *prósthesis*, the addition or attachment of nutrients to the body parts
paragraphs.openai_translation: Almost all their blood has all but perished, and for this reason the redness of the complexion has perished along with it. Moreover, digestion [pepsis], and distribution [anadosis: the spreading of nutriment], withdrawal of blood [exaimatosis], addition [prosthesis: the supplying of new matter], and nourishment, as well as appetite, sensation, and movement, are all faint and in poor condition. For what else is old age but a road to death?

paragraphs.content: ὥστ’ εἴπερ ὁ θάνατος σβέσις ἐστὶ τῆς ἐμφύτου θερμασίας εἴη ἂν καὶ τὸ γῆρας οἷον μαρασμός τις αὐτῆς. οὐ μὴν περί γε τῆς τῶν παίδων ἡλικίας καὶ τῶν ἀκμαζόντων οὔθ’ ὁμολογεῖται τοῖς ἰατροῖς οὔτε κρῖναι τὴν διαφωνίαν αὐτῶν εὐπετές. πιθανοὶ γὰρ ἑκατέρων οἱ λόγοι τῶν τε τοὺς παῖδας ἀποφῃνάντων θερμοτέρους εἶναι τῶν ἀκμαζόντων καὶ τῶν ἔμπαλιν τούτοις τοὺς ἀκμάζοντας τῶν παίδων. οἱ μὲν γὰρ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

So if death is an extinction of the innate heat, then old age would also be a kind of withering of it. However, concerning the age of children and those in their prime, the physicians neither agree with one another, nor is it easy to judge their disagreement. For the arguments of both sides are plausible—both those who declare that children are hotter than those in their prime and those who, contrary to these, claim that those in their prime are hotter than children. For the one group...
paragraphs.openai_translation: So if death is the extinguishing of the innate heat [the inborn vital warmth], then old age would be, as it were, a kind of wasting of it. However, with respect to the age of children and of those in their prime [akmazontes], the physicians are neither in agreement, nor is it easy to adjudicate their disagreement. For the arguments on both sides are plausible—both those who declare children to be hotter than those in their prime, and those who, conversely, [declare] those in their prime to be hotter than children. For the former...

paragraphs.content: ὅτι θερμότατον ἁπάντων ἐστὶ τῶν ἐν τῷ ζώῳ κατὰ φύσιν ὑπαρχόντων ὁ τοῦ αἵματος χυμός· εἶθ’ ὅτι καὶ τὰ κυούμενα τὸ μὲν πρῶτον ὀλίγου δεῖν αἷμα μόνον ἐστὶν ὕστερον δὲ διαπλαττομένων ἤδη τῶν μορίων τὸ μὲν ὀστοῦν γίνεται τὸ δὲ ἀρτηρία τὸ δὲ φλὲψ τὸ δ’ ἄλλο τι πάντα μὲν ἐρυθρὰ καὶ πλεῖστον αἵματος εἰλικρινεστάτου τε καὶ θερμοτάτου μετέχοντα συλλογίζονται θερμότατον εἶναι τὸ κυούμενον· εἰ δὲ τοῦτο καὶ τοὺς παῖδας ὅσῳπερ ἐγγυτέρω τοῖς κυουμένοις
paragraphs.openai_translation: That the humor [fluid] of the blood is the hottest of all the things naturally present in a living creature; and then that embryos, at the beginning, are almost nothing but blood, but later, when the parts are already being shaped, one becomes bone, another an artery, another a vein, and another something else—while all are red and share in a very great quantity of blood, most pure and hottest—so they conclude that the embryo is the hottest. And if this is so, then children too, in proportion as they are nearer to embryos...
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.19:

That the humor of blood is the hottest of all things that exist naturally in the animal; then, that embryos in the first stage are almost nothing but blood alone, but later, when the parts are already being formed, one becomes bone, another artery, another vein, and another something else—all of them red and partaking of the most abundant, purest, and hottest blood—they conclude that the embryo is the hottest; and if this is so, then children too, insofar as they are closer to embryos

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end, suggesting this is an incomplete excerpt from a larger passage discussing the heat of blood and its relationship to embryonic development and childhood.

paragraphs.content: θερμοτέρους εἶναι τῶν ἀκμαζόντων. οἱ δ’ ὅτι πολὺ μὲν κἀν τοῖς ἀκμάζουσι τὸ αἷμα καὶ πλέον ἢ ἐν τοῖς παισὶν ὥστε συνεχῶς διὰ τοῦθ’ αἱμοῤῥαγεῖν  ἀλλὰ καὶ ὁ τῆς ξανθῆς χολῆς χυμὸς αἵματος πολὺ θερμότερος ὑπάρχων πλεῖστος αὐτοῖς ἐστι καὶ διὰ τοῦτο θερμοτέρους ἀποφαίνουσι τῶν παίδων τοὺς ἀκμάζοντας. αὖθις δ’ ἀπὸ τῶν ἐνεργειῶν οἱ μὲν ὅτι καὶ αὐξάνονται καὶ πλειόνων ἢ κατὰ τὴν ἀναλογίαν τοῦ σώματος ὀρέγονταί τε καὶ κρατοῦσιν ἐδεσμάτων
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

to be hotter than those in their prime. But others say that the blood is indeed abundant even in those in their prime, and more so than in children, so that they continually suffer nosebleeds on this account; but also the humor of yellow bile, being much hotter than blood, is most plentiful in them, and for this reason they declare that those in their prime are hotter than children. Again, from their activities, some say that both because they grow and because they desire and can digest more food than is proportional to their body—
paragraphs.openai_translation: …to be hotter than those in their prime [i.e., children hotter than adults at their prime]. Others say that even in those at their prime there is much blood, and more than in children, so that on this account they frequently bleed; and further, that the humor of yellow bile [ξανθὴ χολή], being much hotter than blood, is very abundant in them, and for this reason they declare those in their prime to be hotter than children. Again, from [their] activities [ἐνέργειαι], some argue that they [sc. children] both grow and, beyond what is proportionate to the body, crave and “master” foods [i.e., digest them] in greater quantity.

paragraphs.content: ἰσχυρὰν ἐν τοῖς παισὶν εἶναί φασι τὴν θερμασίαν· οἱ δὲ τὸ μὲν αὐξάνεσθαι διὰ τὴν ὑγρότητα μᾶλλον ἢ τὴν τοῦ θερμοῦ ῥώμην ὑπάρχειν αὐτοῖς φασι ταῖς μέντοι πέψεσιν οὐχ ὅπως πλεονεκτεῖν ἀλλὰ καὶ πολὺ τῶν ἀκμαζόντων ἀπολείπεσθαι. ἐμέτους τε γὰρ ἀπέπτων αὐτοῖς γίνεσθαι τῶν σιτίων καὶ διαχωρήσεις ὑγρῶν καὶ τραχέων καὶ ἀχυμώτων αὐτῶν. εἰ δ’ ὀρέγονται πλειόνων οὐδὲν εἶναι τοῦτό φασι πρὸς τὴν ῥώμην τοῦ θερμοῦ. πρῶτον μὲν γὰρ οὐδὲ πλεονεξίᾳ θερμότητος ὀρέγεσθαι τὰ ζῶα
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.21:

They say that the heat in children is strong; but others say that their growth occurs due to moisture rather than the strength of heat, and that in their digestions they not only do not have an advantage but actually fall far short of those in their prime. For they say that vomiting of undigested foods occurs in them, as well as evacuations [diarrhea] of foods that are liquid, rough, and lacking in nutriment. And if they desire more food, they say this has nothing to do with the strength of heat. For in the first place, living creatures do not desire food due to an excess of heat
paragraphs.openai_translation: They say that warmth is strong in children; but others maintain that their growth comes about on account of moisture rather than through the strength of heat present in them, and that in regard to digestions [pepsies: processes of digestion] they not only fail to have the advantage but are in fact far behind those in their prime. For vomitings of undigested food occur in them, and fluxes [diarrheic discharges] of fluids that are thin, harsh, and without juice. And if they crave more [sc. food], they say this has nothing to do with the strength of their heat. For, in the first place, animals do not crave by reason of a surplus of heat.

paragraphs.content: τοὐναντίον δ’ ἅπαν ἀποψυχομένων τῶν ὀρεκτικῶν μορίων· ἔπειτα δὲ διότι μὴ μόνον εἰς θρέψιν ἀλλὰ καὶ εἰς αὔξησιν αὐτοῖς ἡ τροφὴ διοικεῖται διὰ τοῦτο πλειόνων ἐδεσμάτων προσδεῖσθαι. καὶ μέντοι ταῖς ἄλλαις ἐνεργείαις ἁπάσαις καὶ πάνυ σαφῶς ἀπολείπεσθαι τοὺς παῖδας τῶν ἀκμαζόντων. οὔτε γὰρ βαδίζειν οὔτε θεῖν οὔτε βαστάζειν οὔθ’ ὅλως τι τῶν πρακτικῶν ἐνεργειῶν ὁμοίως ἐπιτελεῖν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.22:

But the complete opposite occurs when the appetitive parts are cooled; then, because nourishment is distributed to them not only for nutrition but also for growth, for this reason they require more food. And indeed, in all other activities children very clearly fall short of those in their prime. For they are not able to walk or run or carry things or, in general, to perform any of the practical activities in the same way.
paragraphs.openai_translation: On the contrary, all the appetitive parts [of the soul] are growing faint; and then, because food is administered to them not only for nourishment but also for growth, for this reason they require more kinds of food. And indeed, in all the other activities, quite clearly, children fall short of those in their prime; for they are able neither to walk nor to run nor to carry, nor in general to perform any of the practical activities [i.e., actions involving bodily execution] to the same degree.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ τὰς αἰσθήσεις καὶ τὰς νοήσεις ἐν τοῖς ἀκμάζουσί φασιν εἰς ἄκρον ἥκειν ἀρετῆς· ὅλως δὲ τὸ μὲν ἀτελὲς ἔτι τὸ δ’ ἤδη τέλειον εἶναι ζῶον. ἐν δὲ τοῖς τελείοις εὔλογον τὸ πρακτικώτατόν τε καὶ ἀρχικώτατον τῶν στοιχείων φασὶν ἐπικρατεῖν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But they also say that the senses and thoughts reach the peak of excellence in those who are in their prime; and in general, one creature is still incomplete while another is already complete. And in complete creatures, they say, it is reasonable that the most active and most governing of the elements holds sway.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But they also say that both the perceptions [aisthēseis: sense-perceptions] and the intellections [noēseis: acts of understanding] in those at their prime [akmazousi] reach the highest pitch of excellence [aretē]. And in general, the one is as yet incomplete, whereas the other is already a complete living being. And in complete beings it is reasonable, they say, that the most operative and most commanding [praktikōtaton and archikōtaton: most active/efficacious and most ruling] of the elements [stoicheia: constituent principles] should prevail.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ τοὺς ὕπνους πλείστους μὲν ἐν τοῖς παισὶν ἰδεῖν ἐστι γιγνομένους ἐλαχίστους δὲ τοῖς ἀκμάζουσι. καίτοι τούτους γε φασὶν οὐδὲ μανεὶς ἄν τις ἑτέρως ἡγήσαιτο γίγνεσθαι ἢ τοῦ θερμοῦ νικηθέντος πως καὶ βαρυνθέντος ὑπὸ πλήθους ὑγρότητος ὡς ἔκ τε τῶν οἰνωθέντων ἐστὶν ἰδεῖν ἔτι τε τῶν πλείω λουσαμένων. οὕτω δὲ καὶ μήκων ὑπνοποιός ἐστι καὶ μανδραγόρας καὶ θριδακίνη
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.24:

But indeed, one can observe that sleep occurs most frequently in children and least frequently in those in their prime. And yet they say that no one, not even if mad, would think that this happens in any other way than by the heat being somehow overcome and weighed down by an abundance of moisture, as can be seen both from those who are intoxicated and still more from those who have bathed excessively. And in this same way, poppy is sleep-inducing, as are mandrake and lettuce.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But one may observe that sleep occurs most in children, and least in those at their prime. And indeed they say—and not even a madman would think otherwise—that it comes to be when the heat is somehow overcome and weighed down by an abundance of moisture, as one may see in those who have been drinking wine and also in those who have bathed excessively. So too poppy [opium poppy], mandrake, and lettuce-juice [expressed juice of lettuce] are sleep-inducing.

paragraphs.content: καὶ πάνθ’ ὅσα τὴν κρᾶσιν ὑγρότερα καὶ ψυχρότερα. τοιαῦται μέν τινες αἱ ἑκατέρωθεν ἀμφισβητήσεις εἰσὶ περὶ τῶν προκειμένων ἡλικιῶν τῆς κράσεως.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"and all things which are moister and colder in their mixture. Such, then, are the disputes on both sides concerning the mixture of the ages under consideration."

---

**Brief notes:**
- κρᾶσις (krasis) = "mixture" or "temperament" [a medical/physiological term referring to the balance of bodily humors or qualities]
- ἡλικιῶν (hēlikiōn) = "ages" [referring to stages or periods of life]
paragraphs.openai_translation: and everything that makes the [bodily] temperament [κρᾶσις: the mixture/constitution of qualities] more moist and colder. Such, then, are some of the disputes argued on both sides concerning the aforesaid ages with respect to temperament.

paragraphs.content: ἁπάσας γὰρ αὐτὰς ἐπεξέρχεσθαι περιττὸν εἶναί μοι δοκεῖ, τοῦ τύπου τῶν ἐπιχειρημάτων σαφῶς ἤδη κᾀξ ὧν εἰρήκαμεν ἐγνωσμένου. πόῤῥωθεν γὰρ ἑκάτεροι καὶ σχεδὸν ἀπὸ τῶν δευτέρων τὰ πρότερα συλλογίζονται, καὶ ὥσπερ εἰδότων ἤδη τῶν ἀκροατῶν, ὅπως μὲν αὔξησις, ὅπως δὲ πέψις, ὅπως δὲ θρέψις γίνεται, ποιοῦνται τὸν λόγον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.26:

For it seems to me to be superfluous to go through all of them, since the pattern of the arguments has already been clearly understood even from what we have said. For both sides reason from a distance, and practically from secondary matters they draw conclusions about primary ones, and they construct their argument as if the audience already knows how growth occurs, how digestion occurs, and how nutrition occurs.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For it seems to me superfluous to go through all of them in detail, since the pattern of the arguments has already become clear from what we have said. For both parties reason from afar, and, as it were, from secondary matters to primary ones; and they conduct their argument as though the audience already knew how growth occurs, how digestion [pepsis] takes place, and how nutrition [threpsis] is effected.

paragraphs.content: ὡσαύτως δ’ ὑπὲρ αἰσθήσεως, καὶ κινήσεως, καὶ πρακτικῶν, καὶ φυσικῶν ἐνεργειῶν διέρχονται, καὶ γενέσεως ὕπνου μνημονεύουσι, καὶ σιτίων φύσεως, ὧν οὐδὲν ἁπλῶς ἐστι καὶ ῥᾳδίως γνώριμον, ἀλλὰ παμπόλλης μὲν ζητήσεως δεόμενον, ἴσως δ’ οὐδ’ εὑρεθῆναι δυνάμενον, εἰ μὴ πρότερόν τις εἰδείη γνωρίζειν ὑγρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν καὶ θερμὴν καὶ ψυχρὰν κρᾶσιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Likewise, they go through discussions concerning perception, and motion, and practical matters, and natural activities, and they make mention of the origin of sleep and the nature of foods—none of which is simply and easily knowable, but rather requiring very extensive investigation, and perhaps not even able to be discovered unless one first knows how to recognize a mixture that is moist and dry and hot and cold.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Likewise they go through matters concerning sensation, and motion, and the voluntary and natural functions, and they make mention of the generation of sleep and the nature of foods—none of which is straightforward or easy to know, but requires very extensive inquiry and perhaps cannot even be discovered, unless one first knows how to discern the mixture [krasis: mixture/temperament] of the moist and the dry, the hot and the cold.

paragraphs.content: ὅ τι γὰρ ἂν ἐκείνων ὡς γινώσκοντες ἤδη λέγωσιν, εἰ ἀναγκάσειέ τις αὐτοὺς ἀποδεικνύναι, πάντως δεήσονται τοῦ περὶ κράσεων λόγου τοῦ νῦν ἡμῖν ἐνεστῶτος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
For whatever they may say as if they already know it, if someone were to compel them to demonstrate it, they will certainly need the account concerning mixtures [or: temperaments] which is now before us.

[Note: κράσεων (kraseōn) can refer to "mixtures," "blendings," or "temperaments" - a technical term in ancient medical and philosophical discourse, particularly in Galenic medicine where it refers to the balance of bodily humors or qualities]
paragraphs.openai_translation: For whatever of those matters they assert as though already knowing them, if someone were to compel them to demonstrate it, they would in any case need the account concerning mixtures [kraseis/temperaments] that is now before us.

paragraphs.content: ὥστε δι’ ἀλλήλων τε καὶ ἐξ ἀλλήλων αὐτοῖς γίνεσθαι τὰς ἀποδείξεις ἐκ μὲν τῶν νῦν ζητουμένων ὡς ἤδη γινωσκομένων ἐπειδὰν ὑπὲρ τῶν ἐνεργειῶν διαλέγωνται καὶ τὴν τῶν ἐδεσμάτων τε καὶ φαρμάκων ἐξευρίσκωσι δύναμιν ὕπνου τε καὶ τῶν ἄλλων τῶν τοιούτων ἐπισκέπτωνται. πάλιν δὲ αὖ τὰ νῦν ἐνεστῶτα δι’ ἐκείνων ὡς ἤδη προεγνωσμένων ἀποδεικνύουσιν. ἐγὼ δὲ οὐκ ἐπαινῶ τὰς τοιαύτας ἀποδείξεις ἀλλ’ εἰ χρὴ τἀληθὲς εἰπεῖν οὐδ’ ἀποδείξεις εἶναι νομίζω
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

So that their demonstrations come to be through one another and from one another—on the one hand, from the matters now being investigated as if they were already known, whenever they discuss the functions [or activities] and discover the power of foods and drugs and examine sleep and other such things. But then again, conversely, they demonstrate the matters now at hand through those things as if they were already known in advance. But I do not approve of such demonstrations, and if the truth must be told, I do not even consider them to be demonstrations at all.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So that their demonstrations [apodeixeis: proofs] end up being both through one another and from one another: from the very things now under investigation, as if already known, whenever they engage in discussion about the activities [energeiai: functions/operations] and discover the power [dynamis: capacity/effect] of foods and drugs, and examine sleep and other such matters. Then again in turn they prove the present points by means of those others, as if already known beforehand. For my part, I do not commend such demonstrations, but—if the truth must be told—I do not even think they are demonstrations at all.

paragraphs.content: καθάπερ ἐπὶ πλέον δι’ ἑτέρων ἐδήλωσα. καὶ βέλτιον εἶναί φημι κατὰ πᾶσαν διδασκαλίαν ὁρίσασθαι τὴν τάξιν τῶν νοημάτων. εἴπερ οὖν ἀρχὴ μέν ἐστι ἁπάσης τῆς περὶ κράσεων πραγματείας ἡ περὶ τῶν στοιχείων ἐπίσκεψις εἴτε ἀπαθῆ καὶ ἀμετάβλητα τελέως ἐστὶν εἴτ’ ἀλλοιοῦσθαί τε καὶ μεταβάλλεσθαι δυνάμενα μετὰ δὲ τὴν ἐκείνων ἐπιστήμην ἐφεξῆς ἐστι δεύτερος ὁ νῦν ἡμῖν ἐνεστηκὼς λόγος οὐ χρὴ λαμβάνειν αὐτῶν τὰς πίστεις ἐκ τῶν μήπω γινωσκομένων ἀλλ’ ὥσπερ ὀρθόν τέ ἐστι καὶ δίκαιον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

as I have explained more fully through other works. And I say that it is better in every teaching to define the order of concepts. If therefore the examination concerning the elements is the beginning of the entire treatise on mixtures [krasis]—whether they are unaffected and completely unchangeable, or whether they are capable of being altered and changed—and after the knowledge of those things comes next in order the second argument which now stands before us, one must not take the proofs concerning them from things not yet known, but just as it is right and just

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence. *Krasis* refers to mixture or blending, particularly of the fundamental elements or qualities in Greek medical and philosophical theory.
paragraphs.openai_translation: As I have shown at greater length elsewhere. And I maintain that in every exposition it is better to determine the order of the conceptions. If, then, the inquiry concerning the elements [stoicheia: the basic constituents] is the starting point of the whole treatise on mixtures [kraseis], whether they are completely unaffected and unchangeable, or capable of being altered and undergoing change, and if, after knowledge of those matters, the discourse now before us comes next in due order as second, we must not take our proofs concerning them from things not yet known, but, as is both correct and just...

paragraphs.content: ἤ τι τῶν ἐναργῶν εἶναι προσήκει τὸ ληφθησόμενον εἰς τὴν ἀπόδειξιν ἤ τι τῶν προαποδεδειγμένων. οὔτ’ οὖν ὕπνου γενέσεως μνημονευτέον οὔτε πέψεως οὔτ’ αὐξήσεως οὐδ’ ἄλλου τῶν τοιούτων μηδενὸς ἀλλ’ ἀπὸ μόνης καὶ ψιλῆς τῆς οὐσίας τῶν ὑποκειμένων πραγμάτων ἡ ζήτησις γιγνέσθω καθάπερ καὶ διὰ τοῦ πρώτου λόγου πεποιήμεθα. διελόμενοι γὰρ ὡς ἕτερον μέν ἐστι τὸ κατ’ ἐνέργειαν ἕτερον δὲ τὸ κατὰ δύναμιν ὑπὲρ τοῦ κατ’ ἐνέργειαν ὄντος ἤδη θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

What is to be taken up for the demonstration must be either something self-evident or something previously demonstrated. Therefore, one must make no mention of the coming-to-be of sleep, nor of digestion, nor of growth, nor of any other such things, but let the inquiry proceed from the substance alone and by itself of the underlying matters, just as we have done through the first argument. For having distinguished that what exists in actuality is one thing and what exists in potentiality is another, concerning what is already actually hot and cold and dry
paragraphs.openai_translation: Either what is to be taken for the demonstration must be something evident [enargēs], or something previously demonstrated. Therefore we must make no mention of the coming-to-be of sleep, nor of digestion [pepsis], nor of growth, nor of anything else of that sort, but let the inquiry proceed from the bare and simple essence of the underlying things, just as we have done in the first argument. For having distinguished that what is in actuality [kat’ energeian] is one thing and what is in potentiality [kata dynamin] another, we shall speak concerning what already exists in actuality as hot and cold and dry...

paragraphs.content: καὶ ὑγροῦ τὸν λόγον ἔφαμεν χρῆναι ποιήσασθαι πρότερον· ἔπειτα οὕτως ἐπὶ τὰ κατὰ δύναμιν ἀφικέσθαι. πρόχειρος δ’ ἐστὶ πᾶσι καὶ γνώριμος ἡ τῶν κατ’ ἐνέργειαν ἤδη θερμῶν καὶ ψυχρῶν ὑγρῶν τε καὶ ξηρῶν διάγνωσις.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

And we said that one must first make an account concerning the moist; then in this way to arrive at things according to potentiality. But the discernment of things that are already hot and cold, moist and dry in actuality is ready at hand for everyone and familiar.

---

**Alternative translation with slightly different emphasis:**

And we said that the account must first be made concerning the moist; then thus to proceed to things according to capacity. But the recognition of those things already hot and cold, moist and dry in actuality is readily available to all and well-known.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And we said that we ought first to have set out the account of the wet; then, in this way, to proceed to the things according to potentiality [dunamis]. For the discrimination of things already in actuality [energeia] hot and cold and wet and dry is ready to hand and familiar to everyone.

paragraphs.content: ἁφὴ γὰρ τά γε τοιαῦτα διακρίνειν πέφυκεν ἡ καὶ τὸ πῦρ αὐτὸ θερμὸν εἶναι διδάξασα καὶ τὸν κρύσταλλον ψυχρόν. εἰ δ’ ἄλλοθέν ποθεν ἔχουσιν ἔννοιάν τε καὶ διάγνωσιν θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ λεγέτωσαν ἡμῖν· ἀμήχανυν γάρ τινα σοφίαν ἐπαγγέλλονται μᾶλλον δ’ εἰ χρὴ τἀληθὲς εἰπεῖν ἐμπληξίαν εἰ πραγμάτων αἰσθητῶν ἕτερόν τι πρεσβύτερον αἰσθήσεως ἔχουσι κριτήριον. καὶ μὴν εἰ μηδὲν ἄλλο τῶν ἐνεργείᾳ θερμῶν ἐγχωρεῖ κριτήριον ὑπάρχειν ἁπτέσθωσαν ἤδη πολλῶν ἐφεξῆς ἀνδρῶν καὶ γερόντων καὶ μειρακίων
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For touch is naturally suited to distinguish such things, being the very sense that has taught us that fire itself is hot and crystal is cold. But if they have a conception and discernment of hot and cold from some other source, let them tell us; for they profess a certain impossible wisdom, or rather, if one must speak the truth, madness, if they have some other criterion older than sense-perception for sensible things. And yet if there can be no other criterion for things that are actually hot, let them now touch many men in succession, both old men and young men.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For touch is by nature suited to discriminate such things—the very sense that has taught us that fire itself is hot and crystal cold. But if they have from somewhere else any conception and discernment of hot and cold, let them tell us; for they claim some impracticable sort of wisdom—or rather, to tell the truth, mere bewilderment—if they possess for perceptible things some criterion [standard of judgment] other than sense-perception, something prior to sense. And indeed, if no other criterion can be admitted for things that are actually hot, let them now in succession touch many persons—men, old men, and youths.

paragraphs.content: καὶ παίδων καὶ βρεφῶν· οὕτω γὰρ ἐξευρήσουσι τοὺς μᾶλλόν τε καὶ ἧττον θερμούς. εἰ δ’ αἰσθητῶν πραγμάτων λογικὰς ἀποδείξεις ζητοῦσιν ὥρα τι καὶ περὶ τῆς χιόνος αὐτῆς ἤδη σκοπεῖν εἴτε λευκὴν ὡς ἅπασιν ἀνθρώποις φαίνεται νομιστέον αὐτὴν εἴτε καὶ μὴ λευκὴν ὡς Ἀναξαγόρας ἀπεφῄνατο· καὶ μέντοι καὶ περὶ πίττης ὡσαύτως ἀνασκοπεῖν τε καὶ κόρακος ἁπάντων τε τῶν ἄλλων. οὐ γὰρ δὴ τὸ μὲν λευκὸν ἀπιστεῖσθαι χρὴ τοὺς ὀφθαλμοὺς ὁρῶντας
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.34:

and of children and infants; for in this way they will discover those who are more and less hot. But if they seek logical proofs for matters of sense-perception, it is time now to examine also concerning snow itself whether one ought to consider it white as it appears to all people, or not white as Anaxagoras declared; and moreover to investigate likewise concerning pitch and the raven and all other things. For surely one ought not to distrust the eyes when they see white things,

---

**Brief contextual notes:**
- The reference to Anaxagoras alludes to his paradoxical claim that snow is not white (but black), based on his theory that snow is frozen water, and water is dark/black.
- The argument appears to be part of a larger epistemological debate about whether sense-perception or rational argument should be trusted in determining the nature of things.
paragraphs.openai_translation: —and of children and of infants; for in this way they will discover those who are hotter and cooler. But if they demand rational demonstrations concerning perceptible matters, it is time to examine even about snow itself—whether one ought to consider it white, as it appears to all human beings, or not white, as Anaxagoras declared; and likewise to review the case of pitch [bitumen/tar] and the raven, and all other such things. For surely one ought not, in the case of what is white, to distrust the eyes when they see—

paragraphs.content: ἄνευ δ’ ἀποδείξεως ἐπὶ τῶν μελάνων πιστεύεσθαι.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
But in the case of black things, [one ought] to be trusted without demonstration.

---

**Alternative translation:**

But in matters concerning black things, trust should be given without proof.
paragraphs.openai_translation: —and, without demonstration, to put one’s trust in what is set down in black [ink, i.e., merely because it is written].

paragraphs.content: ἅπαντα οὖν ἤδη τὰ τῶν αἰσθήσεων ἄπιστα φάμενοι μήτε τὸν κύκνον λευκὸν εἶναι λεγόντων ἐὰν μὴ πρότερον ἐπισκέψωνται λόγῳ μήτε τὸν τίτανον ἢ τὴν ἡμέραν ἢ αὐτὸν τὸν ἥλιον. οὕτω δὲ καὶ περὶ τῶν φωνῶν ἀπιστησάτωσαν ἀκοῇ καὶ περὶ τῶν ὀσμῶν ταῖς ῥισὶ καὶ περὶ πάντων τῶν ἁπτῶν ἁφῇ. εἶτα ταῦτα οὐ Πυῤῥώνειος ἀπορία καὶ λῆρος ἀπέραντος; οὐ μὴν καὶ δίκαιόν γε ἦν τοὺς τὴν ἀρίστην αἵρεσιν ἑλομένους τῶν ἐν φιλοσοφίᾳ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.36:

Therefore, since they declare all the evidence of the senses to be untrustworthy, let them not say that the swan is white unless they have first examined it by reason, nor the chalk or the day or the sun itself. And in this same way let them distrust hearing concerning sounds, and the nostrils concerning smells, and touch concerning all tangible things. Then are these things not Pyrrhonian aporia [skeptical doubt] and endless nonsense? And yet it was certainly not just that those who had chosen the best school [philosophical sect] among those in philosophy...

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end of this paragraph]
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, if they now declare all the data of the senses untrustworthy, let them not say that the swan is white unless they first examine it by reason [logos: a reasoned account], nor [say this] of chalk [titanos: gypsum], or of day, or of the sun itself. And so too, let them disbelieve, in the case of sounds, their hearing, and in the case of smells, their noses, and, in the case of all tangible things, their touch. Then is not this Pyrrhonian aporia [skeptical impasse] and endless babble? Yet surely it was just that those who had chosen the best sect among those in philosophy...

paragraphs.content: τὴν τὸ θερμὸν καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν καὶ τὸ ξηρὸν καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν ἀρχὰς καὶ στοιχεῖα τιθεμένην εἰς τοσοῦτο ἀποπλανηθῆναι ἀπὸ τῶν ταῦτα θεμένων ἀνδρῶν ὡς μὴ γινώσκειν ὅτι τε πάσης ἀποδείξεως ἀρχαὶ τὰ πρὸς αἴσθησίν τε καὶ νόησίν ἐστιν ἐναργῆ καὶ ὅστις περὶ τούτων ἀπορεῖ μάτην ὑπὲρ τῶν ἄλλων ζητεῖ μηδ’ ὁπόθεν ἄρξηται καταλελοιπὼς ἑαυτῷ. πόθεν οὖν εἰς μακρὰν οὕτως ἄλην ἐτράποντο καὶ λόγῳ ζητεῖν ἐπεχείρησαν αἰσθητῶν πραγμάτων διάγνωσιν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.37:

[The school] that posits hot and cold and dry and wet as principles and elements has wandered so far from the men who established these things as not to recognize that the principles of every demonstration are those things which are evident to perception and thought, and that whoever is at a loss concerning these things searches in vain for other matters, having left himself no starting point from which to begin. How then did they turn aside into such a long wandering and attempt to seek by argument the discernment of perceptible things?

---

**Brief notes:**
- The subject "the school" or "the theory" is implied from context
- ἀρχαί and στοιχεῖα: "principles and elements" - technical philosophical terms for fundamental constituents
- ἐναργῆ: "evident" or "clear" - a key epistemological term in ancient philosophy
- The hot, cold, dry, and wet refer to the fundamental qualities in pre-Socratic and later Greek natural philosophy
paragraphs.openai_translation: The school that posits the hot, the cold, the dry, and the wet as principles and elements [archai and stoicheia] has wandered so far from the men who first laid down these doctrines that it does not even recognize that the starting points of every demonstration are the things that are evident to sense-perception and to intellection, and that whoever is at a loss about these seeks the rest in vain, having left himself not even a place from which to begin. Whence, then, did they turn aside into so long a wandering and attempt, by reasoning, to determine the discrimination of perceptible matters?

paragraphs.content: ἐγὼ μὲν οὐδ’ ἐπινοῆσαι δύναμαι. καὶ διὰ τοῦτο ἁφῇ μὲν κρίνω τὸ κατ’ ἐνέργειαν θερμόν· εἴ τι δ’ οὔπω μέν ἐστι θερμὸν ἐπιτήδειον δὲ γενέσθαι τοιοῦτο ὃ δὴ καὶ δυνάμει θερμὸν ὀνομάζεται τοῦτ’ ἐξευρίσκειν λόγῳ πειρῶμαι. τοῖς δ’ οὐκ οἷδ’ ὅπως ἀνατέτραπται πάντα καὶ ῥητορεία μακρὰ περὶ τῶν ἐπιχειρημάτων ἤσκηται. τούτους μὲν οὖν ἐάσωμεν ἀναμνήσαντες ἡμᾶς αὐτοὺς τό γε τοσοῦτο καὶ νῦν ὡς ἀρχὴ δογμάτων μοχθηρῶν ἐστι μία τὸ μηδὲν ὑπὲρ ἀποδείξεως ἐσκέφθαι πρότερον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.38:

I myself am not even able to conceive of it. And for this reason, I judge what is actually hot by touch; but if something is not yet hot but is suitable to become such—which indeed is also called potentially hot—this I attempt to discover by reason. But for these people, somehow everything has been turned upside down, and lengthy rhetoric about arguments has been practiced. Let us then leave these people aside, having reminded ourselves at least of this much even now: that one source of corrupt doctrines is to have given no prior consideration to demonstration.
paragraphs.openai_translation: I, for my part, cannot even conceive it. And for this reason I judge by touch what is hot in actuality [kat’ energeian]; but if something is not yet hot, yet is apt to become such—that which is indeed also called hot in potential [dynamis]—I try to discover this by reasoning. As for those in whom, I know not how, everything has been turned upside down, and who have cultivated long-winded rhetoric about arguments—let us leave them aside, reminding ourselves at least this much even now: that there is a single source of corrupt doctrines, namely, having previously examined nothing with respect to demonstration [apodeixis].

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἅμα τὰ πράγματα ζητεῖν καὶ ὡς εἰδότας ὅ τί ποτέ ἐστιν ἀπόδειξις ἐπιχειρεῖν ἀποδεικνύειν. ἐπανελθόντες οὖν αὖθις ἐπὶ τὸ προκείμενον ἁφῇ κρίνωμεν πρώτως καὶ μάλιστα τὸ κατὰ τὰς ἡλικίας θερμόν. ἔσται δ’ ἡμῶν ἡ κρίσις ἀρίστη καθ’ ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ σῶμα βρέφους ἑνός. οὐ γὰρ ἀδύνατον ὁποία τέ τις ἡ θερμασία διετεῖ τὴν ἡλικίαν ὑπάρχοντι προϋπῆρχεν αὐτῷ μεμνῆσθαι καὶ ὁποία νῦν ἐστι δυοῖν ἢ τριῶν ἐτῶν εἰ τύχοι
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But [they seek] to investigate matters and at the same time to attempt to demonstrate as if they already know what demonstration actually is. Therefore, returning again to the matter at hand, let us judge primarily and especially the heat according to ages by touch. Our judgment will be most accurate in the case of one and the same body of a single infant. For it is not impossible to remember what sort of heat belonged to him when he was two years of age and what sort it is now when he happens to be, say, two or three years old.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But at the same time let us both inquire into the facts and attempt to prove them as people who know what a demonstration [apodeixis] is. Returning, then, again to the matter at hand, let us judge by touch [palpation] first and especially the degree of heat according to the ages. Our assessment will be best with one and the same body, that of a single infant. For it is not impossible to remember what sort of warmth previously belonged to it as it passed through that age, and what it is now, if it happens to be two or three years old.

paragraphs.content: μεταξὺ γενομένων. εἰ γὰρ ὅλως φαίνοιτο μεταβολή τις ἐπὶ θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν γεγονέναι τῷ βρέφει χαλεπὸν οὐδὲν ἔτι συλλογίζεσθαι τὴν ἕως τῆς ἀκμῆς ἐσομένην ὑπεροχήν. εἰ δὲ καὶ πλείω παιδία πολλοῖς ἀκμάζουσιν ἐθέλοις παραβάλλειν ἰσχνὰ μὲν ἰσχνοῖς εὔσαρκα δ’ εὐσάρκοις καὶ παχέα παχέσι παράβαλλε· οὕτω δὲ καὶ χρόας ὡσαύτως ἔχοντα καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ἁπάντων ὡς οἷόν τε. τὴν γὰρ ἐν ταῖς ἡλικίαις διαφορὰν ἐξευρεῖν ζητῶν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

that have occurred in between. For if any change whatsoever toward hot or cold should appear to have occurred in the infant, it is no longer difficult to calculate the superiority that will exist up to the prime of life. But if you should wish to compare several children with many adults in their prime—compare lean ones with lean, well-fleshed with well-fleshed, and fat with fat; and in the same way also compare those having similar complexions and all the other characteristics as far as possible. For seeking to discover the difference in the ages...
paragraphs.openai_translation: Once the intermediate stages have taken place. For if in general some change toward hot or cold should appear to have occurred in the infant [brephos], it is no longer difficult to infer the predominance [hyperochē] that will exist up to the prime [akmē]. And if you wish to compare a larger number of children with many who are at their prime, compare the lean with the lean, the well-fleshed with the well-fleshed, and the fat with the fat; and do likewise with complexions [chroas] that are alike, and, as far as possible, with all other features. For you are seeking to discover the difference that belongs to the ages.

paragraphs.content: ἐπὶ τῶν ὁμοίων ὡς ἔνι μάλιστα φύσεων ἀσφαλέστερον ἂν ἐπισκέπτοιο. τὸ δ’ ἐπὶ τῶν ἐναντίων ἐξετάζειν οὐ σμικρὸν ἔχει τὸν παραλογισμὸν οὐ διὰ τὴν ἡλικίαν ἐνίοτε τῆς τῶν δοκιμαζομένων σωμάτων διαφορᾶς ἀλλὰ διὰ φυσικὴν ὑπαρχούσης κρᾶσιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
You would examine more safely upon natures that are as similar as possible. But examining upon contraries involves no small degree of false reasoning, not because of the age of the difference in the bodies being tested, but because of the naturally existing mixture [or temperament].

---

**Alternative translation with clarified syntax:**

One would examine more safely in cases of natures that are as similar as possible. But the examination in cases of contraries involves no small degree of false reasoning—not on account of the age [as a factor] in the difference of the bodies being tested, but on account of their naturally existing mixture [krasis].

[Note: *krasis* refers to the mixture or blending of qualities/humors in medical theory]
paragraphs.openai_translation: Among natures as similar as possible you would make your inquiry more safely; but to examine matters on the basis of opposites involves no small fallacy—not, at times, because of a difference in age of the bodies under trial, but because of an underlying natural temperament [krasis: innate constitutional mixture].

paragraphs.content: ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ διαίτῃ πάσῃ καὶ τοῖς καιροῖς ἐν οἷς ἐξετάζεται παραπλησίως ἔχοντα προαιρεῖσθαι τὰ σώματα μὴ γεγυμνασμένον ἠργηκότι παραβάλλοντας ἢ λελουμένον ἀλούτῳ μηδ’ ἄσιτον ἐδηδοκότι καὶ διψῶντα μεμεθυσμένῳ μηδὲ τὸν ἐν ἡλίῳ θαλφθέντα τῷ ῥιγώσαντι διὰ κρύος ἢ τὸν ἀγρυπνήσαντα τῷ κεκοιμημένῳ μήθ’ ὅλως τοῖς ἐξ ἐναντίας φύσεως ἢ διαίτης ἢ περιστάσεως πραγμάτων ἡστινοσοῦν ἀλλ’ ὡς οἷόν τε πάνθ’ ὡσαύτως ὑπαρχέτω τἄλλα
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.42:

Likewise, also with regard to every regimen and the times at which they are examined, one should choose bodies that are in similar condition—not comparing one who has not exercised with one who has been inactive, nor one who has bathed with one who has not bathed, nor one who has not eaten with one who has eaten, nor one who is thirsty with one who is drunk, nor one who has been warmed in the sun with one who has been chilled by cold, nor one who has stayed awake with one who has slept, nor at all those who are from opposite nature or regimen or circumstance of any kind whatsoever, but rather, as far as possible, let all other things be alike in the same way.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Likewise, in every regimen [diaita] and in the times [kairoi, i.e., seasons/occasions] in which the examination is conducted, choose bodies that are similarly conditioned, not comparing one that has been trained with one that has been idle, or one that has bathed with one unbathed, nor one fasting with one that has eaten, or one thirsty with one that is drunk; nor the one warmed in the sun with the one chilled by cold, or the one that has stayed awake with the one that has slept; nor, in general, those differing in nature, regimen, or any circumstances whatsoever; but, so far as possible, let all other conditions be the same.

paragraphs.content: πλὴν τῆς ἡλικίας αὐτῆς. οὕτω δὲ δηλονότι καὶ αὐτὸν τὸν ἕνα παῖδα παραβάλλων ἑαυτῷ τὰς ἔξωθεν ἁπάσας αὐτοῦ περιστάσεις ἀκριβῶς ὁμοίας φυλάξεις ἵνα μὴ τὸ διά τινα τούτων ἐν θάλψει τε καὶ ψύξει διαφέρον εἰς τὴν τῆς ἡλικίας ἀναφέρηται μεταβολήν. μακρὰν ἴσως σοι δόξω λέγειν τὴν ἐξέτασιν ἀλλ’ ἀληθῆ γε παντὸς μᾶλλον ἐξ αὐτῆς τε τοῦ ζητουμένου τῆς οὐσίας λαμβανομένην ὡς ἐν τοῖς ὑπὲρ ἀποδείξεως ἐλέγομεν. σὺ δὲ ἴσως αἱρήσῃ τὴν ἐπίτομον οὐδὲν φροντίζων
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.43:

except for age itself. And thus, evidently, even when comparing the one child himself to yourself, you will keep all his external circumstances precisely similar, so that any difference in warming and cooling due to some of these factors may not be attributed to the change of age. Perhaps I will seem to you to be making the examination lengthy, but it is certainly most true of all, being derived from the very essence of what is being investigated, as we said in the works on demonstration. But you will perhaps choose the abbreviated [method], caring nothing
paragraphs.openai_translation: Except for age itself. And thus, clearly, when you compare that one child with himself, you will keep all his external circumstances exactly alike, so that what differs in warmth and in cold because of some of these [external factors] may not be attributed to the change of age. Perhaps I shall seem to you to be making the inquiry too long; but at any rate it is true above all, and from it one derives the very essence of the object of inquiry, as we said in the discussions on demonstration [apodeixis]. You, however, will perhaps choose the abridged way, caring not at all...

paragraphs.content: εἰ ψευδὴς εἴη.
paragraphs.claude_translation: if it were false.
paragraphs.openai_translation: If it were false.

paragraphs.content: ἴσθι τοίνυν οὐ μόνον ψευδῆ βαδίσων, ἀλλὰ καὶ μακράν. οὐ γὰρ ἔτεσι τρισὶν ἢ τέτταρσιν ἐξευρήσεις τὸ ζητούμενον, ἀλλ’ ἐν παντὶ τῷ βίῳ φυλάξεις τὴν ἄγνοιαν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Know then that you will be walking not only a false path, but also a long one. For you will not discover what you seek in three or four years, but you will preserve your ignorance throughout your entire life.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Know then that you will be going not only astray, but far astray. For you will not discover what you seek in three or four years; rather, you will maintain your ignorance throughout your whole life [agnōia = ignorance].

paragraphs.content: ὅσον γὰρ ἐπὶ ταῖς ἀντιλογίαις τῶν ἀνδρῶν οὐδὲν ἀποδειχθῆναι δύναται σαφῶς· οὐδ’ εὔλογον ὅλως ἐκ τῶν ὑστέρων πιστοῦσθαι τὰ πρότερα. κρίνωμεν οὖν αἰσθήσει τὸ θερμὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν σῶμα τό γε κατ’ ἐνέργειαν ἤδη τοιοῦτο καὶ μηκέτι δυνάμει παρέντες τήν τε κρίσιν πρώτην τά τ’ ἄλλα σύμπαντα γνωρίσματα. καὶ δὴ σὲ μὲν ὡς εὖ κρινοῦντα πρὸς τὴν πεῖραν ἀπολύω τὴν δ’ ἐμὴν αὐτὸς κρίσιν ἑρμηνεύσω. πολλῶν γὰρ ἐφεξῆς ἁπτόμενος σωμάτων ἐπιμελῶς οὐ παίδων μόνων ἢ βρεφῶν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.46:

For insofar as it depends on the contradictory arguments of these men, nothing can be clearly demonstrated; nor is it at all reasonable to confirm prior things from posterior ones. Let us therefore judge by sensation the hot and cold body—at least that which is already such in actuality and no longer potentially—setting aside both the primary judgment and all the other signs together. And indeed I release you to the test, trusting that you will judge well, but I shall interpret my own judgment myself. For having carefully touched many bodies in succession, not only of children or infants
paragraphs.openai_translation: For as far as men’s counter-arguments go, nothing can be clearly demonstrated; nor is it at all reasonable to confirm what comes earlier from what comes later. Let us therefore judge by perception the hot and the cold body—the body, that is, already such in actuality and no longer only in potential [energeia vs. dynamis]—laying aside both the original criterion and all the other marks [gnorismata] alike. And so, since you will judge well, I leave you to the test [peira], while I myself will set forth my own judgment. For by carefully touching in succession many bodies, not only those of boys or infants...

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ μειρακίων καὶ ἀκμαζόντων εὕρισκον οὐδετέρους ἀληθεύοντας οὔτε τοὺς θερμότερον ἁπλῶς οὔτε τοὺς ψυχρότερον εἰπόντας εἶναι τὸν ἀκμάζοντα τοῦ παιδός. εἰ γὰρ τὰς ἄλλας ἁπάσας τὰς ἔξωθεν ἀφελὼν ἀλλοιώσεις τὰς ἐκ τῆς ἡλικίας μόνης ἐπισκέπτοιο διαφορὰς οὐδέτερός σοι φαίνεται θερμότερος ἁπλῶς. ποιότητι γάρ τοι διαφέρουσιν αὐτῶν αἱ θερμότητες ἐπ’ ἀνίσῳ τῇ διαπνοῇ δι’ ἣν καὶ σοφιζόμενοί τινες ἢ τοὺς πέλας ἢ σφᾶς αὐτοὺς οἱ μὲν τὴν τοῦ παιδὸς
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.47:

But also in the case of youths and those in their prime, I found that neither group was speaking the truth—neither those who said that a person in their prime is simply hotter, nor those who said they are colder than a child. For if you were to remove all the other external alterations and examine only the differences arising from age itself, neither appears to you to be simply hotter. For their heats differ in quality due to the unequal transpiration [through the skin], on account of which some people, either deceiving others or themselves, some [say] that the child's [heat]...

[Note: The text breaks off mid-sentence with "οἱ μὲν τὴν τοῦ παιδὸς" ("some [say] that the child's..."), suggesting the paragraph continues beyond what was provided.]
paragraphs.openai_translation: But even in the case of youths and men in their prime, I found neither party telling the truth—neither those who said, without qualification, that the man in his prime is hotter than the child, nor those who said he is colder. For if, removing all the other external alterations, you were to examine only the differences that arise from age itself, neither would appear to you simply hotter. For their heats differ in quality, owing to unequal diapnoe [transpiration/perspiration], on account of which some, contriving arguments, deceive either others or themselves: some maintain the child’s...

paragraphs.content: οἱ δὲ τὴν τοῦ νεανίσκου θερμασίαν ἰσχυροτέραν εἶναι νομίζουσιν. ἔστι γὰρ ἡ μὲν τῶν παίδων ἀτμωδεστέρα τε καὶ πολλὴ καὶ ἡδίων τοῖς ἁπτομένοις ἡ δὲ τῶν ἀκμαζόντων ὑπόδριμύ τι καὶ οὐχ ἡδὺ κέκτηται. τοῦτ’ οὖν τὸ διάφορον τῆς προσβολῆς ἀναπείθει τοὺς πλείους ἀποφαίνεσθαι θερμότερον εἶναι τῶν ἀκμαζόντων τὸ σῶμα. τὸ δ’ οὐχ οὕτως ἔχει. τῷ γὰρ ἀσκήσαντι τὴν ἁφὴν ἐν διαφόροις ὕλαις διαγνωστικὴν εἶναι θερμότητος ἰσχυροτέρας τε καὶ ἀσθενεστέρας καὶ ἴσης
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But they consider the heat of the young man to be stronger. For the heat of children is more vapor-like and abundant and more pleasant to those who touch it, while that of those in their prime possesses something rather pungent and not pleasant. This difference in the sensation upon contact, then, persuades the majority to declare that the body of those in their prime is hotter. But this is not how it is. For to one who has trained his sense of touch in different materials to be capable of distinguishing stronger and weaker and equal heat
paragraphs.openai_translation: Some, however, suppose the warmth of the young man to be stronger. For that of children is more vaporous, more abundant, and more pleasant to the touch, while that of those in their prime [akmazontes: at full maturity] has something slightly acrid about it and is not pleasant. This difference, then, in the impression on contact persuades the majority to declare that the body of those in their prime is the hotter. But the case is not so. For one who has trained the sense of touch [haphe] across different materials to discern heat that is stronger, weaker, and equal…

paragraphs.content: εὖ οἶδ’ ὅτι καὶ ἡ τῶν παίδων αὐτῷ ἤτοι γ’ ἴση φανεῖται τὴν ἰσχὺν τῇ τῶν ἀκμαζόντων ἢ πλείων. ἡ δ’ ἄσκησις ἥδε· χρὴ γὰρ ἀπὸ τῶν ἐναργεστάτων ἄρξασθαι. τῶν βαλανείων ἐνίοτε θερμὸς οὕτως ἐστὶν ὁ ἀὴρ ὡς μηδένα φέρειν αὐτὸν ἀλλὰ καίεσθαι δοκεῖν ἐνίοτε δ’ οὕτω ψυχρὸς ὡς ἱδροῦν μὴ δύνασθαι. καὶ μὴν καὶ ὅτι τρίτη τις ἄλλη παρὰ τάσδε κατάστασίς ἐστιν ἧς μάλιστα χρῄζομεν ἡ εὔκρατος
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.49:

I know well that the strength of children will appear to him either equal to that of those in their prime or even greater. And this is the training—for one must begin from the most evident examples. Sometimes the air in bathhouses is so hot that no one can bear it but seems to be burning; sometimes it is so cold that one cannot sweat. And indeed there is also a certain third condition besides these two, which we need most of all: the well-tempered [moderate] one.
paragraphs.openai_translation: I know well that even the condition of children, to him, will appear either equal in strength to that of those in their prime, or even greater. The exercise [askēsis: demonstration/test] is this; for one must begin from what is most evident. In the public baths [balaneia] the air is sometimes so hot that no one can endure it but seems to be getting burned, and sometimes so cold that one cannot work up a sweat. And furthermore, there is a third condition besides these, the one we especially need—the well-tempered state [eukratos: balanced mixture].

paragraphs.content: οὐδὲν δέομαι λέγειν. αἱ δ’ αὐταὶ τρεῖς καταστάσεις ἐν τῷ τῆς κολυμβήθρας ὕδατι φαίνονται. καὶ γὰρ θερμὸν οὕτως ὡς καίεσθαι πρὸς αὐτοῦ καὶ ψυχρὸν ὡς μηδὲ θερμαίνεσθαι καὶ εὔκρατον ὡς συμμέτρως θερμαίνεσθαι πολλάκις εὑρίσκεται. εἰ τοίνυν ἐροίμην σε πότερόν ἐστι θερμότερον;
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.50:

I need say nothing. The same three conditions appear in the water of the bath. For it is often found to be hot to such a degree as to burn one with it, and cold so as not even to warm one, and temperate so as to warm one moderately. If, therefore, I were to ask you which is hotter?
paragraphs.openai_translation: I have no need to say anything.
