The same three conditions appear in the water of the bath as well; for it is often found hot, to such a degree that one is burned by it, and cold, to the point that one is not even warmed, and temperate [well-balanced], so that one is warmed in due measure. If then I were to ask you, which is the hotter?

paragraphs.content: ἆρά γε τὸ ὕδωρ τὸ εὔκρατον, ἢ ὁ ἀὴρ ὁ εὔκρατος; οὐκ ἂν ἔχοις εἰπεῖν οὐδέτερον.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Is it the well-tempered water, or the well-tempered air? You would not be able to say either one.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Is it the well-balanced water, or the well-balanced air [eukratos: properly mixed/temperate]? You could not say which of the two.

paragraphs.content: ἀμφοῖν γὰρ ὄντων ὁμοίως ἡδέων τε καὶ συμμέτρων τῷ σώματι τὸ μὲν θερμότερον λέγειν αὐτῶν τὸ δὲ ψυχρότερον οὐδένα νοῦν ἔχειν ἡγοῦμαι. καὶ μὴν εἰ νοήσαις τὸ τῆς δεξαμενῆς ὕδωρ εἰς ἄκρον θερμότητος ἀφικνούμενον ὡς ζεῖν ἢ τὸν ἀέρα τελέως ἐκφλογούμενον ὅτι πρὸς ἀμφοῖν ὡσαύτως καυθήσῃ πρόδηλον. εἰ δὲ δὴ καὶ νοήσαις αὖθις ἢ τὸ ὕδωρ οὕτω ψυχρὸν ὡς ἐγγὺς ἤδη πήξεως εἶναι ἢ τὸν ἀέρα τελέως ἐψυγμένον ὡς ἐν τοῖς νιφετοῖς γίγνεται
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.52:

For when both are equally pleasant and suitable to the body, I consider it senseless to say that one of them is hotter and the other colder. And indeed, if you conceive of the water in a reservoir reaching the extreme point of heat so as to boil, or the air becoming completely inflamed, it is obvious that you will be burned in the same way by both. But if again you conceive of either the water being so cold as to be already near freezing, or the air being completely chilled as happens in snowstorms,
paragraphs.openai_translation: For when both are alike pleasant and proportionate to the body, I think it makes no sense to call one of them hotter and the other colder. And yet if you imagine the water in the cistern [reservoir] reaching the extreme of heat, to the point of boiling, or the air being completely set aflame, it is evident that by both alike you would be burned. And if in turn you imagine either the water so cold as to be already near congealment [freezing], or the air completely chilled as happens in snowstorms...

paragraphs.content: δῆλον ὡς καὶ πρὸς τούτων ἑκατέρων ὁμοίως ψυγήσῃ τε καὶ ῥιγώσεις. οὐκοῦν καὶ θερμότητα καὶ ψύξιν ἄκραν ὡσαύτως ἀέρι νοήσεις ἐγγινομένην ὡσαύτως καὶ ὕδατι καὶ τῶν ἄκρων ἑκατέρων τὸ μέσον ὁμοίως ἀμφοῖν ἐγγινόμενον· ὥστε καὶ τὸ μεταξὺ πάντων τῶν ἄκρων τε καὶ τοῦ μέσου κατά τε τὸ ὕδωρ καὶ τὸν ἀέρα τὰς αὐτὰς ὑπεροχάς τε καὶ διαστάσεις ἕξει. καὶ τοσούτῳ ποτὲ φήσεις εἶναι τοῦ μετρίου θερμότερον θάτερον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.53:

It is clear that you will be cooled and shivered by each of these in the same way. Therefore, you will conceive of extreme heat and cold occurring in air in the same manner as in water, and the middle point between each of the extremes occurring similarly in both; so that the intervals between all the extremes and the middle point will have the same proportions and distances in both water and air. And you will say that one is sometimes hotter than the moderate [mean] by such-and-such an amount

---

**Notes:**
- The text appears to be discussing the relationship between temperature extremes (hot and cold) and their middle points in different media (air and water)
- "ψυγήσῃ τε καὶ ῥιγώσεις" - both verbs relate to experiencing cold, with the second emphasizing shivering
- The argument establishes proportional relationships between temperature states across different substances
- The final clause appears incomplete in the provided excerpt
paragraphs.openai_translation: It is clear that, in the presence of either of these, you will be cooled and will shiver alike. Accordingly, you will conceive both extreme heat and extreme cold as arising in air, and likewise in water, and the mean between the two extremes as arising equally in both. Hence everything intermediate between all the extremes and the mean will, with respect to both water and air, have the same excesses and intervals [degrees of difference]. And you will, in a given case, say that the one is hotter than the moderate by just so much—

paragraphs.content: ὅσῳ θάτερον. οὕτω δὲ καὶ ψυχρότερον τοῦ μετρίου τοσούτῳ φήσεις εἶναί ποτε τὸ ὕδωρ ὅσῳ καὶ τὸν ἀέρα. καίτοι τό γε τῆς προσβολῆς ἴδιον οὐ ταὐτὸ ἑκατέροις ἦν. οὐ γὰρ ὡσαύτως ὕδωρ εὔκρατον ὡς ἀὴρ εὔκρατος προσπίπτει. καὶ τί δεῖ λέγειν ἐπὶ τῶν οὕτως ἀνομοίων; αὐτοῦ γὰρ τοῦ ἀέρος ὁμοίως ὄντος θερμοῦ διαφέρουσαι γίγνονται προσβολαὶ παρὰ τὸ ποτὲ μὲν οἷον ἀχλυώδη τε καὶ ἀτμώδη ποτὲ δὲ οἷον λιγνυώδη τε καὶ καπνώδη
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.54:

by however much the other is. And in this same way you will say that water is at some time colder than the moderate degree by however much the air is also. And yet the particular quality of the impact was not the same for each of them. For water at a temperate state does not strike us in the same way as air at a temperate state does. And why need we speak of things so dissimilar? For even when the air itself is similarly hot, different impacts occur depending on whether it is at one time, as it were, misty and vaporous, and at another time, as it were, smoky and sooty.
paragraphs.openai_translation: By as much as the other. And so you would also say that at times water is colder than the mean by as much as air is. And yet the distinctive feature of the impact [prosbolē: the mode of contact on sensation] was not the same in both. For temperate water does not strike [the sense] in the same way as temperate air. And what need is there to speak of things so dissimilar? For even when the air itself is equally warm, the impacts differ, owing to its being sometimes, as it were, misty and vaporous, and at other times, as it were, sooty and smoky.

paragraphs.content: ποτὲ δὲ καθαρὸν ἀκριβῶς ὑπάρχειν. ἐν πολλαῖς οὖν καὶ διαφερούσαις ἰσότης γίνεται θερμότητος ἐξαπατῶσα τοὺς ἀσκέπτους ὡς ἄνισος ὅτι γε κατὰ πᾶν ὁμοία φαίνεται. λελογισμένου μήν ἐστιν ἀνδρὸς τοὺς λογισμοὺς οὓς εἴρηκα καὶ γεγυμνασμένου τὴν αἴσθησιν ἐν πολλῇ τῇ κατὰ μέρος ἐμπειρίᾳ τὴν ἰσότητα τῆς θερμότητος ἐξευρεῖν ἔν τε τοῖς παισὶ καὶ τοῖς ἀκμάζουσι καὶ μὴ τῷ τὴν μὲν ἐφ’ ὑγρᾶς οὐσίας φαίνεσθαι τὴν δ’ ἐπὶ ξηρᾶς
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

ever to exist purely in an exact sense. Therefore, equality of heat occurs in many different [substances], deceiving those who do not examine carefully, as if it were unequal, because it appears similar in every respect. However, it belongs to a man who has reasoned through the arguments which I have stated and who has trained his perception through much particular experience to discover the equality of heat both in children and in those in their prime, and not [to be deceived] by the fact that the one [heat] appears to be upon a moist substance while the other upon a dry one.
paragraphs.openai_translation: - and sometimes it is present pure and exact. Accordingly, an equality of heat arises in many and different things, deceiving the unexamining as if it were unequal, although it appears similar in every respect. Yet it is the part of a calculating man—one who has trained his perception through much particular experience—to discern the equality of heat both in children and in those at their prime [i.e., mature adults], and not [to judge otherwise] on the ground that in the one case it appears on a moist substance and in the other on a dry [i.e., differing humoral qualities].

paragraphs.content: ἐξαπατᾶσθαι. καὶ γὰρ λίθος ὕδατι δύναταί ποτε τὴν ἴσην δέξασθαι θερμασίαν οὐδὲν διαφέρον εἰ ξηρὸς μὲν ὁ λίθος ἐστὶν ὑγρὸν δὲ τὸ ὕδωρ. οὕτως οὖν ἔμοιγε μυριάκις ἐπισκεψαμένῳ καὶ παῖδας καὶ νεανίσκους πολλοὺς καὶ μειράκια καὶ τὸν αὐτὸν παῖδα καὶ βρέφος καὶ μειράκιον γενόμενον οὐδὲν μᾶλλον ἐφάνη θερμότερος οὔτε παιδὸς ἀκμάζων οὔτ’ ἀκμάζοντος παῖς.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

to be deceived. For indeed a stone can at some time receive the same degree of heat as water, it making no difference that the stone is dry while the water is wet. Thus then, to me at least, having examined countless times both children and many young men and youths, and the same child having become both an infant and a youth, it appeared no more that one in his prime is hotter than a child, nor that a child is hotter than one in his prime.
paragraphs.openai_translation: to be deceived. For a stone too can at times receive the same degree of heating as water, there being no difference, even if the stone is dry and the water moist [dry/moist: standard elemental qualities]. Accordingly, after I myself had examined countless times both children and many youths and lads, and the same boy as both an infant and, later, a lad, no one ever appeared any hotter—neither one at his prime than a child, nor a child than one at his prime.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὡς εἴρηται μόνον ἐν μὲν τοῖς παισὶν ἀτμωδεστέρα τε καὶ πολλὴ καὶ ἡδεῖα ἐν δὲ τοῖς ἀκμάζουσιν ὀλίγη καὶ ξηρὰ καὶ οὐχ ὁμοίως ἡδεῖα τῆς θερμασίας ἡ προσβολή. πολὺ μὲν γὰρ τῆς τῶν παίδων οὐσίας ὑγρᾶς οὔσης ἐκτὸς ἀποῤῥεῖ βραχὺ δὲ τῆς τῶν ἀκμαζόντων ξηρᾶς ὑπαρχούσης. οὐδέτερος οὖν αὐτῶν ἁπλῶς φαίνεται θερμότερος ἀλλ’ ὁ μὲν τῷ πλήθει τῆς διαπνοῆς ὁ δὲ τῇ δριμύτητι. τὸ γὰρ ἔμφυτον θερμὸν ὁ παῖς ἔχει πλέον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.57:

But as has been said, only in children is the contact of heat more vaporous and abundant and pleasant, while in those in their prime it is slight and dry and not similarly pleasant. For much flows out externally from the substance of children, which is moist, but little from that of those in their prime, which is dry. Therefore neither of them appears simply hotter, but the one [appears hotter] by the abundance of the exhalation, the other by its sharpness. For the child possesses more innate heat.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But, as has been said, the onset of warming [prosbolē tēs thermasias] is in children more vaporous, abundant, and pleasant, whereas in those at their prime it is scant, dry, and not pleasant in the same way. For much flows outwards from the substance of children, since it is moist, but only a little from those at their prime, since theirs is dry. Accordingly, neither of them appears simply hotter: the one does so by the abundance of exhalation [diapnoē, “transpiration”], the other by its sharpness [drimytēs, “pungency/biting quality”]. For the child has more innate heat.

paragraphs.content: εἴ γ’ ἐξ αἵματος καὶ σπέρματος ἡ γένεσις αὐτῷ καὶ ἥδιον· ἐν δὲ τοῖς ἀκμάζουσιν ὀλίγη καὶ ξηρὰ καὶ οὐχ ὁμοίως ἡδεῖα τῆς θερμασίας ἡ προσβολή.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"If indeed the generation [of pleasure] comes from blood and semen, it is also more pleasant for him; but in those who are in their prime, the contact of heat is slight and dry and not similarly pleasant."
paragraphs.openai_translation: If indeed for him generation comes from blood and semen [sperma: semen], it is more pleasant as well; but in those at their prime the onset of the heating [thermasia: warming/sexual arousal] is slight and dry, and not pleasant in the same way [prosbolē: onset/impact].

paragraphs.content: Θερμοῦ μὲν δὴ καὶ ψυχροῦ σώματος ἁφὴ μόνη γνώμων ἐστίν· ὑγροῦ δὲ καὶ ξηροῦ σὺν τῇ ἁφῇ λογισμός. τὸ μὲν γὰρ ξηρὸν σκληρὸν πάντως· ἀλλὰ τοῦτο μὲν ἁφῇ αἰσθητόν· οὐ μὴν, εἴ τι καὶ σκληρὸν, εὐθὺς ἤδη καὶ ξηρόν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Now, touch alone is the judge of hot and cold body; but of wet and dry, reasoning together with touch. For the dry is altogether hard; but this is perceptible by touch; however, if something is also hard, it is not immediately also dry.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Touch alone is the criterion [gnōmōn] for a body’s heat and cold; but for moisture and dryness, along with touch, reasoning [logismos] is required. For the dry is in all cases hard; and hardness is perceptible by touch; yet it does not follow that, if something is hard, it is straightaway also dry.

paragraphs.content: ἀχώριστον μὲν γάρ ἐστι ξηροῦ σώματος ἡ σκληρότης, οὐ μὴν ἴδιόν γε τούτου μόνου. καὶ γὰρ τὸ πεπηγὸς ὑπὸ ψύξεως σκληρὸν, ὥσπερ ὁ κρύσταλλος. ὅθεν οὐδ’ εὐθὺς ἐπιχειρεῖν δεῖ τῇ τοῦ ξηροῦ τε καὶ ὑγροῦ διαγνώσει, πρὶν ἐπισκέψασθαι, πῶς ἔχει θερμότητος ἢ ψυχρότητος. οὔτε γὰρ, εἰ μετὰ ψυχρότητος ἄκρας σκληρὸν, ἤδη τοῦτο ξηρὸν, οὔτ’, εἰ μετὰ θερμότητος σφοδρᾶς μαλακὸν, εὐθέως ὑγρόν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 3.2:

For hardness is inseparable from a dry body, but it is certainly not peculiar to this alone. For what has been solidified by cold is also hard, just as ice is. Hence one must not immediately attempt to diagnose the dry and the moist before examining how the thing stands with respect to heat or cold. For neither, if something is hard with extreme cold, is it thereby dry, nor, if it is soft with intense heat, is it immediately moist.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For hardness is indeed inseparable from a dry body, yet it is not the peculiar property of this alone. For what has been congealed by cold is also hard, like crystal. Hence one must not immediately undertake the distinction between the dry and the moist [technical pair: xēron/hygron] before examining how it stands with respect to heat or cold. For neither, if something is hard along with extreme cold, is it thereby already dry; nor, if soft along with intense heat, is it straightaway moist.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὅταν μετρίως ᾖ θερμὸν, σκοπεῖν ἐφεξῆς, εἰ μαλακόν ἐστιν ἢ σκληρόν. εἰ μὲν γὰρ μαλακὸν, ὑγρὸν, εἰ δὲ σκληρὸν, ξηρόν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But whenever it is moderately warm, one must examine next whether it is soft or hard. For if it is soft, it is moist, but if it is hard, it is dry.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But when it is moderately warm, next examine whether it is soft or hard. For if it is soft, it is moist [i.e., of a wet humor]; but if it is hard, it is dry [i.e., of a dry humor].

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ εἴπερ ταῦθ’ οὕτως ἔχοι τῶν ἐν ἀνθρώπου σώματι μορίων σκληρῶν οὐδὲν ἂν εἴη ὑγρόν. οὐ γὰρ ἐγχωρεῖ τοσαύτην ἐν αὐτῷ γενέσθαι ψύξιν ὡς σκληρυνθῆναί τι διὰ πῆξιν. εἰς μὲν γὰρ σύστασίν τινα τὸ τέως ῥυτὸν ἀφίξεταί ποτε καθάπερ ἡ πιμελή. τὸ γὰρ ἐλαιῶδες ἐν αἵματι ῥυτὸν ὂν καὶ λιπαρὸν ὅταν ἐν ψυχρῷ γένηται χωρίῳ πήγνυται σκληρὸν μὴν οὐδ’ οὕτω γίγνεται. δεόντως οὖν εἴρηται τοῖς παλαιοῖς ὑγροτάτη μὲν ἡ πιμελὴ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 3.5:

But if these things were so, none of the hard parts in a human body would be moist. For it is not possible for such great cooling to occur in it that something would become hardened through solidification. For what was previously fluid will at some point arrive at a certain consistency, just as fat does. For the oily substance in blood, being fluid and greasy, when it comes to be in a cold place, solidifies, though it does not even thus become hard. Therefore it has been rightly said by the ancients that fat is the moistest [substance]

---

**Brief notes:**
- The text appears to be discussing the physical properties of bodily substances, particularly regarding the relationship between temperature, moisture, and hardness
- "πῆξιν" (solidification/coagulation) is a technical term in ancient medical and natural philosophical texts
- The argument follows a logical structure: if X were true, then Y would follow; but Y doesn't occur because Z; therefore the original premise needs qualification
paragraphs.openai_translation: But if these things were so, none of the hard parts among the components in the human body would be moist. For it is not possible for so great a cooling to occur in it as to harden something by coagulation [congealing]. For what was previously fluid will at some point attain a certain consistency, as fat [pimelē] does. For the oily element in the blood, being fluid and unctuous, when it comes to be in a cold place, congeals; yet even so it does not become hard. Accordingly, it has been rightly said by the ancients that fat is the most moist.

paragraphs.content: δεύτερον δ’ ἐπ’ αὐτῇ τὸ σαρκῶδες γένος εἴδη δ’ αὐτοῦ πλείω. πρώτη μὲν ἡ κυρίως ὀνομαζομένη σὰρξ ἣν οὐκ ἂν εὕροις καθ’ αὑτὴν οὐδαμόθι τοῦ σώματος ἀλλ’ ἔστιν ἀεὶ μόριον μυός. ἐφεξῆς δὲ ἑκάστου τῶν σπλάγχνων ἡ ἴδιος οὐσία. καλοῦσι δ’ αὐτὴν οἱ περὶ τὸν Ἐρασίστρατον παρέγχυμα καὶ ὡς περὶ μικροῦ καὶ φαύλου διανοοῦνται πράγματος οὐκ εἰδότες ὡς ἡ καθ’ ἕκαστον σπλάγχνον ἐνέργεια τῆς σαρκὸς ταύτης ἐστίν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 3.6:

Second after it [comes] the fleshy kind, and it has several forms. First is flesh properly so called, which you would not find anywhere in the body by itself, but it is always a part of a muscle. Next is the particular substance of each of the viscera. The followers of Erasistratus call this *parenchyma* [the tissue poured in beside], and they think of it as something small and insignificant, not knowing that the function of each visceral organ belongs to this flesh.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Second after this comes the fleshy kind, and it has several forms. First is what is properly called “flesh,” which you would not find anywhere in the body by itself, but it is always a part of a muscle. Next is the peculiar substance of each of the viscera [internal organs]. Those around Erasistratus call it parenchyma [the organ’s own tissue], and they think of it as something slight and trivial, not realizing that the specific activity [energeia, functional operation] of each organ belongs to this flesh.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ τούτων μὲν οὔπω νῦν ὁ καιρός. ὅτι δ’ αὐτὸ τὸ ἴδιον ἐγκεφάλου σῶμα καὶ πνεύμονος ἐφεξῆς ἐστι τῇ πιμελῇ καθ’ ὑγρότητα, τῇ μαλακότητι τεκμαίρεσθαι πάρεστιν. οὐ γὰρ δὴ ὑπὸ ψυχροῦ γε πέπηγεν, ὅτι μηδὲ θερμῷ χεῖται. πλησίον δὲ τούτων καὶ ὁ μυελὸς τὴν φύσιν ἐστὶν, οὐ μὴν ὁμοιογενὴς ὁ καθ’ ἕκαστον ὀστοῦν μυελὸς ἐγκεφάλῳ τε καὶ νωτιαίῳ.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But now is not yet the time for these matters. However, that the proper substance itself of the brain and lung is next in sequence to fat in terms of moisture, it is possible to judge by their softness. For certainly it has not been solidified by cold, since it does not melt by heat either. And close to these in nature is also the marrow, though the marrow in each individual bone is not of the same kind [homogeneous] as the brain and spinal cord.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
But the time for these matters is not yet.

That the peculiar substance of the brain itself—and, next after it, the lung—is greasy [pimelē: fatty/oily] owing to its moisture can be inferred from its softness. For it has not, in fact, been congealed by cold, since neither is it melted by heat. And the marrow too is close to these in its nature, though the marrow in each individual bone is not homogeneous with the brain and the spinal [marrow].

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἐγκέφαλος μὲν καὶ νωτιαῖος ἐκ ταὐτοῦ γένους· οἱ δ’ ἄλλοι ξύμπαντες μυελοὶ φύσεως ἑτέρας εἰσίν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
But the brain and the spinal cord are of the same kind; however, all the other marrows are of a different nature.

---

**Alternative translation:**

But while the brain and spinal marrow are from the same genus, all the other marrows are of a different nature.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But the brain and the spinal [marrow] are of the same kind, whereas all the other marrows, without exception, are of a different nature.

paragraphs.content: ὑγρότερος μέν ἐστι καὶ θερμότερος ἐγκέφαλος νωτιαίου καὶ διὰ τοῦτο καὶ μαλακώτερος· καὶ μέντοι καὶ αὐτοῦ τοῦ ἐγκεφάλου τὰ πρόσθεν ὑγρότερα τοσοῦτον ὅσονπερ καὶ μαλακώτερα. πάντα μὴν ταῦτα δέρματος οὐχ ὑγρότερα μόνον ἀλλὰ καὶ ψυχρότερα καὶ ὅλως ἄναιμον πᾶν ἐναίμου ψυχρότερον. ἐγγυτάτω δ’ ἐστὶ δέρματος καὶ ἡ τῶν μαλακῶν νεύρων φύσις· ἡ δὲ τῶν σκληρῶν οἷόν περ αὐτὸ τὸ δέρμα καθ’ ὑγρότητα δηλονότι καὶ ξηρότητα. θερμότητι γὰρ ἀπολείπεται τοσοῦτον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 3.10:

The brain is more moist and hotter than the spinal marrow, and for this reason it is also softer; and moreover, the front parts of the brain itself are more moist to the same degree as they are softer. All these parts, however, are not only more moist than skin but also colder, and in general everything bloodless is colder than what contains blood. The nature of the soft sinews [tendons/nerves] is closest to skin; but that of the hard ones is like skin itself, obviously in respect to moisture and dryness. For in heat it falls short by so much—

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end. The word "sinews" (νεύρων) in ancient Greek medical texts can refer to sinews, tendons, or what we would call nerves, as these were not clearly distinguished in ancient anatomy.
paragraphs.openai_translation: The brain is wetter and hotter than the spinal cord [spinal marrow], and for that reason also softer. Moreover, within the brain itself the front parts are wetter by just as much as they are softer. All these, however, are not only wetter than skin, but also colder, and altogether bloodless; whatever has no blood is colder than what has blood. Closest to skin, too, is the nature of the soft “neura” [soft neura = nerves]; whereas the nature of the hard “neura” is like the skin itself, with respect, clearly, to moisture and dryness [hard neura = tendons/ligaments]. For it falls short in heat by just so much.

paragraphs.content: ὅσον εἰκὸς ἀπολείπεσθαι τὸ παντελῶς ἄναιμον ἐναίμου σώματος. ἡ δὲ τοῦ σπληνὸς καὶ ἡ τῶν νεφρῶν καὶ ἡ τοῦ ἥπατος σὰρξ ὑγροτέρα μὲν τοσούτῳ δέρματος ὅσῳ καὶ μαλακωτέρα· θερμοτέρα δὲ ὅσῳ καὶ πολυαιμοτέρα. καὶ μὴν καὶ ἡ τῆς καρδίας σὰρξ ἁπάντων μὲν τούτων ξηροτέρα τοσοῦτον ὅσον καὶ σκληροτέρα· θερμοτέρα δὲ οὐ τούτων μόνον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

as much as it is reasonable for the completely bloodless to fall short of a blood-containing body. But the flesh of the spleen and that of the kidneys and that of the liver is moister than skin to the same degree that it is also softer; and it is hotter to the degree that it is also more full of blood. And indeed the flesh of the heart is drier than all these to the same degree that it is also harder; but it is hotter not only than these
paragraphs.openai_translation: By as much as it is reasonable that what is entirely bloodless should fall short of a blooded body. And the flesh of the spleen, of the kidneys, and of the liver is moister than the skin [derma] by the same degree that it is also softer; and it is hotter by the same degree that it is more full of blood [polyaimoteron]. And indeed, the flesh of the heart is, of all these, drier by as much as it is also harder; and hotter not only than these...

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ πάντων ἁπλῶς τῶν τοῦ σώματος μορίων. καί σοι τοῦτο σαφῶς ἔνεστιν αἰσθήσει μαθεῖν ἐν ταῖς τῶν ζώων ἀνατομαῖς ταῖς κατὰ τὸ στέρνον γιγνομέναις εἰς τὴν ἀριστερὰν κοιλίαν τῆς καρδίας καθέντι τοὺς δακτύλους· εὑρήσεις γὰρ οὐκ ὀλίγῳ τινὶ τὸ χωρίον τοῦτο τῶν ἄλλων ἁπάντων θερμότερον.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But also of all the parts of the body without exception. And you can clearly learn this through sense perception in the dissections of animals that are performed at the chest, by inserting your fingers into the left ventricle of the heart; for you will find that this region is considerably warmer than all the other parts.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Indeed, than all the parts of the body without exception. And you can learn this clearly by sense-perception in the dissections of animals performed through the sternum [breastbone], by inserting your fingers into the left ventricle of the heart; for you will find this region considerably hotter than all the others.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἡ μὲν τοῦ ἥπατός τε καὶ σπληνὸς καὶ νεφρῶν καὶ πνεύμονος σὰρξ ἁπλῆ τὴν φύσιν ἐστὶ ταῖς καθ’ ἕκαστον σπλάγχνον ἀρτηρίαις καὶ φλεψὶ καὶ νεύροις περιπεφυκυῖα. τῆς καρδίας δ’ οὐχ ἁπλοῦν τὸ τῆς σαρκὸς εἶδος ἀλλ’ οἷαί πέρ εἰσιν αἱ ἐν τοῖς μυσὶν ἶνες αἷς ἡ σὰρξ περιπέπηγε τοιαῦται κᾀν τῇ καρδίᾳ. πλὴν οὐ ταὐτὸ γένος τῶν ἰνῶν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 3.13:

But the flesh of the liver, spleen, kidneys, and lung is simple in nature, having grown around the arteries, veins, and nerves in each internal organ. The form of the flesh of the heart, however, is not simple, but just as there are fibers in the muscles around which the flesh has solidified, such fibers exist also in the heart. Except that the type of fibers is not the same—

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end, suggesting continuation in the following passage.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But the flesh of the liver, spleen, kidneys, and lung is simple by nature, having grown around the arteries, veins, and nerves [i.e., vessels and cords supplying each organ] belonging to each organ in particular. The heart’s flesh, however, is not of a simple kind; rather, just as there are fibers in the muscles upon which the flesh is set, such fibers are present in the heart as well—except that the fibers are not of the same kind.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ αἱ μὲν ἐν τοῖς μυσὶν νεύρων εἰσὶ καὶ συνδέσμων μόρια. τῆς καρδίας δὲ τὸ τῶν ἰνῶν γένος ἴδιον ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ τῆς ἀρτηρίας καὶ φλεβὸς χιτῶνος ἐντέρων τε καὶ γαστρὸς καὶ μήτρας καὶ τῶν κύστεων ἑκατέρων. ἔστι γὰρ οὖν δὴ κᾀν τούτοις ἅπασι τοῖς ὀργάνοις τὴν οἰκείαν σάρκα περιπεπηγυῖαν ἰδεῖν ταῖς ἰδίαις αὐτῶν ἰσίν. αὗται μὲν οὖν αἱ σάρκες θερμότεραι τοῦ δέρματος ὑπάρχουσιν αἱ δ’ ἶνες αἱ μὲν ὀλίγῳ τινὶ μᾶλλον αἱ δ’ ἧττον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 3.14:

But the fibers in the muscles are parts of sinews and ligaments. The type of fibers in the heart, however, is distinctive, just as is also that of the tunic of the artery and vein, and of the intestines and stomach and uterus and each of the two bladders. For indeed it is possible to see in all these organs their own flesh solidified around their own fibers. Now these fleshes are warmer than the skin, while the fibers are some somewhat more so and others less so.

---

**Brief notes:**
- [ἶνες (ines) = fibers, the structural filaments in tissues]
- [χιτῶνος (chitonos) = tunic, the membranous coat or layer of vessels and organs]
- [κύστεων ἑκατέρων = "each of the two bladders," likely referring to the urinary bladder and gallbladder]
paragraphs.openai_translation: But the ones in the muscles are parts of nerves and ligaments [neuron = sinew/nerve; syndesmos = ligament]. The kind of fibers [inai] in the heart is of a peculiar sort, as is that of the tunic [chitōn] of the artery and vein, and of the intestines and stomach and womb, and of both bladders [i.e., urinary and gall]. For indeed, in all these organs as well one may see their own proper flesh fixed round about with their own fibers. These fleshes are warmer than the skin, and the fibers—some a little more so, others less.

paragraphs.content: βραχὺ δέρματος ψυχρότεραί τέ εἰσι καὶ ξηρότεραι τινὲς δ’ ὅμοιαι κατὰ πᾶν εἰσι τῇ τοῦ δέρματος οὐσίᾳ. πάντες δ’ ὑμένες ἤδη ξηρότεροι δέρματος ὥσπερ γε καὶ αἱ περὶ τὸν ἐγκέφαλόν τε καὶ τὸν νωτιαῖον μήνιγγες· ὑμένες γὰρ δὴ καὶ αἵδε. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ σύνδεσμοι πάντες εἰς ὅσον σκληρότεροι δέρματος εἰς τοσοῦτο καὶ ξηρότεροι. καὶ οἱ τένοντες δὲ κᾂν τῶν συνδέσμων εἰσὶ μαλακώτεροι
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

A little colder and drier than skin, while some are similar in every respect to the substance of skin. But all membranes are now drier than skin, just as indeed are the meninges [membranes] around both the brain and the spinal cord; for these too are membranes. And furthermore, all ligaments are drier to the extent that they are harder than skin. And the tendons, even though they are softer than the ligaments,
paragraphs.openai_translation: Those that are a little short of skin [i.e., slightly inferior to skin in character] are both colder and drier, while some are in every respect like the substance of the skin. And all membranes [hymenes] are in fact drier than skin, as indeed are the coverings about the brain and the spinal cord, for these too are membranes [meninges]. Moreover, all ligaments [sundesmoi], in proportion as they are harder than skin, are by so much also drier. And the tendons [tenontes], even if they are softer than the ligaments...

paragraphs.content: δέρματος γοῦν ἐναργῶς ἤδη σκληρότεροι. χόνδροι δὲ μετὰ τοὺς συνδέσμους εἰσί. καί τι μέσον ἀμφοῖν σῶμα· καλοῦσι δ’ αὐτὸ νευροχονδρώδη σύνδεσμον ἔνιοι τῶν ἀνατομικῶν. ἔστι δὲ τοῦτο σύνδεσμος σκληρὸς καὶ χονδρώδης.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Cartilages, at any rate, are clearly already harder than skin. And after the ligaments come the cartilages. And there is a certain body intermediate between both; some of the anatomists call it a neuro-chondroid [nerve-cartilaginous] ligament. This is a ligament that is hard and cartilaginous.
paragraphs.openai_translation: At any rate, [the ligaments] are already plainly harder than the skin. And the cartilages come after the ligaments. There is also a substance intermediate between the two; some of the anatomists call it a “neurochondrous ligament” [i.e., a ligament of sinewy (neural = tendon/sinew) and cartilaginous character]. And this is a ligament that is hard and cartilaginous.

paragraphs.content: ὀστοῦν δὲ τὸ πάντων ξηρότατον ὃ καλύπτει τὸ δέρμα. καὶ τῶν ἐξεχόντων αὐτοῦ ξηροτάτη μὲν ἡ θρὶξ ἐφεξῆς δὲ κέρας εἶτ’ ὄνυχές τε καὶ ὁπλαὶ καὶ πλῆκτρα καὶ ῥάμφη
paragraphs.claude_translation: Bone is the driest of all things that the skin covers. And of its projecting parts, hair is the driest, then horn, and next nails and hooves and spurs and beaks.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And the bone is the driest of all, the thing that the skin covers. And of the things that project from it [i.e., from the skin], the driest is hair; next comes horn; then nails and hooves [hoof = ὁπλή], and spurs [cock spurs], and beaks.

paragraphs.content: καὶ ὅσα τοιαῦτα καθ’ ἕκαστον τῶν ἀλόγων ζώων ἐστὶ μόρια. τῶν δὲ χυμῶν ὁ μὲν χρηστότατός τε καὶ οἰκειότατός ἐστι τὸ αἷμα. τούτου δὲ οἷον ὑπόστασίς τε καὶ ἰλὺς χολὴ ἡ μέλαινα. ταῦτ’ ἄρα καὶ ψυχροτέρα τέ ἐστι καὶ παχυτέρα τοῦ αἵματος· ἡ δέ γε ξανθὴ θερμοτέρα μακρῷ. ψυχρότατον δὲ καὶ ὑγρότατον ἁπάντων τῶν ἐν τῷ ζώῳ τὸ φλέγμα. κριτήριον δὲ καὶ τῆς τούτου διαγνώσεως ἡ ἁφὴ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 3.18:

And all such parts as these are in each of the irrational animals. Of the humors [bodily fluids], the most useful and most proper is the blood. And of this, black bile is like a sediment and dregs. Therefore it is both colder and thicker than blood; but yellow bile is much hotter. The coldest and most fluid of all things in the animal is phlegm. And touch is the criterion for discerning this as well.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And such things are the parts of this sort in each of the nonrational animals. Of the humors [bodily fluids], the best and most native [most proper to the animal] is blood. Of this, black bile is, as it were, the sediment and dregs. This, then, is both colder and thicker than blood, whereas the yellow [bile] is by far hotter. Phlegm is the coldest and moistest of all the constituents within the animal. And the criterion for the discernment of this, too, is touch.

paragraphs.content: καθάπερ καὶ Ἱπποκράτης ἐν τῷ περὶ φύσεως ἀνθρώπου πεποίηται λόγῳ.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Just as Hippocrates has done in his treatise *On the Nature of Man*.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Just as Hippocrates too has done in the discourse On the Nature of Man [title of a Hippocratic treatise].

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὅτι μὲν ψυχρὸν, ἡ ἁφὴ μόνη γιγνώσκει· τὸ δ’, ὅτι καὶ ὑγρὸν, ἁφή τε ἅμα καὶ ὄψις καὶ λογισμός. ἁφὴ μὲν καὶ ὄψις, ὅτι τοιοῦτο ἑκατέρῳ φαίνεται· ὁ λογισμὸς δὲ, διορισάμενος, ὡς οὐ πλήθει θερμότητος, ἀλλ’ ὑγρότητι συμφύτῳ τοιοῦτο ἐγένετο. περὶ μὲν οὖν τῶν κατὰ τὸ σῶμα μορίων τε καὶ χυμῶν ᾧδε ἔχει.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But that it is cold, touch alone perceives; but that it is also moist, touch and sight and reasoning [perceive] together. Touch and sight [perceive it] because it appears such to each of them; but reasoning [perceives it] by determining that it became such not through an abundance of heat, but through innate moisture. Concerning the parts and humors of the body, then, the matter stands thus.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But that it is cold, touch alone recognizes; that it is also moist, touch together with sight and reasoning. Touch and sight, because to each it appears such; reasoning, after drawing the distinction, [judges] that it became such not by a quantity of heat, but by inborn moisture [συμφυτός = connate]. So, with regard to the parts of the body and the humors [χυμοί = bodily fluids], the case stands thus.

paragraphs.content: Περὶ δὲ τῶν ἑπομένων ταῖς κράσεσιν ἐφεξῆς χρὴ διελθεῖν. ἕπεται μὲν γὰρ καὶ τὰ προειρημένα, μᾶλλον δ’ ἀχώριστα τελέως ἐστὶ, ξηρῷ μὲν σκληρότης, ὑγρῷ δὲ μαλακότης, ὅταν γε μετὰ χλιαρᾶς ᾖ θερμότητος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.1:

Concerning the things that follow upon the mixtures [krasis], it is necessary to go through them in order. For the previously mentioned things also follow, but rather they are completely inseparable: hardness belongs to the dry, and softness to the moist, at least when it is accompanied by mild warmth.

---

**Brief notes:**
- [krasis]: temperaments or mixtures of qualities (hot, cold, wet, dry) in medical/philosophical theory
- The text discusses the necessary properties that accompany different temperamental mixtures in humoral theory
paragraphs.openai_translation: As for the properties that accompany the mixtures [krasis: the compositional “temperament” of qualities], we must next go through them in order. For those previously mentioned also follow—and indeed are entirely inseparable—namely, hardness with the dry, and softness with the moist, provided that the heat is mild [tepid warmth].

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ παχύτητες ἕξεως καὶ λεπτότητες ἕπονται κράσεσιν οὐ ταῖς συμφύτοις μόνον ἀλλὰ κᾂν ἐξ ἔθους μακροῦ τις ἐπίκτητος γένηται. πολλοὺς γὰρ καὶ τῶν φύσει λεπτῶν ἐθεασάμην παχυνθέντας καὶ τῶν παχέων λεπτυνθέντας τοὺς μὲν ἀργίᾳ τε καὶ ἁβρᾷ διαίτῃ τὴν ὅλην κρᾶσιν ὑπαλλάξαντας ἐπὶ τὸ ὑγρότερον τοὺς δὲ ἐν ταλαιπωρίαις πλείοσι καὶ φροντίσι καὶ διαίτῃ λεπτῇ καταξηρανθέντας. εἰρήσεται δὲ καὶ τούτων τὰ γνωρίσματα. κάλλιον γὰρ ἡμᾶς αὐτοὺς ἔκ τινων σημείων ὁρμωμένους πρὶν παρ’ ἑτέρου πυθέσθαι
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.2:

But indeed both thickness and thinness of bodily condition follow upon mixtures [of humors/temperaments], not only the innate ones but also if some acquired mixture should come about from long habit. For I have observed many people who are naturally thin becoming thick, and thick people becoming thin—some having altered their entire mixture toward the more moist through idleness and luxurious living, others having been dried out through numerous hardships and anxieties and a meager diet. The signs of these conditions will also be discussed. For it is better for us, proceeding from certain indicators, before learning from another person...

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end of this paragraph]
paragraphs.openai_translation: But thicknesses and thinnesses of habit [hexis: bodily condition] also follow upon mixtures [kraseis: humoral temperaments], not only those that are inborn but even when one becomes acquired through long-standing habit. For I have seen many of those naturally thin grow stout, and of the stout grow thin—some having altered their whole mixture toward the wetter through idleness and a luxurious regimen [diaita: overall mode of living], others dried out through many hardships and cares and a meager regimen. The signs of these, too, will be set forth; for it is better that we ourselves proceed on the basis of certain indications before inquiring it from someone else.

paragraphs.content: δύνασθαι γνωρίζειν εἰ φύσει τοιοῦτος ἦν ὁ ἄνθρωπος ἢ ἐξ ἔθους ἐγένετο. διδάσκαλος δὲ καὶ τούτων τῶν γνωρισμάτων ὥσπερ οὖν καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ἁπάντων ὁ θαυμάσιος Ἱπποκράτης.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

to be able to discern whether a person was such by nature or came to be so through habit. And the teacher of these signs of recognition, just as indeed of all other things, is the marvelous Hippocrates.
paragraphs.openai_translation: To be able to determine whether the person was such by nature or became so through habit [ἔθος: habit/custom]. And the teacher of these signs [γνωρίσματα: diagnostic signs], as indeed of all the others as well, is the admirable Hippocrates.

paragraphs.content: ὅσοι μὲν γὰρ εὐρυτέρας ἔχουσι τὰς φλέβας, θερμότεροι φύσει· ὅσοι δὲ στενοτέρας, ψυχρότεροι. τοῦ θερμοῦ γὰρ ἔργον ἀνευρῦναί τε καὶ διαφυσῆσαι ταύτας. ὥστ’ εὐλόγως εἰς ταὐτὸ.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
For those who have wider veins are hotter by nature; while those who have narrower ones are colder. For it is the function of heat to dilate and expand these [veins]. Consequently, it is reasonable [that they come] to the same thing.

---

**Brief notes:**
- [veins] φλέβας can refer to blood vessels generally
- [that they come] The phrase "εἰς ταὐτὸ" (literally "to the same thing") is elliptical, suggesting that the two observations (vein width and temperature) are causally connected or amount to the same conclusion
paragraphs.openai_translation: For all who have broader veins are by nature warmer; whereas those who have narrower [veins] are colder. For it is the function of heat to widen and to distend these [veins]. Thus, reasonably, it comes to the same thing [i.e., the two accounts agree].

paragraphs.content: ὡς τὸ πολὺ συντρέχει στενότης μὲν φλεβῶν ἕξει πιμελώδει τε καὶ παχυτέρᾳ λεπτότης δ’ ἕξεως εὐρύτητι φλεβῶν. εἰ δ’ ἅμα τις εἴη πιμελώδης τε καὶ παχὺς καὶ τὰς φλέβας εὐρείας ἔχοι δι’ ἔθος οὗτος οὐ φύσει πιμελώδης ἐγένετο· ὥσπερ εἰ καὶ στενὰς μὲν ἔχοι τὰς φλέβας εἴη δὲ ἰσχνὸς οὐδ’ οὗτος ἐξ ἀνάγκης φύσει τοιοῦτος. κᾀν τοῖσι λιμαγχονικοῖσι φησὶ τὰς μετριότητας ἀπὸ τούτων σκεπτέον τῆς τῶν ἀγγείων εὐρύτητος δηλονότι καὶ στενότητος
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.6:

For the most part, narrowness of veins coincides with a fatty and rather thick constitution, while thinness of constitution coincides with width of veins. But if someone should be at the same time both fatty and thick and have wide veins, this person did not become fatty by nature but through habit; just as if someone should have narrow veins but be thin, neither is this person necessarily such by nature. And in the case of those who suffer from ravenous hunger [bulimia], he says that one must examine the moderate conditions based on these factors—clearly the width and narrowness of the blood vessels.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For the most part, narrowness of the veins goes along with a fatty and thicker habit, while thinness of habit goes with breadth of the veins. But if someone at once is fatty and stout and has wide veins through habituation, this man did not become fatty by nature; just as, even if he had narrow veins and were lean, neither is he of necessity such by nature. And in the case of the limanchonic patients [those subject to “limanchonia,” i.e., attacks associated with hunger/choking], he says one should determine the proper mean on the basis of these factors—namely, the breadth and the narrowness of the vessels.

paragraphs.content: οὐ τῆς ἄλλης ἕξεως ὅλου τοῦ σώματος. οἱ μὲν γὰρ στενὰς ἔχοντες τὰς φλέβας ὀλίγαιμοί τέ εἰσι καὶ μακρὰς ἀσιτίας οὐ φέρουσιν ὅσοις δ’ εὐρεῖαι καὶ πλῆθος αἵματος τούτοις ἔνεστι καὶ χωρὶς βλάβης ἀσιτοῦσιν. αἱ δ’ αἰτίαι τῶν εἰρημένων ἤδη μὲν δῆλαι κᾂν ἐγὼ μὴ λέγω τοῖς γε προσέχουσι τὸν νοῦν. ἐπεὶ δ’ οὐ πάντες προσέχουσιν ἀναγκαῖον ἴσως ἐστί τι καὶ δι’ ἐκείνους εἰπεῖν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

not of the other condition of the whole body. For those who have narrow veins are both deficient in blood and do not tolerate long periods of fasting, but those in whom the veins are wide and there is an abundance of blood, in these people it is present and they fast without harm. The causes of what has been said are already clear even if I do not speak them, at least to those who pay attention. But since not everyone pays attention, it is perhaps necessary to say something on account of those people as well.
paragraphs.openai_translation: —not from any other condition of the whole body. For those who have narrow veins are low in blood [oligaimoi: deficient in blood] and do not endure long fasts, whereas those whose veins are wide and have an abundance of blood can do so and go without food without harm. The causes of what has been said are already clear, even if I do not state them, to those who pay attention. But since not all pay attention, it is perhaps necessary to say something also for their sake.

paragraphs.content: ὅσον ἐν αἵματι πῖόν τέ ἐστι καὶ κοῦφον καὶ λεπτὸν ἐν μὲν τοῖς θερμοτέροις σώμασι τροφὴ γίνεται τοῦτο τῷ θερμῷ κατὰ δὲ τὰ ψυχρότερα διασώζεται. καὶ τῶν φλεβῶν ἔξω διηθούμενον ἐπειδὰν μὲν ψυχροῖς περιπέσῃ μορίοις οἷοί περ οἱ ὑμένες εἰσὶν ἐκείνοις περιπήγνυται· κατὰ δὲ τὰ φύσει θερμότερα μόρια (τοιαῦτα δ’ ἐστὶ δηλονότι τὰ σαρκώδη,) δαπανᾶταί τε πρὸς τοῦ θερμοῦ καὶ διαφορεῖται
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.8:

Whatever in the blood is rich and light and thin—in the hotter bodies this becomes nourishment by means of the heat, but in the colder bodies it is preserved. And when it is filtered outside the veins, whenever it encounters cold parts such as the membranes are, it congeals around them; but in the naturally hotter parts (and such parts are clearly the fleshy ones), it is both consumed by the heat and dispersed.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Whatever in the blood is oily [fatty], light, and fine, in hotter bodies this becomes nourishment for the heat, whereas in colder ones it is preserved. And when, having been filtered out beyond the veins, it encounters cold parts—such as the membranes—it congeals upon them; but in the parts that are by nature warmer (and such, plainly, are the fleshy parts), it is expended by the heat and carried off [dissipated].

paragraphs.content: πλὴν εἴ ποτε πρὸς τῷ ψυχροτέρῳ τῆς κράσεως ἔτι καὶ τὸ τῆς διαίτης ἀταλαίπωρον ἐπιθρέψει ἔτι καὶ αὐτοῖς τοῖς σαρκώδεσι μορίοις πιμελήν. οὕτω τοι καὶ τὰ φωλεύοντα ζῶα πολλάκις εὑρίσκεται πιμελωδέστερα. καὶ γυναῖκες ἀνδρῶν ὅτι καὶ τῇ κράσει ψυχρότερον ἄῤῥενος τὸ θῆλυ καὶ οἰκουρεῖ τὰ πολλά.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

However, if ever in addition to a colder temperament, a soft lifestyle without hardship should also build up fat even in the fleshy parts themselves. Thus indeed animals that live in burrows are often found to be more fatty. And women more than men, because the female is colder in temperament than the male and for the most part stays at home.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Except that whenever, in addition to a colder state of the krasis [mixture/temperament], an unlabored regimen [diaita: lifestyle/diet] is also added, it fosters fat even in the fleshy parts themselves. Thus, too, animals that den are often found to be fatter; and women are [fatter] than men, because the female is colder in krasis than the male and for the most part stays indoors [i.e., is more sedentary].

paragraphs.content: ὅσαι μὲν οὖν ἕξεις σωμάτων εὔκρατοί τέ εἰσι φύσει καὶ πονοῦσι τὰ μέτρια, ταύτας ἀναγκαῖον εὐσάρκους γίνεσθαι, τοῦτ’ ἔστι πάντῃ συμμέτρους.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Therefore, those bodily conditions which are naturally well-tempered and which undergo moderate exercise, these necessarily become well-fleshed, that is to say, proportionate in every respect.

**Alternative translation:**

Therefore, those constitutions of bodies which are naturally well-balanced and which engage in moderate exertion, these must necessarily become well-fleshed, that is, symmetrical in all respects.

[Note: εὔκρατος refers to a good mixture or balance of humors/qualities; εὔσαρκος means having good/healthy flesh; σύμμετρος indicates proper proportion or symmetry]
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, all bodily constitutions that are by nature well-balanced [eukrasia: good humoral mixture] and undertake moderate exertion must become well-fleshed [well-muscled], that is, proportionate in every respect.

paragraphs.content: ὅσαις δὲ τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν αὔταρκες ἀπολείπεται δ’ οὐ πολλῷ τῆς ἄκρας συμμετρίας τὸ θερμὸν αὗται πολύσαρκοι γίνονται. πολύσαρκοι δὲ καὶ ὅσαι φύσει μὲν εὔκρατοι ῥᾳθύμως δὲ καὶ ἀπόνως βιοῦσιν. εἴρηται γὰρ δὴ καὶ τοῦτο κάλλιστα πρὸς τῶν παλαιῶν ὡς ἐπίκτητοι φύσεις εἰσὶ τὰ ἔθη. καὶ οὐδὲν ἴσως διοίσει τοῦθ’ ἅπαξ εἰρηκότας νῦν μηκέτι διορίζεσθαι καθ’ ἕκαστον κεφάλαιον εἴτε φύσει ψυχρότερος εἴτ’ ἐξ ἔθους ὅδε τις ἐγένετο ἀλλὰ τοῦτο μὲν ἀπολείπειν τοῖς ἀναγινώσκουσιν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.11:

Those women in whom the moisture remains sufficient but the heat falls short by not much of the perfect balance, these become fleshy. And those who are well-balanced by nature but live lazily and without exertion also become fleshy. For this too has been most excellently stated by the ancients, that habits are acquired natures. And perhaps it will make no difference, having said this once, not to distinguish any longer in each chapter whether someone has become colder by nature or from habit, but rather to leave this to the readers.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And those in whom the moist element is sufficient, while the hot [element] falls short by no great amount of perfect proportion, these become very fleshy. Fleshy too are those who, though well-tempered [in bodily mixture] by nature, live lazily and without exertion. For it has been most aptly said by the ancients that habits are acquired natures. And perhaps it will make no difference, since we have said this once, not to distinguish any further in each section whether someone became colder by nature or from habit, but to leave this point to the readers.

paragraphs.content: αὐτὸν δὲ βραχυλογίας ἕνεκα τὰς οἰκείας ἑκάστῃ τῶν κράσεων ἕξεις τοῦ σώματος ἐπελθεῖν. εἰσὶ δή τινες ἰσχνοί τε ἅμα καὶ φλέβας ἔχοντες μικρὰς ἀλλ’ εἰ τέμοις ἐξ αὐτῶν ἡντιναοῦν προσπίπτει πιμελὴ δῆλον ὡς ὑποπεφυκυῖα τῷ δέρματι κατὰ τὸν ἔνδον ὑμένα. σπάνιον μὲν οὖν ἐπ’ ἀνδρῶν τὸ τοιοῦτο
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.12:

But for the sake of brevity, [let us] examine the bodily conditions proper to each of the temperaments. Now there are certain people who are at once thin and have small veins, but if you were to cut any one of them, fat appears, clearly having grown beneath the skin along the inner membrane. Such a condition is rare in men.

---

**Brief notes:**
- κράσεων (kraseōn) = "temperaments" or "mixtures" [referring to the humoral theory of bodily constitutions]
- πιμελή (pimelē) = "fat" [medical term for adipose tissue]
- The subject of ἐπελθεῖν (epelthein) "to examine" is implied from context (likely the author or reader)
paragraphs.openai_translation: I will, for the sake of brevity, go over the bodily dispositions [hexeis: conditions] appropriate to each of the temperaments [krasis: mixture]. There are, then, some who are at once lean and have small veins; but if you cut any one of them, fat [pimelē] appears, clearly as having grown beneath the skin along the inner membrane [the inner layer under the skin]. Such a condition is rare among men.

paragraphs.content: ἐπὶ δὲ γυναικῶν καὶ πάνυ πολλάκις εὑρισκόμενον. ἔστι γὰρ καὶ φύσεως ψυχροτέρας καὶ ἀργοτέρου βίου. τὸ τοιοῦτο γνώρισμα. πιμελὴ μὲν γὰρ ἀεὶ διὰ ψύξιν ἕξεως γίνεται· πολυσαρκία δὲ πλήθους αἵματος ἔγγονος· εὐσαρκία δὲ φύσεως εὐκράτου γνώρισμα. πάντως μὲν οὖν οἱ πολύσαρκοι καὶ τὴν πιμελὴν εὐθέως ἔχουσι πλείονα τῶν εὐκράτων· οὐ μὴν ἀνάλογος ἀεὶ ταῖς σαρξὶν ἡ πιμελὴ συναύξεται ἀλλ’ ἔστιν ἰδεῖν τῶν παχέων τοὺς μὲν τὴν σάρκα πλείονα τοὺς δὲ τὴν πιμελὴν ἔχοντας
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.13:

And it is found very frequently indeed in women. For this is a sign of both a colder nature and a more inactive life. The following is the distinguishing feature: fat always develops through coldness of condition; fleshiness, however, is the product of an abundance of blood; but good flesh is a sign of a well-balanced nature. Certainly, then, the fleshy immediately have more fat than those of well-balanced constitution; nevertheless, the fat does not always increase proportionally with the flesh, but it is possible to see among the stout that some have more flesh while others have more fat.

---

**Brief contextual notes:**
- [πιμελή = fat/adipose tissue]
- [σάρξ/σαρκία = flesh/fleshiness, referring to muscle and tissue]
- [εὔκρατος = well-balanced/well-tempered, a key concept in Greek medical theory referring to proper balance of humors]
paragraphs.openai_translation: And among women it is also found very frequently; for they are of a colder constitution and lead a more inactive life. The distinguishing mark of such a condition is as follows. Fat [pimelē: adipose] always comes about through a cooling of the bodily state [psychsis hexeos]; corpulence [polysarkia: excess of flesh] is born of an abundance of blood; and being well-fleshed [eusarcia] is the mark of a well-balanced nature [eukratos]. Accordingly, the corpulent also at once have more fat than those of well-balanced temperament; however, fat does not always increase in proportion along with the flesh, but one can observe among the stout some who have more flesh and others who have more fat.

paragraphs.content: ἐνίοις δὲ ὁμοίως ἄμφω συνηύξηται. τούτοις μὲν οὖν οἷς ὁμοίως ἄμφω συνηύξηται τοσούτῳ πλέον ὑγρόν ἐστιν ὑπὲρ τὴν εὔκρατον φύσιν ὅσον καὶ ψυχρόν. οἷς δ’ ἡ πιμελὴ πλείων τὸ ψυχρὸν ἐπὶ τούτων πλέον ἐστὶν ἤπερ τὸ ὑγρόν· ὥσπερ οἷς ἡ σὰρξ πλείων ὑγρότης μέν ἐστι τοῦ δέοντος πλείων οὐ μὴν καὶ ψύξις.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.14:

In some cases both have increased together equally. Now in those cases where both have increased together equally, there is as much more moisture beyond the well-tempered nature as there is also coldness. But in those in whom the fat is greater, in these cases the cold is more excessive than the moisture; just as in those in whom the flesh is greater, there is more moisture than necessary, but not indeed also coldness.

---

**Brief explanatory notes:**
- [εὔκρατον φύσιν] = "well-tempered nature" refers to the ideal balanced constitution in Greek medical theory
- [πιμελή] = "fat" (adipose tissue)
- [σάρξ] = "flesh" (muscle tissue)
paragraphs.openai_translation: In some people, both have increased equally. Accordingly, in those for whom both have increased alike, they are moister beyond the well-balanced constitution [eukratic nature] by exactly as much as they are also colder. But in those whose fat [pimelē: adipose tissue] is more abundant, the cold exceeds the moist; just as in those whose flesh is more abundant, there is more moisture than is fitting, but not, however, a corresponding coldness.

paragraphs.content: ὅταν γὰρ, ἐν τοῖς οἰκείοις ὅροις μένοντος τοῦ θερμοῦ, προσγένηταί τις αἵματος χρηστοῦ πλεονεξία, πολυσαρκίαν ἀναγκαῖον ἀκολουθῆσαι. τὸ δὲ, ὅσῳ χρὴ πλέον εἶναι τοῦ συμμέτρου τὸ αἷμα, μέτρῳ μὲν οὐχ οἶόν τε μηνῦσαι καὶ σταθμῷ, λόγῳ δ’ ἐγχωρεῖ διελθεῖν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.15:

For whenever, while heat remains within its proper limits, there occurs some excess of good blood, it is necessary that corpulence follow. But by how much the blood ought to be more than the moderate amount, it is not possible to indicate by measure and weight, though it is feasible to go through it by reasoning.

---

**Brief notes:**
- *πολυσαρκία* [polysarkia]: corpulence, fleshiness, obesity
- *χρηστός* [chrēstos]: useful, good (in quality)
- *σύμμετρος* [symmetros]: moderate, proportionate, well-measured
- The passage discusses medical theory about the relationship between blood quantity and bodily condition
paragraphs.openai_translation: For whenever, while the heat remains within its proper bounds, there supervenes some excess of good blood [i.e., healthy, well-tempered blood], it is necessary that corpulence follow. As to how much the blood ought to exceed the proportionate amount, it is not possible to indicate it by measure or by scale, but it can be set forth by reasoning.

paragraphs.content: ὡς ἐπειδὰν μήπω νοσῶδες μηδὲν γένηται τῷ τοῦ ζώου σώματι σύμπτωμα παχυνομένῳ, τὸ πλῆθος τῆς ὑγρότητος τηνικαῦτα τῶν τῆς ὑγείας ὅρων ἐντός ἐστιν. ἐπιδέδεικται γὰρ ἡμῖν καὶ δι’ ἄλλων, ὡς ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστιν, οὐ σμικρὸν ὑποθέσθαι πλάτος τῆς ὑγιεινῆς καταστάσεως.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

So that whenever no morbid condition has yet occurred as a symptom in the body of the living creature as it becomes thickened, the amount of moisture at that time is within the boundaries of health. For it has been demonstrated by us in other works as well that it is necessary to assume no small range [or: latitude] for the healthy state.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, whenever no morbid symptom has yet arisen in the living creature’s body as it becomes thickened, the quantity of moisture at that time is within the bounds of health. For it has been shown by us elsewhere as well that it is necessary to assume no small breadth [latitude, range] of the healthy condition.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ νῦν φαίνεται σχεδὸν ἐν ὅλῳ τῷ λόγῳ, τὴν μὲν εὔκρατόν τε καὶ μέσην φύσιν οἶον κανόνα τῶν ἄλλων ἀεὶ τιθεμένοις, ὅσαι δ’ ἐφ’ ἑκάτερα τῆσδε, δυσκράτους ἀποφαίνουσιν· ὅπερ οὐκ ἂν ἦν, εἰ μὴ τὸ μᾶλλόν τε καὶ ἧττον ἡ ὑγιεινὴ κατάστασις ἐδέχετο.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But even now it appears that throughout nearly the whole discussion, they consistently establish the well-tempered and intermediate nature as a sort of standard for the others, while those [natures] that deviate in either direction from this one they declare to be ill-tempered; which would not be the case, unless the healthy condition admitted of more and less [i.e., degrees of variation].
paragraphs.openai_translation: But even now it appears, almost throughout the whole discussion, that we always set the well-mixed and middle nature [eukratos: balanced mixture] as a kind of rule [kanon: standard] for the others, while those that incline to either side of this we declare to be dyscratic [dyskrasia: ill-balanced mixture]; which would not be the case, if the healthy condition did not admit of “more” and “less.”

paragraphs.content: ἄλλη μὲν γάρ ἐστιν ὑγιεινὴ, ἄλλη δὲ νοσώδης δυσκρασία· νοσώδης μὲν, ἡ ἐπὶ πλεῖστον ἀποκεχωρηκυῖα τῆς εὐκράτου, ὑγιεινὴ δὲ, ἡ ἐπὶ ὀλίγον. ὁρίσαι δὲ οὐδ’ ἐνταῦθα μέτρῳ καὶ σταθμῷ τὸ ποσὸν ἐγχωρεῖ· ἀλλ’ ἱκανὸν γνώρισμα τῆς ὑγιεινῆς δυσκρασίας τὸ μηδέπω μηδεμίαν ἐνέργειαν τοῦ ζώου βεβλάφθαι σαφῶς.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For there is one kind of dyskrasia [imbalance of qualities] that is healthy, and another that is diseased: diseased is the one that has departed to the greatest degree from the well-balanced state, while healthy is the one that has departed only slightly. But even here it is not possible to define the quantity by measure and weight; rather, a sufficient sign of a healthy dyskrasia is that no function of the living creature has yet been clearly impaired.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For there is one kind of dyscrasia [abnormal mixture/imbalance of constituents] that is conducive to health, and another that is morbid. Morbid is that which has departed the farthest from the well-balanced state [eucrasia]; healthful, that which only a little. And even here it is not possible to determine the amount by measure and scale; but a sufficient sign of the healthful dyscrasia is that none of the living being’s functions has yet been clearly impaired.

paragraphs.content: ὅσον δ’ οὖν μεταξὺ τοῦ τε ἄκρως ἐνεργεῖν καὶ τοῦ βεβλάφθαι σαφῶς ἐνέργειαν ὑπάρχει, τοσοῦτο καὶ τῆς ὑγιείας τὸ πλάτος ἐστὶ καὶ τῆς κατ’ αὐτὴν δυσκρασίας. τούτῳ δ’ ἐφεξῆς ἐστιν ἡ νοσώδης δυσκρασία, ὅταν γε διὰ δυσκρασίαν νοσῇ τὸ ζῶον. οὐ γὰρ δὴ διὰ ταύτην γε μόνην, ἀλλὰ καὶ κατ’ ἄλλας διαθέσεις οὐκ ὀλίγας, ὑπὲρ ὧν ἐν τοῖς περὶ τῆς τῶν νοσημάτων διαφορᾶς λογισμοῖς ἐπὶ πλέον εἰρήσεται· νυνὶ δὲ πάλιν ἀναληπτέον τὸν ἐξ ἀρχῆς λόγον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.19:

Now, to the extent that there exists activity between the state of functioning at peak capacity and the state of being clearly impaired, to that same extent is the range both of health and of the dyskrasia [imbalance] associated with it. Next in sequence after this is pathological dyskrasia, namely when the living creature is diseased on account of dyskrasia. For indeed it is not on account of this alone, but also according to quite a few other conditions, concerning which matters more will be said in the discussions about the differentiation of diseases; but now we must take up again the argument from the beginning.
paragraphs.openai_translation: In proportion, then, as there exists a range of activity between functioning at the highest pitch and being manifestly harmed, just so great is the breadth of health and of the dyscrasia [imbalance of mixture/humors] that accords with it. Next to this in order is morbid dyscrasia, whenever the living being is diseased on account of dyscrasia. For it is not on account of this alone, but also in accordance with many other dispositions, concerning which more will be said at greater length in the discussions on the differences of diseases; but for the present we must take up again the argument from the beginning.

paragraphs.content: ὡς γὰρ τοῦ συμφύτου θερμοῦ τὴν ἀρίστην εὐκρασίαν φυλάττοντος αὐξηθὲν τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐν ὅροις ὑγιεινοῖς οὐ πιμελώδη τὸν ἄνθρωπον ἀλλὰ πολύσαρκον ἀποδείκνυσι συναυξομένης μὲν ἐπ’ ὀλίγον καὶ τῆς πιμελῆς ἀλλὰ πολλῷ πλείονι μέτρῳ τῆς σαρκός· οὕτως αὖ πάλιν εἰ τὸ ὑγρόν τε καὶ ξηρὸν ἀκριβῆ τὴν πρὸς ἄλληλα φυλάττοι συμμετρίαν ἧττον δ’ εἴη θερμὸς ὁ ἄνθρωπος ἀνάγκη πιμελῶδες μᾶλλον ἢ πολύσαρκον γενέσθαι τοῦτο τὸ σῶμα. εἰ δ’ αὖ πάλιν αὐξηθείη τὸ θερμὸν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.21:

For just as when the innate heat maintains the best balance of mixture, the moisture that has increased within healthy limits makes the person not fat but fleshy, with the fat also increasing to a small degree but the flesh in a much greater measure; so again, conversely, if the moist and the dry maintain an exact proportion to one another but the person is less hot, this body must necessarily become fatty rather than fleshy. But if, on the other hand, the hot should increase—

---

**Brief contextual notes:**
- [συμφύτου θερμοῦ = "innate heat," a fundamental concept in ancient Greek medical theory referring to the body's natural warmth]
- [εὐκρασία = "balance of mixture" or "good temperament," referring to the proper balance of bodily qualities]
- [πιμελώδης = "fatty" or "adipose"]
- [πολύσαρκος = "fleshy" or "having much flesh/muscle"]
paragraphs.openai_translation: For just as, when the innate heat [the body’s “connate” or inborn heat] maintains the best balance [eukrasia, a well-tempered mixture], an increase of the moist element within healthy limits makes a person not fatty but fleshy, the fat [pimelē] increasing only a little along with it, but the flesh by a much greater measure; so again, if the moist and the dry preserve a precise proportion [symmetria] to one another, but the person is less hot, it is necessary that this body become fatty rather than fleshy. And if, again, the heat were increased—

paragraphs.content: ἐν συμμετρίᾳ μενούσης τῆς ἑτέρας ἀντιθέσεως πλέον ἀπολείπεται τούτου τὸ ζῶον πιμελῆς ἢ σαρκός· ὥσπερ εἰ καὶ κρατήσει ποτὲ τὸ ξηρὸν ἐν συμμετρίᾳ μενούσης τῆς τέρας ἀντιθέσεως ἰσχνότερόν τε ἅμα καὶ σκληρότερον ἔσται τὸ σῶμα. ταῦτ’ εἴρηταί μοι καὶ δῆλον ἤδη ὡς οὐ λόγῳ μόνῳ ἐδείχθησαν αἱ ἁπλαῖ δυσκρασίαι τοῖς τῶν ζώων ὑπάρχουσαι σώμασιν ἀλλὰ καὶ τὰ γνωρίσματα σαφῆ πασῶν ἐστιν· οὔκουν ἐν θερμότητι καὶ ψυχρότητι καὶ μαλακότητι καὶ σκληρότητι μόνον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.22:

When the other opposition remains in balance, the animal lacks more of fat than of flesh in this respect; just as if the dry should at some point prevail while the other opposition remains in balance, the body will be at once both leaner and harder. These things have been stated by me, and it is now clear that the simple dyskrasias [imbalances of qualities] that belong to the bodies of animals have been demonstrated not by reason alone, but also that the distinguishing signs of all of them are evident; therefore not only in heat and coldness and softness and hardness...

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end of this paragraph]
paragraphs.openai_translation: With the other opposition remaining in due proportion [symmetry of one pair of qualities preserved], the animal is left with more of this—fat rather than flesh. Just as, if ever the dry should prevail while the other opposition remains in symmetry, the body will at once be both thinner and harder. These points have been stated by me, and it is now clear that the simple dyscrasias [simple imbalances of temperament] present in the bodies of animals have been shown not by reasoning alone, but that the diagnostic marks of all of them are plain; therefore, not only in heat and cold and softness and hardness...

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ ταῖς ἄλλαις ἁπάσαις τῆς ἕξεως τοῦ ὅλου σώματος διαφοραῖς ὧν ὑπὲρ μὲν τῆς κατὰ λεπτότητα καὶ πάχος εἴρηται νῦν ὑπὲρ δὲ τῶν ἄλλων ἤδη λεγέσθω.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But also with all the other differences in the condition of the whole body—concerning those relating to thinness and thickness, discussion has been given now, but concerning the others, let it now be stated.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But with respect to all the other differences in the hexis [condition/disposition] of the whole body—of which, as regards fineness and thickness, something has now been said—let the discussion now proceed to the rest.

paragraphs.content: Δασεῖα μὲν ἡ θερμὴ καὶ ξηρὰ κρᾶσίς ἐστιν, ἀλλ’ αὕτη μὲν ἐσχάτως· μετρίως δ’ ἡ θερμὴ μὲν, σύμμετρος δὲ κατὰ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν· ὥσπερ γε καὶ ἡ ξηρὰ μὲν, εὔκρατος δὲ κατὰ τὸ θερμόν τε καὶ ψυχρὸν· ἔστι γὰρ καὶ ἥδε μετρίως δασεῖα. ψιλαὶ δὲ τριχῶν αἱ ψυχραὶ πᾶσαι κράσεις, εἴτ’ οὖν ἀμέτρως ἔχοιεν ὑγρότητος, εἴτε μετρίως.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 5.1:

A hairy constitution is one that is hot and dry, but this is so in the extreme degree; moderately hairy, however, is one that is hot but balanced in the other opposition [i.e., neither excessively dry nor moist]; just as also one that is dry but well-tempered with respect to hot and cold—for this too is moderately hairy. Hairless, on the other hand, are all cold constitutions, whether they possess moisture immoderately or moderately.

---

**Brief notes:**
- [κρᾶσις (krasis)] refers to the mixture or temperament of bodily qualities in ancient medical theory
- [ἀντίθεσις (antithesis)] refers to the paired oppositions of qualities: hot-cold and dry-moist
- [εὔκρατος (eukratos)] means well-mixed or balanced in temperament
paragraphs.openai_translation: Hairiness is the hot-and-dry mixture [krâsis: bodily temperament], but this in the extreme; in a moderate way, it is hot indeed, yet proportionate with respect to the other opposition [i.e., wet/dry]. Likewise, a dry mixture, yet well-tempered [eúkratos] with respect to hot and cold; for this too is moderately hair-producing [daséa]. By contrast, all cold mixtures are fine-haired [psilaì trichôn], whether they possess moisture to an excessive degree or in due measure.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἐσχάτως μὲν ἄτριχος ἡ ψυχρὰ καὶ ὑγρὰ κρᾶσίς ἐστιν· ἔλαττον δὲ ταύτης ἡ ψυχρά τε ἅμα καὶ κατὰ τὴν ἑτέραν ἀντίθεσιν εὔκρατος· ἔτι δ’ ἔλαττον ἡ ψυχρὰ καὶ ξηρά. καίτοι δόξει τις ὡς ἐν γῇ ξηρᾷ ταῖς πόαις ἀδύνατόν ἐστι καὶ φυῆναι καὶ τραφῆναι καὶ αὐξηθῆναι τὸν αὐτὸν λόγον κᾀν τῷ δέρματι ταῖς θριξίν· ἔχει δ’ οὐχ οὕτως. γῆ μὲν γὰρ ὡς γῆ ξηρὰ λέγεται
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 5.2:

But the cold and moist mixture is extremely hairless; less so than this is the mixture that is both cold and well-balanced [temperate] with respect to the other opposition [i.e., the dry-moist spectrum]; and still less hairless is the cold and dry mixture. And yet someone might think that just as it is impossible for grasses to sprout, be nourished, and grow in dry earth, so too by the same reasoning it would be impossible for hairs on the skin; but this is not how it is. For earth qua earth is called dry

---

**Brief notes:**
- "κρᾶσις" (krasis) = mixture/blend, referring to the mixture of elemental qualities in humoral theory
- "ἑτέρα ἀντίθεσις" (the other opposition) = refers to the dry-moist axis, as opposed to the hot-cold axis
- "εὔκρατος" = well-balanced/temperate in mixture
- The argument appears to be addressing a potential objection about hair growth in relation to bodily moisture
paragraphs.openai_translation: But in the extreme, the cold-and-wet mixture [krasis: bodily “temperament” or blend] is hairless; less so than this is the cold one that is at the same time well-balanced with respect to the other opposition [i.e., along the moist–dry axis]; and still less so, the cold-and-dry. And yet someone might suppose that, just as in dry soil it is impossible for grasses both to sprout and to be nourished and to grow, by the same reasoning it would be so with hairs on the skin; but it is not so. For “earth,” as earth, is called dry.

paragraphs.content: δέρμα δὲ ὡς δέρμα. καὶ τοίνυν τὸ μὲν ἐν γῇ ξηρὸν ἄνικμον ἐσχάτως ἐστί· τὸ δ’ ἐν ἀνθρώπου σώματι καὶ τῶν ὁμοίων ἀνθρώπῳ ζώων οὐκ ἄνικμον ἐπιτήδειόν τε καὶ μάλιστα πάντων εἰς γένεσιν τριχῶν. ἐκ μὲν γὰρ τῶν ὀστρακοδέρμων τε καὶ μαλακοστράκων οἷον ὀστρέων καὶ καράβων καὶ καρκίνων ὅσα τε φολιδωτὰ τῶν ζώων ἐστὶν ὥσπερ οἱ ὄφεις ἢ λεπιδωτὰ καθάπερ οἱ ἰχθύες
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 5.3:

Skin, however, [differs] as skin [differs from] skin. And indeed, the [skin] in the earth is extremely dry and without moisture; but the [skin] in the body of a human and of animals similar to humans is not without moisture and is suitable and especially of all things for the generation of hair. For from shell-skinned creatures and soft-shelled creatures such as oysters and crayfish and crabs, and all those animals that are scale-covered like snakes or have scales like fish—

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence, suggesting it continues beyond this excerpt. The passage is discussing different types of skin/covering and their varying capacities for producing hair, contrasting the dry skin of the earth with the moist skin of humans and similar animals, and then moving to enumerate creatures with various types of protective coverings that do not produce hair.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Skin, qua skin. Accordingly, what is dry in the earth is utterly barren; but that on the body of a human being and of animals akin to the human is not barren—indeed it is suitable, and most of all, for the production of hairs. For from the shell-skinned [ostrakoderm: shelled creatures] and the soft-shelled [malakostraka: crustaceans], such as oysters, crabs, and crayfish, and from all those animals that are scaly, like snakes, or lepidote [scaly-plated], as are the fishes, ...

paragraphs.content: οὐκ ἂν δύναιτο φύεσθαι θρίξ· ὄντως γάρ ἐστι τὰ τούτων δέρματα τελέως ξηρὰ δίκην ὀστράκου τινὸς ἢ πέτρας. ἐκ μέντοι τῶν μαλακοδέρμων οἷον καὶ ἄνθρωπός ἐστιν ὅσον περ ἂν ξηρότερόν τε καὶ θερμότερον ᾖ τὸ δέρμα τοσόνδε μᾶλλον ἐγχωρεῖ φύεσθαι τρίχας.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

hair would not be able to grow; for in reality the skins of these creatures are completely dry like some kind of shell or stone. However, among soft-skinned animals, such as man is, to the extent that the skin is drier and warmer, to that degree it is more possible for hairs to grow.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Hair could not possibly grow; for indeed the skins of such creatures are completely dry, like some kind of shell or a stone. But among the soft-skinned [i.e., animals with supple skin], such as the human being, the drier and warmer the skin is, by so much the more does it allow hair to grow.

paragraphs.content: ἵνα γὰρ ὡς ἐκεῖνοι προκαλοῦνται τῷ τῆς γῆς ἑπώμεθα παραδείγματι τὰς πόας οὔτ’ ἐν ξηρᾷ καὶ αὐχμώδει πάνυ γῇ φύεσθαι δυνατὸν οὔτ’ ἐν ὑγρᾷ καὶ τελματώδει ἀλλ’ ἐπειδὰν μὲν ἄρχηται δαπανᾶσθαι τὸ περιττὸν τῆς ὑγρότητος ἐκφύονται τῆς γῆς· αὐξάνονται δ’ ἐπὶ πλέον ὅταν καὶ ἥδε ξηραίνηται μετρίως μὲν ἐν τῷ ἦρι τάχιστα δὲ καὶ μέχρι πλείστου κατὰ τὴν ἀρχὴν τοῦ θέρους· ἀποξηραίνονται δὲ τελέως αὐανθείσης τῆς γῆς ἐν μέσῳ τῷ θέρει. καί σοι πάρεστιν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For in order that we may follow the example of the earth, just as those men challenge us to do: grasses are able to grow neither in very dry and parched land nor in wet and marshy land, but when the excess moisture begins to be consumed, they sprout forth from the earth; and they grow more abundantly when the earth itself is moderately dried—most rapidly in spring and to the greatest extent at the beginning of summer; but they are completely dried up when the earth has withered in the middle of summer. And it is possible for you

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence with "καί σοι πάρεστιν" ("And it is possible for you"), suggesting this is an incomplete excerpt from a larger passage.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For, so that—as they appeal to the example of the earth—we may follow it: the grasses [herbage] can grow neither in very dry and parched soil nor in wet and marshy [soil]; but whenever the excess of moisture begins to be spent, they sprout from the earth; and they increase further when this too has dried to a moderate degree—moderately in spring, but most rapidly and to the greatest extent at the beginning of summer; and they are completely dried up when the earth has withered in mid-summer. And you have at your disposal...

paragraphs.content: εἰ βούλει καὶ νῦν ὥσπερ που κᾀν τῷ πρὸ τούτου λόγῳ δέδεικται τὸ μὲν ἔαρ ὅτι τῶν ὡρῶν εὐκρατότατόν ἐστιν εἰκάζειν εὐκράτου δέρματος φύσει καὶ μάλιστά γε τὰ μέσα τῆς ὥρας τῆσδε· τηνικαῦτα γὰρ οὖν καὶ ἡ γῆ μέση πως ὑγρότητός τε καὶ ξηρότητός ἐστιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

If you wish, even now, just as it was demonstrated somewhere in the previous discussion, you may liken spring—which is the most temperate of the seasons—to skin that is temperate by nature, and especially the middle part of this season; for at that time indeed the earth is in a middle state between moisture and dryness.
paragraphs.openai_translation: If you wish, even now—as has, I suppose, been shown also in the preceding discussion—you may take spring, since it is the most temperate [well-balanced] of the seasons, as an image of a skin that is naturally temperate, and especially the middle part of this season; for at that time the earth too is in a kind of middle state between moisture and dryness.

paragraphs.content: ὅσα δὲ τῷ θέρει συνάπτει τῆς ἠρινῆς ὥρας, ταῦτ’ ἤδη ξηροτέραν ἔχει τοῦ συμμέτρου τὴν γῆν, ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον ἀρχομένου θέρους. ὃ τοίνυν λέγω δέρμα θερμὸν καὶ ξηρὸν, εἰκάζοις ἂν μάλιστα τῇ τῆς γῆς διαθέσει τῇ γινομένῃ τελευτῶντος ἦρος ἢ ἀρχομένου θέρους. μεσοῦντος γὰρ θέρους ἄκρως ξηρὰ γίνεται τοῖς τῶν ὀστρακοδέρμων ζώων ὁμοίως, οὐ μὴν ἀνθρώπων, ἢ συῶν, ἢ ὄνων, ἢ ἵππων, ἢ ἄλλου τινὸς τῶν τριχωτῶν ζώων.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 5.7:

Those parts [of the spring season] that connect with summer already have earth that is drier than the moderate state, and even more so at the beginning of summer. Therefore, what I call hot and dry skin, you would most likely compare to the condition of the earth that occurs at the end of spring or the beginning of summer. For in the middle of summer it becomes extremely dry, similar to the shell-bearing animals [crustaceans], but not so for humans, or pigs, or donkeys, or horses, or any other of the hairy animals.
paragraphs.openai_translation: As much of the spring season as borders on summer already makes the earth drier than is in due proportion [i.e., beyond the “balanced” measure], and even more so at the beginning of summer. So what I call a warm and dry skin you might most aptly compare to the condition of the earth that comes to be at the end of spring or the start of summer. For when summer is at its height, it becomes extremely dry—like that of shell-skinned animals [i.e., creatures with a hard outer covering], not, however, like that of human beings, or pigs, or donkeys, or horses, or any other of the hairy [fur-bearing] animals.

paragraphs.content: ὥστ’ εἴπερ τῇ γῇ βούλονται παραβάλλειν τὸ δέρμα καὶ κατὰ τοῦτο τὸν λόγον ὁμολογοῦντα τοῖς πρὸς ἡμῶν ἔμπροσθεν εἰρημένοις εὑρήσουσιν. αὐτοὶ δὲ σφᾶς αὐτοὺς ὑπὸ τῆς ὁμωνυμίας σοφισθέντες παραλογίζονται. ἐν γὰρ τῷ ξηρῷ καὶ θερμῷ δέρματι πολλὰς καὶ μεγάλας ἐλέγομεν φύεσθαι τρίχας ὡς ὑπὲρ ἀνθρώπου δηλονότι ἢ ζώου τριχωτοῦ τὸν λόγον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

So if they wish to compare the skin to earth, they will find that the argument in this respect agrees with what was said by us earlier. But they deceive themselves, having been misled by the equivocation [homonymy]. For we said that in dry and hot skin many large hairs grow, clearly making our argument about a human being or a hairy animal.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, if they wish to compare the skin to the earth, they will find the explanation in this respect to agree with what we previously said. But they, having been tricked by homonymy [equivocation], delude themselves. For we said that in dry and hot skin many and large hairs grow—the discussion being, of course, with reference to a human being, or to a shaggy animal.

paragraphs.content: οὐχ ὑπὲρ ὀστρέων τε καὶ καρκίνων ποιούμενοι. διαπνεῖται μὲν γὰρ ἀεί τι καθ’ ἕκαστον δέρμα ὑπὸ τοῦ θερμοῦ συναπάγοντος ἑαυτῷ τῆς ἔνδοθεν ὑγρότητος οὐκ ὀλίγον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"not making [our argument] on behalf of oysters and crabs. For something is always being breathed out through each skin, as the heat draws off along with itself no small amount of the moisture from within."

---

**Brief notes:**
- The opening phrase appears to be the end of a previous thought, indicating the discussion does not concern shellfish
- "διαπνεῖται" refers to transpiration or exhalation through the skin
- "δέρμα" (skin) is used in a general sense for outer covering
- The passage describes a physiological process of evaporation driven by internal heat
paragraphs.openai_translation: We are not pleading the case for oysters and crabs. For there is always some exhalation through every skin, because the heat draws to itself no small amount of the moisture within [i.e., internal humor].

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἐν οἷς μὲν ὑγρόν ἐστι τὸ δέρμα καὶ ἀκριβῶς μαλακὸν οἷος ὁ νεωστὶ πηγνύμενος τυρὸς οὐχ ὑπομένουσιν αἱ τῶν διεκπεσόντων ὁδοὶ τῶν τέως διεστηκότων αὐτοῦ μορίων αὖθις ἀλλήλοις ἑνουμένων· ἐν οἷς δ’ ἤδη σκληρὸν ὑπάρχει πεπηγότι παραπλήσιον τυρῷ κατατίτραται μὲν ὑπὸ τῆς ῥύμης τῶν ἐξιόντων ἑνωθῆναι δ’ ὑπὸ ξηρότητος μὴ δυνάμενον ὑπομένοντας ἴσχει τοὺς πόρους ἀεὶ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But in cases where the skin is moist and extremely soft, like freshly curdling cheese, the pathways of those things that have passed through do not remain open, since the parts that were previously separated from one another unite again; but in cases where it is already hard, similar to solidified cheese, it is perforated by the force of the things passing out, but being unable to unite because of dryness, it keeps the pores permanently open.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But in cases where the skin is moist and thoroughly soft—like cheese that has only just begun to set—the passageways of what has leaked through do not persist, because its parts, which previously had been separated, come together with one another again. Whereas where it is already hard, resembling cheese that has set, it is pierced by the rush of what goes out, and, being unable to be united on account of dryness, it keeps the pores [channels] continually open.

paragraphs.content: καὶ μᾶλλον συριγγουμένους ταῖς συνεχέσι πληγαῖς τῶν διαῤῥεόντων. ἐὰν μὲν οὖν τὸ διαῤῥέον ἢ ἀτμὸς ἢ ὑγρὸν εἰλικρινὲς ᾖ τῷ μὲν ἀτμῷ ταχεῖά τέ ἐστι καὶ ἀκώλυτος ἡ φορά· τὸ δ’ ὑγρὸν ἴσχεται πολλάκις ἐν τοῖς μικροτέροις πόροις καὶ τι παλινδρομεῖν εἴσω εἰς τὸ βάθος ἀναγκάζεται. εἰ δ’ οἷον αἰθαλώδης τε καὶ παχεῖα καὶ γεώδης ἡ ἀναθυμίασις ᾖ κίνδυνος αὐτῇ πολλάκις ἐν ταῖς στεναῖς τῶν διεξόδων σφηνωθείσῃ μήτ’ εἴσω ῥᾳδίως ὑπονοστεῖν ἔτι
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

and [the passages] being more hollowed out by the continuous impacts of the things flowing through. Now if what flows through is either vapor or pure liquid, for vapor the movement is both swift and unobstructed; but the liquid is often held back in the smaller passages and is forced to flow back inward into the depths. But if the exhalation is, as it were, sooty and thick and earthy, there is danger that it, having often been wedged in the narrow parts of the passages, can neither easily return back inward still
paragraphs.openai_translation: and making a still more piping/wheezing sound [syrigmos] under the continuous blows of the fluids passing through. If, then, what flows through is either vapor or a pure liquid, in the case of the vapor the movement is swift and unimpeded; but the liquid is often checked in the smaller pores and is forced to run back somewhat inward into the depth. If, however, the exhalation is, as it were, sooty, thick, and earthy, there is frequent danger that, once wedged in the narrowness of the outlets, it can no longer easily creep back inward.

paragraphs.content: μήτε κενοῦσθαι δύνασθαι. ταύτην οὖν ἑτέρα τοιαύτη πάλιν ἐκ τοῦ βάθους ἀναφερομένη πλήττει τε καὶ ὠθεῖ πρόσω καὶ ταύτην αὖθις ἑτέρα κᾀκείνην ἄλλη. καὶ πολλὰς αἰθαλώδεις οὕτω μοι νόει σφηνουμένας ἐπ’ ἀλλήλαις ἀναθυμιάσεις ἐν τῷ χρόνῳ περιπλέκεσθαί τε καὶ συνάπτεσθαι καί τι ποιεῖν ἕν σῶμα τοιοῦτο οἷον ἐκτὸς ἡ λιγνύς ἐστι πλὴν ὅσῳ πεπύκνωται τοσούτῳ καὶ ἀκριβῶς ἔσφιγκται τῇ τῆς διεξόδου στενότητι πιληθέν. ἐπειδὰν δὲ τὸν πόρον ἀποφράξῃ πάντα
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

nor be able to be emptied. Therefore another such exhalation rising up from the depths in turn strikes this one and pushes it forward, and again another strikes this one and yet another that one. And imagine many sooty exhalations being wedged upon one another in this way, becoming intertwined and joined together over time, and forming a single body of such a kind as soot is on the outside, except that to the degree it has been condensed, to that same degree it has been compressed and tightly packed by being felted together through the narrowness of the passage. But when it blocks up the entire passage
paragraphs.openai_translation: …nor be able to be emptied. Accordingly, another such one, rising up again from the depth, strikes it and pushes it forward, and in turn yet another [does so] to this one, and another to that one.
