And so, conceive of many sooty exhalations [anathumiasis = vapors] being wedged upon one another, and in the course of time becoming intertwined and joined, and making a single mass of the sort that thick smoke [lignys = sooty smoke] is outside—only that, by just as much as it has been condensed, by so much has it also been tightly compressed, packed together by the narrowness of the outlet [diexodos]. And whenever it blocks the whole passage [poros = pore/channel]…

paragraphs.content: τὸ τοιοῦτο σῶμα τοὐντεῦθεν ἤδη βιαίως πληττόμενον ὑπὸ τῶν ὁμοίων ἑαυτῷ περιττωμάτων οὐκ ἐχόντων διέξοδον ὠθεῖται πρόσω σύμπαν ἐν τῷδε ὥστε καὶ προκύπτειν ἀναγκάζεται τοῦ δέρματος ἱμαντῶδες ἤδη γεγονός. ἔοικε δ’ αὐτοῦ τὸ μὲν ἐν τῷ πόρῳ σφηνωθὲν οἷον ῥίζῃ τινὶ πόας ἢ φυτοῦ τὸ δ’ ἐξέχον ἤδη τοῦ δέρματος οἷόν περ αὐτὸ τὸ φυτόν. ἡ θρὶξ δ’ ἐστὶ μέλαινα μὲν ὅταν ὑπὸ ῥώμης τοῦ θερμοῦ συγκαυθείσης τῆς ἀναθυμιάσεως ἀκριβὴς λιγνὺς γένηται τὸ περίττωμα
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 5.14:

Such a body, being now violently struck from within by residues similar to itself that have no passage out, is pushed forward as a whole in this way so that it is also forced to protrude from the skin, having now become strap-like. Its part wedged in the pore resembles the root of a grass or plant, while the part already projecting from the skin resembles the plant itself. The hair is black whenever, through the strength of the heat burning up the vapor, the residue becomes perfect soot.

---

**Brief contextual notes:**
- [This appears to be from a medical or natural philosophical text discussing the formation and growth of hair]
- [The "body" (σῶμα) refers to the material substance that forms the hair]
- [The "residues" (περιττώματα) are excess materials or waste products in ancient medical theory]
- [The "vapor" (ἀναθυμίασις) refers to the evaporative process in ancient theories of bodily processes]
paragraphs.openai_translation: Such a body, from this point, being violently struck by superfluities like itself that have no outlet, is pushed bodily forward in this region, so that it is compelled to protrude, having already become strap-like as it passes through the skin. And it resembles in this: the part wedged in the pore is like the root of a blade of grass or a plant, while the part projecting from the skin is like the plant itself. Hair is black when, by the strength of the heat, the exhalation, being thoroughly baked, makes the residue [perittōma: leftover matter] into a very fine soot [lignys: lampblack/soot].

paragraphs.content: ξανθὴ δὲ ὅταν ἧττον κατοπτηθῇ. ξανθῆς γὰρ χολῆς τηνικαῦτά ἐστιν ἰλυῶδες περίττωμα τὸ σφηνωθὲν οὐ μελαίνης. ἡ δὲ λευκὴ. θρὶξ ἔκγονος φλέγματος. ἡ πυῤῥὰ δὲ ὥσπερ τῇ χρόᾳ μεταξὺ ξανθῆς ἐστι καὶ λευκῆς οὕτω καὶ γενέσει μεταξὺ φλεγματώδους τε καὶ χολώδους ἰλύος. οὖλαι δὲ τρίχες ἢ διὰ τὴν ξηρότητα τῆς κράσεως ἢ διὰ τὸν πόρον ἐν ᾧ κατεῤῥίζωνται
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 5.15:

Hair becomes blonde when it is less thoroughly roasted. For at that point the sediment that has been trapped is residue of yellow bile, not black bile. White hair is the offspring of phlegm. Red hair, just as it is intermediate in color between blonde and white, is likewise intermediate in origin between phlegmatic and bilious sediment. Curly hairs occur either because of the dryness of the mixture [temperament] or because of the pore in which they are rooted.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And hair is blond when it has been less thoroughly “cooked” [i.e., concocted]. For at such times the sludgy residue that is impacted comes from yellow bile, not from black bile. White hair is the offspring of phlegm. Red hair, just as in complexion it lies between blond and white, so also in its origin lies between a phlegmatic and a bilious sludge. Hairs are woolly/curly either because of the dryness of the temperament [crasis] or because of the pore in which they are rooted.

paragraphs.content: γίνονται· διὰ μὲν τὴν ξηρότητα παραπλησίως ἱμᾶσι τοῖς ἐπὶ πλέον ὑπὸ πυρὸς ξηρανθεῖσι. καίτοι τί δεῖ τῶν ἱμάντων μνημονεύειν αὐτὰς τὰς τρίχας ὁρῶντας εἰ πλησιάσειαν πυρὶ παραχρῆμα διαστρεφομένας; οὕτως μὲν οὖν Αἰθίοπες ἅπαντες οὖλοι. τῇ δὲ τῶν πόρων ἐν οἷς ἐῤῥίζωνται φύσει κατὰ τάδε. πολλάκις μὲν ἡ ἀναθυμίασις εὐθυπορεῖν ὑπ’ ἀῤῥωστίας ἀδυνατοῦσα καθ’ ὃν ἂν αὕτη τρόπον ἑλίττηται καὶ τὸν πόρον οὕτως ἐτύπωσεν. ἐνίοτε δὲ ἡ μὲν ἀναθυμίασις εὔρωστός ἐστιν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

they occur: on account of dryness, similarly to leather straps that have been excessively dried by fire. And yet why is it necessary to mention straps when we see hairs themselves, if they approach fire, immediately becoming twisted? Thus then all Ethiopians are woolly-haired. But [this occurs] according to the nature of the pores in which they are rooted in the following way. Often the exhalation [or vapor], being unable to travel straight through on account of weakness, has molded the pore in whatever manner it itself happens to be twisted. But sometimes the exhalation is strong
paragraphs.openai_translation: They come about as follows: because of dryness, in a manner similar to straps that have been dried out too long by fire. And yet, what need is there to mention straps, when we see the very hairs themselves, if they come near the fire, immediately twisting? Thus, then, all Ethiopians are woolly-haired. As for the pores [the follicular openings] in which they are by nature rooted, the situation is as follows. Often the exhalation [anathumiasis]—being unable to proceed in a straight course because of a disorder—twists in whatever way it does, and it has thus shaped the pore accordingly. At other times the exhalation is vigorous…

paragraphs.content: ὑπὸ δὲ τῆς τοῦ δέρματος φύσεως σκληροτέρας τοῦ προσήκοντος οὔσης εἰργομένη φέρεσθαι κατ’ εὐθὺ πρὸς τὸ πλάγιον ἐπιστρέφεται καθάπερ γε κᾀκτὸς ἰδεῖν ἐστιν οὐ μόνον ἀτμὸν ἢ καπνὸν ἀλλὰ καὶ τὰς φλόγας αὐτὰς ὅταν ἀποκλεισθῶσι τῆς ἄνω φορᾶς λοξὰς ἐφ’ ἑκάτερα μέρη σχιζομένας. οὕτως οὖν καὶ ἡ ἐκ τοῦ σώματος ἀναθυμίασις ὅταν εἰρχθῇ κατὰ τι καὶ κωλυθῇ φέρεσθαι πρὸς τοὐκτὸς λοξὴν ὑπὸ τὸ δέρμα διέξοδον ὁδοποιεῖται
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Being prevented from moving straight upward by the nature of the skin, which is harder than it should be, it turns aside toward the lateral direction, just as indeed it is possible to see externally not only vapor or smoke but also flames themselves, whenever they are blocked from their upward movement, splitting obliquely into both directions. Thus, therefore, the exhalation from the body too, whenever it is blocked at some point and prevented from moving outward, makes for itself an oblique passage beneath the skin.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But when the nature of the skin is harder than is fitting, the [exhalation] being prevented from being carried straight turns aside toward the lateral, just as one may indeed observe not only vapor or smoke but even the flames themselves, whenever they are shut off from their [upward motion], splitting obliquely to either side. So too the exhalation from the body, whenever it is confined in some way and hindered from being carried to the [outside], makes for itself an oblique passage under the skin.

paragraphs.content: μέχρι περ ἂν ἀθροισθεῖσα χρόνῳ πλείονι βιάσηταί τε καὶ ἀναπνεύσῃ πρὸς τοὐκτός. ἐνίοτε δ’ ἅμ’ ἀμφοῖν συνδραμόντων ἀῤῥώστου τε τῆς πρώτης ἀναθυμιάσεως ἥτις τὸν πόρον ἐδημιούργησε καὶ ξηροῦ τοῦ δέρματος ἡ λοξότης γίνεται ταῖς ῥίζαις τῶν τριχῶν. οἷαι δ’ ἂν ἐν τῇ ῥιζώσει διαπλάττωνται
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

until such time as it, having accumulated over a longer period, forces its way through and breathes out toward the exterior. But sometimes, when both conditions occur together—both weakness of the initial exhalation which created the passage and dryness of the skin—the crookedness occurs in the roots of the hairs. And whatever shapes they are molded into during their rooting process
paragraphs.openai_translation: until, having accumulated over a longer time, it both forces its way and breathes outward toward the outside. Sometimes, however, when both occur together at once—the unsoundness of the initial exhalation [anathumiasis: vaporous efflux] that fashioned the pore and the dryness of the skin—the roots of the hairs become slanted. And whatever form they are molded into in the rooting, [so they remain].

paragraphs.content: τοιαύτας εἰκὸς ὑπάρχειν αὐτὰς ἕως παντός. οὐδὲ γὰρ οὐδ’ ἄλλο τι τῶν σκληρῶν καὶ ξηρῶν σωμάτων εὐθῦναι δυνατὸν ἄνευ τοῦ μαλάξαι πρότερον. αὕτη μὲν οὖν ἡ γένεσις τῶν τριχῶν. ἐφεξῆς δ’ ἂν εἴη λέγειν τὰς αἰτίας ἁπάντων τῶν συμβεβηκότων ταῖς κράσεσιν ἐν ταῖς τῶν τριχῶν διαφοραῖς καθ’ ἡλικίαν καὶ χώραν καὶ φύσιν σώματος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

It is reasonable that they remain such throughout. For indeed it is not possible to straighten any other hard and dry bodies either without first softening them. This, then, is the generation of hairs. Next it would be appropriate to discuss the causes of all the characteristics that belong to the mixtures [temperaments] in the differences of hairs according to age, region, and bodily nature.
paragraphs.openai_translation: It is reasonable that they should remain such for all time. For indeed no other of the hard and dry bodies can be straightened without first being softened. Such, then, is the generation of hairs. Next it would be appropriate to set forth the causes of all the attributes that have accrued to the mixtures [kraseis: the bodily “temperaments” or blends of qualities/humors] in the differences of hairs, according to age, region [chōra: place/climate], and the nature of the body.

paragraphs.content: Αἰγύπτιοι μὲν οὖν, καὶ Ἄραβες, καὶ Ἰνδοὶ, καὶ πᾶν τὸ θερμὴν καὶ ξηρὰν ἐποικοῦν ἔθνος, μελαίνας τε καὶ δυσαυξεῖς καὶ ξηρὰς καὶ οὔλας καὶ κραύρας ἔχουσι τὰς τρίχας.
paragraphs.claude_translation: The Egyptians, then, and the Arabs, and the Indians, and every nation that inhabits a hot and dry region, have hair that is black and difficult to grow and dry and curly and brittle.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So then Egyptians, and Arabs, and Indians, and every nation that inhabits a hot and dry region, have hair that is black, slow-growing, dry, crisp/woolly [οὔλας], and brittle [κραύρας].

paragraphs.content: ὅσοι δ’ ἔμπαλιν τούτοις ὑγρὰν καὶ ψυχρὰν χώραν οἰκοῦσιν, Ἰλλύριοί τε καὶ Γερμανοὶ, καὶ Δαλματαὶ, καὶ Σαυρόμαται, καὶ σύμπαν τὸ Σκυθικὸν, εὐαυξεῖς μετρίως καὶ λεπτὰς καὶ εὐθείας καὶ πυῤῥάς.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But those who, in contrast to these, inhabit a wet and cold region—both Illyrians and Germans, and Dalmatians, and Sarmatians, and the entire Scythian people—are moderately well-grown and have thin and straight and reddish-blond [hair].
paragraphs.openai_translation: But those who, on the contrary, dwell in a moist and cold land—the Illyrians and Germans, and the Dalmatians, and the Sauromatae, and the whole Scythian people—have hair that grows moderately well, and is fine, straight, and fair [reddish-blond].

paragraphs.content: ὅσοι δ’ ἐν τῷ μεταξὺ τούτων εὔκρατον νεμόμενοι γῆν εὐαυξεστάτας τε καὶ ἰσχυροτάτας καὶ μελαίνας μετρίως καὶ παχείας συμμέτρως καὶ οὔτ’ ἀκριβῶς οὔλας οὔτ’ ἀκριβῶς εὐθείας. οὕτω δὲ κᾀν ταῖς ἡλικίαις βρέφεσι μὲν οἷαί περ τῶν Γερμανῶν ἀκμάζουσι δὲ οἷαί περ τοῖς Αἰθίοψιν ἐφήβοις δὲ καὶ παισὶ οἷαί περ τοῖς εὔκρατον ἐποικοῦσι γῆν ἔθνεσιν ἀνάλογον αἱ τρίχες ἔχουσιν ἰσχύος τε πέρι καὶ πάχους καὶ μεγέθους
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 5.22:

But those who inhabit a temperate land between these extremes have hair that is most well-developed and strongest, and moderately dark and proportionately thick, and neither precisely curly nor precisely straight. And so too in the stages of life: in infants the hair is of the sort that belongs to the Germans, in those at their prime of the sort that belongs to the Ethiopians, and in youths and children of the sort that belongs to the peoples inhabiting temperate land—the hair corresponds proportionally in respect to strength, thickness, and length.
paragraphs.openai_translation: As for those who dwell in the temperate [eukraton, “well-balanced”] land between these [extremes], their hair is the most luxuriant in growth, very strong, moderately black, proportionately thick, and neither strictly woolly [curly] nor strictly straight. Likewise in the stages of life [hêlikiai]: in infants it is as among the Germans, at full prime as among the Ethiopians, and in youths and children as among the peoples who inhabit a temperate land; the hairs are proportionate with respect to strength, thickness, and size [length].

paragraphs.content: καὶ χρόας. οὕτω δὲ καὶ κατ’ αὐτὰς τῶν σωμάτων τὰς φύσεις ἀνάλογον ἡλικίαις τε καὶ χώραις αἱ τρίχες διάκεινται. παῖδες μὲν γὰρ οἱ πάνυ σμικροὶ ψιλοὶ τριχῶν ὅτι μήπω μήτε πόρος αὐτοῖς ἐστι μηδεὶς κατὰ τὸ δέρμα μήτε λιγνυώδη περιττώματα· προσάγοντες δὲ τῷ ἡβάσκειν ὑποφύουσι σμικρὰς καὶ ἀσθενεῖς· ἀκμάζοντες δὲ ἰσχυροτέρας καὶ πολλὰς καὶ μεγάλας καὶ μελαίνας ἴσχουσιν ὅτι τε πλῆθος ἤδη πόρων ἐν αὐτοῖς ἐγένετο
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

and complexions. And in this same way, the hairs are disposed in proportion to ages and regions according to the very natures of bodies themselves. For very small children are bare of hair because they have neither any pore yet in their skin nor sooty residues; but as they approach puberty they grow small and weak hairs; and those in their prime have stronger and many and large and black hairs because both a multitude of pores has now developed in them
paragraphs.openai_translation: …and of complexion. Thus, in accordance with the very natures of bodies, the condition of the hairs corresponds proportionally to ages and to regions. For very small children are smooth and lacking in hairs, because as yet they have neither any pore [πόρος: pore] in the skin nor soot-like residues [λιγνυώδη περιττώματα: carbonous waste products]. As they draw near to puberty [ἡβάσκειν], they begin to sprout hairs that are small and weak; but when they are in their prime, they have hairs that are stronger, more numerous, larger, and darker, because by then a multitude of pores has come to be in them.

paragraphs.content: καὶ ὅτι μεστοὶ τῶν αἰθαλωδῶν εἰσι περιττωμάτων ὑπὸ ξηρότητος καὶ θερμότητος. αἱ δ’ ἐν τῇ κεφαλῇ τε καὶ ταῖς ὀφρύσι καὶ κατὰ τὰ βλέφαρα καὶ παισὶν οὖσιν ἡμῖν ὑπάρχουσιν ἤδη. γένεσις γὰρ δὴ ταύταις οὐχ οἵα ταῖς πόαις ἀλλ’ οἵα τοῖς φυτοῖς κατὰ πρῶτον λόγον ὑπὸ τῆς φύσεως ἀπειργασμέναις καὶ οὐκ ἐξ ἀνάγκης ἑπομέναις ταῖς κράσεσιν ὡς κᾀν τοῖς περὶ χρείας μορίων δείκνυται.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

And that they are full of sooty residues due to dryness and heat. But those on the head and on the eyebrows and on the eyelids are already present in us even when we are children. For indeed the generation of these is not like that of grass, but like that of plants, fashioned by nature according to a primary principle and not following necessarily from the mixtures [of bodily humors], as is also demonstrated in the work *On the Usefulness of Parts*.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And that they are filled with sooty residues [perittōmata: excremental by-products] because of dryness and heat. Those on the head, and on the eyebrows, and along the eyelids are already present even when we are children. For the generation of these is not like that of grasses, but like that of plants, in the primary sense, as things fashioned by Nature, and not following of necessity upon the mixtures [kraseis: temperamental blends], as is shown even in the works On the Usefulness of the Parts [Peri chreias moriōn].

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ τοι καὶ ταῖσδε τὸ μὲν εἶναι διὰ τὴν τῆς φύσεως τέχνην, τὸ δ’ ἤτοι μελαίναις, ἢ πυῤῥαῖς, ἤ τινα ἄλλην ἐχούσαις διαφορὰν, ἐξ ἀνάγκης ἕπεται τῇ κράσει τῆς ἡλικίας.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But indeed even for these, their existence is due to the art of nature, while their being either dark, or reddish, or having some other difference, follows necessarily from the mixture of their age.

[Note: "mixture" (κρᾶσις/krasis) refers to the blend or temperament of bodily humors, a key concept in ancient Greek medical theory]
paragraphs.openai_translation: But indeed, for these too, their very existence is due to nature’s art, whereas their being either black or auburn, or having some other distinction, necessarily follows from the mixture of the age [i.e., the bodily temperament appropriate to a given life-stage].

paragraphs.content: ὑπόπυῤῥοι μὲν γὰρ εἰσιν τοὐπίπαν, ὅτι καὶ τὸ σφηνούμενον ἐν τοῖς πόροις οὐδέπω μέλαν ἐστὶν ὅλον. ἥ τε γὰρ ὑγρότης πολλὴ, καὶ ἡ διέξοδος ῥᾳδία, καὶ ἡ σύγκαυσις ἀσθενής. εὐαυξεῖς δὲ καὶ παχεῖαι συμμέτρως τῇ τῶν τρεφόντων αὐτὰς περιττωμάτων ἀφθονίᾳ. τὸ μὲν γὰρ μόριον αὐτὸ τοῦ σώματος, ἐν ᾧ γίγνονται, ξηρόν· ὅλον γὰρ τὸ κρανίον ὀστέϊνόν ἐστι· τὸ δὲ περικείμενον αὐτῷ δέρμα τοσούτῳ ξηρότερον τοῦ κατὰ τὸ λοιπὸν σῶμα δέρματος ἅπαντος, ὅσῳ περ καὶ σκληρότερον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For they are generally reddish-yellow, because what is wedged in the pores is not yet entirely black. For the moisture is abundant, the passage through is easy, and the burning together is weak. They grow well and are moderately thick due to the abundance of the residues that nourish them. For the part of the body itself in which they grow is dry—for the entire skull is bony—and the skin surrounding it is drier than all the rest of the skin on the body by as much as it is also harder.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For they are for the most part reddish-blond, because the matter wedged in the pores is not yet wholly black. For the moisture is abundant, the outlet easy, and the singeing [sygkausis: charring/concoction] weak. They grow readily and are thick, in proportion to the abundance of the superfluities of the nutriments that feed them. For the part of the body in which they come to be is dry—for the whole skull is bony—and the skin that lies over it is drier than the skin over the rest of the body by as much as it is also harder.

paragraphs.content: ἀναφέρεται μέντοι πλῆθος οὐκ ὀλίγον ἔκ τε τῶν κατὰ τὸν ἐγκέφαλον, ἤδη δὲ κᾀξ ὅλου τοῦ σώματος αἰθαλωδῶν περιττωμάτων.
paragraphs.openai_translation: However, a not inconsiderable quantity of sooty waste [fuliginous residues, i.e., smoky/byproduct excretions] is brought up from the regions about the brain, and now even from the whole body.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
However, no small amount of sooty residues is carried up both from the region of the brain and indeed also from the whole body.

---

**Alternative translation:**

Nevertheless, a considerable quantity of sooty waste products is carried upward both from the parts around the brain and also from the entire body.

paragraphs.content: ὥσθ’ οἶον τοῖς ἀκμάζουσιν ὅλον γίνεται τὸ σῶμα τοιοῦτο ἤδη τὸ δέρμα τῆς κεφαλῆς ἐστι τοῖς βρέφεσι. εὐλόγως οὖν ἔνιοι φαλακροῦνται τοῦ χρόνου προϊόντος οἷς ἐξ ἀρχῆς ἦν σκληρότερον τὸ δέρμα. δέδεικται γὰρ ἔμπροσθεν ὡς τῶν γηρασκόντων ἅπαντα ξηραίνεται τὰ μόρια. γίνεται δὴ πολλοῖς ὀστρακῶδες τὸ δέρμα ἐπὶ πλέον ἢ δεῖ ξηρανθέν. ἐν τοιούτῳ δ’ οὐδὲν φύεσθαι δύναται καθ’ ὅ τι καὶ διὰ τῶν ἔμπροσθεν ὡμολόγηται. καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ τῶν χειρῶν τὰ ἔνδον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 5.28:

So that just as the whole body becomes such in those who are in their prime, so already is the skin of the head in infants. Reasonably, therefore, some people become bald as time goes on, those for whom the skin was harder from the beginning. For it has been demonstrated earlier that all the parts of those who are aging become dry. Indeed, in many people the skin becomes shell-like, having been dried more than necessary. But in such [skin] nothing can grow, according to what has also been agreed upon in the earlier [discussion]. And indeed also the inner parts of the hands

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end, suggesting this is an incomplete excerpt from a larger work (likely from Aristotle's biological or medical writings, discussing baldness and the properties of skin).
paragraphs.openai_translation: So, just as in those at their prime the whole body becomes of such a sort, the skin of the head is already so in infants. Accordingly, it is reasonable that, as time goes on, some people go bald—namely those whose skin was harder from the beginning. For it has been shown above that in those who are aging all the parts dry out. Thus in many the skin becomes potsherd-like [ostracodes: hard and scaly], dried out more than it should be. And in such a condition nothing can grow, as indeed has been agreed from the preceding considerations. For in fact even the inner parts of the hands…

paragraphs.content: ὥσπερ καὶ τὰ κάτω τῶν ποδῶν ἀεὶ ἄτριχα καὶ ψιλὰ ξηροτάτου καὶ πυκνοτάτου τοῦ κατ’ αὐτὰ τένοντος ὄντος ὃς ὑποτέτακται τῷ δέρματι.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Just as also the undersides of the feet are always hairless and smooth, since the tendon beneath them, which lies under the skin, is extremely dry and dense.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Just as the undersides of the feet are always hairless and smooth, because the tendon [sinew] that runs beneath them—lying under the skin—is extremely dry and very dense.

paragraphs.content: ὅσοις δ’ εἰς τέλος ξηρότητος οὐκ ἀφικνεῖται τὸ δέρμα τῆς κεφαλῆς, ἄῤῥωστοι τούτοις γίνονται καὶ λευκαὶ πάντως αἱ τρίχες, ἃς ὀνομάζουσιν οἱ ἄνθρωποι πολιάς· ἄῤῥωστοι μὲν ἐνδείᾳ τῆς οἰκείας τροφῆς, λευκαὶ δὲ, διότι καὶ τὸ τρέφον αὐτὰς τοιοῦτο, οἷον εὐρώς τις φλέγματος ἐν χρόνῳ διασαπέντος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But for those in whom the skin of the head does not reach a complete state of dryness, the hairs become weak and entirely white for them, which people call gray hairs; weak on account of a deficiency of their proper nourishment, and white because the substance nourishing them is of such a kind as a sort of mold of phlegm that has rotted away over time.
paragraphs.openai_translation: As for those in whom the skin of the head does not attain complete dryness, they become unhealthy, and their hairs are in any case white—what people call “grey hairs.” Unhealthy, on the one hand, from a lack of their proper nourishment; and white, on the other, because what nourishes them is of such a kind—like a sort of mildew [mould], a phlegm [humoral “phlegm”] that has rotted over time.

paragraphs.content: ὅταν γὰρ ὁ μὲν πόρος ἔτι μένῃ τὸ περίττωμα δ’ ὀλίγον ᾖ καὶ γλίσχρον ἀῤῥώστως δ’ ὑπὸ τῆς θερμασίας ὠθῆται πρόσω πάσχει τι παραπλήσιον ἐν τῷδε σηπεδόνι. καὶ δὴ φαλακροῦνται μὲν μᾶλλον τὸ βρέγμα γηρῶντες οἱ ἄνθρωποι πολιοῦνται δὲ τοὺς κροτάφους μᾶλλον ὅτι τὸ μὲν ξηρότατόν ἐστι τῶν μορίων ἁπάντων τῆς κεφαλῆς· ἐπὶ γὰρ ὀστῷ τὸ δέρμα ταύτῃ ψιλῷ· οἱ κρόταφοι δ’ ὑγρότεροι· μύες γὰρ ἐνταῦθ’ εἰσιν ὑπὸ τῷ δέρματι μεγάλοι σαρκώδης δὲ πᾶς μῦς
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For whenever the passage still remains but the residue is scanty and viscous, and is pushed forward feebly by the heat, it undergoes something similar in this respect to putrefaction. And indeed men become bald more on the crown as they grow old, but turn gray more at the temples, because the crown is the driest of all the parts of the head; for in that place the skin lies upon bare bone; but the temples are moister, for there are large muscles under the skin in that place, and every muscle is fleshy.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For when the pore [poros: passage/opening] still remains, but the residue [perittōma: leftover matter] is scant and viscous, and is driven forward in an unhealthy way by the heating [thermasia], it undergoes something akin to decay in this region. And so, as people grow old, they become bald more at the crown, and they turn gray more at the temples, because the former is the driest of all the parts of the head—for there the skin lies upon bare bone—whereas the temples are moister; for here there are large muscles beneath the skin, and every muscle is fleshy.

paragraphs.content: ἡ δὲ σὰρξ ὀστοῦ καὶ δέρματος ὑγροτέρα.
paragraphs.claude_translation: The flesh is moister than bone and skin.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But the flesh is moister than bone and skin.

paragraphs.content: Ἀκριβῶς δὲ χρὴ προσέχειν τῷ λεγομένῳ τὸν νοῦν ὅπως μὴ λάθωμεν ἡμᾶς αὐτοὺς παρακούσαντές τι καὶ σφαλέντες οἶα δὴ πολλοὶ τῶν πάνυ δοκούντων ἀρίστων ἰατρῶν εἶναι σφάλλονται εἴ τίς ἐστι φαλακρὸς εὐθὺς τοῦτον οἰόμενοι ξηρὰν ἔχειν ἅπαντος τοῦ σώματος τὴν κρᾶσιν. οὐ γὰρ δὴ οὕτως ἁπλῶς εἰκάζειν ἐχρῆν ἀλλὰ διορίζεσθαι πρότερον ἄμεινον ἦν ὡς τῶν ἀνθρώπων τὸ σῶμα τῶν μὲν ὁμαλῶς κέκραται σύμπαν ἐνίων δὲ καὶ οὐκ ὀλίγων τούτων
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

It is necessary to pay close attention to what is being said, so that we do not unwittingly mishear something and make an error, just as many of those who seem to be the very best physicians make an error if someone is bald, immediately thinking that this person has a dry mixture [krasis] of the entire body. For indeed one ought not to make inferences so simply, but it would have been better to make distinctions first: that the body of human beings in some cases is uniformly mixed throughout, but in others—and these are not few—

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence. "Krasis" refers to the mixture or balance of bodily humors/qualities in ancient Greek medical theory.]
paragraphs.openai_translation: One must pay careful attention to what is being said, so that we do not unwittingly mishear something and go astray, just as, in fact, many of those who are thought to be the very best physicians make mistakes: if someone is bald, they immediately suppose that this person has a dry temperament [krāsis: the bodily “mixture” or balance of qualities] throughout the entire body. For one ought not to make inferences so simply; rather, it would have been better first to draw a distinction—namely, that as to the bodies of human beings, some are mixed uniformly as a whole, whereas in others—and not a few of these...

paragraphs.content: ἀνωμάλως διάκειται. τὰ μὲν γὰρ τῶν μορίων αὐτοῖς ὑγρότερα τοῦ συμμέτρου τε καὶ προσήκοντός ἐστι τὰ δὲ ψυχρότερα τὰ δὲ ξηρότερα τὰ δὲ θερμότερα τὰ δὲ καὶ παντελῶς εὔκρατά τε καὶ σύμμετρα. δεῖ δὲ προσέχειν μάλιστα τούτῳ τὸν νοῦν ἐπειδὰν ἐπισκέπτῃ σώματος κρᾶσιν. εἰ μὲν γὰρ ὁμαλῶς εὔρυθμον ὅλον ἐστὶ καὶ πάσας τῶν μορίων ἀποσῶζον τὰς πρὸς ἄλληλα συμμετρίας ἐν μήκει καὶ πλάτει καὶ βάθει
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.2:

They are disposed unevenly. For some of their parts are more moist than what is proportionate and appropriate, others are colder, others are drier, others are hotter, and still others are entirely well-tempered [eukratos] and proportionate. One must pay attention to this especially when examining the mixture [krasis] of a body. For if the whole is uniformly well-proportioned and preserves all the proportions of the parts in relation to one another in length and breadth and depth

---

**Brief notes:**
- [eukratos]: refers to a good or balanced mixture of qualities
- [krasis]: the mixture or temperament of bodily qualities (hot, cold, wet, dry)
paragraphs.openai_translation: It is irregularly constituted. For some of their parts are moister than is proportionate and fitting, others colder, others drier, others hotter, and others even altogether well-tempered and proportionate [eukrata and symmetra]. One must pay the closest attention to this whenever you examine the body’s krasis [mixture/temperament]. For if it is an evenly well-ordered whole, preserving all the mutual symmetries of the parts with one another in length, breadth, and depth…

paragraphs.content: δύναιτ’ ἂν ὅλως ὁμοίως κεκρᾶσθαι τὸ. τοιοῦτο. εἰ δέ τι σῶμα θώρακα μὲν ἔχει καὶ τράχηλον καὶ ὤμους μεγίστους ἰσχνὰ δὲ καὶ μικρὰ τὰ κατ’ ὀσφὺν καὶ σκέλη λεπτὰ καὶ ξηρὰ πῶς ἂν ὁμοίως εἴη τοῦτο διακείμενον ἅπασι τοῖς μορίοις. οὐ μὴν οὐδ’ εἰ τὰ μὲν σκέλη παχέα καὶ τὰ κατ’ ὀσφὺν εὐρέα τὸν θώρακα δ’ ἔχοι στενὸν οὐδὲ τοῦτ’ ἂν εἴη κεκραμένον ὁμαλῶς τοῖς μορίοις. ἕτερα δὲ σώματα μεγίστην ἔχει τὴν κεφαλὴν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

such a thing could in any way be blended uniformly. But if some body has a very large chest and neck and shoulders, but the parts around the loins are thin and small, and the legs are slender and dry, how could this be similarly disposed in all its parts? Nor indeed, if the legs are thick and the parts around the loins are broad, but it has a narrow chest, would this either be blended evenly in its parts. Other bodies have a very large head
paragraphs.openai_translation: Could something of this sort be at all mixed uniformly as a whole [i.e., have an even “mixture”/temperament]? But if a body has a very large chest and neck and shoulders, while the parts about the loins are thin and small, and the legs are slender and dry, how could this be similarly constituted in all its parts [μόρια]? Nor indeed, if the legs were thick and the parts about the loins broad while it had a narrow chest, would this either be evenly mixed in its parts. And other bodies have an exceptionally large head.

paragraphs.content: ἕτερα δὲ σμικρὰν οἵαν οἱ στρουθοί. καὶ τοῖς σκέλεσι τὰ μὲν βλαισὰ τὰ δὲ ῥαιβὰ καὶ ἄκροις τοῖς κώλοις τὰ μὲν ἰσχνὰ τὰ δὲ παχέα. καὶ θώραξ τοῖς μὲν ὡς εἴρηται πρόσθεν εὐθὺς ἐνίοις δὲ στενὸς οὕτως ὡς σανὶς οὓς δὴ καὶ σανιδώδεις ὀνομάζουσιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Others have a small one like sparrows. And as for the legs, some are bow-legged while others are bandy-legged, and at the extremities of the limbs some are thin while others are thick. And the chest in some birds is straight as was stated before, but in others it is narrow in such a way as to resemble a plank, which birds they accordingly call "plank-like" [or "board-chested"].
paragraphs.openai_translation: Other features are small, like those of sparrows. And as for the legs, in some they are knock-kneed [blaisá: knees inclining inward], in others bow-legged [rhaibá: legs curved outward]; and at the extremities of the limbs some are thin, others thick. And the chest in some, as has been said before, is straight, while in others it is so narrow as to be like a plank—these they indeed call “plank-like.”

paragraphs.content: ὅταν δὲ καὶ τὰ κατ’ ὠμοπλάτας αὐτοῖς ἄσαρκα τελέως ᾖ καὶ γυμνὰ καὶ προπετῆ δίκην πτερύγων ὀνομάζονται μὲν αἱ τοιαῦται φύσεις ὑπὸ τῶν ἰατρῶν πτερυγώδεις· εἰς ὅσον δ’ ἥκουσι κακίας ἀπολωλεκότος τοῦ θώρακος ὀλίγου δεῖν ἅπασαν τὴν ἐντὸς εὐρυχωρίαν ἐν ᾗ πνεύμων τε καὶ καρδία τέτακται πρόδηλον παντί. μυρίαι δ’ ἄλλαι τῶν τοῦ σώματος μορίων εἰσὶ προδήλως διαθέσεις
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.5:

And when the areas around their shoulder blades are also completely fleshless and bare and project forward like wings, such physical constitutions are called "pterygoid" [wing-like] by physicians. But to what degree of defectiveness they have reached, when the chest has lost almost all the internal capacity in which both the lung and heart are positioned, is clear to everyone. And there are countless other conditions of the parts of the body that are equally evident.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And whenever the regions about the shoulder blades are completely without flesh, bare, and projecting like wings, such constitutions are called by physicians “pterygōdeis” [winged-scapulae]. How far they advance in malignity—when the chest has been wasted, so that well-nigh the entire inner cavity in which the lung and the heart are set is lost—is evident to everyone. And there are countless other plainly observable conditions of the body’s parts.

paragraphs.content: ὅταν ἐκτραπόμενον τῆς φυσικῆς ἀναλογίας εἰς ἀνώμαλόν τινα δυσκρασίαν εὐθὺς ἐν τῷ κυΐσκεσθαι μεταπέσῃ. οὔκουν ἐπὶ τῶν τοιούτων ἐξ ἑνὸς χρὴ μορίου τεκμαίρεσθαι περὶ τοῦ παντός. οὐδὲ γὰρ οἱ φυσιογνωμονεῖν ἐπιχειροῦντες ἁπλῶς ἀποφαίνονται περὶ πάντων ἀλλ’ ἐκ τῆς πείρας καὶ οἵδε διδαχθέντες. εἰ μὲν γάρ τις ἱκανῶς εἴη δασὺς τὰ στέρνα θυμικὸν ἀποφαίνονται· μηροὺς δ’ εἴπερ εἴη τοιοῦτος ἀφροδισιαστικόν· οὐ μὴν τήν γ’ αἰτίαν προστιθέασιν ἔτι. οὐδὲ γὰρ ὅτι λέοντι μὲν ἐμφερῆ τὰ στέρνα
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.6:

When it deviates from the natural proportion into some irregular imbalance immediately during conception. Therefore, in such cases one must not draw conclusions about the whole from a single part. For indeed, those who attempt to practice physiognomy do not make simple pronouncements about all people, but these men too have been taught by experience. For if someone should be sufficiently hairy on the chest, they declare him spirited [or hot-tempered]; but if his thighs should be such, they declare him lustful; however, they do not yet add the cause. For neither do they explain that the chest resembles that of a lion—

---

**Note:** This text appears to be from a medical or physiognomic treatise, likely Galen, discussing the limitations of drawing conclusions about a person's entire nature from individual body parts. The passage breaks off mid-sentence at the end.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Whenever, having deviated from the natural proportion, it at once, at the very moment of conception, falls into some irregular dyscrasia [imbalance of humors]. Therefore, in such cases one must not infer the whole from a single part. For even those who attempt physiognomy do not make blanket pronouncements about everything, but speak from experience and from having been trained. For if someone is sufficiently hairy on the chest, they declare him spirited/irascible; and if his thighs are of such a sort, [they declare him] lustful. Yet they do not go on to add the cause. Nor, indeed, [do they explain] that the chest, because it resembles a lion’s...

paragraphs.content: τράγῳ δὲ τὰ κατὰ μηροὺς ἐπειδὰν φῶσι τὴν πρώτην αἰτίαν ἐξευρήκασι. διὰ τί γὰρ ὁ μὲν λέων θυμικὸς ὁ δὲ τράγος ἀφροδισιαστικὸς ὁ λόγος ἐξευρεῖν ἐπιζητεῖ. μέχρι γὰρ τοῦδε τὸ μὲν γινόμενον εἰρήκασι τὴν δ’ αἰτίαν αὐτοῦ παραλελοίπασιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But when they say that the characteristics relating to the thighs in the case of the goat constitute the discovery of the primary cause, they think they have found the first cause. For the argument seeks to discover why the lion is spirited while the goat is lustful. For up to this point they have stated what comes to be, but they have omitted its cause.
paragraphs.openai_translation: As for the he-goat, when they say that the decisive factor lies in the region of the thighs, they have discovered the primary cause [“the region of the thighs” = the genitals/testes]. For the account seeks to find why the lion is spirited, whereas the he-goat is lustful. For up to this point they have said what happens, but have left aside its cause.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὁ φυσικὸς ἀνὴρ ὥσπερ τῶν ἄλλων ἁπάντων οὕτω καὶ τὰς τούτων αἰτίας ἐξευρίσκειν ἐπιχειρεῖ. διότι γὰρ ἀνωμάλως διάκεινται κατὰ τὰς τῶν μορίων κράσεις οὐ λέων μόνον καὶ τράγος ἀλλὰ καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ζώων πάμπολλα διὰ τοῦτ’ ἄλλα πρὸς ἄλλας ἐνεργείας ἑτοίμως ἔχει. περὶ μὲν δὴ τούτων Ἀριστοτέλει καλῶς ἐπὶ πλεῖστον εἴρηται. τὸ δ’ οὖν εἰς τὰ παρόντα χρηστὸν ἤδη φαίνεται διότι χρὴ σκοπεῖσθαι τῶν ἀνθρώπων τὰς κράσεις ἕκαστον τῶν μορίων ἐξετάζοντα καθ’ ἑαυτὸ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.8:

But the natural philosopher [physikos], just as with all other things, so too attempts to discover the causes of these matters. For because not only the lion and the goat but also very many of the other animals are disposed unevenly with respect to the mixtures [kraseis] of their parts, for this reason different animals are readily disposed toward different activities. Now concerning these matters, Aristotle has spoken well at great length. But what is useful for present purposes already appears clear: that one must examine the mixtures [kraseis] of human beings, investigating each of the parts by itself.

---

**Brief notes:**
- *physikos* = natural philosopher/scientist, one who studies nature (physis)
- *kraseis* = mixtures, temperaments, or blendings (referring to the mixture of elemental qualities in bodily parts according to ancient medical theory)
paragraphs.openai_translation: But the natural philosopher, just as he does in all other matters, likewise attempts to discover their causes. For because there are irregular conditions with respect to the mixtures [kraseis: temperaments/constitutions] of the parts, not only the lion and the he-goat, but very many of the other animals as well, are on this account readily fitted in different ways for different activities [energeiai: functions]. On these topics Aristotle has spoken well, for the most part. What now appears useful for the present purpose is this: one must consider the mixtures [kraseis] of human beings by examining each of the parts [moria] by itself.

paragraphs.content: καὶ μὴ νομίζειν. εἴ τῳ δασὺς ὁ θώραξ ὅλον ἐξ ἀνάγκης τούτῳ τὸ σῶμα θερμότερόν τε καὶ ξηρότερον ὑπάρχειν ἀλλ’ ἐν τῇ καρδίᾳ τὸ θερμὸν εἶναι πλεῖστον διὸ καὶ θυμικόν· δύνασθαι δ’ ἐνίοτε δι’ αὐτὸ τοῦτο μὴ ὁμοίως ἅπαν αὐτοῖς τὸ σῶμα θερμὸν καὶ ξηρὸν ὑπάρχειν ὅτι πλεῖστον ἀνέπνευσεν ἐνταῦθα καὶ πρὸς τὸ περιέχον ἐξεκενώθη τὸ θερμόν. εἰ μὲν γὰρ ὅλη τοῦ σώματος κρᾶσίς ἐστιν ὁμαλὴ εὐθὺς ἂν εἴη τούτοις αὐτὸς σύμπας ὁ θώραξ εὐρύτατος
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

And one must not suppose that if someone has a hairy chest, the entire body necessarily is hotter and drier for this person, but rather that the heat is most abundant in the heart, and for this reason they are also spirited; but it is possible sometimes, on account of this very thing, that not all of their body is similarly hot and dry, because there is most respiration there and the heat has been evacuated toward the surrounding air. For if the mixture [krasis] of the whole body were uniform, the entire chest itself would immediately be very broad for these people.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And do not suppose that, if someone’s chest is wholly hairy, it is of necessity that his body as a whole is hotter and drier; rather, the heat is greatest in the heart, and therefore he is spirited [thumic, prone to anger]. At times, for this very reason, it can happen that their whole body is not alike hot and dry, because the heat has here breathed out most and been vented toward the surrounding [air]. For if the entire mixture [krasis: overall constitution] of the body were uniform, then at once their whole chest itself would be the very broadest.

paragraphs.content: αἵ τε φλέβες εὐρεῖαι καὶ αἱ ἀρτηρίαι μεγάλαι τε ἅμα καὶ μέγιστον καὶ σφοδρότατον σφύζουσαι καὶ τρίχες πολλαὶ καθ’ ὅλον τὸ σῶμα καὶ αἱ τῆς κεφαλῆς εὐαυξέσταται μὲν καὶ μέλαιναι καὶ οὖλαι κατὰ τὴν πρώτην ἡλικίαν ἐπὶ δὲ προήκοντι τῷ χρόνῳ φαλάκρωσις ἀκολουθήσει. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ σύντονον καὶ διηρθρωμένον καὶ μυῶδες ἐπειδὰν ὁμαλῶς τῆς κράσεως ἔχωσιν ὅλον ἔσται τοῖς τοιούτοις ἀνθρώποις τὸ σῶμα καὶ τὸ δέρμα σκληρότερόν τε καὶ μελάντερον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

The veins are wide and the arteries are both large and at the same time pulse most vigorously and most strongly, and there are many hairs over the whole body, and those of the head grow most abundantly and are black and curly in the first period of life, but as time advances baldness will follow. And indeed the body will be sinewy and well-articulated and muscular for such people when they possess an even temperament [krasis], and the skin will be rather hard and rather dark.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Both the veins will be broad, and the arteries large and at the same time pulsing to the greatest degree and most vehemently [strong pulse], and there will be many hairs over the whole body; those of the head in the first age are exceedingly luxuriant, black, and curly, but as time advances baldness will follow. And indeed, provided their krasis is in due balance [mixture/temperament], the whole body in such persons will be tense, well-knit, and muscular, and the skin harder and darker.

paragraphs.content: ὥσπερ καὶ δασύτερον. οὕτω δὲ κᾂν εἰ τἀναντία περὶ τὸν θώρακα συμπέσῃ τῆς κράσεως ὁμαλῆς ὑπαρχούσης ἐν ὅλῳ τῷ σώματι τοῦτ’ ἔστιν ὑγροτέρων τε καὶ ψυχροτέρων ἁπάντων τῶν μορίων γενομένων ὁ μὲν θώραξ αὐτοῖς στενὸς καὶ ἄτριχος ἔσται καθάπερ οὖν καὶ σύμπαν τὸ σῶμα ψιλὸν τριχῶν ἁπαλόν τε καὶ λευκὸν τὸ δέρμα καὶ ὑπόπυῤῥον ταῖς θριξὶ καὶ μάλιστ’ ἐν νεότητι καὶ οὐ φαλακροῦνται γηρῶντες εὐθὺς δὲ καὶ δειλοὶ καὶ ἄτολμοι καὶ ὀκνηροὶ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

just as also hairier. And thus, even if the opposite conditions regarding the chest should occur when the mixture is uniform throughout the whole body—that is, when all the parts have become moister and colder—the chest will be narrow and hairless for them, just as indeed the whole body is bare of hair, and the skin is soft and white, and reddish-blond in the hair, and especially in youth, and they do not go bald when growing old; and immediately they are also cowardly and unventuresome and sluggish.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Just as also [it becomes] shaggier. And so, if the opposite should occur in respect to the chest, with an even krâsis [“mixture” or “temperament”] present in the whole body—that is, with all the parts becoming moister and colder—then for such people the chest will be narrow and hairless, and likewise the whole body will be bare of hair, the skin soft and white, and the hairs slightly reddish, especially in youth; and they do not go bald as they grow old, and they are also timid, unadventurous, and sluggish.

paragraphs.content: καὶ μικρὰς καὶ ἀδήλους ἔχοντες τὰς φλέβας καὶ πιμελώδεις καὶ νεύροις τε καὶ μυσὶν ἄῤῥωστοι καὶ ἀδιάρθρωτοι τὰ κῶλα καὶ βλαισοὶ γίνονται. διαφόρου μέντοι τῆς κράσεως τῶν μορίων ἀπεργασθείσης οὐκ ἔτ’ ἐξ ἑνὸς αὐτῶν οἶόν τε περὶ τοῦ σύμπαντος ἀποφαίνεσθαι σώματος ἀλλ’ ἄμεινον ἐφ’ ἕκαστον ἰέναι καὶ σκοπεῖσθαι ὅπως μὲν ἡ γαστὴρ ἔχει κράσεως ὅπως δ’ ὁ πνεύμων ὅπως δὲ ὁ ἐγκέφαλος
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

And having small and indistinct veins and being fatty, and weak in their sinews and muscles, they become poorly articulated in their limbs and bow-legged. However, when the mixture [krasis] of the parts has been rendered variable, it is no longer possible to make a judgment about the whole body from one of them alone, but it is better to proceed to each part individually and examine how the stomach is in respect to its mixture, how the lung is, and how the brain is.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And they have small and not easily discernible veins, are fatty, and unsound in their sinews and muscles; their limbs are unarticulated, and they become knock-kneed. However, when the krasis [mixture/temperament] of the parts has turned out differently, it is no longer possible to make a judgment about the whole body from any one of them; rather, it is better to go to each in turn and examine how the stomach stands in respect of krasis, how the lung, and how the brain.

paragraphs.content: ἕκαστόν τε τῶν ἄλλων ἰδίᾳ καὶ καθ’ ἑαυτό. ταυτὶ μὲν οὖν ἐκ τῶν ἐνεργειῶν γνωρίζειν· οὐ γάρ ἐστιν οὔθ’ ἁψάμενον ἁφῇ οὔτ’ ὀφθαλμοῖς θεασάμενον ἐξευρεῖν τὴν κρᾶσιν αὐτῶν. προσεπισκέψασθαι δὲ καὶ τὰς τῶν περιεχόντων αὐτὰ μορίων διαθέσεις ὧν ἁπάντων ἔξωθέν ἐστι τὸ δέρμα κατὰ τὴν ἡμετέραν οἴκησιν εὔκρατον οὖσαν ἐνδεικνύμενον τῶν ὑποκειμένων μορίων τὴν φύσιν οὐδ’ ἐν αὐτῇ πάντων ἁπλῶς
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

each of the other things individually and by itself. These things, then, must be recognized from their activities; for it is not possible either by touching with touch or by observing with the eyes to discover their mixture [krasis]. One must also examine the conditions of the parts that surround them, of all of which the skin is on the outside, indicating in our dwelling the nature of the underlying parts when it is well-mixed [eukratos], though not in all cases simply

---

**Brief notes:**
- [krasis]: the mixture or blending of qualities/humors in medical theory
- [eukratos]: having a good mixture/temperament, well-balanced
paragraphs.openai_translation: And each of the others individually and in itself. One must recognize these from their activities [energeiai, i.e., functions]; for it is not possible, either by touching with touch or by viewing with the eyes, to discover their mixture [krasis, the temperament/compound]. One should also examine, in addition, the dispositions [diatheseis] of the parts that surround them, of all which the skin is the outermost; and in our region the skin, being well-balanced [eukraton, i.e., of good mixture], indicates the nature of the underlying parts—though not, even in the case of the skin, that of all of them without qualification.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὅσα ταῖς κράσεσιν ὡσαύτως ἔχει τῷ δέρματι. κατὰ δὲ τὰς ὑπὸ ταῖς ἄρκτοις τε καὶ τῇ μεσημβρίᾳ χώρας ἐπειδὴ τῶν μὲν εἰς τὸ βάθος ἀπελήλαται τὸ θερμὸν ὑπὸ τοῦ περιέχοντος ἔξωθεν κρύους νικώμενον τῶν δὲ εἰς τὸ δέρμα προσελήλυθεν ὑπὸ τοῦ περιέχοντος θάλπους ἑλκόμενον οὐκ ἐκ τῆς κατὰ τὸ δέρμα διαθέσεως οἷόν τε γνῶναι σαφῶς ὑπὲρ τῆς ἔνδον τῶν μορίων κράσεως.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But [this applies only to] those things which are similarly disposed in their mixtures to the skin. However, in the regions under the Bears [the northern constellations] and under the south, since in the former the heat has been driven into the depths, being overcome by the external cold of the surrounding air, while in the latter it has come forth to the skin, being drawn out by the warmth of the surrounding air, it is not possible to know clearly about the mixture of the internal parts from the condition of the skin.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But whatever concerns the mixtures [kraseis: the bodily “temperament” or balance of qualities] holds likewise for the skin. As for the regions under the Bears [i.e., the north] and those under the midday sun [i.e., the south], since in the former the heat has been driven inward, overpowered by the surrounding cold from without, while in the latter it has come up to the skin, drawn outward by the surrounding warmth, it is not possible from the condition of the skin to know clearly about the internal mixture of the parts.

paragraphs.content: ἀνώμαλος γὰρ ἡ τοῦ σώματος κρᾶσις ἐν ταῖς δυσκράτοις χώραις, οὐχ ὡσαύτως ἐχόντων τῶν τ’ ἔξωθεν μορίων καὶ τῶν ἐντός. Κελτοῖς μὲν γὰρ καὶ Γερμανοῖς καὶ παντὶ τῷ Θρᾳκίῳ τε καὶ Σκυθικῷ γένει ψυχρὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν τὸ δέρμα, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο μαλακόν τε καὶ λευκὸν καὶ ψιλὸν τριχῶν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.15:

For the mixture [krasis] of the body is uneven in regions with poor climates, since the external parts and the internal ones are not in the same condition. For among the Celts and Germans and the entire Thracian and Scythian race, the skin is cold and moist, and because of this it is soft and white and hairless.

---

**Brief notes:**
- [krasis]: the mixture or blending of bodily humors/qualities, a key concept in ancient Greek medical theory
- The text reflects ancient Greek medical-geographical theory about how climate affects bodily constitution
paragraphs.openai_translation: For in regions of disordered temperament [krasis: bodily “mixture” or balance] the body’s constitution is irregular, the external parts and the internal not being in the same condition. For among the Celts and the Germans and every Thracian and Scythian people the skin is cold and moist, and therefore soft, white, and scant of hair.

paragraphs.content: ὅσοις δ’ ἔμφυτον θερμὸν εἰς τὰ σπλάγχνα καταπέφευγεν ἄμα τῷ αἵματι, κᾀνταῦθα κυκωμένου τε καὶ στενοχωρουμένου καὶ ζέοντος αὐτοῦ, θυμικοὶ, καὶ θρασεῖς, καὶ ὀξύῤῥοποι ταῖς γνώμαις ἀποτελοῦνται.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But those in whom the innate heat has taken refuge into the internal organs along with the blood, and there, as it is churned and compressed and boiling, they become spirited, bold, and quick-tempered in their dispositions.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Those in whom the inborn heat has taken refuge into the viscera [internal organs] along with the blood—and there is churned, constrained, and boiling—turn out spirited [choleric], bold, and precipitate in their judgments.

paragraphs.content: Αἰθίοψι δὲ καὶ Ἄραψι καὶ ὅλοις τοῖς κατὰ μεσημβρίαν ἡ μὲν τοῦ δέρματος φύσις ὡς ἂν ὑπό τε τοῦ περιέχοντος θάλπους καὶ τῆς ἐμφύτου θερμασίας ἔξω φερομένης διακεκαυμένη καὶ σκληρὰ καὶ ξηρὰ καὶ μέλαινα. τὸ δ’ ὅλον σῶμα τῆς μὲν ἐμφύτου θερμότητος ἥκιστα μετέχει θερμὸν δ’ ἐστὶν ἀλλοτρίῳ τε καὶ ἐπικτήτῳ θερμῷ. καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ τοῦτο κάλλιστα πρὸς Ἀριστοτέλους ἐπὶ πολλῶν διώρισται. καὶ χρὴ προσέχειν αὐτῷ τὸν νοῦν εἴπερ τινὶ καὶ ἄλλῳ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.18:

Among the Ethiopians and Arabs and all those who live in the southern regions, the nature of their skin is burned, hard, dry, and black, as it would be both from the surrounding heat and from their innate heat being carried outward. But the whole body partakes least of innate warmth, and is hot with an external and acquired heat. For indeed this too has been most excellently distinguished by Aristotle in many cases. And one must pay attention to him if to anyone else at all.

---

**Brief notes:**
- [ἔμφυτος θερμασία/θερμότης] refers to "innate heat," a key concept in ancient Greek medical and physiological theory
- [ἀλλότριος] literally "belonging to another," here rendered as "external"
- [ἐπίκτητος] means "acquired" or "adventitious," as opposed to natural or innate
paragraphs.openai_translation: Among Ethiopians, Arabs, and all those who live toward the south, the nature of the skin—since, under the encompassing heat and with the innate warmth being carried outward—is seared, and hard, and dry, and black. As for the whole body, it partakes least of innate heat [inborn physiological warmth], and is warm instead by an alien and acquired heat [external/ambient and incidental warmth]. For this, too, has been most excellently distinguished by Aristotle in many instances, and one ought to pay heed to him—if to anyone at all.

paragraphs.content: καὶ σκοπεῖσθαι καθ’ ἕκαστον σῶμα πότερον οἰκείῳ θερμῷ θερμόν ἐστιν ἢ ἐπικτήτῳ. πάντα γοῦν τὰ σηπόμενα θερμὰ μὲν ἐπικτήτῳ θερμῷ ψυχρὰ δ’ οἰκείῳ. καὶ τὰ τῶν ἐποικούντων τὴν μεσημβρινὴν χώραν θερμὰ μὲν ἐπικτήτῳ θερμῷ ψυχρὰ δὲ οἰκείῳ. καὶ παρ’ ἡμῖν δὲ κατὰ μὲν τὸν χειμῶνα τὸ φύσει θερμὸν πλεῖον τὸ δ’ ἐπίκτητόν ἐστιν ἧττον. ἐν δὲ τῷ θέρει τὸ μὲν ἐπίκτητον πλέον ἔλαττον δὲ τὸ σύμφυτον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.19:

And one must examine in the case of each body whether it is hot with innate heat or with acquired heat. At any rate, all things that are putrefying are hot with acquired heat but cold with innate heat. And the bodies of those who inhabit the southern region are hot with acquired heat but cold with innate heat. And among us too, in winter the naturally hot is greater while the acquired heat is less. But in summer the acquired heat is greater while the innate heat is less.

---

**Brief notes:**
- [οἰκείῳ θερμῷ / "innate heat" - literally "proper" or "one's own" heat, referring to the body's natural internal heat]
- [ἐπικτήτῳ θερμῷ / "acquired heat" - heat obtained from external sources]
- [σύμφυτον / "innate" - literally "born together with," synonymous with οἰκείῳ in this context]
paragraphs.openai_translation: And one must examine, for each body, whether it is hot by its own heat or by an acquired [epiktētos, “adventitious”] heat. For indeed all things undergoing putrefaction are hot by acquired heat but cold by their own [oikeios, “proper/natural”] heat. And the inhabitants of the southern region are hot by acquired heat but cold by their own. Among us, in winter the heat that is by nature is greater, while the acquired is less; whereas in summer the acquired is greater and the inborn [symphytos, “connate”] is less.

paragraphs.content: ἅπαντα γοῦν ταῦτα διορίζεσθαι χρὴ τὸν μέλλοντα καλῶς διαγνῶναι κρᾶσιν. οὐ γὰρ δὴ ἁπλῶς, εἰ τὸ δέρμα μελάντερον ἤδη, θερμότερος ὁ ἄνθρωπος ὅλος, ἀλλ’ εἰ τῶν ἄλλων ἁπάντων ὡσαύτως ἐχόντων. εἰ γὰρ ὁ μὲν ἐν ἡλίῳ θερμῷ διέτριψεν ἐπιπλέον, ὁ δ’ ἐν σκιᾷ, τῷ μὲν ἔσται μελάντερον τὸ δέρμα, τῷ δὲ λευκότερον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

All these things, then, must be distinguished by one who intends to diagnose temperament [krasis] correctly. For it is not simply the case that if the skin is already rather dark, the whole person is hotter, but only if all other things are likewise equal. For if one person has spent more time in the hot sun, and another in the shade, the one will have darker skin, the other paler skin.
paragraphs.openai_translation: At any rate, anyone who intends to diagnose the krasis [the bodily “mixture” or temperament] correctly must distinguish all such factors. For it is not simply the case that, if the skin is darker, the person as a whole is hotter; rather, that holds only if all the other conditions are likewise the same. For if one has spent more time in the hot sun and another in the shade, the former will have darker skin and the latter lighter.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ οὐδὲν τοῦτο πρὸς τὴν τῆς ὅλης κράσεως ὑπάλλαξιν. αὐτὸ μὲν γὰρ τὸ δέρμα ξηρότερον ἡλιούμενον, ὑγρότερον δ’ ἔσται σκιατραφούμενον. ἡ φυσικὴ δ’ οὐκ εὐθὺς ὑπαλλαχθήσεται κρᾶσις οὔθ’ ἥπατος, οὔτε καρδίας, οὔτε τῶν ἄλλων σπλάγχνων.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But this has nothing to do with the alteration of the mixture of the whole body. For the skin itself will become drier when exposed to the sun, but it will be moister when kept in the shade. However, the natural mixture [krasis] will not immediately be altered, neither of the liver, nor of the heart, nor of the other internal organs [splanchna].
paragraphs.openai_translation: But this contributes nothing to the alteration of the overall krasis [constitutional mixture/temperament]. For the skin itself will be drier when exposed to the sun, and wetter when kept in the shade. But the natural krasis will not be immediately altered—neither that of the liver, nor of the heart, nor of the other viscera [internal organs].

paragraphs.content: ἄριστον οὖν, ὡς εἴρηται καὶ πρόσθεν, ἑκάστου τῶν μορίων ἴδια πεπορίσθαι τῆς κράσεως τὰ γνωρίσματα. οἶον τῆς μὲν γαστρὸς, εἰ πέττει καλῶς, εὔκρατος, εἰ δ’ οὐ πέττει καλῶς, δύσκρατος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Therefore it is best, as has been said previously, that the distinguishing marks of the temperament [krasis] of each of the parts have been determined individually. For example, the stomach, if it digests well, is well-tempered [eukratos]; but if it does not digest well, it is ill-tempered [dyskratos].

---

**Brief notes:**
- [krasis]: mixture or temperament, referring to the balance of bodily humors or qualities
- [eukratos]: having a good mixture/temperament
- [dyskratos]: having a bad mixture/temperament
paragraphs.openai_translation: Best, then—as has been said before—is that each of the parts have its own distinctive signs of its krasis [mixture/temperament]. For example, as regards the stomach: if it digests well, it is eucratic [well-balanced in mixture]; if it does not digest well, it is dyscratic [imbalanced in mixture].

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ εἰ μὲν κνισσώδεις τινὰς ἢ καπνώδεις ἐργάζοιτο τὰς ἐρυγὰς ἄμετρον αὐτῆς καὶ πυρῶδες ὑπάρχει τὸ θερμόν· εἰ δ’ ὀξείας ἄῤῥωστόν τε καὶ ἀσθενές. οὕτω δὲ καὶ βόεια κρέα καὶ πάντα τὰ δυσκατέργαστα καλῶς πεπτόντων ἄμετρον τὸ θερμόν· ἀσθενὲς δὲ τῶν ταῦτα μὲν οὐ πεπτόντων ἰχθύας δὲ πετραίους ἤ τι τοιοῦτο πεπτόντων. ἐπισκέπτεσθαι δὲ χρὴ πάλιν ἐνταῦθα
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.23:

But if it should produce belches that are somewhat greasy or smoky, the heat is excessive and fiery in nature; but if it produces sour belches, the heat is weak and feeble. Similarly also, when beef and all hard-to-digest foods are being digested well, the heat is excessive; but the heat is weak when these foods are not being digested, while rock-fish or something of that sort are being digested. One must examine again in this case

---

**Brief notes:**
- The text discusses diagnostic signs related to digestive heat [thermal capacity of digestion] in medical context
- "Rock-fish" (πετραίους ἰχθύας) refers to fish living among rocks, typically considered easier to digest in ancient medical theory
- The sentence appears incomplete, suggesting continuation in the next paragraph
paragraphs.openai_translation: But if it produces belchings that are greasy-roast-smelling [knissōdeis] or smoky, the heat is excessive and fiery; whereas if they are sharp [acrid], the heat is diseased and weak. Likewise, in those who digest beef and all hard-to-concoct foods well, the heat is immoderate; but it is weak in those who do not digest these, yet do digest rock fish or something of that sort. One must examine this point again here.

paragraphs.content: εἰ μὴ διά τινα χυμὸν ἑτέρωθεν ἐπιῤῥέοντα τὸ σύμπτωμα γίνεται τῇ γαστρί. φλέγμα μὲν γὰρ ἐνίοις ἐκ τῆς κεφαλῆς ξανθὴ δ’ ἄλλοις ἐξ ἥπατος ἐς τὴν γαστέρα καταῤῥεῖ χολὴ σπάνιον δὲ τοῦτο καὶ ὀλιγίστοις συμβαίνει. παμπόλλοις δὲ ἐκ τῆς κεφαλῆς κατέρχεται φλέγμα καὶ μάλιστα ἐν Ῥώμη τε καὶ τοῖς ὑγροῖς οὕτω χωρίοις.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.24:

unless the symptom occurs in the stomach due to some humor flowing down from elsewhere. For in some people phlegm flows down from the head, while in others yellow bile flows down from the liver into the stomach; but this is rare and happens to very few people. However, in very many people phlegm descends from the head, and especially in Rome and in similarly wet regions.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Unless the symptom in the stomach arises because some humor [fluid] is flowing down from elsewhere. For in some people phlegm descends from the head, and in others yellow bile from the liver flows down into the stomach—this is rare and occurs in very few. But in very many, phlegm comes down from the head, especially in Rome and in places that are moist in this way.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλά τοι καὶ τὸ σπάνιον ἐπιβλέπειν χρὴ καὶ μηδὲν ἐν παρέργῳ τίθεσθαι μηδ’ ἀμελεῖν. οἶδα γὰρ ἐγώ τισιν ἱκανῶς φλεγματώδεσιν ἀνθρώποις ἀθροιζομένην ἐν τῇ γαστρὶ χολὴν παμπόλλην ξανθὴν ἣν ἐδέοντο πρὸ τῶν σιτίων ὕδωρ πίνοντες ἢ οἶνον ἐξεμεῖν. εἰ δ’ ἥψαντό ποτε σιτίων πρὶν ἐμέσαι διέφθειράν τε ταῦτα καὶ τὴν κεφαλὴν ὠδυνῶντο καὶ τούτους ᾤοντό τινες χολώδεις εἷναι φύσει. καίτοι μαλακοί τε ἦσαν ὅλον τὸ σῶμα καὶ λευκοὶ καὶ ἄτριχοι καὶ πιμελώδεις καὶ ἄφλεβοι
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.25:

But indeed one must also pay attention to what is rare and not regard anything as incidental or neglect it. For I know certain people who are sufficiently phlegmatic, in whom a great amount of yellow bile accumulates in the stomach, which they needed to vomit up by drinking water or wine before meals. But if they ever touched food before vomiting, they both corrupted it and suffered headaches, and some people thought these men were bilious by nature. And yet they were soft in their whole body and pale and hairless and fat and without visible veins.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But one must also look to what is uncommon and set nothing aside as a mere by-matter or neglect it. For I know of certain men who are sufficiently phlegmatic [dominated by the humor phlegm] in whom bile, very abundant and yellow, accumulates in the stomach, which they need to vomit up before eating by drinking water or wine. If ever they touched food before vomiting, they ruined the food and suffered pain in the head, and some supposed these men to be choleric [bile-dominated] by nature. And yet they were soft in the whole body, pale, hairless, fatty, and without visible veins [i.e., not well vascularized].

paragraphs.content: καὶ ἄμυοι καὶ ἄναιμοι καὶ ἁπτομένοις οὐ λίαν θερμοί.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

and without muscle and without blood and not very hot to the touch.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And they are without muscles and bloodless, and not very warm to the touch. [“without muscles” = lacking muscle tissue; “bloodless” = lacking blood; “to the touch” indicates perceived temperature on contact]

paragraphs.content: ἄλλους δέ τινας οἶδα μηδέποτε μὲν ἐμέσαντας χολὴν ξανθὴν, ἰσχνοὺς δὲ καὶ δασεῖς καὶ μυώδεις καὶ μέλανας καὶ φλεβώδεις καὶ θερμοὺς ἱκανῶς, εἴ τις ἅψαιτο, φαινομένους, οἷος καὶ ὁ φιλόσοφος Εὔδημος.
paragraphs.claude_translation: But I know certain other men who have never vomited yellow bile, yet appear lean and hairy and muscular and dark-complexioned and full-veined and quite hot, if one should touch them—such as was also the philosopher Eudemus.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And yet I know certain others who have never vomited yellow bile [cholê xanthê], and who appear lean, hairy, muscular, dark, and veiny [with prominent veins], and sufficiently warm to the touch if one were to handle them—such, for example, as the philosopher Eudemus.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἐνταῦθα μὲν ἐμπέπτωκε καὶ ἀνατομικόν τι θεώρημα ὃ μὴ γνόντες ἔνιοι τῶν ἰατρῶν ἀποροῦνται δεινῶς ἐπὶ τῇ διαφωνίᾳ τῶν συμπτωμάτων ἀγνοοῦντες ὡς ὁ πόρος ᾧ τὴν χολὴν εἰς τὴν γαστέρα τὸ ἧπαρ ἐξερεύγεται τοῖς μὲν διπλοῦς ἐστι τοῖς δὲ ἁπλοῦς ὡς κᾀν ταῖς τῶν τετραπόδων ζώων ἀνατομαῖς ἐστι θεάσασθαι. τὰ πολλὰ μὲν οὖν ἢ ἁπλοῦς ἐστιν εἰς τὰ μεταξὺ πυλωροῦ τε καὶ νήστεως ἐκφυόμενος ὃ δὴ γαστρὸς ἔκφυσιν ὀνομάζουσιν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But at this point there has arisen also a certain anatomical observation which some physicians, not knowing it, are terribly perplexed by the discrepancy of symptoms, being ignorant that the passage through which the liver discharges bile into the stomach is double in some cases but single in others, as one can observe also in the dissections of quadruped animals. In most cases, then, it is single, growing out into the space between the pylorus and the jejunum [fasting intestine], which they call the outgrowth of the stomach.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But at this point there also intrudes an anatomical observation, which, not knowing, some physicians are greatly perplexed by because of the discrepancy of the symptoms—being unaware that the channel [poros, i.e., duct] by which the liver discharges bile into the stomach is in some people double and in others single, as one may see even in the dissections of quadrupeds. For the most part, then, it is single, putting forth into the region between the pylorus [pyloros] and the nēstis [jejunum], which they call an outgrowth of the stomach [ekphysis].

paragraphs.content: ἢ διπλοῦς γενόμενος εἰς μὲν τὴν ἔκφυσιν ἐμβάλλει θατέρῳ στόματι τῷ μείζονι θατέρῳ δὲ τῷ μικροτέρῳ κατὰ τὸν πυθμένα μικρὸν ἀνωτέρω τοῦ πυλωροῦ. σπανιώτατα δὲ τὸ μὲν ἄνω μέρος αὐτοῦ ποτὲ μεῖζον εὑρίσκεται τὸ κάτω δ’ ἔλαττον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Or having become double, it inserts into the outgrowth with one opening, the larger one, and with the other, the smaller one, at the fundus [bottom], a little above the pylorus [gastric outlet]. But very rarely the upper part of it is sometimes found to be larger and the lower part smaller.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Or else, becoming double, it opens with one mouth—the larger—into the outgrowth [the duodenum], and with the other—the smaller—at the fundus, a little above the pylorus. Very rarely, its upper part is found at times to be larger and the lower smaller.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἐφ’ ὧν γε μεῖζόν ἐστιν ἐπὶ τούτων ἡ γαστὴρ ἐφ’ ἡμέραν ἐμπίπλαται χολῆς οὐκ ὀλίγης ἣν ἐμεῖν τε δέονται πρὸ τῶν σιτίων καὶ βλάπτονται κατασχόντες. οἷς δὲ παντελῶς ἁπλοῦς ἐστιν ὁ πόρος εἰς τὴν νῆστιν ἡ χολὴ τούτοις σύμπασα καταῤῥεῖ. πῶς οὗν χρὴ διαγινώσκειν αὐτούς; οὐ γὰρ δὴ ἀνατεμεῖν γε ζῶντας τοὺς ἀνθρώπους ἀξιῶ. πρῶτον μὲν ὅλῃ τοῦ σώματος τῇ κράσει καθ’ ὅ τι καὶ μικρὸν ἔμπροσθεν ἐλέγετο
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But in those cases where it [the opening] is larger, in these cases the stomach fills up daily with no small amount of bile, which they need to vomit up before meals, and they are harmed if they retain it. But in those for whom the passage into the jejunum [nēstis, literally "fasting intestine"] is entirely simple, for these people all the bile flows down. How then should one diagnose them? For surely I do not think it right to dissect people while they are alive. First, by the whole mixture [krasis, temperament] of the body, according to what was also said a little earlier
paragraphs.openai_translation: But in those at least in whom the stomach [gaster] is larger, each day it fills with no small amount of bile, which they both need to vomit up before eating, and they are harmed if they hold it back. In those, however, for whom the passage for the bile into the jejunum [nēstis] is altogether straightforward, all of it flows down. How, then, should one diagnose such persons? For I certainly do not approve of cutting open human beings while alive. First, by the overall temperament [krasis, bodily mixture] of the body, as was said a little before.

paragraphs.content: δεύτερον δὲ τοῖς ὑπιοῦσι κάτω. χολώδη μὲν γὰρ ἄκρατα διὰ τῆς γαστρὸς ἐξεκενοῦτο συνεχῶς Εὐδήμῳ διότι καὶ πολλὴν ἤθροιζε χολὴν καὶ οὐδὲν αὐτῆς εἰς τὴν ἄνω κοιλίαν ἀφικνεῖτο. τοῖς δὲ ἄλλοις οἷς ἡ μὲν ἕξις φλεγματώδης ἐμοῦσι δὲ χολὴν ἥκιστα διαχωρεῖται χολῶδες· καὶ γὰρ ὀλίγον γεννᾶται τῆς ξανθῆς χολῆς αὐτοῖς
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.31:

Second, for those whose discharges go downward. For in Eudemus's case, unmixed bilious matter was continuously evacuated through the bowels, because he both accumulated much bile and none of it reached the upper cavity [stomach]. But for the others whose constitution is phlegmatic and who vomit bile least, bilious matter is least passed through the bowels; for only a small amount of yellow bile is generated in them.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Secondly, for those lying supine with the head downward [posture: supine, head lower than the body]. For in Eudemus unmixed bilious matter was being emptied continuously through the stomach, because he both accumulated a great quantity of bile and none of it made its way into the upper cavity [upper belly/chest]. But in others whose constitution is phlegmatic, although they vomit bile, the bilious component separates least; for only a small amount of yellow bile is produced in them.

paragraphs.content: καὶ πλεῖστον εἰς τὴν ἄνω κοιλίαν ἀφικνεῖται. τρίτον ἐπὶ τοῖς εἰρημένοις εἶδος γνωρισμάτων ἐν αὐτοῖς τοῖς κενουμένοις ἐστίν. οἷς μὲν γὰρ ἐν τῇ γαστρὶ τὸ χολῶδες γεννᾶται περίττωμα πρασοειδὲς φαίνεται· ξανθὸν δ’ ἀκριβῶς ἐστιν ἢ ὠχρόν γε πάντως οἷς ἐξ ἥπατος ὑπέρχεται. καὶ οἷς μὲν ἐν γαστρὶ τὸ πρασοειδὲς τοῦτο γεννᾶται χρὴ πάντως αὐτοῖς τὸ ἐδηδεσμένον σιτίον οὐκ ἄρτον οὐδὲ κρέας εἶναι χοίρειον ἤ τι τοιοῦτο παραπλήσιον ἀλλὰ θερμότερόν γε τῶν δ’ ἐξ ἀνάγκης
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

And the greatest amount reaches the upper cavity [stomach]. A third type of distinguishing sign, in addition to those mentioned, is found in the evacuations themselves. For in those cases where the bilious residue is generated in the stomach, it appears leek-green; but it is precisely yellow or at any rate pale in those cases where it passes down from the liver. And in those cases where this leek-green substance is generated in the stomach, the food that has been eaten must necessarily not be bread or pork or anything similar of that sort, but rather something more heating. But of those things which necessarily...
paragraphs.openai_translation: And for the most part it makes its way to the upper abdomen. Third, in addition to what has been said, there is a kind of sign found in the evacuations themselves [i.e., stools]. For in those in whom the bilious excess [cholōdes perittōma: bile-like residue] is generated in the stomach, a leek-colored [greenish] discharge appears; but in those in whom it comes from the liver it is distinctly yellow, or at any rate pale. And for those in whom this leek-colored [greenish] matter is generated in the stomach, the food they consume must by all means not be bread nor pork, nor anything of that sort akin to it, but rather something hotter than these—and of those, of necessity—

paragraphs.content: καὶ οὐκ εὔχυμον. οἷς δ’ ἐξ ἥπατος εἰς αὐτὴν ἀφικνεῖται ξανθὸν ἢ ὠχρὸν ἐμεῖται κᾂν εὐχυμώτατον ᾖ τὸ ληφθὲν σιτίον κᾂν ἄκρως πεφθῇ. καὶ μᾶλλον τοῖς ἀκριβῶς πέψασιν ἐμεῖται τὰ ξανθὰ καὶ πολλῷ μᾶλλον ἔτι τοῖς ἐπὶ πλέον αὐτῶν ἀσιτήσασι. τὰ δὲ πρασοειδῆ μόνοις τοῖς κακῶς πέψασιν ἐν τῇ κοιλίᾳ γεννᾶται. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ φροντίδες καὶ θυμοὶ καὶ λῦπαι καὶ πόνοι καὶ γυμνάσια καὶ ἀγρυπνίαι καὶ ἀσιτίαι
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

and not of good humor. But for those to whom yellow or pale bile comes from the liver into it [the stomach], they vomit yellow bile even if the food taken is most wholesome and even if it has been perfectly digested. And those who have digested thoroughly vomit yellow bile more, and much more still those who have fasted for a longer time after this. But leek-green [bile] is produced only in those who have digested badly in the stomach. And indeed anxieties and fits of anger and griefs and labors and exercises and sleeplessness and fasting
paragraphs.openai_translation: And it is not well-humored [euchymon: having good, well-concocted juices]. But in those for whom yellow or pale [bile] arrives into it from the liver, they vomit, even if the food taken is most well-humored and even if it has been thoroughly cooked/digested. And the yellow matters are vomited especially by those who have digested most exactly, and much more still by those who have fasted longer. But leek-colored [prasoeidē: greenish] matters are produced only in those who have digested badly in the belly [koilia: stomach]. And indeed anxieties, outbursts of anger, griefs, pains, exercises, sleeplessnesses, and fastings…

paragraphs.content: καὶ ἔνδειαι πλείονα τὸν τῆς ξανθῆς χολῆς τούτοις ἀθροίζουσι χυμὸν ὅτι καὶ πλείονα γεννῶσιν ἐν ἥπατι. ταῦτά τε οὖν ἀκριβῆ τὰ γνωρίσματα καὶ πρὸς τούτοις ἔτι τῷ μὲν αὐχμηρῷ καὶ πυρώδει τοῦ κατὰ τὴν γαστέρα θερμοῦ τῆς εἰς τὸ χολῶδες τροπῆς ἑπομένης ἄρτοι καὶ κρέα χοίρεια καὶ βόεια κάλλιον πεφθήσονται τῶν πετραίων ἰχθύων. εἰ δ’ ἐξ ἥπατος καταῤῥέοι
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.34:

And deficiencies cause these people to accumulate a greater amount of the yellow bile humor because they also generate more of it in the liver. These signs, then, are reliable, and in addition to these, since the transformation into bile follows from the dry and fiery quality of the heat in the stomach, breads and pork and beef will be better digested than rock fish. But if it should flow down from the liver

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence with "εἰ δ' ἐξ ἥπατος καταῤῥέοι" ("But if it should flow down from the liver"), suggesting this is an incomplete excerpt from a larger medical treatise, likely from the Hippocratic corpus or a similar Galenic text discussing humoral theory and digestion.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And deprivations [fasting or lack of nourishment] gather in these people a larger amount of the humor of yellow bile, since they also generate more of it in the liver. These, then, are exact diagnostic signs; and in addition, when the heat about the stomach is dry and burning, with the ensuing change inclining toward the bilious, breads and pork and beef, when boiled, will be better than rock fish. But if it should flow down from the liver— [sc. the bile; sentence continues]

paragraphs.content: παρὰ τὴν τῶν ἐδεσμάτων ὑπάλλαξιν οὐδὲ μία τῆς πέψεως ἔσται διαφορά. ἐν τούτοις μὲν δὴ διώρισται τὸ δι’ ἄλλο τι καὶ μὴ διὰ τὴν κρᾶσιν γενόμενον. κατὰ τὸν αὐτὸν δὲ τρόπον εἰ κᾀκ τῆς κεφαλῆς ἐπὶ τὴν γαστέρα φλέγμα καταῤῥέον ὀξυρεγμίας αἴτιον γίγνοιτο χρὴ κᾀνταῦθα κατὰ τὰς ὁμοίας μεθόδους ἀποχωρίζειν αὐτὸ τοῦ τῆς γαστρὸς ἰδίου παθήματος. οὕτω δὲ καὶ τὰς τῆς κεφαλῆς ὀδύνας ἢ διὰ τὴν οἰκείαν αὐτῆς δυσκρασίαν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.35:

In relation to the variation of foods, there will be not even a single difference in digestion. In these matters, then, what occurs on account of something else and not on account of the mixture [krasis] has been distinguished. In the same manner, if phlegm flowing down from the head to the stomach should become the cause of acid eructation [heartburn], one must here too separate it from the stomach's own affection by means of similar methods. And likewise, one must [distinguish] the pains of the head either through its own bad mixture [dyskrasia]

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end. The term *krasis* refers to the mixture or balance of bodily humors, while *dyskrasia* indicates an imbalance or bad mixture of these humors—both key concepts in ancient Greek medical theory.
paragraphs.openai_translation: In spite of a substitution of foods, not even the least difference in digestion will occur. In such cases, then, it has been distinguished what comes about on account of something else and not because of the [bodily] temperament [krasis]. And in the same way, if phlegm flowing down from the head to the stomach becomes the cause of acid eructation [sour belching: oxyregmia], one must here too, by analogous methods, separate this from an affection proper to the stomach itself. So too the pains of the head, either on account of its own dyskrasia [faulty mixture/temperament]…

paragraphs.content: ἢ διὰ τὰ τῆς γαστρὸς περιττώματα. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ τὸν ἐγκέφαλον ἐπισκέπτεσθαι καθ’ ἑαυτὸν ὁποίας ἐστὶ κράσεως ἄμεινον οὖκ ἐκ τῆς τοῦ παντὸς σώματος διαθέσεως. αὐτοῦ δὲ κατ’ αὐτὸν ὁποίας ἐστὶ κράσεως ἐπίσκεψις ἥ τε πολίωσίς ἐστιν οἵ τε κάταῤῥοι καὶ βῆχες καὶ κόρυζαι καὶ σιέλου πλῆθος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Or because of the residues of the stomach. And indeed it is better to examine the brain itself by itself, to determine what kind of mixture [temperament] it has, rather than from the condition of the whole body. The examination of what kind of mixture it has in and of itself consists of: graying of hair, catarrhs [mucous discharges], coughs, head colds, and abundance of saliva.
paragraphs.openai_translation: —or because of the stomach’s superfluities [perittōmata: excess residues]. And indeed, it is better to examine the brain by itself as to what kind of krasis [mixture/temperament] it has, rather than from the condition of the whole body. The investigation of what krasis it has from its own signs consists in poliosis [graying of the hair], catarrhs, coughs, coryzas [head-colds, nasal discharge], and an abundance of saliva.

paragraphs.content: ἅπαντα γὰρ ταῦτα ψυχρότερον αὐτὸν ἐμφαίνει καὶ ὑγρότερον ὑπάρχειν. ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον εἰ ἐπὶ ταῖς τυχούσαις προφάσεσιν εἰς τοιαύτας ἔρχεται διαθέσεις. ἡ δέ γε φαλάκρωσις ἐπὶ ξηρότητι καὶ ἡ τῶν μελαινῶν τε καὶ πολλῶν τριχῶν γένεσις εὐκρασίας ἐγκεφάλου γνώρισμα. κατὰ τοῦτον οὖν τὸν τρόπον ἀεὶ χρὴ σκοπεῖσθαι περὶ κράσεως ἕκαστον ἰδίᾳ μόριον ἐξετάζοντα καὶ μὴ περὶ πάντων ἀποφαίνεσθαι τολμᾷν ἐξ ἑνὸς ὥσπερ ἐποίησαν ἔνιοι τοὺς μὲν σιμοὺς ὑγροὺς εἶναι φάμενοι τοὺς δὲ γρυποὺς ξηροὺς
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.37:

For all these things show that he is rather cold and moist in constitution. And even more so if he falls into such conditions upon random occasions. Baldness, on the other hand, occurs due to dryness, while the production of dark and abundant hair is a sign of good mixture [eucrasia] of the brain. Therefore, one must always examine the mixture [krasis] in this manner, investigating each part individually, and not dare to make pronouncements about all things from a single feature, as some have done who say that snub-nosed people are moist and hook-nosed people are dry.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For all these things show him to be colder and to have a moister constitution. And even more so if, on whatever occasions arise, he comes into such conditions. Baldness is due to dryness, and the growth of dark and abundant hair is a sign of a well-balanced mixture of the brain [eukrasia = balanced temperament]. In this way, then, one must always investigate matters of temperament [krasis = mixture/temperament], examining each part individually, and not presume to pronounce about everything from a single feature, as some have done—saying that the snub-nosed are moist, while the hooked-nosed are dry.

paragraphs.content: καὶ οἶς μὲν οἱ ὀφθαλμοὶ μικροὶ ξηροὺς οἷς δὲ μεγάλοι ὑγρούς. τοῦτο μὲν οὖν καὶ διαπεφώνηται πρὸς αὐτῶν. οἱ μὲν γάρ τινες ὑποθέμενοι τῶν ὑγρῶν εἶναι μορίων τοὺς ὀφθαλμοὺς ἐν οἷς ἂν μείζους εὑρίσκωσιν ὑγρότητα κράσεως ἐν τούτοις κρατεῖν ὑπολαμβάνουσιν. ἔνιοι δὲ τῇ ῥώμῃ τοῦ θερμοῦ κατὰ τὴν πρώτην διάπλασιν ἀναπνεύσαντος ἀθροώτερόν τε καὶ πλεῖον οὐκ ὀφθαλμοὺς μόνον ἀλλὰ καὶ τὸ στόμα καὶ τοὺς ἄλλους ἅπαντας πόρους γενέσθαι φασὶ μείζονας ὅθεν οὐχ ὑγρότητος
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.38:

And for those whose eyes are small [they indicate] dry [temperaments], while for those whose eyes are large [they indicate] moist [temperaments]. Now this matter has indeed been disputed among them. For some, having assumed that the eyes are among the moist parts [of the body], believe that in whomever they find the eyes larger, moisture of mixture [i.e., moist temperament] prevails in these people. But others say that by the strength of the heat breathing out more abundantly and copiously during the first formation [of the embryo], not only the eyes but also the mouth and all the other passages become larger—whence [the larger size comes] not from moisture...

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence with "whence not from moisture," suggesting the argument continues in the next section.]
paragraphs.openai_translation: And we reckon those with small eyes dry, and those with large [eyes] moist. This, then, has even been expressly declared by them themselves. For some, assuming that the eyes are among the moist parts, suppose that wherever they find the eyes larger, in those cases moisture of constitution [krâsis: mixture/temperament] prevails. Others, however, say that, by the vigor of the heat [rhômê: strength], at the first formation, as it “breathed out/expanded” [anapneûsantos], more copiously and in greater quantity, not only the eyes but also the mouth and all the other pores came to be larger—whence not from moisture—

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ θερμότητος εἶναι γνώρισμα.
paragraphs.claude_translation: but to be a sign of heat.
paragraphs.openai_translation: but it is a distinguishing mark of heat [gnōrisma: identifying sign].

paragraphs.content: ἀμφότεροι δὲ διαμαρτάνουσι τῆς ἀληθείας ἑνὶ μὲν καὶ κοινῷ λόγῳ διότι περὶ παντὸς τοῦ σώματος ἐξ ἑνὸς ἀποφαίνεσθαι τολμῶσι μορίου· κατὰ δὲ δεύτερον τρόπον ὅτι τῆς διαπλαστικῆς ἐν τῇ φύσει δυνάμεως οὐ μέμνηνται τεχνικῆς οὔσης καὶ τοῖς τῆς ψυχῆς ἤθεσιν ἀκολούθως διαπλαττούσης τὰ μόρια. περὶ ταύτης γάρ τοι καὶ Ἀριστοτέλης ἠπόρησε μήποτ’ ἄρα θειοτέρας τινὸς ἀρχῆς εἴη καὶ οὐ κατὰ τὸ θερμὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Both err from the truth, first by a single and common argument, because they dare to make pronouncements about the entire body from a single part; and secondly because they make no mention of the formative power in nature, which is artistic and fashions the parts in accordance with the character traits of the soul.
