For indeed even Aristotle raised the question whether this power might perhaps belong to some more divine principle and not operate according to hot and cold.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Both parties miss the truth, first in a single, common respect, because they dare to pronounce on the whole body from a single part; and, second, because they fail to remember the formative power in nature [diaplastikē dynamis: the shaping/formative faculty], which is of an artful kind and fashions the parts in accordance with the dispositions of the soul [ēthē: character/temperaments]. For about this even Aristotle was perplexed, wondering whether perhaps it derives from some more divine principle, and not on the basis of the hot and the cold [elemental qualities].

paragraphs.content: καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ ὑγρόν. οὔκουν ὀρθῶς μοι δοκοῦσι ποιεῖν οἱ προπετῶς οὕτως ὑπὲρ τῶν μεγίστων ἀποφαινόμενοι καὶ ταῖς ποιότησι μόναις ἀναφέροντες τὴν διάπλασιν. εὔλογον γὰρ ὄργανα μὲν εἶναι ταύτας τὸ διαπλάττον δ’ ἕτερον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

and dry and moist. Therefore, it seems to me that those who pronounce judgment so rashly about the greatest matters and attribute the formation [of living things] to the qualities alone do not act correctly. For it is reasonable that these are instruments, but that which forms is something else.
paragraphs.openai_translation: …and both dry and moist. Accordingly, I do not think those men act rightly who so rashly make pronouncements on matters of the greatest importance and ascribe formation [διάπλασις, “shaping/organization”] to the qualities alone [i.e., hot, cold, dry, moist]. For it is reasonable that these should be instruments, while that which does the shaping is something else.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ χωρὶς τῶν τηλικούτων ζητημάτων ἐνδέχεται ἐξευρίσκειν, ὡς ἔμπροσθεν ἐδείξαμεν, ὑγρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν, καὶ θερμὴν καὶ ψυχρὰν κρᾶσιν. ἁμαρτάνουσιν οὖν οἱ τῶν οἰκείων μὲν ἀμελοῦντες γνωρισμάτων, ἐπὶ δὲ τὰ πόῤῥω τε καὶ ζητήσεως ἱκανῆς τετυχηκότα καὶ μέχρι τοῦ δεῦρο καὶ παρ’ αὐτοῖς τοῖς ἀρίστοις φιλοσόφοις ἀπορούμενα μεταβαίνοντες. οὐδὲ γὰρ οὐδ’ ὅτι τὰ μὲν παιδία σιμώτερα, γρυπώτεροι δ’ οἱ παρακμάζοντες, εὔλογον, ὑγροὺς μὲν νομίζειν τοὺς σιμοὺς ἅπαντας, ξηροὺς δὲ τοὺς γρυπούς.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But even apart from such great questions, it is possible to discover, as we demonstrated earlier, a moist and dry temperament, and a hot and cold temperament. Therefore those who neglect their own proper signs of recognition, but proceed to matters that are remote and have received considerable investigation and remain disputed up to the present day even among the best philosophers themselves, are in error. For it is not reasonable, just because children are rather snub-nosed while those past their prime are more hook-nosed, to consider all snub-nosed people moist and hook-nosed people dry.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But even apart from such far‑reaching questions it is possible, as we showed earlier, to determine a moist and a dry, and a hot and a cold krasis [mixture/temperament]. Those, then, are in error who, neglecting the proper signs [diagnostic indications], turn instead to remote matters that have demanded considerable investigation and are to this day puzzling even for the best philosophers. For it is not reasonable, just because children are more snub‑nosed [simoi] and those in decline [the aging] more hooked‑nosed [gryps], to suppose that all the snub‑nosed are moist and all the hooked‑nosed are dry.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἐνδέχεται μὲν καὶ τῆς διαπλαστικῆς δυνάμεως ἔργον εἶναι τὸ τοιοῦτο μᾶλλον ἢ τῆς κράσεως. εἰ δ’ ἄρα καὶ τῆς κράσεως εἴη γνώρισμα τῆς ἐν τῇ ῥινὶ μόνης εἴη ἄν οὐ τῆς ἐν ὅλῳ τῷ σώματι. μάτην οὖν ὑπ’ αὐτῶν κᾀκεῖνο λέγεται τὸ ῥῖνά τε ὀξεῖαν γίνεσθαι καὶ ὀφθαλμοὺς κοίλους καὶ κροτάφους συμπεπτωκότας ἐν ταῖς ξηραῖς φύσει κράσεσιν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But it is possible that such a thing is the work of the formative faculty rather than of the mixture [krasis]. And if indeed it should be a sign of the mixture, it would be only of the mixture in the nose, not of that in the whole body. Therefore, that other thing is also said by them in vain: that the nose becomes sharp and the eyes hollow and the temples sunken in those whose natures have dry mixtures [kraseis].
paragraphs.openai_translation: But it is also possible that such a phenomenon is the work of the formative power [diaplastic power] rather than of the temperament [krasis]. And if it were in fact a mark of temperament, it would be of the temperament in the nose alone, not of that in the whole body. Therefore their further claim is made in vain, namely that in natures whose temperament is naturally dry the nose becomes sharp, the eyes hollow, and the temples sunken.

paragraphs.content: ὅτι κᾀν τοῖς πάθεσιν οὕτω συμπίπτει τοῖς συντήκουσί τε καὶ κενοῦσι πέρα τοῦ μετρίου τὰ σώματα. πολλάκις μὲν γὰρ οὕτω συμπίπτει πολλάκις δ’ οὐχ οὕτως.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Because even in diseases it happens in this way with those that waste away and empty the bodies beyond what is moderate. For often it happens in this way, but often not in this way.

[Note: This appears to be from a medical text discussing bodily conditions. "Waste away" (συντήκουσι) and "empty" (κενοῦσι) refer to processes that deplete or drain the body of its substances or fluids.]
paragraphs.openai_translation:
That even in illnesses it likewise happens in the case of those who melt down and empty the bodies beyond the mean. For often it happens thus, and often not thus.

[“melt down” = induce wasting/resolution; “empty” = purge/evacuate; “beyond the mean” = beyond due/moderate measure]

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἔστιν ἰδεῖν καὶ μαλακὴν καὶ πιμελώδη καὶ λευκὴν καὶ πολύσαρκον ὅλου τοῦ σώματος τὴν ἕξιν ἐπὶ μικροῖς ὀφθαλμοῖς ἢ ὀξείᾳ ῥινὶ καὶ ξηρὰν καὶ ἄσαρκον καὶ μέλαιναν καὶ δασεῖαν ἐπί τε τοῖς μεγάλοις ὀφθαλμοῖς σιμῇ τε τῇ ῥινί. βέλτιον οὖν εἴπερ ἄρα τῆς ῥινὸς μόνης ὑγρότητα μὲν τῇ σιμότητι ξηρότητα δὲ τῇ γρυπότητι τεκμαίρεσθαι
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But it is possible to see a soft and fatty and pale and fleshy condition of the whole body in the case of small eyes or a sharp nose, and a dry and fleshless and dark and hairy condition in the case of both large eyes and a snub nose. It is better therefore, if indeed one must, to infer moisture from the snubness of the nose alone and dryness from its hookedness.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But one may also observe the whole body’s habit to be soft, fatty, white, and very fleshy in those with small eyes or a pointed nose, and dry, fleshless, dark, and shaggy [hairy] in those with large eyes and with a snub nose [upturned]. It is better, then, if one is to judge from the nose alone, to infer moistness from snubness and dryness from hookedness [aquiline shape].

paragraphs.content: καὶ μὴ περὶ τῆς ἅπαντος τοῦ ζώου κράσεως ἐντεῦθεν ἀποφαίνεσθαι. κατὰ ταῦτα δὲ καὶ περὶ τῶν ὀφθαλμῶν καὶ παντὸς οὗτινος οὖν ἑτέρου μορίου τὴν ἰδίαν κρᾶσιν ἐκ τῶν οἰκείων ἐπισκοπεῖσθαι γνωρισμάτων ἄμεινον οὐ περὶ τῆς ὅλης τοῦ σώματος κράσεως ἀφ’ ἑνὸς μέρους ἐπίδειξιν λαμβάνειν. εἴτε γὰρ ὑγρότητος εἴτε θερμότητος ἐπικρατούσης εἴτε καὶ ἀμφοτέρων ὀφθαλμοὺς γλαυκοὺς τίθεσθαι χρὴ γνώρισμα τῆς οἰκείας ἂν εἶεν οὕτω γε
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.47:

And one should not make pronouncements about the mixture [krasis] of the entire animal based on this. In the same way, it is better to examine the particular mixture of the eyes and of any other part whatsoever from their own proper signs, rather than to take a demonstration about the mixture of the whole body from a single part. For whether one must regard gray-blue eyes [glaukous ophthalmous] as a sign of predominating moisture or heat or both, they would thus be a sign of their own particular [mixture]

---

**Notes:**
- *krasis* (κρᾶσις/κράσεως): the mixture or blending of bodily humors or qualities, a key concept in ancient Greek medical theory
- *glaukous ophthalmous* (ὀφθαλμοὺς γλαυκούς): literally "gleaming" or "bright" eyes, typically referring to gray-blue or light-colored eyes
paragraphs.openai_translation: And do not, on this basis, pronounce about the krâsis [mixture/temperament] of the living creature as a whole. In the same way, with regard to the eyes and to any other part whatsoever, it is better to examine the part’s own krâsis from its proper signs, rather than to derive a demonstration of the whole body’s krâsis from a single part. For whether a predominance of moisture or of heat, or of both, is present, one should take glaukos eyes [pale/grey-blue, gleaming] as a mark of the eye’s own condition; in that way, at least, they would be a sign of its proper krâsis.

paragraphs.content: καὶ οὐ τῆς ἁπάντων τῶν μορίων τοῦ σώματος ἐνδεικτικοὶ κράσεως. οὐδὲ γὰρ εἰ σκληρὰ καὶ ἄσαρκα τὰ σκέλη ξηρὰ πάντως καὶ ἡ κρᾶσις ὅλου τοῦ σώματος. ἔνιοι γὰρ ἱκανῶς εὔσαρκοι καὶ πιμελώδεις καὶ παχεῖς καὶ προγάστορες καὶ μαλακοὶ καὶ λευκοὶ γίνονται μετὰ τοιούτων σκελῶν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

And they are not indicative of the temperament of all the parts of the body. For even if the legs are hard and lacking in flesh, the temperament of the whole body is not necessarily dry. For some people become quite fleshy and fat and stout and pot-bellied and soft and pale even with such legs.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And they are not indications of the temperament [krâsis: the bodily mixture/constitution] of all the parts of the body. For not even if the legs are hard and without flesh is the temperament of the whole body necessarily dry. For some people become quite well-fleshed and fatty and stout and pot-bellied and soft and pale, even with such legs.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ εἰ μὲν ὁμαλῶς ἅπαν ἔχει τὸ σῶμα τῆς κράσεως οἶς μὲν ἰσχνὰ τὰ σκέλη ξηροὶ πάντως εἰσὶν ὑγροὶ δ’ οἷς παχέα. καὶ οἷς μὲν ἡ ῥὶς ὀξεῖα ἢ γρυπὴ οὗτοι ξηροὶ σιμῆς δ’ οὔσης ὑγροί. κατὰ ταῦτα δὲ καὶ περὶ τῶν ὀφθαλμῶν καὶ τῶν κροτάφων ἁπάντων τε τῶν ἄλλων μορίων. οἷς δ’ ἀνώμαλος ἡ κρᾶσις καὶ οὐχ ἡ αὐτὴ πάντων τῶν μορίων
paragraphs.claude_translation:
But if the entire body has a uniform mixture [of qualities], those who have thin legs are altogether dry, while those who have thick ones are moist. And those who have a sharp or hooked nose are dry, but when it is snub-nosed they are moist. And the same principles apply concerning the eyes and the temples and all the other parts. But for those whose mixture is non-uniform and not the same in all their parts—

---

**Brief notes:**
- [κρᾶσις/κράσεως] refers to the "mixture" or "temperament" of bodily humors, a key concept in ancient Greek medical theory
- The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end, suggesting continuation in the next paragraph
paragraphs.openai_translation: But if the body as a whole is evenly disposed in respect to its mixture [krasis: the bodily “blend” or temperament], then those whose legs are slender are entirely dry, while those whose legs are thick are moist. And those whose nose is sharp or hooked are dry; if it is snub, they are moist. The same holds, correspondingly, for the eyes and the temples and all the other parts. But in those whose mixture is irregular and not the same in all the parts—

paragraphs.content: ἄτοπόν ἐστιν ἐξ ἑνὸς μορίου φύσεως ὑπὲρ ἁπάντων ἀποφαίνεσθαι. τοιοῦτο δέ τι τοὺς πλείστους αὐτῶν ἠπάτησεν οὐχ ὑπὲρ ἀνθρώπων μόνων ἀλλὰ καὶ περὶ τῶν ἄλλων ζώων ἀποφῄνασθαι τολμήσαντας ὑπὲρ ὅλης τῆς κράσεως ἐκ μόνων τῶν κατὰ τὸ δέρμα γνωρισμάτων. οὐδὲ γὰρ εἰ σκληρὸν τὸ δέρμα ξηρὸν ἐξ ἀνάγκης τὸ ζῶον ἀλλ’ ἐγχωρεῖ τὸ δέρμα μόνον οὔτ’ εἰ μέλαν οὔτ’ εἰ δασύ. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον οὔτ’ εἰ μαλακὸν ἢ ψιλὸν τριχῶν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

It is absurd to make pronouncements about all things from one part of nature. Something of this sort has deceived most of them who have dared to make pronouncements not only about human beings but also about other animals concerning the whole mixture [temperament] from only the signs relating to the skin. For neither if the skin is hard is the animal necessarily dry, but it is possible for the skin alone to be so, nor if it is dark nor if it is hairy. And in the same way, neither if it is soft or hairless

---

**Brief notes:**
- [κρᾶσις/mixture] refers to the temperament or constitutional blend of qualities in medical/physiological theory
- The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end
paragraphs.openai_translation: It is absurd to pronounce on all things from a single part of a creature’s nature. Something of this sort deceived most of them: they dared to make pronouncements not only about human beings but also about the other animals concerning the entire krasis [mixture/temperament] on the basis of signs taken solely from the skin. For even if the skin is hard, it does not follow of necessity that the animal is dry; it may be that only the skin is so—nor, if it is black, nor if it is shaggy [i.e., thickly haired]. And in the same way, not even if it is soft or scant of hair [i.e., smooth].

paragraphs.content: ὑγρὸν ἐξ ἀνάγκης ὅλον τὸ ζῶον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
The entire animal is necessarily moist.

---

**Alternative translation:**

The whole animal is of necessity moist.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Of necessity, the whole living organism is moist.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ εἰ μὲν ὁμαλῶς κέκραται σύμπαν εὔλογόν ἐστιν οἷόν περ τὸ δέρμα τοιοῦτο εἶναι καὶ τῶν ἄλλων ἕκαστον μορίων· εἰ δ’ ἀνωμάλως οὐκέτι. τῶν γοῦν ὀστρέων ὑγρότατον μὲν ὅλον τὸ σῶμα ξηρότατον δὲ τὸ δέρμα. τὸ γὰρ δὴ ὄστρακον αὐτοῖς οἷόν περ ἡμῖν τὸ δέρμα. καὶ ἡ προσηγορία δ’ ἐντεῦθεν ὀστρακοδέρμων ἁπάντων τῶν τοιούτων ζώων ὀνομασθέντων ἐκ τοῦ τὸ δέρμα παραπλήσιον αὐτοῖς εἶναι τῷ ὀστράκῳ. καὶ τὰ μαλακόστρακα δὲ καθάπερ ἀστακοὶ καὶ κάραβοι καὶ καρκῖνοι
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.52:

But if the whole is blended uniformly, it is reasonable that each of the other parts should be of the same sort as the skin; but if it is blended non-uniformly, this is no longer the case. At any rate, in the case of oysters, the whole body is very moist but the skin is very dry. For the shell is to them what the skin is to us. And the name too comes from this, since all such animals have been called "ostracoderms" [shell-skinned creatures] from the fact that their skin is similar to a shell. And the soft-shelled creatures also, such as lobsters and crayfish and crabs
paragraphs.openai_translation: But if the whole is blended uniformly, it is reasonable that the skin should be such as it is, and likewise each of the other parts; but if it is blended irregularly, then not so. For in shellfish, at any rate, the whole body is exceedingly moist, whereas the skin is exceedingly dry. For their shell is, in fact, to them what the skin is to us. And hence the designation: all such animals have been called “ostracoderms” [shell-skinned], from the fact that their skin is akin to a shell. And the malacostracans [soft-shelled crustaceans], such as lobsters, prawns, and crabs…

paragraphs.content: ξηρὸν μὲν ἔχει τὸ δέρμα τὴν δ’ ἄλλην ἅπασαν κρᾶσιν ὑγράν. καὶ αὐτὸ δὴ τοῦτο πολλάκις αἴτιον ὑπάρχει τοῖς ζώοις τῆς ἐν ταῖς σαρξὶν ὑγρότητος ὅτι πᾶν αὐτοῖς τὸ ξηρὸν καὶ γεῶδες ἡ φύσις ἀποτίθεται πρὸς τὸ δέρμα. μὴ τοίνυν μήθ’ ὅτι ξηρὸν τοῦτο τοῖς ὀστρέοις εὐθέως καὶ τὴν σάρκα νομιστέον ὑπάρχειν ξηρὰν μήθ’ ὅτι πλαδαρὰ καὶ μυξώδης ἤδη τοιοῦτο ὑποληπτέον εἶναι καὶ τὸ δέρμα. δίκαιον γὰρ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.53:

It has dry skin but all the rest of its mixture is moist. And this very thing is often the cause for animals of the moisture in their flesh—because nature deposits all that is dry and earthy in them toward the skin. Therefore, one should not suppose that just because this [the shell] is dry in shellfish, the flesh is also necessarily dry, nor should one assume that because [the flesh] is soft and mucous-like, the skin [shell] is also of such a nature. For it is reasonable...
paragraphs.openai_translation: It has the skin dry, but the rest of its entire constitution [krasis: overall blend/temperament] moist. And this very fact is often the cause, in animals, of the moisture in their flesh, since nature deposits upon the skin all that in them is dry and earthy. Therefore one must not, because this [i.e., the skin] is dry in shellfish [ostracea], at once suppose that the flesh is dry as well, nor, because the flesh is flabby and mucous [mucus-like], infer that the skin is of that sort too. For it is reasonable...

paragraphs.content: ἕκαστον τῶν μορίων ἐξ ἑαυτοῦ γνωρίζεσθαι. ταῦτά τε οὖν ἁμαρτάνουσιν οἱ τὰ περὶ κράσεων ἡμῖν ὑπομνήματα καταλελοιπότες· ἔτι δὲ πρὸς τούτοις ὅτι μηδὲ μέμνηνται τοῦ πρὸς Ἱπποκράτους ὀρθότατα παρῃνημένου τοῦ δεῖν ἐπισκέπτεσθαι τὰς μεταβολὰς ἐξ οἵων εἰς οἶα γίγνεται. πολλάκις γὰρ τὰ παρόντα γνωρίσματα τῆς ἔμπροσθεν κράσεώς ἐστιν οὐ τῆς νῦν ὑπαρχούσης τῷ σώματι. φέρε γὰρ εἴ τις ἐτῶν γεγονὼς ἑξήκοντα δασὺς ἱκανῶς εἴη μὴ διότι νῦν ἐστι θερμὸς καὶ ξηρὸς
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.54:

each of the parts should be recognized from itself. These then are the errors made by those who have left us treatises concerning temperaments [krasis]; and furthermore, in addition to these things, that they have not even remembered what was most correctly advised by Hippocrates, namely that one must examine the changes—from what sorts of states into what sorts they occur. For often the signs that are present belong to the former temperament, not to the one now existing in the body. For suppose that someone who has reached sixty years of age should be quite hairy, not because he is now hot and dry

---

**Notes:**
- *krasis* (κράσις): temperament or mixture, referring to the balance of bodily humors in ancient medical theory
- The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end of this paragraph
paragraphs.openai_translation: Each of the parts is to be recognized from itself. And so, in these points those who have left us memoranda concerning mixtures [kraseis: bodily temperaments] go astray; moreover, in addition to this, they have not even remembered Hippocrates’ most correct admonition—that one must examine the changes, from what sorts into what sorts they come to be. For often the present indications are of the earlier temperament, not of the one now existing in the body. For consider: if someone at sixty years of age should be sufficiently hairy, it is not because he is now hot and dry.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὅτι πρόσθεν μὲν τοιοῦτος ἐγένετο ὑπομένουσι δ’ αἱ τότε γεννηθεῖσαι τρίχες ὥσπερ ἐν τῷ θέρει πολλάκις αἱ κατὰ τὸ ἔαρ ἀναφυεῖσαι βοτάναι. τισὶ μὲν γὰρ ἐν τῷ χρόνῳ καὶ κατὰ βραχὺ συνέβη τῆς ἄγαν ἐκείνης ἀπαλλαγῆναι δασύτητος ἐκπιπτουσῶν ἐκ τῆς ἄκρας ξηρότητος τῶν τριχῶν· ἐνίοις δὲ ἄχρι πλείστου παραμένουσιν οἶς ἂν μήτ’ ἀποξηρανθῶσιν ἱκανῶς ἐπὶ προήκοντι τῷ χρόνῳ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But [the reason] that he became such previously, yet the hairs that grew at that time persist, is just as in summer the plants that sprouted in spring often [persist]. For in some cases it happened over time and gradually that they were freed from that excessive hairiness, the hairs falling out from extreme dryness; but in some cases they remain for a very long time—in those who have not been sufficiently dried out as time progresses.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But that previously he became of such a sort; and the hairs that were produced then persist, just as in summer the plants that sprouted in spring often do. For in some people, with time and little by little, it has come about that they are rid of that excessive hairiness [dasytes], as the hairs fall out because of their extreme dryness; whereas in others they remain for a very long time—namely, in those in whom they are not sufficiently dried out even over an extended period.

paragraphs.content: καὶ τὴν πρώτην ἔκφυσιν αἱ τρίχες αὐτοῖς ἰσχυρὰν ποιήσωνται δίκην φυτῶν ἀκριβῶς ἐνεῤῥιζωμένων τῇ γῇ. μὴ τοίνυν εἰ δασύς τις ἱκανῶς ἐστιν εὐθὺς τοῦτον οἰώμεθα μελαγχολικὸν ὑπάρχειν ἀλλ’ εἰ μὲν ἀκμάζων οὔπω τοιοῦτον· εἰ δὲ παρακμάζων ἤδη μελαγχολικόν· εἰ δὲ γέρων οὐκ ἔτι. γίνονται γὰρ αἱ μελαγχολικαὶ κράσεις ἐκ συγκαύσεως αἵματος. οὐ μὴν ἐπειδὰν ἄρξηται τοῦτο πάσχειν εὐθὺς καὶ κατοπτᾶται τελέως.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.56:

And let the hairs make their first growth strong for them, just like plants firmly rooted in the earth. Therefore, let us not suppose that if someone is quite hairy, he is immediately melancholic on this account, but rather: if he is in his prime, not yet such; if he is past his prime, already melancholic; but if he is an old man, no longer so. For melancholic temperaments arise from the burning up of blood. However, it is not the case that as soon as this begins to occur, the blood is immediately and completely scorched through.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And their first sprouting of hair becomes strong in them, like plants firmly rooted in the earth. So let us not, if someone is sufficiently hairy, straightway suppose him to be melancholic [of a melancholic temperament]; rather, if he is in his prime, he is not yet such; if he is past his prime, he is already melancholic; but if he is an old man, no longer. For melancholic mixtures [kraseis: bodily “temperaments” or “mixtures”] arise from the scorching of the blood [synkausis: overdrying/overheating]. Yet when this process begins, it does not at once also become completely “cooked” [cocted].

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἐν τάχει μὲν ἱκανῶς ἔσται δασὺς ὁ θερμὸς καὶ ξηρὸς εἴ γε μεμνήμεθα τῶν ἔμπροσθεν λόγων οὐκ εὐθέως δὲ μελαγχολικός. ἡ γὰρ τοῦ δέρματος πύκνωσις εἴργουσα τῶν παχυτέρων περιττωμάτων τὴν διέξοδον ἀναγκάζει συγκαίεσθαι κατὰ τὰς ἄκρως θερμὰς κράσεις ὥστε τοιοῦτο αὐτοῖς ὑπάρχειν ἤδη τὸ περίττωμα τὸ φύον τὰς τρίχας οἷον ἐν τοῖς ἀγγείοις ἔσεσθαι μέλλει προελθόντος τοῦ χρόνου. καὶ ταῦτ’ οὖν ἠμέληται τοῖς ἔμπροσθεν ἔτι τε πρὸς τούτοις
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But the hot and dry person will quickly enough be hairy, if indeed we remember the earlier arguments, but not immediately melancholic. For the denseness of the skin, blocking the passage out of the thicker residues, forces them to be burned up together in extremely hot temperaments, so that the residue which produces the hairs is already of such a kind for them as it is going to be in the blood vessels when time has advanced. And these matters, then, have been neglected by earlier writers, and still in addition to these things

---

**Note:** This text appears to be from a medical or physiological treatise discussing bodily temperaments (κράσεις) and the relationship between heat, dryness, hairiness, and the melancholic condition. The passage breaks off mid-sentence at the end.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But before long the hot-and-dry man will be sufficiently hairy—if we remember the preceding arguments—though he will not at once be melancholic [i.e., characterized by black bile]. For the thickening of the skin, by blocking the outlet for the coarser superfluities [perittōmata], forces them, in the case of extremely hot temperaments [kraseis], to be baked together, so that the residue that produces the hairs already has, for such men, the very quality it will come to have in the vessels [blood vessels] when time has advanced. And these points, then, were passed over in the foregoing—and, besides these…

paragraphs.content: ἐπειδὰν ἐκ τῆς φύσεως τῶν περιττωμάτων ἀδιορίστως περὶ τῶν κράσεων ἀποφαίνωνται. νομίζουσι γὰρ ἀνάλογον ἔχειν τὰς κράσεις τῶν μορίων τῇ φύσει τῶν περιττωμάτων. τὸ δὲ οὐχ ὅλον ἀληθές ἐστιν ἀλλ’ ἐγχωρεῖ ποτε περιττώματα μὲν ἀθροίζεσθαι φλεγματώδη ὑγρὸν δὲ οὐκ εἶναι τὸ μόριον ἀλλὰ ψυχρὸν μὲν ἐξ ἀνάγκης ὑγρὸν δ’ οὐκ ἐξ ἀνάγκης· ἐγχωρεῖ γὰρ καὶ ξηρὸν εἶναι. τὸ δ’ ἀπατῆσαν αὐτοὺς εὐφώρατον. οὐ γὰρ ἐνόησαν ὡς ἐκ τῶν σιτίων
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

whenever they make pronouncements about mixtures [temperaments] indiscriminately based on the nature of residues. For they believe that the mixtures of the parts correspond proportionally to the nature of the residues. But this is not entirely true; rather, it is possible sometimes for phlegmatic residues to accumulate while the part is not moist but necessarily cold, though not necessarily moist—for it is possible for it to be dry as well. What deceived them is easily detected. For they did not realize that from foods

---

**Note:** The text appears to break off mid-sentence. "Mixtures" (κράσεις) refers to the temperaments or constitutional blends of bodily parts according to ancient medical theory. "Residues" (περιττώματα) are the waste products or superfluities produced by the body.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Whenever they make indiscriminate pronouncements about the mixtures [kraseis: the temperaments/constitutions] on the basis of the nature of the excretions [perittōmata], they suppose that the mixtures of the parts [moria] correspond to the nature of the excretions. But this is not entirely true; for it can happen that phlegmatic excretions accumulate, while the part is not moist—rather, it is necessarily cold but not necessarily moist; indeed, it may even be dry. What deceived them is easy to discern. For they did not realize that from the foods—

paragraphs.content: καὶ οὐκ ἐξ αὐτοῦ τοῦ σώματος ἡμῶν γίγνεται τὸ φλέγμα. θαυμαστὸν οὖν οὐδὲν εἰ μὴ κρατῆσάν ποτε τὸ σῶμα τῶν προσενεχθέντων σιτίων ὑγρῶν εἰ τύχοι τὴν φύσιν ὑπαρχόντων ὅμοιον αὐτοῖς ἀποτελέσει καὶ τὸ περίττωμα. μὴ τοίνυν ὑπολαμβανέτωσαν ὥσπερ τὸ σῶμα ξηρὸν οὕτω καὶ τὸ περίττωμα δεῖν ξηρὸν εἶναι. εἰ γάρ τις εὐθὺς ἐξ ἀρχῆς ἐγένετο τῇ κράσει ξηρότερός τε καὶ ψυχρότερος οὐ μελαγχολικός ἐστιν ὁ τοιοῦτος
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.59:

And phlegm does not arise from our body itself. Therefore it is not at all surprising if the body, not having mastered the foods that have been consumed—which happen to be moist in nature—produces a residue similar to them. Let them not suppose, then, that just as the body is dry, so too must the residue be dry. For if someone from the very beginning was born drier and colder in temperament [krasis], such a person is not melancholic.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And phlegm does not come to be from our body itself. There is therefore nothing remarkable if, whenever the body at some time fails to master the foods that are brought to it—if it so happens that their moist nature remains present—it will produce a residue [perittōma: superfluity/waste] similar to them. Let them not, then, suppose that, just as the body is dry, the residue must be dry as well. For if someone from the very beginning has been, in respect of his krasis [mixture/temperament], both drier and colder, such a person is not melancholic.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ φλεγματικὸς τοῖς περιττώμασιν. εἰ δ’ ἐκ μεταπτώσεως ἐγένετο ξηρὸς καὶ ψυχρὸς ἐξ ἀνάγκης ὁ τοιοῦτος εὐθὺς ἤδη καὶ μελαγχολικός ἐστιν· οἷον εἴ τις ἔμπροσθεν θερμὸς καὶ ξηρὸς ἐκ συγκαύσεως τοῦ αἵματος ἐγέννησε πλείστην τὴν μέλαιναν χολήν. οὗτος γοῦν ἐστιν ὁ πρὸς τῷ ξηρὸς εἷναι καὶ ψυχρὸς εὐθὺς καὶ μελαγχολικὸς ὑπάρχων. εἰ δ’ ἀπ’ ἀρχῆς εἴη ψυχρὸς καὶ ξηρὸς ἡ μὲν ἕξις τοῦ σώματος τούτῳ λευκὴ καὶ μαλακὴ καὶ ψιλὴ τριχῶν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But [he is] phlegmatic in his residues. If, however, through transformation he has become dry and cold, such a person is necessarily straightaway also melancholic; for example, if someone who was previously hot and dry generated a great amount of black bile from the burning up of the blood. This person, then, is the one who, in addition to being dry and cold, is straightaway also melancholic. But if he were cold and dry from the beginning, the condition of his body would be white and soft and hairless

**Explanatory notes:**
- [phlegmatic] - relating to phlegm, one of the four humors in ancient medical theory
- [melancholic] - relating to black bile (melaina chole), another of the four humors
- [residues/periττώμασιν] - refers to bodily waste products or superfluities in humoral theory
paragraphs.openai_translation: But he is phlegmatic in his excretions [i.e., dominated by phlegm in his residual matter]. If, however, through a change he has become dry and cold, such a person is of necessity straightway also melancholic [i.e., governed by black bile]; for example, if someone previously, being hot and dry, through the co-burning of the blood produced a very great quantity of black bile. Such a man, then, in addition to being dry, is also cold, and immediately melancholic. But if from the start he were cold and dry, the bodily habit in his case is pale, soft, and bare of hair [sparse-haired].

paragraphs.content: ἄφλεβος δὲ καὶ ἄναρθρος καὶ ἰσχνὴ καὶ ἁπτομένοις ψυχρὰ καὶ τὸ τῆς ψυχῆς ἦθος ἄτολμον καὶ δειλὸν καὶ δύσθυμον οὐ μὴν μελαγχολικά γε τὰ περιττώματα. ταῦτά γε οὖν ἅπαντα διαμαρτάνουσιν οἱ πολλοὶ τῶν ἰατρῶν ἐκ τοῦ τῶν οἰκείων μὲν ἀποχωρῆσαι γνωρισμάτων ἐπὶ δὲ τὰ συμβεβηκότα μὴ διὰ παντὸς ἀλλ’ ὡς ἐπὶ τὸ πολὺ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Without veins and without joints and thin and cold to the touch and the character of the soul lacking in courage and cowardly and despondent—though the excretions are not indeed melancholic. Now most physicians make errors in all these matters because they depart from the proper distinguishing signs and turn to those that are accidental [symptoms], not invariably but only for the most part.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Veinless and inarticulate, thin, and cold to the touch, and in the disposition of the soul timid, cowardly, and gloomy—yet the residues are not melancholic [perittōmata = excretions/wastes]. In all these points most physicians go wrong, through abandoning the proper diagnostic signs and turning instead to what is incidental [sumbebēkota = accidental features], not in every case, but for the most part.

paragraphs.content: μεταβῆναι. διὰ ταῦτα γὰρ καὶ τὸ θερμαῖνον ἡγοῦνται πάντως ξηραίνειν. ἔγνωκα γὰρ ἔτι τοῦτο προσθεὶς οἶον κορωνίδα τε καὶ κεφαλὴν τῷ λόγῳ παντὶ καταπαύειν ἤδη τὸ δεύτερον γράμμα. θερμὸν γοῦν ὕδωρ ἐπαντλοῦντες ἑκάστοτε τοῖς φλεγμαίνουσι μορίοις εἶθ’ ὁρῶντες αὐτῶν ἐκκενουμένην τὴν ὑγρότητα προφανῶς οἴονται δείκνυσθαι τὸ ξηραίνεσθαι πάντῃ πρὸς θερμασίας οὐκ εἰ μετὰ ξηρότητος μόνον ἀλλ’ εἰ καὶ μεθ’ ὑγρότητος εἴη. ἔστι δ’ οὐ ταὐτὸ ἢ κενῶσαί τινος ὑγρότητα παρεσπαρμένην ἔν τισι χώραις
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.62:

to change. For it is because of these things that they think that what heats necessarily also dries. For I have decided to add this as well, like a flourish and capstone to the entire argument, and now to bring the second book to a close. At any rate, when they pour hot water each time upon inflamed parts and then see the moisture being evacuated from them, they think it is clearly demonstrated that drying occurs entirely through heating—not only if it occurs with dryness but even if it occurs with moisture. But it is not the same thing either to evacuate some moisture that has been dispersed in certain regions
paragraphs.openai_translation: to pass on. For on these grounds they even suppose that whatever heats necessarily dries. For I have observed that, by adding this further point—something like a coronis and a heading [scribal marks signaling closure and summary] to the whole argument—they think they have already put to rest the second point. Indeed, whenever they repeatedly draw off hot water onto inflamed parts and then see the moisture being evacuated from them, they suppose they are plainly demonstrating that drying in every respect accompanies heating—not only if it occurs along with dryness, but even if it occurs along with moisture. But it is not the same thing as emptying out the moisture of something that has been drawn off into certain areas...

paragraphs.content: ἢ ξηροτέραν ἀπεργάζεσθαι τὴν οἰκείαν κρᾶσιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
or to render its own mixture drier.

[Note: κρᾶσις (krasis) refers to the mixture or blend of bodily humors/qualities in medical contexts, or more generally to temperament or constitution]
paragraphs.openai_translation: or to render the natural constitution drier [krasis: the body’s mixture/temperament]

paragraphs.content: ἀνώμαλος γάρ τις ἐν τοῖς φλεγμαίνουσι μορίοις γίνεται δυσκρασία, τῶν μὲν ὁμοιομερῶν σωμάτων οὔπω τῆς οἰκείας ἐξεστηκότων φύσεως, ἀλλ’ ἔτι μεταβαλλομένων τε καὶ ἀλλοιουμένων, ἐμπεπλησμένων δὲ τοῦ ῥεύματος ἁπάντων τῶν μεταξὺ χώρων.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For a certain irregular imbalance occurs in the inflamed parts, since the homogeneous bodies [homoeomerous tissues] have not yet departed from their proper nature, but are still being changed and altered, while all the spaces in between have been filled with the flux [rheum].
paragraphs.openai_translation: For in the inflamed parts there arises a certain irregular dyscrasia [imbalance of humors], the homogeneous bodies [uniform tissues] not yet having departed from their proper nature, but still undergoing change and alteration, while all the intermediate spaces are filled with the flux [discharge].

paragraphs.content: ἅπαντα οὖν, ὅσα θερμὰ καὶ ὑγρὰ τὴν κρᾶσίν ἐστιν, προσαγόμενα τοῖς οὕτω διακειμένοις, ἐκκενοῖ μὲν τὸ περιττὸν ἐκεῖνο, τὸ τὰς μεταξὺ χώρας τῶν ὁμοιομερῶν κατειληφός· αὐτὰ δὲ τὰ σώματα τοσούτου ἀποδεῖ τοῦ ξηραίνειν, ὥστε καὶ προσδίδωσιν αὐτοῖς ὑγρότητα. τὸ μὲν οὖν ἀληθὲς ὧδ’ ἔχει. δεῖ δὲ τοῖς εἰρημένοις ἀποδείξεως, ἣν μακροτέραν τε εἶναι νομίζων, ἢ ὥστε προσγράφεσθαι κατὰ τόνδε τὸν λόγον, ἔτι δὲ ἀκροατοῦ δεομένην ἐπισταμένου περὶ φαρμάκων δυνάμεως, ἀναβάλλομαι τό γε νῦν διελθεῖν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 6.65:

Therefore, all things that are hot and moist in their mixture [temperament], when applied to those who are in such a condition, evacuate that excess matter which has occupied the spaces between the homoeomerous parts [uniform tissues]; but so far are these substances themselves from drying the bodies that they actually impart moisture to them. This, then, is how the truth stands. But the statements I have made require a demonstration, which I consider to be too lengthy to be added to this present treatise, and moreover to require a reader knowledgeable about the powers of drugs; therefore I postpone going through it for now.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, all things whose krasis [mixture/temperament] is warm and moist, when applied to those who are disposed in this way, evacuate the superfluity that has occupied the intervening spaces between the homoeomerous parts [uniform tissues]; but the substances themselves are so far from drying them that they even impart moisture to them. Such, then, is the truth of the matter. What has been said, however, requires a demonstration—one which I judge to be too long to append to the present discussion and, moreover, to require a hearer knowledgeable about the powers of drugs—so I defer setting it out for now.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἐπειδὰν τὸν τρίτον τοῦτον λόγον τὸν περὶ κράσεων ἅπαντα διέλθω, καὶ δείξω περὶ τῶν κατὰ δύναμιν ὑγρῶν καὶ ψυχρῶν καὶ θερμῶν καὶ ξηρῶν ἅπασαν τὴν μέθοδον, ἐφεξῆς οὕτω βιβλίον ἕτερον ὅλον ὑπὲρ τῆς ἀνωμάλου δυσκρασίας ἔγνωκα γράψασθαι. τελειωθήσεται γὰρ ἅπας ἡμῖν ὁ περὶ κράσεων λόγος, εἴς τε τὴν θεραπευτικὴν μέθοδον οὐ σμικρὰς ἀφορμὰς παρέξει.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But when I have gone through all of this third treatise concerning mixtures [kraseis], and have demonstrated the entire method concerning things that are moist, cold, hot, and dry in potentiality [kata dynamin], I have decided to write next in this manner another whole book concerning uneven bad-mixture [anomalos dyskrasia]. For the entire treatise concerning mixtures will be completed by us, and it will provide no small starting-points for the therapeutic method.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But when I have gone through this third discourse on mixtures in its entirety, and have set out the whole method concerning the powers of the moist, the cold, the hot, and the dry, then, in due sequence, I have resolved to write another entire book on irregular dyscrasia [abnormal imbalance of humors/qualities]. For our whole treatment of mixtures will then be brought to completion, and it will provide no small starting-points for the therapeutic method.

paragraphs.content: ΓΑΛΗΝΟΥ ΠΕΡΙ ΚΡΑΣΕΩΝ ΒΙΒΛΙΟΝ ΤΡΙΤΟΝ.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
GALEN'S ON MIXTURES, BOOK THREE.

[Note: The Greek title "ΠΕΡΙ ΚΡΑΣΕΩΝ" (Peri Kraseōn) is traditionally translated as "On Mixtures," "On Temperaments," or "On Complexions," referring to Galen's medical theory about the balance of bodily qualities and humors.]
paragraphs.openai_translation: Galen, On Mixtures [On Temperaments], Book Three.

paragraphs.content: Ὅτι μὲν οὖν ἕκαστον τῶν ἐνεργείᾳ θερμῶν καὶ ψυχρῶν καὶ ξηρῶν καὶ ὑγρῶν ἢ τῷ τὴν ἄκραν δεδέχθαι ποιότητα τοιοῦτο εἶναί φαμεν ἢ ἐπικρατήσει τινὸς ἐξ αὐτῶν ἢ πρὸς τὸ σύμμετρον ὁμογενὲς παραβάλλοντες ἢ πρὸς ὁτιοῦν τῶν ἐπιτυχόντων ἔμπροσθεν εἴρηται. δέδεικται δὲ καὶ ὡς ἄν τις μάλιστα δύναιτο διαγινώσκειν ἀκριβῶς αὐτά. λοιπὸν δ’ ἂν εἴη περὶ τῶν δυνάμει τοιούτων ἐπελθεῖν αὐτὸ πρότερον ἐξηγησαμένοις τοὔνομα τί ποτε σημαίνει
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.1:

Now then, that we say each of the things that are actually hot and cold and dry and moist is such either because it has received the extreme quality, or by the predominance of one of these, or by comparing it to what is proportionate and of the same kind, or in relation to any random things—this has been stated previously. And it has also been shown how one might be best able to discern these things accurately. What remains would be to proceed to discuss those things that are such potentially, after first explaining what the term itself signifies.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So, then, as regards each of the things that are actually hot, cold, dry, or moist, we say it is such either because it has received the extreme quality, or because one of these predominates, or by comparing the homogeneous thing to the commensurate [i.e., the well-proportioned, balanced state], or to whatever happens to be at hand—this has been said above. And it has also been shown how one might best be able to distinguish them accurately. What remains is to proceed to those that are such potentially, after first explaining what exactly the term signifies [“potentially” = in capacity, as opposed to “actually” = in realized state].

paragraphs.content: δυνάμει. σύντομος δὲ καὶ ῥᾴστη καὶ σαφὴς ἡ ἐξήγησις.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"in power/potentiality. And the explanation is concise and easy and clear."

---

**Alternative translation:**

"in capacity. And the exposition is brief and straightforward and lucid."
paragraphs.openai_translation: in potentiality [dynamis]. And the exposition is brief, simplest, and clear.

paragraphs.content: ὃ γὰρ ἂν ὑπάρχῃ μὲν μηδέπω τοιοῦτο, οἷον λέγεται, πέφυκε δὲ γενέσθαι, δυνάμει φαμὲν ὑπάρχειν αὐτό· λογικὸν μὲν τὸν ἄρτι γεγενημένον ἄνθρωπον, πτηνὸν δὲ τὸν ὄρνιθα, καὶ θηρατικὸν τὸν κύνα, ταχὺν δὲ τὸν ἵππον· ὅπερ ἔσεσθαι πάντως ἕκαστον αὐτῶν μέλλει, μηδενὸς τῶν ἔξωθεν ἐμποδὼν αὐτῷ γενομένου, τουθ’ ὡς ὂν ἤδη λέγοντες.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.3:

For whatever does not yet exist in such a state as it is said to be, but is naturally disposed to become so, we say exists potentially. We call the newly born human being rational, the bird capable of flight, the dog capable of hunting, and the horse swift—speaking of each of these as already being what it will certainly become, provided nothing external prevents it, even though it is not yet actually so.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For whatever is not yet such as it is said to be, but is by nature to become such, we say that it exists potentially [in potentiality]: thus we call the newborn human being rational, the bird a flying creature, the dog one suited to the hunt, and the horse swift; for each of them is altogether going to be this, provided nothing external hinders it—speaking of it as though it already is so.

paragraphs.content: ὅθεν οἶμαι καὶ δυνάμει πάντα ταῦτά φαμεν ὑπάρχειν οὐκ ἐνεργείᾳ. τέλειον μὲν γάρ τι καὶ ἤδη παρὸν ἡ ἐνέργεια· τὸ δυνάμει δὲ ἀτελές τι καὶ μέλλον ἔτι καὶ οἷον ἐπιτήδειον μὲν εἰς τὸ γενέσθαι μηδέπω δὲ ὑπάρχον ὃ λέγεται. οὔτε γὰρ τὸ βρέφος λογικὸν ἤδη ἀλλ’ ἔσεσθαι μέλλει οὔθ’ ὁ γεγενημένος ἄρτι κύων ἤδη θηρατικὸς ὅ γε μὴ βλέπων μηδέπω τῷ δύνασθαι δ’ εἰ τελειωθείη θηρᾷν οὕτως ὀνομάζεται. κυριώτατα μὲν οὖν ἐκεῖνα μόνα δυνάμει λέγομεν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.4:

Whence I think we also say that all these things exist potentially and not actually. For actuality is something complete and already present; but the potential is something incomplete and still to come and, as it were, suitable for coming into being but not yet being what it is said to be. For neither is the infant yet rational but is going to be, nor is the newly born puppy yet a hunter, seeing that it cannot yet see, but it is named thus by virtue of the fact that it would be able to hunt if it were brought to completion. Therefore, we speak most properly of those things alone as potential
paragraphs.openai_translation: Hence, I think, we say that all these things exist in potentiality [dynamis], not in actuality [energeia]. For actuality is something complete and already present; whereas what is in potentiality is in a sense incomplete and still forthcoming, and, as it were, suited for coming-to-be but not yet possessing the thing that is spoken of. For neither is an infant already rational [logikon], but it is going to be; nor is a dog just born already a hunting animal, since it does not yet see—nor yet merely by having the capacity; but if it were brought to completion so as to be able to hunt, then it is so called. Accordingly, in the most proper sense we call only those things “in potentiality.”

paragraphs.content: ἐφ’ ὧν ἡ φύσις αὐτὴ πρὸς τὸ τέλειον ἀφικνεῖται μηδέ τινος τῶν ἔξωθεν ἐμποδὼν αὐτῇ γενομένου. ἤδη δὲ καὶ ὅσαι προσεχεῖς ὕλαι τῶν γινομένων εἰσίν. οὐδὲν δὲ διοίσει προσεχῆ λέγειν ἢ οἰκείαν ἢ ἰδίαν ἐξ ἁπάντων γὰρ αὐτῶν δηλοῦται τὸ πλησίον καὶ μὴ διὰ μέσης ἄλλης μεταβολῆς οἷον εἰ τὸ αἷμα δυνάμει σάρκα προσαγορεύοις ἐλαχίστης μεταβολῆς δεόμενον εἰς σαρκὸς γένεσιν. οὐ μὴν τό γ’ ἐν τῇ γαστρὶ πεπεμμένον σιτίον ὕλη προσεχὴς σαρκὸς
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"[those things] upon which nature itself arrives at completion without anything external becoming an obstacle to it. And also all the proximate materials of things that come into being. It will make no difference to speak of 'proximate' or 'proper' or 'specific' [material], for from all of these terms what is indicated is that which is near and not [reached] through another intermediate change—for example, if you were to call blood potentially flesh, since it requires the smallest change for the generation of flesh. However, the food digested in the stomach is not the proximate material of flesh"
paragraphs.openai_translation: …under conditions in which nature itself reaches what is complete, with nothing external becoming an impediment to it. And now also which are the proximate materials [proximate matter: the immediately suitable substrate] of things that come to be. It makes no difference to say “proximate” or “proper” or “peculiar,” for by all of them is indicated what is nearest and not through the mediation of some other change—for example, if you were to call blood “flesh in potentiality” [in potentiality: capable of becoming by minimal change], as needing the least change for the generation of flesh. But the food that has been digested in the stomach is not proximate matter of flesh.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ διὰ μέσου τοῦ αἵματος· ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον ἡ μάζα καὶ ὁ ἄρτος ἐπιπλέον ἀποκεχώρηκε. τριῶν γὰρ δεῖται μεταβολῶν εἰς σαρκὸς γένεσιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

but through the medium of blood; and furthermore, barley-cake and bread have departed even further. For they require three transformations for the generation of flesh.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But through the intermediary of the blood; and still more, the maza [barley-cake/meal-porridge] and the bread have withdrawn further. For the generation of flesh requires three transformations.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὅμως καὶ ταῦτα πάντα δυνάμει λέγεται σὰρξ. καὶ πρὸ τούτων πῦρ καὶ ἀὴρ καὶ ὕδωρ καὶ γῆ καὶ ἡ τούτων αὐτῶν ὕλη κοινή. ταῦτα μὲν οὖν ἅπαντα καταχρωμένων ἢ μᾶλλον ἢ ἧττον λέγεται.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But nevertheless, all these things are also called flesh potentially. And prior to these, fire and air and water and earth, and the common matter of these very things. All these things, then, are spoken of through a misuse of terms [or: in an extended sense], either more or less so.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Yet nevertheless, even all these are called “flesh” in potentiality [dynamis, potentiality]; and prior to these [there are] fire, air, water, and earth, and the common matter [hylē, underlying matter] of these themselves. All these, then, are so called by way of catachresis [improper or figurative usage], to a greater or lesser extent.

paragraphs.content: ὁ δὲ πρῶτος τρόπος ὁ κυριώτατός ἐστι τῶν δυνάμει τόδε τι λεγομένων ὑπάρχειν. ἐφεξῆς δὲ ὁ κατὰ τὴν οἰκείαν ὕλην οἷον εἰ τὴν ἀναθυμίασιν τὴν καπνώδη φλόγα λέγεις ὑπάρχειν ἢ τὸν ἀτμὸν ἀέρα δυνάμει. λέγεται δέ ποτε τὸ δυνάμει καὶ τῷ κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς ἀντιδιαιρούμενον οἷον εἰ τὴν ψυχρολουσίαν ἐπ’ εὐσάρκου νέου θερμαίνειν τις φαίη τὸ σῶμα κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς οὖν οἰκείᾳ δυνάμει. κατὰ τοσούτους δὴ τρόπους καὶ τὰ δυνάμει ψυχρὰ καὶ ξηρὰ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.8:

The first mode is the most proper of those things said to exist potentially as a particular thing. Next is the mode according to proper matter, for example if you say that smoky exhalation is potentially flame, or that vapor is potentially air. But sometimes "potentially" is also used in the sense of being distinguished by opposition to "accidentally," for example if someone were to say that a cold bath heats the body of a well-fleshed young man—therefore accidentally, not by its proper power. In just so many ways, then, are things potentially cold and dry [spoken of].

---

**Brief notes:**
- [τόδε τι] "a particular thing" - a technical Aristotelian term referring to individual substances
- [κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς] "accidentally" - as opposed to essentially or per se
- [οἰκείᾳ δυνάμει] "proper power" - the inherent capacity belonging to something by its own nature
paragraphs.openai_translation: And the first mode is the most authoritative of the senses in which things are said to exist potentially as some particular thing. Next comes the one that is according to the proper matter [oikeia hylē], as when you say that in smoky exhalation flame is present, or that vapor is potentially air. Sometimes, too, “potentially” is spoken in contrast to “per accidens” [kata symbebēkos], as if someone should say that a cold bath warms the body of a well-fleshed youth—then it warms per accidens, yet by its own proper power [oikeia dynamis]. In just so many modes, then, are things also said to be potentially cold and dry.

paragraphs.content: καὶ ὑγρὰ καὶ θερμὰ λεχθήσεται καὶ ζητήσεται δεόντως τί δήποτε καστόριον ἢ εὐφόρβιον ἢ πύρεθρον ἢ στρουθίον ἢ νίτρον ἢ μίσυ θερμὰ λέγομεν ἢ θριδακίνην ἢ κώνειον ἢ μανδραγόραν ἢ σαλαμάνδραν ἢ μήκωνα ψυχρά· πότερον τοῖς εἰρημένοις τρόποις ὑποπέπτωκεν ἢ κατ’ ἄλλον τινὰ λέγεται μηδέπω δ’ εἰρημένον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

And moist and hot things will be discussed, and it will be properly investigated why on earth we call castoreum or euphorbia or pellitory or soapwort or natron or yellow copper ore hot, or lettuce or hemlock or mandrake or salamander or poppy cold—whether they fall under the methods already mentioned or are so called according to some other method not yet stated.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Both the moist and the hot will be set forth, and it will be duly inquired why, in fact, we call castoreum [beaver secretion], euphorbium [spurge resin], pyrethrum [pellitory], struthion [soapwort], nitron [natron], or misy [copper sulfate] “hot,” and thridacine [lettuce-juice], hemlock, mandrake, salamander, or poppy “cold”: whether they fall under the modes already stated, or are said according to some other mode not yet mentioned.

paragraphs.content: ἄσφαλτος μὲν γὰρ καὶ ῥητίνη καὶ στέαρ ἔλαιόν τε καὶ πίττα δυνάμει θερμὰ διότι ῥᾳδίως ἐνεργείᾳ γίνεται θερμά· καὶ γὰρ ἐκφλογοῦται τάχιστα καὶ τοῖς σώμασιν ἡμῶν προσαγόμενα θερμαίνει σαφέστατα. χαλκῖτις δὲ καὶ μίσυ καὶ νάπυ καὶ νίτρον ἄκορόν τε καὶ μαῖον καὶ κόστος καὶ πύρεθρον ἡμῖν μὲν προσαγόμενα θερμὰ φαίνεται τὰ μὲν αὐτῶν μᾶλλον τὰ δ’ ἧττον οὐ μὴν ἐκφλογοῦσθαι πέφυκεν. ἢ οὖν παραλογίζονται σφᾶς αὐτοὺς οἱ τοῦτο μόνον ἐπισκοποῦντες
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.10:

For asphalt, resin, tallow, oil, and pitch are hot in potentiality because they easily become hot in actuality; for they ignite very quickly and when applied to our bodies they heat most clearly. But chalcitis [copper sulfate], misy [iron sulfate], mustard, natron [native sodium carbonate], sweet flag, meon [an aromatic plant], costus [an aromatic root], and pellitory, when applied to us, appear hot—some of them more so, others less—yet they are not naturally disposed to ignite. Either, then, those who examine only this criterion deceive themselves
paragraphs.openai_translation: For asphalt, resin, tallow, oil, and pitch are hot in potentiality, because they readily become hot in actuality; for they are kindled most quickly, and when applied to our bodies they manifestly heat them. But chalcitis [a copper compound], misy [a copper mineral], napy [a pungent plant, perhaps cress/rocket], nitron [natron/soda], acoron [sweet flag], maion [an aromatic drug; identification uncertain], costus [costus root], and pyrethrum, when applied to us, appear hot—some more, some less—yet they are not by nature apt to catch fire. Therefore, those who consider only this are deceiving themselves.

paragraphs.content: εἰ μὴ ῥᾳδίως ἐκφλογοῦνται; ἐχρῆν γὰρ οὐχ οὕτως ἀλλ’ εἰ μὴ διανθρακοῦνται σκοπεῖν ὡς οὐδὲν ἧττον φλογὸς ὁ ἄνθραξ πῦρ.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"unless they easily burst into flame? For one ought to examine not in this way but rather whether they turn to charcoal, since charcoal is no less fire than flame."
paragraphs.openai_translation: “If they do not easily burst into flame? For one ought not to examine the matter in that way, but rather—if they do not turn to charcoal—to consider that charcoal [ánthrax: glowing coal] is no less fire than flame.”

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἡ μὲν φλὸξ ἀέρος ἐκπυρωθέντος, ἤ τινος ἀερώδους σώματος, ὁ δ’ ἄνθραξ γῆς, ἤ τινος γεώδους γίνεται. καὶ δὴ μέχρι μὲν τοῦδε συμφωνεῖν ὁ λόγος ἔοικεν ἑαυτῷ πάντῃ, φαίνεται γὰρ, ὅσα πυρὸς ἁπτόμενα φάρμακα ῥᾳδίως ἐκπυροῦται, ταῦτα καὶ ἡμᾶς θερμαίνοντα, πλὴν εἴ τι, διὰ τὸ παχυμερὲς εἶναι, μὴ παραδέξεται ῥᾳδίως εἴσω τὸ σῶμα. διορισθήσεται γὰρ ἐπὶ πλέον ὑπὲρ τούτων ἐν τοῖς περὶ φαρμάκων δυνάμεως.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But flame comes from air that has been set on fire, or from some airy body, while charcoal comes from earth, or from some earthy substance. And indeed up to this point the argument seems to be in agreement with itself in every respect, for it is evident that all those drugs which, when touched by fire, are easily ignited, these also warm us—except if something, because of being thick-particled, does not readily admit the body inside. For this matter will be distinguished more fully in the works on the powers of drugs.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But flame arises from air that has been set on fire, or from some aeriform body, while charcoal comes from earth, or from some earthy body. And indeed, up to this point the account seems in every respect consistent with itself; for it appears that the substances which, when they come into contact with fire, are readily kindled, also warm us, except in cases where something, because of its thickness of texture [dense consistency], does not readily penetrate into the interior of the body. A fuller determination on these points will be given in the works On the Powers of Medicines [Peri Dynameon Pharmakon].

paragraphs.content: ὅσα μέντοι σῶμα τὸ ἡμέτερον φαίνεται θερμαίνοντα, ταῦθ’ ἑτοίμως ἐκπυροῦται. πῶς οὖν, φασὶν, ἁπτομένοις οὐ φαίνεται θερμά; τοῦτο δὲ οὐκ οἶδα τίνος ἕνεκα λέγουσιν. εἰ μὲν γὰρ ἐνεργείᾳ τε καὶ ἤδη θερμὸν ἐλέγομεν ἕκαστον τῶν εἰρημένων ὑπάρχειν, ἦν ἂν δήπου θαυμαστὸν, ὅπως ἁπτομένων οὐ φαίνεται θερμά. νυνὶ δὲ, τῷ δύνασθαι γενέσθαι ῥᾳδίως θερμὰ, δυνάμει τὰ τοιαῦτα προσαγορεύομεν. θαυμαστὸν οὖν οὐδὲν πέπονθεν, εἰ μήπω θερμαίνει τοὺς ψαύοντας αὐτῶν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.13:

However, all those things which are observed to heat our body are readily set on fire. "How then," they say, "do they not appear hot to the touch?" But I do not know for what reason they say this. For if we were saying that each of the aforementioned things exists as hot in actuality and already, it would surely be remarkable how they do not appear hot when touched. But as things stand, we call such things hot in potentiality because they are able to become hot easily. Therefore, nothing remarkable has occurred if they do not yet heat those who touch them.

---

**Brief notes:**
- The text discusses the distinction between actual heat (ἐνεργείᾳ) and potential heat (δυνάμει), key Aristotelian concepts
- The argument addresses an objection about why certain substances that can heat the body don't feel hot to the touch
paragraphs.openai_translation: However, all the things that appear to warm our body are readily set ablaze. “How then,” they say, “do they not appear hot to those who touch them?” I do not know for what reason they say this. For if we were asserting that each of the aforementioned things possesses heat in actuality [energeia] and is already hot, it would indeed be surprising that, when people touch them, they do not appear hot. But as it is, because they are able to become hot easily, we describe such things as being in potentiality [dynamis]. There is therefore nothing surprising if they do not yet heat those who touch them.

paragraphs.content: ὡς γὰρ οὐδὲ τὸ πῦρ αὔξεται πρὶν ὑπ’ αὐτοῦ νικηθέντα τὰ ξύλα μεταβληθῆναι καὶ τοῦτο πάντως ἔν τινι χρόνῳ γίνεται· κατὰ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον οὐδὲ τὴν ἐν τοῖς ζώοις θερμασίαν εἰ μὴ πρότερον ἀπ’ αὐτῆς ἐκείνης τὰ φάρμακα μεταβληθῇ. καθ’ ἕτερον μὲν γὰρ τρόπον ὁ παρὰ πυρὶ θαλπόμενος ἢ ἐν ἡλίῳ θερμαίνεται καθ’ ἕτερον δὲ ὁ ὑφ’ ἑκάστου τῶν εἰρημένων φαρμάκων. ἐκεῖνα μὲν γὰρ ἐνεργείᾳ θερμὰ τῶν φαρμάκων δὲ οὐδέν. οὔκουν οὐδὲ θερμαίνειν ἡμᾶς δύναται
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.14:

For just as fire does not increase until the wood, having been overcome by it, is transformed—and this certainly happens over some period of time—in the same way neither does the heat in animals [increase] unless the drugs are first transformed by that very heat itself. For in one manner is a person warmed who is being heated by a fire or in the sun, and in another manner is one warmed by each of the aforementioned drugs. For those things [fire and sun] are actually hot, but none of the drugs are. Therefore they are not able to heat us either.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For just as even fire does not increase until the wood has been overcome by it and transformed—and this in any case takes place in some interval of time—so too the heat within living creatures [thermasia] does not [increase] unless the drugs [pharmaka: medicaments] are first altered by that very heat arising from it. For a person warmed by a fire or heated in the sun is heated in one way, whereas he is heated in another way by each of the aforesaid drugs. For the former are hot in actuality [energeia], but none of the drugs is so. Therefore they are not even able to heat us.

paragraphs.content: πρὶν ἐνεργείᾳ γενέσθαι τοιαῦτα τὸ δ’ ἐνεργείᾳ παρ’ ἡμῶν αὐτῶν λαμβάνει καθάπερ γε οἱ ξηροὶ κάλαμοι παρὰ τοῦ πυρός. οὕτω καὶ ξύλα ψυχρὰ μὲν ἅπαντα κατά γε τὴν αὐτῶν φύσιν ἀλλὰ τὰ μὲν ξηρότερά τε καὶ σμικρὰ ῥᾳδίως εἰς πῦρ μεταβάλλει τὰ δ’ ὑγρότερά τε καὶ μεγάλα χρόνου δεῖται πλείονος. οὐδὲν οὖν θαυμαστὸν εἰ καὶ τὰ φάρμακα πρῶτον μὲν εἰς μικρὰ καὶ λεπτὰ καταθραυσθῆναι δεῖται δεύτερον δὲ χρόνῳ τινὶ κᾂν ἐλαχίστῳ τοῖς σώμασιν ἡμῶν ὁμιλῆσαι
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.15:

before they become such things in actuality; and they receive actuality from us ourselves, just as dry reeds do from fire. So too with wood: all wood is cold according to its own nature, but wood that is drier and smaller changes easily into fire, while wood that is wetter and larger requires more time. Therefore it is not at all surprising if drugs also first need to be broken down into small and fine particles, and second need to interact with our bodies for some time, even if a very brief time.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Before they become such in actuality, they receive their actualization [energeia: being-in-act] from us ourselves, just as dry reeds receive it from fire. So too with wood: all of it is cold by its own nature, yet the drier and smaller pieces quickly change into fire, while the wetter and larger require more time. It is therefore nothing surprising if medicines, first, must be broken up into small and fine [particles], and second, must have some time—even the least—to come into contact with our bodies.

paragraphs.content: πρὸς τὸ γενέσθαι θερμά. σὺ δ’ εἰ μήτε καταθραύσας αὐτὰ μήτε θερμήνας πρότερον ἀξιοῖς ἤδη γενέσθαι θερμὰ τί ποτε σημαίνει τὸ δυνάμει θερμὸν ἐπιλελῆσθαί μοι δοκεῖς.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"in order to become hot. But if you claim that they should already be hot without having either broken them up or heated them beforehand, you seem to me to have forgotten what 'potentially hot' means."
paragraphs.openai_translation: toward becoming hot. But if, without either crushing them or heating them beforehand, you expect them already to become hot, you seem to me to have forgotten what “hot in potentiality” [i.e., hot in capacity/potential] means.

paragraphs.content: ὡς οὖν ἐνεργείᾳ θερμὰ βασανίζεις αὐτά. καὶ μὴν οὐδ’ ἐκεῖνο θαυμαστὸν εἰ θερμανθῆναι δεῖται πρότερον ἵν’ ἀντιθερμάνῃ. γίνεται γὰρ δὴ τοῦτο καὶ κατὰ τὴν τῶν ξύλων εἰκόνα. τὴν γοῦν ἀποσβεννυμένην φλόγα διασώζει τε ἅμα καὶ αὔξει θερμαινόμενα πρότερον ὑπ’ ἐκείνης αὐτῆς. οὔκουν οὐδὲν ἀπεικός ἐστιν οὐδὲ τὴν ἐν τοῖς ζώοις θερμασίαν οἷον τροφῇ τινι χρῆσθαι τοῖς τοιούτοις φαρμάκοις
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

So then you test them when they are hot in actuality. And indeed it is not surprising if they need to be heated first in order to heat in return. For this happens also according to the analogy of wood. At any rate, pieces of wood preserve and at the same time increase a dying flame, having first been heated by that very flame. Therefore it is not at all implausible that the heat in living creatures also uses such drugs as a kind of nourishment.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So, then, you assay them as actually hot [in actuality, not just potentially]. And indeed, it is not surprising either if they need first to be warmed in order to give warmth in return. For this happens too, as in the case of wood: the pieces of wood, having first been warmed by that very flame, both preserve and at the same time increase the flame that is being extinguished. Accordingly, it is not at all implausible that the heating in living creatures [the innate heat/process of warming] should make use of such drugs as a kind of nourishment.

paragraphs.content: ὡς τὸ πῦρ τοῖς ξύλοις. οὕτω γὰρ δὴ καὶ φαίνεται γινόμενον. εἰ δὲ κατεψυγμένῳ σώματι περιπάττοις ὁτιοῦν αὐτῶν ἀκριβῶς λεπτὸν ἐργασάμενος οὐδ’ ὅλως θερμαίνεται. καὶ διὰ τοῦτο τρίβομεν ἐπὶ πλεῖστον τὰ κατεψυγμένα μόρια τοῖς τοιούτοις φαρμάκοις ἅμα μὲν ἀνάπτοντες τῇ τρίψει θερμασίαν ἅμα δ’ ἀραιὸν ἐργασάμενοι τὸ τέως ὑπὸ τῆς ψύξεως πεπυκνωμένον ἵνα τε εἴσω δύῃ τὸ φάρμακον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.18:

as fire to wood. For indeed this is how it appears to happen. But if you sprinkle any of these substances on a chilled body, having worked it into a fine powder, it does not warm it at all. And for this reason we rub chilled parts extensively with such medicines, at once kindling warmth by the rubbing and at the same time making porous what has previously been condensed by the cold, so that the medicine may penetrate within
paragraphs.openai_translation: As fire [acts] upon wood. For so indeed it appears to occur. But if you were to smear upon a chilled body any one of these [remedies], having worked it up to an exact fineness, it is not warmed at all. And for this reason we rub the chilled parts at length with such drugs, at once kindling warmth by the rubbing and at the same time making rare what had previously been condensed by the cold, so that the drug may also sink inward.

paragraphs.content: καὶ ὁμιλοῦν τῷ συμφύτῳ τοῦ ζώου θερμῷ μεταβάλληταί τε καὶ θερμαίνηται. καὶ γὰρ εἰ μόριον αὐτοῦ τι σμικρότατον ἐνεργείᾳ κτήσαιτο τὴν θερμασίαν εἰς ἅπαν οὕτω διαδίδωσι κατὰ τὸ συνεχὲς ὡς εἰ καὶ τῆς δᾳδὸς ἅψαις τὸ ἄκρον ἀπὸ σμικροῦ σπινθῆρος· ἅπασαν γὰρ καὶ ταύτην ἐπινέμεται ῥᾳδίως τὸ πῦρ οὐδὲν ἔτι τοῦ σπινθῆρος δεόμενον. ἕκαστον μὲν οὖν τῶν δυνάμει θερμῶν οὔπω μὲν ἐν τῇ φύσει πλεονεκτοῦν ἔχει τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.19:

And associating with the innate heat of the living creature, it is transformed and heated. For even if some very small part of it should actively acquire the heat, it spreads throughout the whole in this way by continuity, just as if you were to light the tip of a torch from a small spark; for the fire easily spreads over all of this too, no longer needing the spark at all. Therefore, each of the things that are potentially hot, not yet having an excess of the hot over the cold in its nature

---

**Notes:**
- "συμφύτῳ θερμῷ" = "innate heat" [the natural, inborn heat of living beings, a key concept in ancient Greek physiology]
- "δυνάμει θερμῶν" = "potentially hot" [referring to Aristotelian potentiality vs. actuality]
- The sentence appears to break off mid-thought at the end of this excerpt
paragraphs.openai_translation: And by associating with the animal’s connate heat [innate/connate heat], it is altered and warmed. For even if some very tiny part of it were to acquire in actuality [actualization] the warming, it thus transmits it through the whole according to continuity [through the continuum], as if you touched the tip of a torch with a small spark; for the fire quickly takes possession of the whole of it as well, no longer needing the spark. Therefore each of the things hot in potential [potentiality] does not yet, in its nature, possess the hot as prevailing over the cold.

paragraphs.content: πλησίον δὲ ἤδη τοῦ πλεονεκτεῖν ἐστιν ὥστε βραχείας τῆς ἔξωθεν ἐπικουρίας δεῖσθαι πρὸς τὸ κρατῆσαι. καὶ ταύτην αὐτῷ ποτὲ μὲν ἡ τρίψις ἱκανὴ παρέχειν ἐστὶ ποτὲ δ’ ἤτοι τὸ πῦρ ἤ τι τῶν φύσει θερμῶν σωμάτων ἁπτόμενον. οὔκουν οὐδὲν θαυμαστὸν εἰπεῖν διὰ τί τὰ μὲν εὐθὺς ἅμα τῷ ψαῦσαι τοῦ σώματος ἡμῶν ἀντιθερμαίνειν αὐτὸ πέφυκε τὰ δὲ ἐν πλείονι χρόνῳ δρᾷν τοῦτο. καὶ γὰρ καὶ τῶν πλησιαζόντων τῷ πυρὶ τὰ μὲν εὐθὺς ἐξάπτεται
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.20:

It is already close to prevailing, so that it needs only a little external assistance to gain mastery. And sometimes rubbing is sufficient to provide this assistance for it, while at other times either fire or some naturally hot body touching it does so. Therefore it is not at all surprising to explain why some things are naturally able to warm our body in return immediately upon contact with it, while others accomplish this over a longer period of time. For indeed, even among things that approach fire, some catch fire immediately,
paragraphs.openai_translation: And it is already close to gaining the upper hand, so that it needs only a little assistance from outside [ἐπικουρία] in order to prevail. Sometimes rubbing [τρίψις; friction] is sufficient to supply this, and sometimes either fire or the contact of some bodies that are naturally hot. It is therefore not at all surprising to explain why some things, immediately upon touching our body, are by nature disposed to warm it in return [ἀντιθερμαίνειν], while others accomplish this over a longer time. For even among things that come near fire, some are ignited at once...

paragraphs.content: καθάπερ ἡ θρυαλλὶς καὶ ἡ δᾲς ἡ λεπτὴ καὶ ἡ πίττα καὶ ὁ κάλαμος ὁ ξηρὸς τὰ δ’ εἰ μὴ πολλῷ χρόνῳ πλησιάσειεν οὐ νικᾶται καθάπερ τὸ ξύλον τὸ χλωρόν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

just as the lamp-wick and the thin torch and pitch and the dry reed [are easily ignited]; but other things, if fire does not approach them for a long time, are not overcome, just as green wood [is not].
paragraphs.openai_translation: Just as with the wick [lamp‑wick], the slender torch, pitch [resin], and the dry reed; whereas other things, unless one were to bring [the fire] near for a long time, are not mastered—as with green wood.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ μᾶλλον ἐκεῖνο διελέσθαι δικαιότερον οὗ τὴν μὲν ἀπόδειξιν ἐν τοῖς περὶ φυσικῶν δυνάμεων ἐροῦμεν· ἐξ ὑποθέσεως δ’ αὖ ἕνεκα τῶν παρόντων καὶ νῦν αὐτῷ χρησόμεθα τέσσαρας εἰπόντες εἷναι παντὸς σώματος δυνάμεις οἰκείας ἑλκτικὴν μὲν τῶν οἰκείων μίαν ἑτέραν δὲ τὴν τῶν αὐτῶν καθεκτικὴν καὶ τρίτην ἀλλοιωτικὴν καὶ τετάρτην ἐπ’ αὐταῖς τῶν ἀλλοτρίων ἀποκριτικὴν εἶναί τε τὰς αὐτὰς δυνάμεις ὅλης τῆς οὐσίας ἑκάστου τῶν σωμάτων ἣν ἐκ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.22:

But it is more just to discuss that matter whose demonstration we shall speak of in the works concerning natural faculties; but from hypothesis, in turn, for the sake of present matters, we shall also now make use of it, having stated that there are four proper faculties of every body: one being attractive of things proper to it, another being retentive of these same things, a third being alterative, and a fourth in addition to these being expulsive of things foreign to it, and that these same faculties belong to the whole substance of each of the bodies, which [substance is composed] of hot and cold—

---

**Note:** The sentence appears to break off, suggesting the text continues with further description of the bodily substance composed of hot and cold (likely followed by "wet and dry" in keeping with standard Greek medical theory of the four qualities).
paragraphs.openai_translation: But rather it is fairer to discuss that topic, the demonstration of which we shall give in the work On the Natural Faculties; for the present, however, for the sake of what lies before us, we will employ it as a hypothesis, saying that there are four proper faculties of every body: one, the attractive of what is appropriate [helktikē: attracting what is akin/proper]; another, the retentive of the same [kathektikē: holding/retaining]; a third, the alterative [alloiōtikē: transforming/assimilating]; and a fourth, consequent upon these, the expulsive of what is alien [apokritikē: expelling/separating the foreign]; and that these same faculties belong to the entire substance of each of the bodies, which is composed from the hot and the cold.

paragraphs.content: καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ κεκρᾶσθαι φαμέν. ἐπειδὰν δὲ κατὰ μίαν ἡντιναοῦν τῶν ἐν αὐτῇ ποιοτήτων τὸ σῶμα μεταβάλλῃ τὸ πλησιάζον οὔτε καθ’ ὅλην ἐνεργεῖν αὐτοῦ τηνικαῦτα τὴν οὐσίαν ὑποληπτέον οὔτ’ ἐξομοιωθῆναι δύνασθαι τὸ μεταβαλλόμενον· ὥστ’ οὐδὲ θρέψειεν ἄν ποτε τὸ οὕτω μεταβληθὲν οὐδὲν τῶν μεταβαλλόντων. εἰ δ’ ἐκεῖνο μεταβάλλοι τοῦτ’ ἔστι καθ’ ὅλην ἑαυτοῦ τὴν οὐσίαν ἐνεργήσαι ἐξομοιώσειεν ἂν οὕτως ἑαυτῷ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 1.23:

and we say that it is a mixture of dry and moist. But whenever the body that approaches changes according to any one of the qualities in it, one must not suppose that it is then acting according to its whole substance, nor that what is being changed can be assimilated; consequently, what has been changed in this way would never nourish any of the things that change it. But if that thing were to change this—that is, to act according to its whole substance—it would thus assimilate it to itself.

---

**Brief contextual notes:**
- This passage discusses the process of assimilation and nourishment, likely from a medical or natural philosophical text (possibly Galenic or related physiological theory)
- "qualities" [ποιότητες] refers to the fundamental properties (hot, cold, dry, moist) in ancient Greek medical theory
- The argument concerns the conditions under which one substance can properly transform and nourish another
paragraphs.openai_translation: —and we say that it is mixed of the dry and the moist. But whenever the body changes with respect to any one of the qualities in it, we must not suppose that what is brought near acts at that moment according to its whole substance, nor that the thing undergoing change is able to be assimilated [made like the agent]. Consequently, what has been altered in this way would never nourish any of the things that effect the alteration. If, however, that [adjacent thing] were to alter it—that is, to act according to its whole substance—then it would in this way assimilate it to itself.

paragraphs.content: καὶ τραφείη πρὸς τοῦ μεταβληθέντος. οὐδὲ γὰρ ἄλλο τι θρέψις ἐστὶ παρὰ τὴν τελείαν ὁμοίωσιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

and it might be nourished by that which has been transformed. For nourishment is nothing other than complete assimilation.
paragraphs.openai_translation: and it would be nourished by what has been transformed. For nutrition is nothing other than complete assimilation [the ingested becoming fully like the nourished body].

paragraphs.content: Ἐπειδὴ δὲ τοῦτο διώρισται πάλιν ἐκεῖθεν ἀρκτέον τοῦ λόγου. τῶν ζώων ἕκαστον οἰκείαις τρέφεται τροφαῖς· οἰκεία δ’ ἐστὶν ἑκάστῳ τροφὴ πᾶν ὅ τι ἂν ἐξομοιωθῆναι δύνηται τῷ τρεφομένῳ σώματι. χρὴ τοίνυν ὅλην τὴν οὐσίαν τοῦ τρέφοντος ὅλῃ τῇ τοῦ τρεφομένου φύσει κοινωνίαν τέ τινα καὶ ὁμοιότητα κεκτῆσθαι πάντως οὐκ ὀλίγης οὐδ’ ἐνταῦθα τῆς κατὰ τὸ μᾶλλόν τε καὶ ἧττον ὑπαρχούσης ἐν αὐτοῖς διαφορᾶς. τὰ μὲν γὰρ μᾶλλον οἰκεῖά τέ ἐστι καὶ ὅμοια τὰ δ’ ἧττον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.1:

Since this has been determined, we must begin the argument again from that point. Each of the animals is nourished by its proper foods; and proper nourishment for each is everything that is able to be assimilated to the body being nourished. It is necessary, therefore, that the entire substance of what nourishes should possess altogether some communion and similarity with the entire nature of what is being nourished—and here too there exists no small difference in them according to degree [literally "the more and the less"]. For some things are more proper and similar, while others are less so.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Since this has now been defined, once more from that point we must begin the account. Each of the animals is nourished by foods proper to it [oikeia]; and “proper food” for each is whatever is able to be assimilated [exomoiōthēnai] to the body that is being nourished. It is necessary, then, that the whole substance [ousia] of what nourishes possess with the whole nature [physis] of what is nourished some sort of sharing and likeness [koinōnia… homoiotēs]—there being in this, too, no small difference according to the more and the less. For some things are more proper and similar, others less so.

paragraphs.content: ὥστε καὶ τῆς κατεργασίας τὰ μὲν ἰσχυροτέρας τε καὶ πολυχρονιωτέρας τὰ δ’ ἀσθενεστέρας τε ἅμα καὶ ὀλιγοχρονιωτέρας προσδεῖται. τὸ μὲν οὖν ὀρνίθειον κρέας ἐλάττονος τὸ δὲ χοίρειον πλείονος τὸ δὲ βόειον ἔτι πλείονος. ἐλαχίστης δὲ δεῖται μεταβολῆς εἰς ἐξομοίωσιν οἶνος ὅθεν καὶ τρέφει καὶ ῥώννυσι τάχιστα. πάντως μὲν οὖν καὶ τοῦτον ὁμιλῆσαι χρὴ τοῖς πεπτικοῖς ὀργάνοις γαστρί τε καὶ ἥπατι καὶ φλεψὶν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

So that with regard to digestion, some things require a stronger and more prolonged process, while others require a weaker and briefer one at the same time. Thus poultry meat requires less [digestion], pork more, and beef still more. Wine requires the least transformation for assimilation, which is why it also nourishes and strengthens most quickly. Nevertheless, even this must come into contact with the digestive organs—the stomach, liver, and veins.
paragraphs.openai_translation: So, in respect of processing [digestion], some things require a stronger and more prolonged working, while others require a weaker and at the same time briefer one. Thus poultry meat needs less, pork more, and beef still more. Wine requires the least change for assimilation [exomoiōsis], and therefore it nourishes and invigorates the fastest. Nevertheless, even this must associate with the digestive organs—the stomach, the liver, and the veins [blood vessels].

paragraphs.content: ἐν οἶς προκατεργασθεὶς τρέφειν ἤδη δύναται τὸ σῶμα· πρὶν δὲ τῆς ἐν τούτοις μεταβολῆς ἐπιτυχεῖν οὐχ οἷόν τ’ αὐτὸν τροφὴν ζώου γενέσθαι κᾂν εἰ δι’ ὅλης ἡμέρας καὶ νυκτὸς ἐπικείμενος ἔξωθεν εἴη τῷ σώματι. πολὺ δέ τι μᾶλλον ἄρτος ἔξωθεν ἐπικείμενος ἢ τεῦτλον ἢ μάζα τρέφειν ἀδύνατον. τὰ μὲν οὖν ὁμοιούμενα πάντῃ τροφαί· τὰ δ’ ἄλλα σύμπαντα φάρμακα καλεῖται. διττὴ δὲ καὶ τούτων ἡ φύσις. ἢ γὰρ οἷα προσελήφθη διαμένοντα νικᾷ καὶ μεταβάλλει τὸ σῶμα
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.3:

in which [substances], having been previously processed, the body is now able to nourish itself; but before achieving the transformation in these substances, it is not possible for it to become nourishment for a living creature, even if it were applied externally to the body throughout an entire day and night. But much more so is bread applied externally, or beet, or barley-cake unable to nourish. Therefore, those things that are completely assimilated are nutrients; but all other things are called drugs [pharmaka]. And the nature of these too is twofold. For either they prevail by remaining in the state in which they were taken in and transform the body

---

**Brief notes:**
- [pharmaka]: substances that act upon the body; can mean drugs, medicines, or agents that cause change
- The text appears to be from a medical or physiological treatise discussing the distinction between nutrients (which are assimilated into the body) and other substances (which act upon or transform the body without being assimilated)
paragraphs.openai_translation: Once it has been pre-processed in these [organs], it is already able to nourish the body; but before it attains the transformation that occurs in them, it cannot possibly become nourishment for a living being, even if, laid upon it, it were applied to the body from outside for a whole day and night. All the more is it impossible for bread, or a beet, or a barley-cake, when applied externally, to nourish. Thus, the things that are in every respect assimilated [i.e., made like the body] are foods; all the rest are called drugs [pharmaka]. And even among these the nature is twofold. For either, remaining such as it was received, it prevails and alters the body...

paragraphs.content: καθ’ ὃν τρόπον ἐκεῖνο τὰ σιτία καὶ ταῦτα πάντως φάρμακα δηλητήριά τε καὶ φθαρτικὰ τῆς τοῦ ζώου φύσεώς ἐστιν· ἢ μεταβολῆς ἀρχὴν παρὰ τοῦ σώματος λαβόντα σήπεται τοὐντεῦθεν ἤδη καὶ διαφθείρεται κἄπειτα συνδιαφθείρει τε καὶ σήπει τὸ σῶμα. δηλητήρια δέ ἐστιν ἔτι καὶ ταῦτα. τρίτον δ’ ἐστὶν ἐπ’ αὐτοῖς εἶδος φαρμάκων τῶν ἀντιθερμαινόντων μὲν τὸ σῶμα κακὸν δ’ οὐδὲν ἐργαζομένων. καὶ τέταρτον ὅσα καὶ ποιοῦντά τι καὶ πάσχοντα νικᾶται τῷ χρόνῳ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.4:

In the same manner as that [previous case], these foods are also entirely drugs, both poisonous and destructive to the nature of the living creature; or, having received the beginning of transformation from the body, they putrefy from that point onward and are corrupted, and then they jointly corrupt and cause the body to putrefy. And these too are poisons. Third, there is a class of drugs in addition to these—those that warm the body in opposition [to its natural state] but produce no harm. And fourth, there are those which, both acting and being acted upon, are overcome in time.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Just as the former are foodstuffs, so these are in every way drugs [pharmaka], poisons [deleteria], and destructive of the animal’s nature; for either, having taken from the body the starting point of alteration, they putrefy [septic decay] from that point and are destroyed, and then in turn destroy and rot the body along with themselves. These too, moreover, are poisons. A third, besides these, is a class of drugs that warm the body in response yet do no harm. And a fourth is those which, while both acting in some way and being acted upon, are overcome by time.

paragraphs.content: καὶ τελέως ἐξομοιοῦται. συμπέπτωκε δὲ καὶ τούτοις ἅμα τε φαρμάκοις εἷναι καὶ τροφαῖς. θαυμαστὸν δ’ οὐδὲν εἰ βραχείας ἀφορμῆς ἔνια λαβόμενα μεγίστην ἐκτροπὴν ἴσχει τῆς ἀρχαίας φύσεως.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

and it is completely assimilated. It has also happened that these things are at the same time both drugs and foods. And it is nothing remarkable if some things, having received a small starting point, undergo the greatest transformation from their original nature.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And it becomes completely assimilated. It has also come about, moreover, that these are at once both drugs and foods [pharmaka]. And it is no wonder if, from a slight starting-point, some things undergo the greatest departure from their original nature.

paragraphs.content: ὁρᾶται γοῦν καὶ τῶν ἔξω πολλὰ τοιαῦτα. κατὰ μὲν γὰρ τὴν ἐπὶ τῆς Ἀσίας Μυσίαν οἰκία ποτὲ κατεκαύθη τρόπῳ τοιῷδε. κόπρος ἀπέκειτο περιστερῶν ἤδη σεσηπυῖα καὶ τεθερμασμένη καὶ ἀτμὸν ἀναπέμπουσα καὶ ἁπτομένοις ἱκανῶς θερμή. ταύτης δὲ πλησίον ἦν ὡς καὶ ψαύειν ἤδη θυρὶς ἔχουσα ξύλα νεωστὶ καταληλιμμένα ῥητίνῃ πολλῇ. θέρους οὖν μέσου λάβρος ἥλιος προσβαλὼν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.6

At any rate, many such things are also observed among external phenomena. For in Mysia in Asia, a house was once burned down in the following manner. Pigeon dung had been stored away, already rotted and heated and sending up vapor and quite hot to the touch. Near this was a window frame having wood freshly coated with abundant resin, so close as even to touch it. Then in the middle of summer, when the fierce sun struck upon it—
paragraphs.openai_translation: At any rate, many such cases are observed also among external things [i.e., outside the body]. For in Mysia, in Asia, a house once burned down in the following manner. There had been stored pigeon dung, already putrefied and warmed, giving off vapor and sufficiently hot to the touch. And near this—indeed close enough to reach out and touch—there was a small window [θυρίς] whose timbers had been newly smeared with much resin. Accordingly, in the height of summer, when the blazing sun struck it...
