paragraphs.content: ἐξῆψε τὴν ῥητίνην τε καὶ τὰ ξύλα. κᾀντεῦθεν ἤδη θύραι τινὲς ἕτεραι πλησίον ὑπάρχουσαι καὶ θυρίδες ἔναγχος ἐξαληλιμμέναι ῥητίνῃ ῥᾳδίως διεδέξαντο τὸ πῦρ καὶ μέχρι τῆς ὀροφῆς ἐξέτειναν. ἐπεὶ δ’ ἅπαξ ἡ φλὸξ ἐκείνης ἐλάβετο ταχέως ἐπὶ πᾶσαν ἐνεμήθη τὴν οἰκίαν. οὕτω δή πως οἶμαι καὶ τὸν Ἀρχιμήδην φασὶ διὰ τῶν πυρίων ἐμπρῆσαι τὰς τῶν πολεμίων τριήρεις.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.7:

He set fire to the resin and the wood. And from that point, certain other doors nearby and windows that had recently been smeared with resin easily caught the fire and extended it up to the roof. But once the flame took hold of that, it quickly spread throughout the entire house. In just this way, I believe, they say that Archimedes too burned the enemy's triremes [warships] by means of burning mirrors.
paragraphs.openai_translation: He kindled both the resin and the timbers. And from there at once certain other doors nearby, and little windows that had just been smeared with resin, readily caught the fire and carried it up to the roof. Once the flame took hold of that, it quickly spread throughout the whole house. In just this way, I suppose, they say that Archimedes too set the enemy triremes ablaze by means of the pyria [fire-devices; commonly understood as burning mirrors].

paragraphs.content: ἀνάπτεται δ’ ἑτοίμως ὑπὸ πυρείου καὶ ἔριον καὶ στυππεῖον καὶ θρυαλλὶς καὶ νάρθηξ καὶ πᾶν ὅ τι ἂν ὁμοίως ᾖ ξηρὸν καὶ χαῦνον. ἐξάπτουσι δὲ φλόγα καὶ λίθοι παρατριβόμενοι καὶ μᾶλλον ἂν θείου τις αὐτοῖς ἐπιπάσσῃ. καὶ τὸ τῆς Μηδείας δὲ φάρμακον τοιοῦτο ἦν. πάντα γοῦν ἀνάπτεται προσβαλλούσης θερμασίας οἶς ἂν ἐπαλειφθῇ. σκευάζεται δὲ κᾀκεῖνο διά τε θείου καὶ τῆς ὑγρᾶς ἀσφάλτου. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ ὡς θαυμαστόν τις ἐδείκνυ· ἀποσβεννὺς λύχνον αὖθις ἧπτε
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.8:

Wool, tow, a lamp-wick, fennel-stalk, and everything that is similarly dry and porous are readily ignited by a fire-drill. Stones also kindle a flame when rubbed together, and even more so if one sprinkles sulfur on them. And the drug of Medea was of this sort. At any rate, everything to which it is smeared ignites when heat is applied. That too is prepared from both sulfur and liquid asphalt [bitumen]. And indeed someone used to demonstrate it as a marvel: after extinguishing a lamp, he would light it again
paragraphs.openai_translation: It is readily kindled by tinder [pyreion], wool, tow [stuppeion], a wick [thryallis], a fennel stalk [narthex], and anything else that is likewise dry and porous. Flame is also produced by stones when they are rubbed together, and even more so if one sprinkles them with sulfur. Medea’s drug was of this sort as well: for everything to which it is smeared ignites when heat approaches. That, too, is prepared by means of sulfur and liquid asphalt [naphtha]. And indeed someone even displayed it as a marvel: after extinguishing a lamp, he lit it again.

paragraphs.content: τοίχῳ προσφέρων· ἕτερος δὲ λίθῳ προσέφερεν· ἐτεθείωτο δὲ ἄρα καὶ ὁ τοῖχος καὶ ὁ λίθος. καὶ ὡς ἐγνώσθη τοῦτο θαυμαστὸν οὐκέτ’ ἦν τὸ γινόμενον. πάντα οὖν ταῦτα τὰ φάρμακα θερμὰ μὲν οὔπω τελέως ἐστὶν ἐπιτηδειότατα μέντοι πρὸς τὸ γενέσθαι θερμά· καὶ διὰ τοῦτο δυνάμει θερμὰ λέγεται. περὶ μὲν δὴ τούτων οὐδὲν ἄπορον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

when bringing it near to a wall; and another brought it near to a stone; and it turned out that both the wall and the stone had been treated with sulfur. And when this was recognized, what was happening was no longer marvelous. Therefore all these drugs are not yet completely hot, but they are most suitable for becoming hot; and for this reason they are called hot in potentiality [dynamei]. Concerning these matters, then, there is no difficulty.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Applying it to a wall; and another applied it to a stone; and it turned out that both the wall and the stone had been sulfurized. And once this was understood, what was happening was no longer a marvel. All these remedies [pharmaka: agents/medicinals], then, are not yet completely hot, yet they are most apt to become hot; and for this reason they are said to be hot in potential [dunamis: potentiality]. As to these matters, then, there is nothing puzzling.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ οὐδὲ διὰ τί πινόμενος μὲν ὁ οἶνος ἱκανῶς θερμαίνει τὸ σῶμα, κατὰ δὲ τοῦ δέρματος ἐπιτιθέμενος οὐ θερμαίνει. δέδεικται γὰρ ὀλίγῳ πρότερον, οὐχ ἁπλῶς ὥσπερ θερμὸν φάρμακον, ἀλλ’ ὡς οἰκεία τροφὴ, θερμαῖνον τὸ ζῶον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But nor [do they explain] why wine, when drunk, sufficiently heats the body, but when applied to the skin does not heat it. For it has been shown a little earlier that it heats the living creature not simply as a hot medicine, but as proper nourishment.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Nor again is it clear why wine, when drunk, sufficiently warms the body, whereas when applied to the skin it does not warm. For it has been shown a little earlier that it warms the living creature not simply as a hot drug [pharmakon], but as proper nourishment.

paragraphs.content: ὡς γὰρ αἱ τοῦ πυρὸς ἐπιτήδειοι τροφαὶ τὸ πῦρ αὔξουσιν οὕτω καὶ τῶν φύσει θερμῶν σωμάτων ὅ τί περ ἂν οἰκεία τε καὶ σύμφυτος ὑπάρχῃ τροφὴ ῥώσει τε διὰ παντὸς αὐτὰ καὶ τὴν ἔμφυτον αὐξήσει θερμασίαν. καὶ τοῦτο μὲν ἁπάσης τροφῆς κοινόν. οἴνῳ δ’ ἴδιον ἐξαίρετον ὑπάρχει τὸ τάχος τῆς μεταβολῆς ὡς δᾳδὶ καὶ θρυαλλίδι καὶ στυππείῳ καὶ πίττῃ. καὶ δὴ καὶ τῆς εἰκόνος ἐχόμενοι τοῦ πυρὸς ἀναμνήσομεν αὖθις ξύλων ὑγρῶν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.11:

For just as suitable fuels increase fire, so too whatever nourishment is appropriate and natural to bodies that are hot by nature will both strengthen them continuously and increase their innate heat. And this indeed is common to all nourishment. But wine has as its own distinctive property the swiftness of its transformation, like a torch and a lamp-wick and tow and pitch. And indeed, keeping to the image of fire, we shall remind [the reader] again of wet wood—

---

**Brief notes:**
- The text breaks off mid-sentence with "wet wood" (ξύλων ὑγρῶν), suggesting the continuation of a comparison about combustible materials
- The passage appears to be from a medical or natural philosophical text discussing nutrition, bodily heat, and the particular properties of wine as nourishment
paragraphs.openai_translation: For just as the suitable fuels of fire increase the fire, so also, in the case of bodies that are by nature warm, whatever nourishment is both proper and connatural [symphytos] will permeate them through and through and will increase their innate heat. And this is common to all nourishment. But wine has as its distinctive, exceptional feature the speed of alteration [metabolē], as in the case of a torch, a wick, tinder, and pitch. And indeed, keeping hold of the image of fire, we shall again call to mind the case of wet wood.

paragraphs.content: ἃ τροφὴ μέν ἐστι καὶ αὐτὰ τοῦ πυρὸς ἀλλ’ οὐκ εὐθὺς οὐδ’ ἐκ τοῦ παραχρῆμα. καὶ διὰ τοῦτο ἐπιβληθέντα πολλὰ τῷ πυρὶ κατακρύπτει τε τὴν φλόγα καὶ μάλιστ’ ἂν ἀσθενὴς ὑπάρχῃ καὶ σμικρὰ κίνδυνον ἐπάγει φθορᾶς. οὕτως οὖν κᾀν τοῖς ζώοις ὅσα τῶν ἐδεσμάτων ἵν’ ἐξομοιωθῇ τελέως καὶ θρέψῃ τὸ σῶμα χρόνου δεῖται ψύχος μᾶλλον ἐπάγειν ἢ θάλπος ἐν τῷ παραχρῆμα φαίνεται. θερμαίνει μὴν ἐν τῷ χρόνῳ καὶ ταῦτα παραπλησίως τοῖς ἄλλοις ἐδέσμασιν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.12:

These things are indeed nourishment for fire itself, but not immediately nor from the outset. And for this reason, when many such things are thrown upon the fire, they both conceal the flame and, especially if it happens to be weak and small, bring a danger of extinction. Thus, then, also in animals, those foods which require time in order to be completely assimilated and nourish the body appear to bring coldness rather than warmth in the immediate moment. Nevertheless, in time these too produce heat similarly to other foods.

---

**Brief contextual notes:**
- This passage appears to be from a medical or natural philosophical text discussing the properties of certain foods and their effects on the body's heat
- The analogy between fire and bodily heat reflects the common ancient Greek medical theory of innate heat in living beings
- The argument follows a structure comparing combustible materials and fire to food and bodily warmth
paragraphs.openai_translation: Things which are themselves fuel for fire, yet not immediately nor on the spot. And for this reason, when many such things are thrown onto a fire, they both smother the flame—especially if it happens to be weak and small—and bring the danger of its extinction. So too in living creatures, those foods which, in order to be completely assimilated [made like the body; assimilation], and to nourish the body, require time, seem at the moment to induce cold rather than warmth. Yet in time these also warm, in much the same way as other foods.

paragraphs.content: εἰ μόνον αὐτοῖς προσγένηται τὸ θρέψαι τὸ σῶμα. τροφὴ γὰρ ἅπασα κατὰ τὸν ἑαυτῆς λόγον αὔξει τὸ τοῦ ζώου θερμόν. εἰ δὲ καταποθείη μὲν ὡς τροφὴ μὴ μέντοι δὲ κρατηθείη τοῦτ’ ἐκεῖνο τὸ πρὸς Ἱπποκράτους εἰρημένον εἴη ἂν ὄνομα τροφῆς ἔργον δ’ οὐχί. τριχῶς γὰρ τῆς τροφῆς λεγομένης ὥς γε αὐτὸς ἐδίδαξε τοῦτ’ εἰπών· Τροφὴ δὲ τὸ τρέφον τροφὴ τὸ οἷον τροφὴ καὶ τὸ μέλλον· ἡ μὲν ἤδη τρέφουσα καὶ προστιθεμένη καὶ μηκέτι μέλλουσα
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 2.13:

if only there should come to them the nourishing of the body. For all nourishment according to its own nature increases the heat of the living creature. But if it should be swallowed down as nourishment yet not be mastered, this would be that which was said by Hippocrates: "the name of nourishment but not the function." For since nourishment is spoken of in three ways, as he himself taught when he said this: "Nourishment: that which nourishes, nourishment: that which is capable [of nourishing], and that which is about to [nourish]"—the one already nourishing and being assimilated and no longer being about to [nourish]

---

**Brief notes:**
- "mastered" (κρατηθείη) refers to the body's ability to digest and assimilate the food
- The Hippocratic quotation distinguishes three senses of "nourishment": actual nourishment in process, potential nourishment, and prospective nourishment
- The text appears to break off mid-sentence at the end
paragraphs.openai_translation: if only there be added to them the capacity to nourish the body. For every food, according to its own account [logos: inherent principle], increases the living creature’s heat [the innate heat]. But if it is swallowed as food and yet is not mastered, then that remark of Hippocrates would apply: it would be “food” in name, but not in deed. For “food” is spoken of in three ways, as he himself taught when he said this: “Food is that which nourishes; food is what is as it were food; and [food is] what is going to be [food].” The first is that which is already nourishing and being incorporated, and is no longer merely about to do so.

paragraphs.content: κυρίως ὀνομάζεται τροφὴ καὶ δὴ καὶ θερμαίνει πάντως τὸ τρεφόμενον σῶμα· τῶν δ’ ἄλλων οὐδετέρα διότι μηδὲ τροφαὶ κυρίως εἰσὶν ἀλλὰ τὸ μὲν οἷον τροφὴ τὸ δ’ ὅτι μέλλει τοιοῦτο γενήσεσθαι. ταῦτ’ ἄρα καὶ αὐτὸς ὁ οἶνος οὐκ ἀεὶ θερμαίνει τὸ ζῶον ὥσπερ οὐδὲ τοὔλαιον ἀνάπτει τὴν φλόγα καίτοι γ’ οἰκειοτάτη τροφὴ πυρὸς ὑπάρχον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

is properly called nourishment and indeed also invariably heats the body being nourished; but neither of these applies to the other things, because they are not properly nourishments either, but rather one is like nourishment and the other is such because it is going to become such. For this reason, then, wine itself does not always heat the living creature, just as oil does not kindle the flame, even though it is the most suitable nourishment for fire.
paragraphs.openai_translation: What is properly [in the strict sense] called “food” does, to be sure, invariably warm the body that is being nourished; but of the other two, neither does so, because they are not foods in the strict sense—one is only as it were food, and the other because it is going to become such. Therefore even wine itself does not always warm the living creature, just as oil does not kindle the flame, though it is the most congenial nourishment [trophē] of fire.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἐὰν ἀσθενεῖ καὶ σμικρᾷ φλογὶ καταχέῃς ἔλαιον ἀθρόον καὶ πολὺ, καταπνίξεις, καὶ τελέως ἀποσβέσεις αὐτὴν μᾶλλον ἢ αὐξήσεις. οὕτως οὖν καὶ ὁ οἶνος, ἐπειδὰν πολὺς, ὡς μὴ κρατεῖσθαι, πίνηται, τοσοῦτον ἀποδεῖ τοῦ θερμαίνειν τὸ ζῶων, ὥστε καὶ πάθη ψυχρότερα γεννᾷ.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But if you pour oil suddenly and in large quantity upon a weak and small flame, you will smother it, and you will extinguish it completely rather than increase it. So too, then, with wine: whenever it is drunk in such quantity that it cannot be mastered [by the body], it is so far from warming the living creature that it actually produces conditions of a colder nature.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But if, upon a weak and small flame, you pour oil all at once and in great quantity, you will stifle it, and you will completely extinguish it rather than increase it. So too with wine: whenever it is drunk in such excess as not to be kept under control, it falls so far short of warming the living creature [zoon: the organism] that it even produces colder conditions [pathe: affections/conditions].

paragraphs.content: ἀποπληξίαι γοῦν καὶ παραπληξίαι καὶ κάροι καὶ κώματα καὶ παραλύσεις ἐπιληψίαι τε καὶ σπασμοὶ καὶ τέτανοι ταῖς ἀμέτροις οἴνου πόσεσιν ἕπονται, ψυχρὰ σύμπαντα πάθη. καθόλου γὰρ, ὅσα τῶν εἰς τὸ σῶμα λαμβανομένων ὡς τροφὴ θερμαίνει, ταῦθ’ εὕροις ἄν ποτε ψύχοντα, καθ’ ὅ τι καὶ τὴν φλόγα πρὸς τῆς αὐτῆς ὕλης οὐκ αὐξανομένην μόνον, ἀλλὰ καὶ σβεννυμένην ἐνίοτε. ταυτὶ μὲν οὖν ἔοικεν ὁμολογεῖν ἅπαντα τοῖς τε περὶ στοιχείων καὶ τοῖς περὶ κράσεων λογισμοῖς.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

At any rate, apoplexies and paraplexies, stupors and comas, paralyses, epilepsies, spasms, and tetanic contractions follow upon immoderate drinking of wine—all of them cold affections. For in general, you would find that whatever things taken into the body as nourishment produce heat, these same things sometimes produce cold, just as a flame is not only increased by the same material but is also sometimes extinguished by it. These observations, then, seem to agree entirely with both the theories concerning the elements and those concerning mixtures [or temperaments].
paragraphs.openai_translation: Apoplexies and paraplexies [apoplexy-like collapses], and stupors [carus], and comas, and paralyses, epilepsies too and convulsions and tetani attend upon immoderate potations of wine—all of them cold affections. For in general, the very things taken into the body as nourishment that heat, you would sometimes find cooling, inasmuch as even flame, by means of the same material, is not only increased but sometimes also extinguished. These points, then, appear to be in full agreement with the reasonings about the elements and about mixtures [temperaments].

paragraphs.content: Ἐκεῖνο δ’ ἂν ἴσως δόξειε διαφέρεσθαι τό τινα τῶν ἐσθιομένων ἐν τροφῆς χρείᾳ κατὰ τοῦ δέρματος ἐπιτιθέμενα διαβιβρώσκειν τε καὶ ἑλκοῦν αὐτὸ καθάπερ νάπυ καὶ τάριχος σκόροδά τε καὶ κρόμμυα. καίτοι τοῦτο συμφωνεῖ τοῖς ἐξ ἀρχῆς ὑποκειμένοις· ἅμα μὲν γὰρ ὅτι μεταβάλλεται καὶ ἀλλοιοῦται κατά τε τὴν γαστέρα πεπτόμενα κᾀν ταῖς φλεψὶν αἱματούμενα· πρὸς δὲ τούτοις καὶ διότι μὴ μένει καθ’ ἕνα τόπον ἀλλ’ εἰς πολλὰ μερίζεται πάντῃ φερόμενα· καὶ πρὸς τούτοις
paragraphs.openai_translation: That point, perhaps, might seem to be at variance: namely, that certain of the things we eat, when applied upon the skin in relation to nourishment, corrode and ulcerate it, just like mustard, salted fish, garlic, and onions. And yet this accords with the assumptions laid down at the outset: both because they undergo change and alteration—being digested in the stomach and made into blood in the veins [phlebes: blood vessels]—and, in addition, because they do not remain in a single place but are divided into many parts and carried everywhere; and besides this—
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 3.1:

But perhaps this might seem to present a difficulty: that some of the things that are eaten, when applied to the skin for the purpose of nourishment, corrode and ulcerate it, such as mustard and salted fish, garlic and onions. And yet this agrees with what was laid down from the beginning. For on the one hand, because they are changed and altered both when being digested in the stomach and when being turned into blood in the veins; and in addition to this, also because they do not remain in one place but are divided into many parts being carried everywhere; and besides these things—

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence, suggesting this is an incomplete excerpt from a longer passage discussing the transformation of food in the body and why certain foods that might irritate the skin externally do not cause the same effect when consumed and digested.]

paragraphs.content: διότι μίγνυται καὶ χυμοῖς πολλοῖς καὶ τοῖς ἅμα αὐτοῖς λαμβανομένοις σιτίοις· ἔτι δὲ πρὸς τούτοις ὅτι διὰ ταχέων ἥ τε πέψις αὐτῶν γίνεται καὶ ἡ διάκρισις ὡς τὸ μὲν οἰκεῖον ἐξομοιωθῆναι τὸ δὲ περιττὸν ἐν αὐτοῖς καὶ δριμὺ διὰ γαστρός τε ἅμα καὶ οὔρων καὶ ἱδρώτων ἐκκριθῆναι διὰ ταῦτα πάντα τὸ ἔξωθεν ἑλκοῦν ἐσθιόμενον οὐχ ἑλκοῖ. καίτοι κᾂν τῶν εἰρημένων ἓν ὁτιοῦν ὑπῆρχεν αὐτοῖς ἱκανὸν ἂν ἦν δήπουθεν ἀβλαβῆ φυλάξαι τὰ ἐκτὸς οἶον εἰ τύχοι
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Because it mixes both with many humors and with the foods taken together with them; and furthermore, because their digestion and separation occur quickly, so that what is suitable is assimilated while what is excessive and acrid in them is excreted through the bowels and at the same time through urine and sweat—for all these reasons, what draws [poison] from outside when eaten does not draw it [when inside the body]. And yet even if any one whatsoever of the things mentioned were present in them, it would surely be sufficient to keep external things [i.e., external substances] harmless, as it might happen—
paragraphs.openai_translation: because it mixes both with many juices [humors] and with the foods taken along with them; and, moreover, that both their digestion [pepsis] and their separation [diakrisis] occur quickly, so that what is proper [oikeion] is assimilated, while the superfluous and acrid [drimys] element in them is excreted through the belly [gaster], along with urine and sweat. For all these reasons, what ulcerates from the outside does not ulcerate when eaten. And indeed, even if any one of the points just mentioned were present in them, it would surely be sufficient to keep the external parts [ta ektos] unharmed—for example, if it should happen…

paragraphs.content: τὸ μεταβάλλειν πρῶτον. εἰ γὰρ οὐ μένει τὸ νάπυ τοιοῦτο οἶον ἔξωθεν ἐλήφθη δῆλον ὡς οὐδὲ τὴν δύναμιν αὐτοῦ μένειν ἀξιώσεις. εἰ δὲ καὶ διακρίνεται καὶ καθαίρεται πολὺ δὴ καὶ μᾶλλον. ἤρκει δὲ καὶ τὸ μὴ χρονίζειν ἐν ἑνὶ χωρίῳ. φαίνεται γὰρ οὐδὲ περὶ τὸ δέρμα δρᾶσαί τι δυνάμενον ἄνευ χρόνου πλείονος.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

to change first. For if the mustard seed does not remain such as it was when taken from outside, it is clear that you will not maintain that its power remains either. And if it is also separated and purified, much more so indeed. But it was also sufficient that it does not linger in one place. For it appears unable to produce any effect even on the skin without a considerable amount of time.
paragraphs.openai_translation: First, that it undergoes change. For if the nápy [rape/turnip, a Brassica used as a drug] does not remain such as it was when taken from outside [i.e., applied externally], it is clear that you will not maintain that even its potency remains. And if it is even dispersed and washed away, then all the more so. It would also have sufficed that it does not linger in one place; for it appears not even capable of doing anything with respect to the skin without a longer time.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ καὶ τὸ μίγνυσθαι πολλοῖς ἑτέροις σιτίοις οὐ σμικρὸν οὐδ’ αὐτό. γνοίης δ’ ἂν, εἰ μόνον αὐτὸ προσενέγκοις χωρὶς τῶν ἄλλων σιτίων, ὅσην ἀνίαν τε καὶ δῆξιν ἐπιφέρει τῇ γαστρί. καὶ μὲν δὴ, κᾂν εἰ πολλοῖς γλυκέσι χυμοῖς ἀναμίξας αὐτὸ κατὰ τοῦ δέρματος ἐπιθείης, οὐδὲν ἐργάσεται φαῦλον.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But also its mixing with many other foods is itself no small matter. You would recognize this if you were to consume it alone, apart from other foods, how much distress and biting pain it brings to the stomach. And indeed, even if you were to mix it with many sweet juices and apply it to the skin, it would cause no harm at all.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But its being mixed with many other foods is itself no small matter. You would realize, if you were to administer it by itself, apart from the other foods, how much distress and stinging [dēxis: biting irritation] it brings upon the stomach. And indeed, even if, after mixing it with many sweet juices [chymoi], you were to apply it to the skin, it would do nothing harmful.

paragraphs.content: ὁπότε οὖν ἕκαστον τῶν εἰρημένων ἱκανόν ἐστι καθ’ αὑτὸ κωλῦσαι τὸ νάπυ δρᾶσαί τι τοιοῦτο ἐντὸς, οἷον ἐκτὸς ἔδρα περὶ τὸ δέρμα, πολὺ δή που μᾶλλον, οἶμαι, πάντων ἅμα συνελθόντων. καὶ γὰρ ἀλλοιοῦται πεπτόμενον, καὶ διακρίνεται, καὶ καθαίρεται, καὶ πολλοῖς ἑτέροις ἀναμίγνυται, καὶ μερίζεται πολλαχῶς, καὶ πανταχῇ φέρεται, καὶ χρονίζει κατ’ οὐδὲν τῶν μορίων.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Therefore, since each of the aforementioned factors is sufficient by
paragraphs.openai_translation: Whenever, then, each of the aforesaid factors is sufficient in itself to prevent the napy [rape/turnip, Brassica napus] from doing anything of that sort inside, such as it did outside upon the skin, how much more, I think, when all of them occur together at once. For it is altered in the course of digestion, and it is separated out, and purified, and mixed with many other things, and divided in many ways, and carried everywhere, and it does not linger in any of the parts.

paragraphs.content: ὅτι δ’ εἴπερ ἔμενε δριμὺ πάντως ἂν ἥλκωσε καὶ τὰ ἐντὸς ἐκ τῶν αὐτομάτων ἑλκῶν ἐπιγνώσῃ. γίνεται γὰρ πολλοῖς πολλάκις τοῖς μὲν ἐξ ἐδεσμάτων μοχθηρῶν τοῖς δ’ ἔκ τινος ἐν αὐτῷ τῷ σώματι διαφθορᾶς καὶ σηπεδόνος ἡ καλουμένη κακοχυμία. καὶ τούτοις ἐνίοτε μὲν ἑλκοῦταί τι καὶ τῶν ἐντός· ὡς τὰ πολλὰ δὲ καὶ τῷ τὴν φύσιν ἀποτρίβεσθαι τὰ κατὰ τὴν ἕξιν περιττώματα πρὸς τὸ δέρμα τοῦθ’ ἑλκοῦται πολλοῖς καὶ συνεχέσιν ἕλκεσι. καρκῖνός τε γὰρ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

That if it had remained acrid, it would certainly have ulcerated the internal parts as well, you will recognize from spontaneous ulcers. For the so-called cacochymia [bad humoral condition] occurs in many people frequently, in some cases from unwholesome foods, in others from some corruption and putrefaction within the body itself. And in these cases sometimes one of the internal parts is ulcerated; but for the most part, because nature rubs off the residues in the bodily condition toward the skin, this is ulcerated in many and continuous ulcers. For cancer...
paragraphs.openai_translation: But if indeed the acrid matter remained, it would certainly ulcerate even the internal parts; you can recognize this from spontaneous ulcerations. For it often happens to many— in some from wretched foods, in others from a certain decay and putrefaction within the body itself, the so-called cacochymy [“bad mixture” of humors]. And in such people, sometimes even some of the internal parts become ulcerated; but for the most part, because nature wears away the superfluities [perittōmata: excess residues] in accordance with the prevailing condition toward the skin, this [the skin] becomes ulcerated in many, with frequent and persistent sores. For cancer too—

paragraphs.content: καὶ φαγέδαινα καὶ ἕρπης ὁ ἀναβιβρωσκόμενος ἄνθρακές τε καὶ τὰ χειρώνεια καὶ τηλέφεια καλούμενα καὶ ἄλλαι μυρίαι γενέσεις ἑλκῶν ἔκγονοι τῆς τοιαύτης εἰσὶ κακοχυμίας. οὔτ’ οὖν τῶν τοιούτων οὐδὲν ἄπορον οὔτε διὰ τί τῶν φαρμάκων ἔνια μὲν ἡμᾶς οὐδὲν ἔξωθεν ἀδικοῦντα μέγα τι κακὸν ἐργάζεται καταποθέντα· τινὰ δὲ πολλάκις ἔβλαψεν εἴσω ληφθέντα πολλάκις δὲ ὠφέλησεν· ἔνια δὲ οὐ μόνον ἔσωθεν ἀλλὰ καὶ ἔξωθεν ἀδικεῖ. συλλήβδην γοῦν εἰπεῖν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 3.7:

And phagédaina [spreading ulcer] and the eroding herpes, carbuncles, and the so-called Chironian and Telephian [ulcers], and countless other types of ulcers are offspring of such bad humoral condition. Therefore, none of these things is difficult to understand, nor [is it difficult to understand] why some drugs, while doing us no harm from the outside, produce some great evil when swallowed; but some have often caused harm when taken internally, and often have been beneficial; and some cause harm not only from within but also from without. In short, to speak

---

**Brief notes:**
- *phagédaina*: a medical term for a rapidly spreading, destructive ulcer
- *Chironian and Telephian*: types of ulcers named after mythological figures (Chiron and Telephus), likely chronic or difficult-to-heal wounds
- *kakochymía*: literally "bad juice/humor," referring to a pathological imbalance of bodily humors in ancient Greek medical theory
paragraphs.openai_translation: Both phagedaena [an “eating” or gangrenous ulcer] and the corroding herpes, anthrakes [carbuncles], and the so‑called cheironeia [hand-ulcers] and telephia [hard-to-heal ulcers], and countless other kinds of sores besides, are offspring of such a bad mixture of humors [dyscrasia]. Accordingly, nothing in such cases is puzzling—nor is it puzzling why, among drugs, some that do us no harm when applied externally work great mischief when swallowed; while others, taken internally, have often harmed and often benefited; and some do harm not only inwardly but also outwardly. In sum, at any rate, to speak briefly…

paragraphs.content: οὐδὲν ὁμοίως ἔσωθέν τε καὶ ἔξωθεν ἐνεργεῖν πέφυκεν. οὔτε γὰρ ὁ τοῦ λυττῶντος κυνὸς ἀφρὸς οὔθ’ ὁ τῆς ἀσπίδος οὔθ’ ὁ τῆς ἐχίδνης ἰὸς οἳ δὴ καὶ χωρὶς ἕλκους ἔξωθεν προσπεσόντες ἀδικεῖν πεπίστευνται τὴν ἴσην ἔχουσι δύναμιν ἢ τῷ δέρματι μόνῳ προσομιλήσαντες ἢ εἴσω μεταληφθέντες. οὐ μὴν οὐδ’ ἐκεῖνο θαυμάζειν ἄξιον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 3.8:

Nothing is naturally capable of acting in the same way both from within and from without. For neither the foam of a rabid dog, nor that of an asp, nor the venom of a viper—which are indeed believed to cause harm even when they fall upon the body from outside without a wound—have the same power whether they merely come into contact with the skin alone or are taken inside. Nor indeed is that other matter worthy of wonder

---

**Brief notes:**
- ἀσπίς [aspis]: a venomous snake, typically translated as "asp"
- ἐχίδνης [echidnēs]: viper
- The sentence appears to break off mid-thought, suggesting this is part of a longer passage
paragraphs.openai_translation: Nothing by nature is constituted to act in the same way from within and from without. For neither the foam of a rabid dog, nor that of the asp [aspis: a venomous snake], nor the venom [ios] of the viper—things which are in fact believed to do harm even when they fall upon one from outside without a wound—have equal power whether they merely come into contact with the skin or are taken within. Yet not even that is a thing worth wondering at.

paragraphs.content: εἴ τινων φαρμάκων οὐκ ἐξικνεῖται πρὸς τὸ βάθος ἡ δύναμις· οὐ γὰρ ἀναγκαῖον ἅπαντα τὴν αὐτὴν ἔχειν ἰσχύν. εἰ δὲ πολλὰ τῶν εἴσω λαμβανομένων ἐν μὲν τῷδε τῷ καιρῷ καὶ μετὰ τοσῆσδε ποσότητος καὶ τῆς πρὸς τάδε μίξεως ὠφέλησεν ἀκαίρως δὲ καὶ πολλὰ καὶ ἄμικτα ληφθέντα βλάβην ἤνεγκεν οὐδὲν ἐντεῦθεν ἀπόρημα τῷ λόγῳ. καὶ γὰρ καὶ τοῖς σιτίοις ὑπάρχει τοῦτό γε καὶ τῷ πυρὶ
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

[It is not surprising] if the power of certain drugs does not reach to the depth; for it is not necessary that all have the same strength. But if many of the things taken internally have been beneficial at this particular time and with this particular quantity and with mixture with these particular things, yet when taken at the wrong time and in large amounts and unmixed have brought harm, there is no difficulty for the argument from this. For indeed this same thing applies both to foods and to fire.
paragraphs.openai_translation: If, in the case of certain drugs, the potency does not reach down to the depths—for it is not necessary that all have the same strength—and if many of the things taken internally [i.e., ingested remedies], at such-and-such a time and with such-and-such a quantity and in mixture with such-and-such ingredients, have been beneficial, whereas taken unseasonably, in great quantity, and without admixture they have brought harm, there is nothing here that poses a difficulty for the argument. For this holds also of foods—and even of fire.

paragraphs.content: καὶ πᾶσιν ὡσαύτως φάναι τοῖς προσπίπτουσι τῷ σώματι. συμμέτρου γοῦν φλογὸς ἔστιν ὅτε δεόμεθα καὶ χρώμενοι μεγάλα πρὸς αὐτῆς ὀνινάμεθα καίτοι τῆς ἀμέτρου καιούσης ἡμᾶς. οὕτω δὲ καὶ ψυχροῦ πόσις ἡ μὲν σύμμετρος ὀνίνησιν ἡ δὲ ἄμετρος ἐσχάτως βλάπτει. τί τοίνυν θαυμαστὸν εἶναί τι φάρμακον οὕτω δυνάμει θερμὸν ὡς εἰ μὲν πολύ τε λαμβάνοιτο καὶ κενῷ τῷ σώματι προσφέροιτο διαβιβρώσκειν τε καὶ καίειν αὐτὸ παντελῶς
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

And one might say the same thing applies to all things that affect the body. At any rate, there are times when we need a moderate flame, and by using it we derive great benefit from it, even though an immoderate one burns us. And so too with drinking something cold: a moderate amount benefits us, but an immoderate amount causes extreme harm. What wonder is it, then, that there exists some drug so hot in power that if it were taken in large quantity and applied to an empty body, it would corrode and burn it completely?
paragraphs.openai_translation: And one should say the same of all things that impinge upon the body. For there are times when we need a proportionate fire, and by using it we gain great benefit from it, although an immoderate fire burns us. So too with a draught of cold: the measured helps, while the unmeasured does the utmost harm. Why then is it surprising that some drug should be hot in its potency [dynamis] to such a degree that, if it were taken in large quantity and applied when the body is empty [i.e., on an empty stomach], it both corrodes and burns it completely?

paragraphs.content: εἰ δ’ ὀλίγον εἴη ἢ καὶ σὺν τοῖς κολάζουσιν τὴν ἰσχὺν αὐτοῦ πρὸς τῷ μὴ βλάπτειν μηδὲν ἔτι καὶ θερμαῖνον ὠφελεῖν;
paragraphs.openai_translation: But if it were slight, could it, along with the agents that curb its strength [i.e., remedies that moderate it], not only no longer harm anything, but even do good by warming?
paragraphs.claude_translation:
But what if it were small, or even together with those things that restrain its strength, in addition to not harming at all, it should also benefit by warming?

---

**Alternative translation (with smoother English flow):**

But what if it were small, or even if its strength, together with those things that restrain it, not only does no harm but also benefits by providing warmth?

paragraphs.content: ὀπὸν γοῦν ἤτοι τὸν Κυρηναικὸν ἢ τὸν Μηδικὸν ἢ τὸν Παρθικὸν αὐτὸν καθ’ αὑτὸν οὐκ ἔστιν ἀλύπως λαβεῖν· ἀλλ’ εἰ παντελῶς ὀλίγος ἢ σὺν ἄλλοις ἐν καιρῷ τῷ προσήκοντι ληφθείη μεγάλως ὠφελεῖ. ταύτῃ μὲν οὖν ὅσα θερμαίνει τὸ σῶμα μεταβολῆς ἀρχὴν ἐν αὐτῷ λαβόντα καθότι πρόσθεν ἐῤῥέθη πάλιν ἀντιθερμαίνειν αὐτὸ πέφυκεν· ὅσα δὲ ψύχει καθάπερ ὀπὸς μήκωνος οὐ μεταβάλλεται πρὸς τοῦ σώματος οὐδ’ ἐπ’ ὀλίγον ἀλλ’ εὐθὺς αὐτὸ νικᾷ καὶ μεταβάλλει
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 3.12:

At any rate, it is not possible to take juice [opos]—whether the Cyrenaic, the Median, or the Parthian—by itself without distress. But if it is taken in a very small amount or together with other things at the appropriate time, it is greatly beneficial. Now in this way, then, all things that heat the body, having undergone the beginning of a change in it as was stated before, are naturally disposed to heat it in turn; but those things that cool, such as poppy juice [opium], are not changed by the body even slightly, but immediately overcome it and change it.

---

**Explanatory notes:**
- [opos]: literally "juice" or "sap," referring to medicinal plant extracts
- The Cyrenaic, Median, and Parthian varieties likely refer to different types of silphium or similar medicinal plant juices from these regions
- [poppy juice]: ὀπὸς μήκωνος, referring to opium
paragraphs.openai_translation: At any rate, the gum—whether the Cyrenaic or the Median or the Parthian—cannot be taken by itself without causing pain; but if it is taken in a very small amount, or together with other substances at the appropriate time, it is highly beneficial. In this respect, then, whatever warms the body, once it has secured a starting-point of change within it—as was said before—is naturally disposed to be warmed back in return by the body; whereas whatever cools, like the juice of the poppy [opium], is not altered by the body even in the least, but immediately overmasters it and alters it.

paragraphs.content: κᾂν εἰ θερμῄνας αὐτὰ δοίης. ἔστι γὰρ ἡ σφῶν αὐτῶν φύσις ψυχρὰ καθότι καὶ τὸ ὕδωρ.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
And even if you should give them after heating them. For their own nature is cold, just as water is also.

---

**Alternative translation (slightly more natural English):**

And even if you should administer them after heating them. For their nature is inherently cold, just as water is.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Even if you were to administer them after warming them. For their own nature is cold, just as water is.

paragraphs.content: ὀρθῶς οὖν καὶ τοῦτο σὺν πολλοῖς ἄλλοις ὑπ’ Ἀριστοτέλους εἴρηται, τὸ τῶν θερμῶν καὶ ψυχρῶν καὶ ξηρῶν καὶ ὑγρῶν σωμάτων τὰ μὲν εἶναι καθ’ αὑτὰ τοιαῦτα, τὰ δὲ κατὰ συμβεβηκός. οἷον καὶ τὸ ὕδωρ καθ’ αὑτὸ μὲν ψυχρὸν, κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς δέ ποτε θερμόν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 3.14:

Therefore, this too has been correctly stated by Aristotle along with many other things: that of hot and cold and dry and wet bodies, some are such in themselves, while others are such accidentally. For example, water is cold in itself, but sometimes hot accidentally.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Rightly, then, this too—along with many other points—has been stated by Aristotle: that among bodies which are hot, cold, dry, and moist, some are such in themselves [per se; kath’ hauto], while others are so incidentally [by accident; kata symbebekos]. For example, water as such is cold, but at times it is hot incidentally.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἡ μὲν ἐπίκτητος αὐτοῦ θερμασία ταχέως ἀπόλλυται, μένει δ’ ἡ σύμφυτος ψυχρότης.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
But its acquired heat perishes quickly, while its innate coldness remains.

---

**Alternative translation:**

But the heat acquired by it is quickly destroyed, whereas the innate coldness persists.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But its acquired warmth quickly dissipates, while the innate coldness remains. [“acquired” = epíktētos; “innate” = sýmphytos]

paragraphs.content: ὡς οὖν ὕδωρ θερμὸν ἐπιβληθὲν φλογὶ κατασβέννυσιν αὐτὴν οὕτω καὶ τὸ μηκώνειον εἰ καὶ ὅτι μάλιστα θερμῄνας δοίης ἀποψύξεις τε τὴν ἐν τοῖς ζώοις θερμασίαν καὶ κίνδυνον ἐπάξεις θανάτου. πάντα οὖν τὰ τοιαῦτα φάρμακα βραχέα τε διδόμενα καὶ σὺν τοῖς κολάζειν αὐτῶν τὸ σφοδρὸν τῆς ψύξεως δυναμένοις ἔστιν ὅτε χρείαν τινὰ παρέχει τοῖς σώμασιν ἡμῶν ὡς ἐν τοῖς περὶ φαρμάκων εἰρήσεται. καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ τὸ διὰ τῶν κανθαρίδων φάρμακον ἱκανῶς ὀνίνησι τοὺς ὑδερικοὺς
paragraphs.openai_translation: Just as hot water, when thrown on a flame, extinguishes it, so too meconium [opium]: even if you administer it heated as much as possible, you will cool the warmth in living creatures and bring on the danger of death. Therefore all such drugs, when given in small doses and together with agents capable of curbing the violence of their cooling, sometimes provide a certain benefit to our bodies, as will be stated in the works on drugs. For indeed, even the remedy made from cantharides [blister beetles, “Spanish fly”] benefits hydropic [dropsical] patients sufficiently.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 3.16:

Just as hot water poured upon a flame extinguishes it, so too poppy juice [opium], even if you administer it after heating it as much as possible, will cool the heat in living creatures and bring the danger of death. Therefore all such drugs, when given in small amounts and together with things capable of restraining their excessive cooling power, sometimes provide a certain benefit to our bodies, as will be discussed in the works on drugs. For indeed the drug made from Spanish flies [cantharides] also sufficiently benefits those suffering from dropsy [edema].

---

**Brief notes:**
- [μηκώνειον (mēkōneion): poppy juice/opium - a cooling drug in ancient medical theory]
- [κανθαρίδες (kantharides): Spanish flies/blister beetles - used medicinally despite their toxicity]
- [ὑδερικοί (hydērikoi): those with dropsy/edema - abnormal fluid accumulation]

paragraphs.content: καίτοι τοὐπίπαν ἑλκοῖ τὴν κύστιν ἡ κανθαρίς· ἀλλ’ ἐπειδὰν ὑπό τε τῶν μιχθέντων αὐτῇ κολασθῇ καὶ σώματι προσάγηται παμπόλλην ὑγρότητα περιέχοντι κενοῖ διὰ τῶν οὔρων αὐτήν. μάλιστα οὖν χρὴ προσέχειν τὸν νοῦν ἐν ἅπασι τοῖς δυνάμει θερμοῖς ἢ ψυχροῖς εἶναι λεγομένοις εἴτε τῆς φύσεώς ἐστι τῶν τρέφειν δυναμένων εἴτε μόνην ἀφορμὴν ἀλλοιώσεως λαμβάνοντα κᾄπειτα κατὰ τὴν οἰκείαν φύσιν ἀλλοιούμενα διατίθησί πως τὸ σῶμα καὶ τρίτον ἐπὶ τούτοις
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 3.17:

And yet, generally speaking, the Spanish fly ulcerates the bladder; but when it has been restrained by the substances mixed with it and is applied to a body containing a very great amount of moisture, it evacuates this through the urine. Therefore, one must pay attention especially in all cases of things said to be hot or cold in potency, whether they belong to the nature of things capable of nourishing, or whether they merely receive an initial impulse of alteration and then, being altered according to their own nature, affect the body in some way—and thirdly, in addition to these...

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence with "and thirdly, in addition to these," suggesting the paragraph continues beyond what was provided.]
paragraphs.openai_translation: And yet, for the most part cantharis [blister beetle/cantharides] ulcerates the bladder; but whenever it has been restrained by the substances mixed with it, and is applied to a body that contains a very great amount of moisture, it evacuates this through the urine. Therefore one must pay the closest attention, in all things said to be potentially hot or cold, whether they belong by nature to the class of things capable of nourishing, or whether, taking only an occasion for alteration and then being altered according to their own nature, they somehow dispose the body—and, third, in addition to these...

paragraphs.content: εἰ μηδ’ ὅλως ἀλλοιοῦται πρὸς αὐτοῦ κατὰ μηδέν. εἰ μὲν γὰρ ἐκ τοῦ γένους εἴη τῶν τρεφόντων εἰ μὲν κρατηθείη θερμαίνει μὴ κρατηθέντα δὲ ψύχει· εἰ δὲ τῶν ἐπ’ ὀλίγον ποσὸν ἀλλοιουμένων θερμαίνει πάντως· εἰ δὲ τῶν μηδ’ ὅλως ψύχει μάλιστα.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

unless it is not altered by it at all in any respect. For if it were of the class of nourishing things, if it is mastered it heats, but if not mastered it cools; but if it is of the class of things altered in small quantity, it heats in all cases; but if it is of the class of things not altered at all, it cools most of all.
paragraphs.openai_translation: If, however, it is not altered by it at all in any respect: for if it belongs to the genus of things that nourish [nutriments], then if it prevails [i.e., dominates in the mixture] it heats, but if it does not prevail it cools; whereas if it is among those altered only in a small quantity, it invariably heats; but if it is among those not altered at all, it cools most of all.

paragraphs.content: Προσέχειν δὲ ὡς εἴρηται μάλιστα καὶ διορίζεσθαι τὰ καθ’ ἑαυτὰ τῶν κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς οὐκ ἐπὶ θερμῶν καὶ ψυχρῶν μόνον ἀλλ’ οὐδὲν ἧττον αὐτῶν ἐφ’ ὑγρῶν τε καὶ ξηρῶν. ἔνια γὰρ τῶν τοιούτων ξηρὰ ταῖς οὐσίαις ὑπάρχοντα πολλῷ θερμῷ τακέντα φαντασίαν ὑγρότητος ἔλαβεν ὡς χαλκὸς καὶ σίδηρος· ἢ καθ’ ἑαυτὰ μέν ἐστιν ὑγρὰ καθάπερ ὁ κρύσταλλος ἀκράτῳ δὲ ψύξει πλησιάζοντα ξηρὰ φαίνεται. χρὴ τοίνυν τούτων ἁπάντων τὴν κρίσιν οὐχ ἁπλῶς ποιεῖσθαι καθότι κᾀν τοῖς ἔμπροσθεν ἐλέγομεν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.1:

One must pay attention, as has been said, especially to distinguish things that are per se from things that are accidental, not only in the case of hot and cold things but no less in the case of moist and dry things. For some of such things, being dry in their substances, when melted by much heat have taken on the appearance of moisture, such as bronze and iron; or they are moist per se, just as crystal is, but when subjected to unmixed cold they appear dry. It is necessary, therefore, to make the judgment concerning all these things not in a simple manner, just as we were saying also in what came before.
paragraphs.openai_translation: One must, as has been said, pay the closest attention and distinguish what is “in itself” [per se] from what is “by accident” [accidental], not only with respect to hot and cold but no less—indeed, in their case too—with respect to the wet and the dry. For some things of this sort, being dry in their natures, when melted by intense heat take on the appearance of moisture, as in the case of bronze and iron; or else they are in themselves wet, like krystallos [ice], yet when subjected to unmixed chilling they appear dry. One should therefore not render judgment about all these matters in a simple way, just as we said in the preceding discussion.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ μετὰ τοῦ συνεπισκέπτεσθαι πῶς ἔχει θερμότητος ἢ ψυχρότητος. εἰ μὲν γὰρ ὀλίγης μετέχοντα θερμότητος ὅμως καὶ ὑγρὰ φαίνοιτο διὰ τὴν οἰκείαν φύσιν ἐστὶ τοιαῦτα κᾂν εἰ μετὰ δαψιλοῦς θερμασίας ξηρά. τὰ δ’ ἤτοι ῥέοντα μετὰ θερμότητος ζεούσης ἢ πεπηγότα διὰ ψύξιν ἄκρατον οὐ καθ’ ἑαυτὰ νομίζειν εἶναι τὰ μὲν ὑγρὰ τὰ δὲ ξηρά. ταύτῃ τε οὖν διαιρεῖσθαι τὰ καθ’ ἑαυτὰ τῶν κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.2:

But [this must be done] together with examining how it stands in relation to heat or cold. For if things appear moist despite partaking of little heat, they are such by their own nature, and [likewise] if they are dry despite abundant heat. But those things that are either flowing due to boiling heat or solidified through unmixed cold should not be considered to be moist or dry respectively in themselves. And so in this way the things [that are moist or dry] in themselves are to be distinguished from those [that are so] accidentally.
paragraphs.openai_translation: …but with a concurrent examination of how it stands with respect to heat or cold. For if, though sharing only a little heat, it nonetheless appears wet owing to its own nature, then it is of that sort; and even if, under abundant heating, it is dry. But things that either flow along with boiling heat, or are congealed through unmixed cold, are not to be regarded in themselves as, the one, wet, and the other, dry. Thus, then, the things in themselves [kath’ heauta, “per se”] are to be distinguished from those that are so by coincidence [kata symbebēkos, “incidentally”].

paragraphs.content: ἀναφέροντά τε πρὸς. αὐτὰ ταῦτα τὴν κρίσιν οὕτω ποιεῖσθαι τῶν δυνάμει θερμῶν ἢ ψυχρῶν ἢ ξηρῶν ἢ ὑγρῶν. οὐ γὰρ πρὸς τὸ κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς ἀλλὰ πρὸς τὸ καθ’ ἑαυτὸ χρὴ κρίνεσθαι τὸ δυνάμει. κοινὴ δ’ ἐπὶ πάντων ἡ κρίσις καὶ μία τὸ τάχος τῆς ἀλλοιώσεως.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"and referring the judgment to these very things themselves, thus to make the determination of things potentially hot or cold or dry or moist. For what is potential must be judged not in relation to what is accidental but in relation to what it is in itself. And the judgment is common and one for all cases: the speed of the alteration."
paragraphs.openai_translation: And by referring the judgment to these very points, one should proceed thus in the case of things that are potentially hot or cold or dry or moist. For what is potential must be judged not with reference to what is accidental [kata sumbebekos], but with reference to what it is in itself [kath’ heauto]. And the criterion is common and single for all: the speed of alteration [qualitative change].

paragraphs.content: ὁμωνύμως δὲ λεγομένου τοῦ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ· τὰ μὲν γὰρ κατ’ ἐπικράτησιν οὕτως ὀνομάζεται τὰ δ’ ὡς ἄκραν ἔχοντα ἧς παρονομάζεται ποιότητος· εἰς ὁπότερον αὐτῶν ἑτοίμως μεθίσταται τὸ κρινόμενον ἔσται δυνάμει τοιοῦτο. ἔλαιον μὲν γάρ ἐστι δυνάμει θερμὸν ὅτι ῥᾳδίως φλὸξ γίνεται. κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ ῥητίνη καὶ ἄσφαλτος καὶ πίττα. οἶνος δὲ διότι ῥᾳδίως αἷμα γίνεται. κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ μέλι καὶ κρέας καὶ γάλα. ταυτὶ μὲν οὖν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.4:

Since "hot" and "cold" and "dry" and "wet" are spoken of homonymously: for some things are named in this way according to predominance, while others are named as having an extreme quality from which they derive their name; that which is being judged will be such-and-such potentially according to whichever of these it readily changes into. For oil is potentially hot because it easily becomes flame. And in the same way resin and asphalt and pitch. Wine, however, [is potentially hot] because it easily becomes blood. And in the same way honey and meat and milk. These things, then...

[Note: The text appears to break off mid-sentence with "ταυτὶ μὲν οὖν"]
paragraphs.openai_translation: Hot, cold, dry, and moist are spoken of homonymously [i.e., with the same name used in different senses]; for in some cases things are so called by predominance [of a quality], and in others as possessing the extreme of the quality from which the name is derived. The thing under examination will be such in potentiality as that into which it readily passes. For oil is potentially hot because it easily becomes flame; and likewise resin, asphalt, and pitch. Wine, on the other hand, because it easily becomes blood; and likewise honey, flesh, and milk. These, then—

paragraphs.content: ὅλαις ἀλλοιούμενα ταῖς οὐσίαις τροφαὶ τῶν ἀλλοιούντων εἰσί. τὰ δὲ κατὰ μίαν ἡντιναοῦν ποιότητα τὴν ἀλλοίωσιν ἴσχοντά τε καὶ τρεπόμενα φάρμακα μόνον ὥσπερ γε καὶ ὅσα ταῖς ὅλαις ἑαυτῶν οὐσίαις ἄτρεπτα μένοντα διατίθησι τὸ σῶμα φάρμακα μέν ἐστι καὶ ταῦτα· χαλεπὰ δὲ καὶ φθαρτικὰ τῆς τοῦ ζώου φύσεως· ὅθεν περ οἶμαι καὶ τὸ γένος αὐτῶν ἅπαν ὀνομάζεται δηλητήριον. οὐ γὰρ δὴ διὰ τοῦτό γε λεκτέον οὐκ εἶναι τῷ γένει δηλητήρια τὰ τοιαῦτα
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.5:

Things that are altered in their entire substances are nourishments of those things that alter them. But those things that have and undergo alteration according to any single quality whatsoever are only drugs, just as indeed also those things which, while remaining unchanged in their entire substances, affect the body—these too are drugs, but they are harmful and destructive to the nature of the living creature. For this reason, I believe, their entire class is called poison [dēlētērion]. For surely one should not say that such things are not poisons by their very nature because of this.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Things that are altered in their entire substances are the nourishment of the things that alter them [i.e., of the living body]. But those which effect alteration according to any one single quality [e.g., hot, cold, dry, or moist], while themselves also being changed, are drugs only; and likewise whatever, remaining unchangeable in their whole substances, disposes the body—these too are drugs, but harsh and destructive to the nature of the living creature. Hence, I suppose, their whole class is called “poison.” For surely not on this account must one say that such things are not, in kind, poisons.

paragraphs.content: διότι παντελῶς ἐλάχιστα προσαχθέντα βλάβην οὐδὲ μίαν αἰσθητὴν ἐπιφέρει. οὕτω γὰρ ἂν οὐδὲ τὸ πῦρ εἴη θερμὸν οὐδ’ ἡ χιὼν ψυχρά· ὡς καὶ τούτων γε παντάπασι τὰ σμικρὰ σαφὲς οὐδὲν ἀποτελεῖ περὶ τοῖς σώμασιν ἡμῶν πάθος. σπινθῆρος γὰρ ἑνὸς ἑκατοστὸν μέρος ἔστι μὲν πάντως τῷ γένει πῦρ ἀλλ’ οὐ μόνον οὐκ ἂν ἡμᾶς καύσειεν ἢ θερμῄνειεν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Because when extremely small amounts are applied, they bring about no perceptible harm whatsoever. For in this way fire would not be hot nor snow cold; since even with these things, completely small amounts produce no clear effect upon our bodies. For the hundredth part of a single spark is certainly fire by its nature, but it would not only fail to burn or warm us
paragraphs.openai_translation: For what is applied in an utterly minimal amount brings about not even a single perceptible harm. For otherwise neither would fire be hot nor snow cold; since, of these too, the utterly small [quantities] produce no evident effect [pathos] upon our bodies. For a hundredth part of a single spark is certainly fire in kind, yet it would not only fail to burn or warm us…

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ οὐδ’ ἄν αἴσθησίν τινα παράσχοι προσπεσόν. οὕτω δὲ καὶ τὸ τῆς ψυχρᾶς ῥανίδος ἑκατοστὸν μέρος οὐ μόνον οὐδὲν ἂν βλάψειεν ἢ ψύξειεν ἀλλ’ οὐδ’ ἂν αἴσθησίν τινα παράσχοι. μὴ τοίνυν οὕτως μηδὲ τὰ δηλητήρια κρίνειν ἀλλὰ τῇ τῆς ὅλης φύσεως ἐναντιώσει τὴν δ’ ἐναντίωσιν ἐκ τῆς ἐμμέσου κρίνειν μεταβολῆς. οἷον εὐθέως ἀπὸ τῶν στοιχείων οὔθ’ ὕδωρ εἰς πῦρ οὔτε πῦρ εἰς ὕδωρ μεταβάλλειν πέφυκεν ἀλλ’ εἰς ἀέρα μὲν ἄμφω ἐκεῖνος δ’ εἰς ἑκάτερα
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But neither would it provide any sensation when it strikes. And in the same way, the hundredth part of a cold droplet not only would neither harm nor cool anything, but would not even provide any sensation. Therefore, one should not judge poisons in this way either, but rather by the opposition to the whole nature, and one should judge the opposition from the intermediate transformation. For example, immediately from the elements, neither does water naturally change into fire nor fire into water, but both change into air, and air changes into each of them.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But even if it came into contact, it would not produce any perception. Similarly, the hundredth part of a cold drop would not only do no harm or cause no chilling, but would not even produce any perception. Do not, then, judge poisons in this way either, but by the opposition of the whole nature [enantiōsis = contrariety], and determine the opposition from the change that proceeds through what is intermediate. For example, at the level of the elements [stoicheia], neither is water by nature disposed to change into fire nor fire into water, but both into air, and that [air] into either of the two.

paragraphs.content: εἰς ἄλληλα δὲ ταῦτ’ οὐδαμῶς.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
But these things [change] into one another in no way whatsoever.

---

**Alternative translation:**

But these do not [change] into each other at all.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But these do not pass into one another at all [i.e., there is no mutual transformation].

paragraphs.content: ἄμεσος μὲν οὖν ἡ εἰς ἀέρα μεταβολὴ τοῦ ὕδατος· ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ τοῦ πυρός. οὐκ ἄμεσον δὲ ἡ πυρὸς καὶ ὕδατος εἰς ἄλληλα ταῦτ’ οὖν ἀλλήλοις ἐναντία ἐστὶ καὶ πολέμια. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον καὶ ὀπὸς μήκωνος ἀνθρωπείῳ σώματι τελέως ἐστὶν ἐναντίος οὐδὲν εἰς αὐτὸ οὔτε κατὰ μίαν ποιότητα δρᾶσαι δυνάμενον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

The transformation of water into air is immediate; and likewise also that of fire. But the transformation of fire and water into one another is not immediate. These, therefore, are opposite and hostile to one another. In the same manner, poppy juice [opium] is completely opposite to the human body, being unable to act upon it in accordance with even a single quality.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Direct, then, is the change of water into air; and likewise that of fire. But the change of fire and water into one another is not direct. Therefore these are contrary and mutually hostile. In the same way, the sap [opos: latex/juice] of the poppy [mēkōn] is utterly opposed to the human body, with nothing in it able to act upon it by any single quality [poiotēs: simple property].

paragraphs.content: οὔτε πολὺ δὴ μᾶλλον ἔτι καθ’ ὅλην τὴν οὐσίαν. ἓν μὲν δὴ τοῦτο γένος τῶν δηλητηρίων. ἕτερον δὲ τῶν ἀφορμὴν μέν τινα μεταβολῆς λαμβανόντων ἐκ τῆς ἐν ἡμῖν θερμασίας εἰς πολυειδεῖς δ’ ἐντεῦθεν ἐκτρεπομένων ἀλλοιώσεις ὑφ’ ὧν διαφθείρεσθαι τὴν φύσιν ἡμῶν συμβαίνει. πάντα γὰρ τὰ τοιαῦτα τῷ γένει δηλητήρια
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"nor indeed much more still according to the whole substance. This then is one class of poisons. But another is of those things which receive a certain starting point of change from the heat within us, and from this point turn aside into manifold alterations, by which it happens that our nature is destroyed. For all such things are poisons by their class."
paragraphs.openai_translation: Nor, to be sure, any further with respect to the substance as a whole. This, then, is one kind of poisons [δηλητήρια]. Another is that of things which take some occasion [ἀφορμή: starting-point] of change from the heat within us [θερμασία: innate heat], and from this point are deflected into manifold alterations [ἀλλοιώσεις: qualitative changes], under the influence of which it comes about that our nature is destroyed. For all such things are, in their kind, poisons.

paragraphs.content: κᾂν διὰ σμικρότητά ποτε μηδὲν αἰσθητὸν ἀπεργάζηται. τὰ μὲν δὴ διαβιβρώσκοντα καὶ σήποντα καὶ τήκοντα τὴν τοῦ σώματος ἡμῶν φύσιν εἰκότως ὀνομάζεται δυνάμει θερμά· τὰ δ’ αὖ ψύχοντα καὶ ναρκοῦντα ψυχρά. τὰ μὲν οὖν πρότερα παράλογον οὐδὲν οὔτε αὐτὰ πάσχειν οὔτε τοῖς σώμασιν ἡμῶν ἐναπεργάζεσθαι δοκεῖ. θερμῷ γὰρ σώματι πλησιάσαντα καί τινα ῥοπὴν ἀλλοιώσεως ἐντεῦθεν λαβόντα τὰ μὲν εἰς ἐσχάτην ἀφικνεῖται θερμότητα
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.11:

And even if on account of smallness it sometimes produces nothing perceptible. Now then, those things that corrode and putrefy and melt the nature of our body are reasonably called hot in potency; and in turn those things that cool and numb are cold. Therefore, as for the former, it seems in no way unreasonable either that they themselves are affected or that they produce effects in our bodies. For having approached a hot body and having received from this some impulse toward alteration, some things arrive at extreme heat
paragraphs.openai_translation: And even if at times, because of its smallness, it produces nothing perceptible. Those things that gnaw through, rot, and melt the nature of our body are reasonably called hot in power [dynamei: in their capacity]; while those that chill and benumb are cold. As for the former, there is nothing unreasonable in their seeming both to be affected themselves and to produce effects within our bodies. For, when they approach a hot body and from that take on some inclination toward alteration [rhopē alloiōseōs: a tendency to change], some of them arrive at extreme heat.

paragraphs.content: τὰ δ’ εἰς σηπεδόνα. διατίθησιν οὖν εἰκότως καὶ τὰ τῶν ζώων σώματα κατὰ τὴν ἑαυτῶν διάθεσιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But those things [lead] to putrefaction. Therefore, it reasonably affects the bodies of animals according to their own condition.
paragraphs.openai_translation: And others into putrefaction [decay]. Accordingly, it fittingly disposes the bodies of animals according to their own condition.

paragraphs.content: ὅσα δὲ ψύχει τὸ σῶμα, κᾂν θερμῄνας αὐτὰ προσενέγκῃς, ἀπορίαν οὐ σμικρὰν ἐπιφέρει, τίνος ποτὲ φύσεώς ἐστιν. εἰ γὰρ ἅπαξ ἐνεργείᾳ θερμὰ γέγονε, τί οὐ θερμαίνει τὸ ζῶον; ἢ εἰ μήπω τεθέρμανται, πῶς φαίνεται θερμά; λύσις δὲ τῆς ἀπορίας, εἰ διορισθείη τὸ καθ’ αὑτὸ ψυχρὸν τοῦ κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς, ὡς Ἀριστοτέλης ἐδίδαξεν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But those things which cool the body, even if you apply them after heating them, present no small difficulty as to what their nature really is. For if they have once become actually hot, why do they not heat the living creature? Or if they have not yet been heated, how do they appear hot? The solution to this difficulty is found if one distinguishes what is cold in itself from what is cold accidentally, as Aristotle taught.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But whatever cools the body, even if you apply them after heating them, brings on no small difficulty as to what sort of nature they have. For if they have once become hot in actuality [energeia], why do they not heat the living creature? Or if they have not yet been heated, how do they seem hot? The solution to the difficulty lies in distinguishing the cold in itself [per se] from the cold by accident [accidentally], as Aristotle taught.

paragraphs.content: ἀπόλλυται γὰρ ἐν τάχει τῶν κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς θερμῶν ἡ ἐπίκτητος διάθεσις ὥστ’ εἰς τὴν ἀρχαίαν αὐτὰ φύσιν ἐπανέρχεσθαι ῥᾳδίως. ἐν δὲ τῷ πλησιάζειν ἡμῖν τὰ φύσει μὲν ψυχρὰ κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς δὲ θερμὰ δύο ταῦτ’ ἐξ ἀνάγκης γίνεται· τὸ μὲν ἐπίκτητον αὐτῶν ἀπόλλυται θερμὸν ἡ δ’ οἰκεία κρᾶσις οὐδὲν ὑπὸ τῆς ἡμετέρας πάσχουσα μένει ψυχρά καὶ τί θαυμαστὸν εἰ μήκωνος ὀπὸς ἢ μανδραγόρας ἢ κώνειον ἤ τι τῶν τοιούτων εἶ καὶ θερμανθέντα προσενεχθείης
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.14:

For the acquired disposition of things that are hot accidentally is destroyed quickly, so that they easily return to their original nature. But when things that are cold by nature but hot accidentally come near us, these two things necessarily occur: their acquired heat is destroyed, while their own mixture [natural temperament], suffering nothing from our own, remains cold. And what is surprising if you should consume juice of poppy or mandrake or hemlock or any such thing even when it has been heated?

---

**Brief notes:**
- [κρᾶσις (krasis)] refers to the natural mixture or temperament of a substance according to ancient medical theory
- The text appears incomplete at the end, breaking off mid-sentence with "εἶ" (a conditional "if")
paragraphs.openai_translation: For the acquired condition of things hot only by accident is quickly lost, so that they readily return to their original nature. And when things that are by nature cold but accidentally hot come near us, two things necessarily occur: their acquired heat is destroyed, while their own proper mixture [crasis: inherent temperament], suffering nothing from our [heat], remains cold. And what is surprising if poppy juice, or mandrake, or hemlock, or something of the sort—even after being warmed—were applied?

paragraphs.content: μικρὸν ὕστερον γίνεται ψυχρά; πτισσάνης καὶ γάλακτος καὶ χόνδρου καὶ ἄρτου τὸ αὐτὸ τοῦτο πασχόντων ἐπειδὰν εἰς ἄῤῥωστον ἐμπεσόντα γαστέρα μὴ κρατηθῇ πρὸς αὐτῆς· ἐμεῖται γοῦν πολλάκις ἱκανῶς ψυχρά. καὶ τό γε τούτων μεῖζον ὃ δὴ καὶ Ἱπποκράτης ἐπεσημῄνατο· καίτοι χυμὸς ὂν ἤδη τὸ φλέγμα κᾀκ τῶν σιτίων τῶν μὴ πεφθέντων πολλάκις ἐν τῇ γαστρὶ γεννώμενος ὅμως ψυχρὸν ἁπτομένοις φαίνεται οὐ μόνον ἐν τῇ γαστρὶ συστὰν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

does it become cold a little later? When barley-gruel and milk and groats and bread undergo this same thing whenever they fall into a weak stomach and are not mastered by it—at any rate they are often vomited up quite cold. And there is something even more significant than these things which Hippocrates indeed noted: although phlegm is already a humor [bodily fluid] and is often generated in the stomach from foods that have not been digested, nevertheless it appears cold to the touch, not only when it has collected in the stomach
paragraphs.openai_translation: A little later does it become cold? Ptisane [barley gruel], milk, chondros [barley groats], and bread experience exactly this same thing whenever, having fallen into a sick stomach, they are not retained by it; one often vomits them, in fact, quite cold. And what is more significant among these—which Hippocrates also noted: although phlegm, being already a juice [humor], and often produced in the stomach from foods that have not been cooked/digested, nevertheless feels cold to the touch, not only when it has formed in the stomach—

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ κᾀκ τῶν φλεβῶν αὐτῶν ὑπό τινος τῶν καθαιρόντων φαρμάκων ἑλχθέν. καί τοί γε γλισχρότατόν ἐστι σφόδρα καὶ βιαίως ἄγεται ἀλλ’ ὅμως οὐδ’ ἡ βία τῆς ὁλκῆς ἐκθερμαίνειν αὐτὸ δύναται. τί οὖν θαυμαστὸν εἰ καὶ τὸ μηκώνειον οὕτως ἐναντίον ἡμῶν τῇ φύσει φάρμακον ἀποψύχεται μὲν αὐτίκα μάλα κᾂν θερμὸν ποθῇ συγκαταψύχει δ’ ἑαυτῷ τὸ σῶμα. τὴν γὰρ ἐπίκτητον οὐ φυλάττει θερμασίαν ὅτι φύσει ψυχρὸν ἦν· τῷ δὲ μηδ’ ἀλλοιοῦσθαι τὴν οὐσίαν αὐτοῦ πρὸς ἡμῶν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But [it is drawn] even from the veins themselves by one of the purgative drugs. And indeed it is extremely viscous and is drawn with force, but nevertheless not even the violence of the drawing is able to heat it. What wonder is it, then, if poppy juice [opium], being a drug so contrary to our nature, cools down immediately even if it is drunk hot, and cools the body along with itself? For it does not retain the acquired heat because it was cold by nature; and because its substance is not even altered by us
paragraphs.openai_translation: But even from their very veins it has been drawn off by some one of the purgative drugs [cathartics]. And indeed it is exceedingly viscid and is carried off by force, yet not even the violence of the traction is able to warm it through. What wonder, then, if opium [mekonion], a drug so contrary to our nature, likewise chills one at once, and even if it craves heat, it cools the body down along with itself. For it does not preserve the warmth that is acquired, since by nature it was cold; and because its substance is not altered by us at all.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλὰ μᾶλλον ἀλλοιοῦν τε καὶ μεταβάλλειν ἡμᾶς οὔτε θερμαίνεταί τι πρὸς ἡμῶν αὐτό τε διατίθησιν ἡμᾶς καθ’ αὑτό· ψυχρὸν οὖν ὑπάρχον φύσει ψύχει δήπου καὶ ἡμᾶς. οὐκοῦν οὐκέτ’ ἄπορον οὐδὲν ὑπόλοιπον ἐν τῷ λόγῳ. καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ ὅτι τούτων ἁπάντων τῶν φύσει ψυχρῶν ὅ τι ἂν ἐπὶ πλέον ἐκθερμῄνης ἐξίσταται τῆς ἰδίας φύσεως πρὸς τῷ μηδὲν ἄπορον ἔχειν ἔτι καὶ μαρτυρεῖ τοῖς εἰρημένοις.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But rather it alters and changes us, while it is not itself heated by us, and it affects us according to its own nature. Therefore, being cold by nature, it surely also cools us. Consequently, nothing problematic or puzzling remains in the argument. And indeed, the fact that whatever of all these things that are cold by nature you heat excessively departs from its own nature, in addition to having nothing puzzling about it, also bears witness to what has been said.
paragraphs.openai_translation: But rather, while it both alters and transforms us, it is not in any way heated by us; instead, it itself disposes us in accordance with its own character [i.e., sets our condition to match its nature]. Since, then, it is by nature cold, it obviously chills us as well. Accordingly, nothing perplexing remains in the argument. For indeed the fact that, among all things that are cold by nature, whatever is heated to excess departs from its own nature not only leaves nothing puzzling, but also corroborates what has been said.

paragraphs.content: ὡς γὰρ καὶ ἡ σαλαμάνδρα μέχρι μέν τινος ὑπὸ πυρὸς οὐδὲν πάσχει κατακαίεται δ’ εἰ πλείονι χρόνῳ τῷ πυρὶ πλησιάσειεν οὕτω καὶ ὁ μανδραγόρας καὶ κώνειον καὶ ψύλλιον ἐπὶ βραχὺ μὲν ὁμιλήσαντα τῷ πυρὶ τὴν οἰκείαν ἔτι διαφυλάττει κρᾶσιν ἐπὶ πλέον δὲ θερμανθέντα διαφθείρεται παραχρῆμα καὶ δρᾷν οὐκέτι οὐδὲν ὧν πρότερον ἐπεφύκει δύναται. τῶν μὲν δὴ τοιούτων ἁπάντων ἡ φύσις ἐναντιωτάτη τοῖς ἀνθρώποις ἐστί· φύσιν δ’ ὅταν εἴπω τὴν ὅλην οὐσίαν τε καὶ κρᾶσιν λέγω
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.18:

For just as the salamander up to a certain point suffers nothing from fire but is burned up if it approaches the fire for a longer time, so too mandrake and hemlock and fleawort, when they come into contact with fire for a brief period, still preserve their own mixture, but when heated for a longer time they are immediately destroyed and are no longer able to do anything that they were naturally capable of doing before. Now the nature of all such things is most contrary to that of human beings; and when I say "nature" I mean the whole substance and mixture.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For just as the salamander up to a certain point suffers nothing from fire, but is burned up if it should approach the fire for a longer time, so too mandrake, hemlock, and psyllium [plantain/psyllium]: after consorting with fire for a short while, they still preserve their own proper mixture [krāsis]; but when heated for longer they are immediately destroyed and can no longer do any of the things they were formerly by nature able to effect. Now the nature [physis] of all such things is most hostile to human beings; and when I say “nature,” I mean the entire substance and mixture [krāsis].

paragraphs.content: τὴν ἐκ τῶν πρώτων στοιχείων θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ· τῶν δὲ τάχιστα τρεφόντων οἰκειοτάτη. τὰ δ’ ἄλλα πάντα μεταξὺ τούτων ἐστί· τὰ μὲν μᾶλλον τὰ δ’ ἧττον δρᾷν καὶ πάσχειν ὑπὸ τοῦ σώματος ἡμῶν δυνάμενα. καστόριον μὲν γὰρ καὶ πέπερι δρᾷν μᾶλλον ἢ πάσχειν ὑπὸ τοῦ σώματος ἡμῶν δυνάμενα· οἶνος δὲ καὶ μέλι καὶ πτισσάνη πάσχειν μᾶλλον ἢ δρᾷν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

from the primary elements of hot and cold and dry and wet; and [it is] most akin to those things that nourish most quickly. All other things are between these extremes: some being more able to act upon and be acted upon by our body, others less so. For castoreum and pepper are more able to act upon rather than be acted upon by our body; while wine and honey and barley-gruel are more able to be acted upon rather than to act.
paragraphs.openai_translation: That which comes from the primary elements—hot, cold, dry, and moist; and of these, the one most akin [to us] is that which nourishes most quickly. All the others fall between these: some are more, others less, able to act upon and to be acted upon by our body. For castoreum and pepper are able to act upon our body rather than to be acted upon, whereas wine, honey, and ptisan [barley gruel/barley-water] are rather acted upon than act.

paragraphs.content: ἅπαντα οὖν ταῦτα καὶ πάσχει τι καὶ δρᾷ περὶ τὸ σῶμα. καθ’ ὅλου γὰρ ἐπειδὰν εἰς ταὐτὸ ἀλλήλοις ἥκοντα διαμάχηταί τε καὶ στασιάζῃ πρὸς ἄλληλα περὶ τῆς ἀλλοιώσεως ἐν χρόνῳ πλείονι, δρᾷν καὶ πάσχειν ἑκάτερον αὐτῶν ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation: Therefore all these things both undergo something and act upon the body. For in general, whenever they come together into the same place with one another and fight and are in conflict with each other concerning their mutual alteration over a longer period of time, it is necessary that each of them both acts and is acted upon.
paragraphs.openai_translation: All these, then, both undergo something and act with respect to the body. For, in general [kath’ holou], whenever, having come together into the same [subject], they contend and are at odds with one another concerning alteration [alloiōsis, qualitative change] over a longer time, it is necessary that each of them both act and be acted upon.

paragraphs.content: ἴσως δὲ, κᾂν μὴ πολλῷ πάνυ χρόνῳ γίγνηται τοῦτο, δρᾷ μὲν ἔτι καὶ τότε τὸ νικώμενον εἰς τὸ κρατοῦν, ἀλλ’ οὕτω σμικρὸν, ὡς λανθάνειν τὴν αἴσθησιν. οὐδὲ γὰρ ὁ τμητικώτατος σίδηρος εἰ τὸν μαλακώτατον τέμνει κηρὸν δι’ ὅλης ἡμέρας καὶ νυκτὸς, ἀδύνατον αὐτῷ μὴ οὐκ ἀμβλὺν γενέσθαι σαφῶς. οὕτω δή που κᾀκεῖνο καλῶς εἰρῆσθαι δοκεῖ, Πέτρην κοιλαίνει ῥανὶς ὕδατος ἐνδελεχείῃ. καὶ γὰρ καὶ φαίνεται γινόμενον οὕτως.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Perhaps, even if this does not happen over a very long time, the thing being overcome still acts even then upon the thing prevailing, but so slightly that it escapes perception. For not even the sharpest iron, if it cuts the softest wax throughout an entire day and night, is it impossible for it not to become clearly blunt. Thus indeed that saying too seems to be well spoken: "A drop of water hollows out a stone by persistence." For indeed this is also seen to happen in this way.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Perhaps, even if this comes about in no very long time, the element being overcome still even then acts upon the prevailing one, but so slightly as to escape perception. For not even the keenest iron, if it cuts the softest wax through a whole day and night, can possibly fail to become plainly blunt. Thus that saying, too, seems well put: “A drop of water hollows a rock by persistence [continual action].” For it is in fact seen to occur in this way.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ἐπὶ μὲν μιᾶς ἢ καὶ δευτέρας προσβολῆς οὐδὲν οὔπω σαφὲς ἐν τοῖς τοιούτοις ἰδεῖν ἐστιν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
But in the case of one or even a second attack, it is not yet possible to see anything clear in such matters.

---

**Alternative translation:**

But at one or even a second encounter, nothing clear can yet be observed in such cases.

[Note: The word "προσβολή" can mean "attack" (in a medical sense, referring to the onset of disease), "encounter," or "approach" depending on context. The medical interpretation is most common in classical medical texts.]
paragraphs.openai_translation: But at the first, or even the second, onset [προσβολή: attack], nothing as yet clear can be seen in matters of this kind.

paragraphs.content: ὅθεν, οἶμαι, καὶ τὸ μηδ’ ὅλως πάσχειν ἔνια πρὸς τῶν ὁμιλούντων ἐδοξάσθη τισί· καὶ συγχωρητέον γε τοῖς οὕτω λέγουσι. πολλάκις δὲ καὶ αὐτοὺς ἡμᾶς ὁμοίως ἐκείνοις λεκτέον ἐστὶ τὰ πολλά· πλὴν εἴ ποτε μέχρι τῆς ἐσχάτης ἀκριβείας ἀνάγοιμεν τὸν λόγον, ὥσπερ ἐν τῷ παρόντι ποιοῦμεν. οὕτως οὖν καὶ τὸ τῆς ἀειπαθείας δόγμα, τῷ λόγῳ μὲν αὐτῷ μόνῳ σκοποῦσιν, ἰσχυρὰν ἔχει τὴν ἀπόδειξιν. οὐ μὴν χρεία γέ τίς ἐστιν αὐτοῦ πρὸς τὰς κατὰ μέρος πράξεις.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.23:

Whence, I believe, the view has been held by some that certain things are not affected at all by those things that come into contact with them; and indeed we must grant this to those who speak in this way. But often we ourselves too must speak in the same manner as they do about most matters; except whenever we might carry the argument to the utmost precision, as we are doing in the present case. Thus, then, the doctrine of perpetual affection [ἀειπάθεια], when examined by reason alone in itself, has a strong demonstration. Nevertheless, there is no practical need for it in relation to particular actions.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Whence, I suppose, some of our interlocutors have even come to think that certain things do not undergo any affection at all [i.e., are entirely unaffected]; and one should indeed grant this to those who speak in that way. Often enough we too, for the most part, must speak as they do—except whenever we carry the argument to the utmost precision, as we are doing in the present discussion. Thus, then, the doctrine of ever-passivity [ἀειπαθεία: continual being-affected] also, for those who consider it by reason alone, has a strong demonstration. However, there is no need of it for particular, practical applications [κατὰ μέρος πράξεις: specific procedures or cases].

paragraphs.content: ἂν γὰρ οὕτω μικρά τινα περὶ ἡμᾶς ᾖ πάθη διὰ παντὸς ὡς μηδεμίαν αἰσθητὴν καὶ σαφῆ βλάβην ἐνεργείας ἐργάζεσθαι μηδεμιᾶς εὐκαταφρόνητα δήπουθέν ἐστι καὶ τῷ μηδὲν εἶναι φάσκοντι τὰ τοιαῦτα συγχωρητέον. οὕτως οὖν ἔχει κᾀπὶ τῶν τρεφόντων ὀλίγου δεῖν ἁπάντων. ἐργάζεται μὲν γάρ τι καὶ ταῦτα περὶ τὸ σῶμα τῶν ἀνθρώπων ἀλλ’ οὐκ αἰσθητὸν
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For if certain affections around us are so small throughout as to produce no perceptible and clear harm to any activity, they are surely contemptible and one must concede to the person who claims that such things are nothing. Now this is how it is with nearly all nourishing things as well. For these too produce some effect upon the human body, but not a perceptible one.
paragraphs.openai_translation: For if the affections concerning us are at all times so slight as to produce no perceptible and clear damage to any activity [function], they are of course easy to disregard, and one may concede the point to the person who claims that such things are nothing. So it is, then, with almost all things that nourish [nutrients/foods]: these too exert some effect upon the human body, but not a perceptible one.

paragraphs.content: οὐδὲ σαφές τι καθάπαξ. ἡ μέντοι πολυχρόνιος αὐτῶν προσφορὰ μεγάλως ἀλλοιοῖ καὶ μεταβάλλει σαφῶς ἤδη τὰ σώματα. ἔνια μέν γε καὶ κατὰ τὴν πρώτην χρῆσιν εὐθὺς ἐναργῶς ἐνδείκνυται τὴν ἀλλοίῳσιν οἶον καὶ ἡ θριδακίνη τοὺς μὲν ἐγκαιομένους τὴν γαστέρα σαφῶς ἐμψύχουσά τε καὶ ἀδίψους ἐργαζομένη τοὺς δὲ κατεψυγμένους ἐναργῶς βλάπτουσα. συντελεῖ δ’ οὐ σμικρὰ καὶ τοῖς ὕπνοις οὐ κατ’ ἄλλον τινὰ λόγον
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

nor anything clearly at all. However, their prolonged application greatly alters and clearly transforms the bodies already. Some things indeed even at the first use immediately demonstrate the alteration clearly, as for example lettuce, which clearly cools those who are burning in the stomach and makes them free from thirst, but manifestly harms those who are chilled. And it contributes not a little also to sleep, not according to any other principle
paragraphs.openai_translation: Nor is anything absolutely certain. Yet their prolonged administration greatly alters and, indeed, now manifestly transforms the bodies. Some substances even on first use at once clearly display the alteration—for example, lettuce [thridakē; often the juice is meant]. It plainly revives those whose stomach is inflamed and makes them without thirst, while it clearly harms those who are chilled. And for much the same reason it also contributes not a little to sleep.

paragraphs.content: ἀλλ’ ὅτι ψυχρά τέ ἐστι καὶ ὑγρὰ τὴν κρᾶσιν· ἀλλ’ οὕτως ὑγρὰ καὶ ψυχρὰ πρὸς ἄνθρωπόν τε καὶ τἄλλ’ ὅσα τρέφειν πέφυκεν ὡς καὶ τὰ ξύλα τὰ χλωρὰ πρὸς τὸ πῦρ.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But [the reason is] that it is cold and moist in its mixture; yet it is moist and cold in relation to man and all other things which it is naturally suited to nourish in the same way that green wood is in relation to fire.
paragraphs.openai_translation: …but that it is cold and moist in its krasis [mixture/temperament]; and so moist and cold in relation to human beings and to all other things that are by nature nourished, as green wood is to fire.

paragraphs.content: ὥστ’ εὐλόγως ἄμφω τοῖς τοιούτοις ἐδέσμασιν ὑπάρχει τό θ’ ὡς φαρμάκοις διατιθέναι τὰ σώμαθ’ ἡμῶν καὶ τὸ τρέφειν παρ’ ὅλον μὲν τὸν χρόνον τῆς πέψεως ὡς φαρμάκοις· ἡνίκα δ’ ἤδη τρέφει τε καὶ τελέως ὁμοιοῦται τότ’ οὐκέτ’ οὐδὲν ἡμᾶς ἀντιδρῶντα τὴν ἔμφυτον αὔξει θερμασίαν ὡς καὶ πρόσθεν εἴρηται. κοινὸν γὰρ ἤδη τῶν τρεφόντων ἁπάντων ἐστὶ καὶ οὐ χρὴ θαυμάζειν εἴ τι πρὶν μὲν ἐξομοιοῦσθαι καὶ τρέφειν ἔτι πεττόμενον ἔψυχεν ἐξομοιωθὲν δὲ καὶ θρέψαν ἐθέρμῃνε
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

So that reasonably both characteristics belong to such foods: both to affect our bodies as drugs do and to nourish. Throughout the entire time of digestion they act as drugs; but when they already nourish and are completely assimilated, then they no longer act against us by counteracting the innate heat, as was said before. For this is now common to all nourishing things, and one should not be surprised if something that cooled while it was still being digested and before being assimilated and nourishing, once assimilated and having nourished, warmed.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, it is reasonable that both properties belong to foods of this sort: both to dispose our bodies as if with drugs [pharmaka], and to nourish—indeed, throughout the whole time of digestion [pepsis] they act as drugs. But when they already nourish and have been completely assimilated, then, no longer in any way reacting against us, they increase the innate heat [the body’s inborn warmth], as was said before. For this is common to all things that nourish; and one should not be surprised if something, before being assimilated and while it still nourishes yet is being digested, cools, but once assimilated and having nourished, warms.

paragraphs.content: μεμνημένους ἀεὶ τοῦ τῶν χλωρῶν ξύλων παραδείγματος.
paragraphs.claude_translation: always remembering the example of green wood.
paragraphs.openai_translation: always keeping in mind the example of green wood [i.e., fresh/unseasoned timber]

paragraphs.content: ὥστε καὶ ἡ χρεία τῶν τοιούτων ἁπάντων διττὴ τοῖς ἰατροῖς ἐστι καὶ ὡς σιτίων καὶ ὡς φαρμάκων. φέρε γὰρ ὑπηλλάχθαι τινὶ τὴν ἀρίστην ἐν τῇ γαστρὶ κρᾶσιν ἐπὶ τὸ θερμότερον. οὗτος ἄχρι μὲν οὗ πέττει τὴν θριδακίνην ἐμψυχθήσεται καὶ συμμετρίαν κτήσεται κράσεως· ἐπειδὰν δ’ ἐξ αὐτῆς ἤδη τρέφηται τὴν οὐσίαν αὐξήσει τῆς ἐμφύτου θερμασίας. ἐν τούτῳ δὴ καὶ μάλιστα δοκοῦσί μοι παραλογίζεσθαι σφᾶς αὐτοὺς οἱ πολλοὶ τῶν νεωτέρων ἰατρῶν ἀγνοοῦντες
paragraphs.claude_translation:
# Translation of Paragraph 4.29:

So the use of all such things is twofold for physicians, both as foods and as medicines. For suppose that someone's best mixture in the stomach has been altered toward the hotter. This person, for as long as he digests the lettuce, will be cooled and will acquire a proper balance of mixture; but when he is already being nourished from it, he will increase the substance of his innate heat. In this matter especially, it seems to me, the majority of the younger physicians deceive themselves, not knowing—

---

**Note:** The text breaks off mid-sentence with "not knowing" (ἀγνοοῦντες), suggesting the passage continues beyond what was provided.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Accordingly, the use of all such things is twofold for physicians—both as foods and as drugs. For suppose that in someone the optimal mixture [krāsis: balance of qualities] in the stomach has been altered toward the hotter. This person, until he digests the lettuce [thridakē], will be reinvigorated and will acquire a proportional balance of mixture; but when he is already being nourished from it, he will increase the stock of his inborn heat. It is precisely at this point, I think, that most of the younger physicians most of all deceive themselves, through ignorance.

paragraphs.content: ὡς ἐνίοτε μὲν ἡ ποιότης ἐπιτείνεται τῆς ἐν ἡμῖν θερμασίας ἐνίοτε δ’ ἡ οὐσία παραύξεται καὶ ὡς ἑκατέρως οἱ παλαιοὶ θερμότερον γεγονέναι τὸ ζῶόν φασι. καὶ γὰρ καὶ γίνεται θερμότερον ἄντ’ ἐπιτείνῃς αὐτοῦ τὴν θερμασίαν ἄντ’ αὐξήσῃς τὴν οὐσίαν ἐν ᾗ πρώτῃ περιέχεται. φέρε γὰρ εἶναι τὸ αἷμα τὸ ἐν τῷ σώματι τοῦ ζώου καθ’ αὑτὸ θερμὸν ἢ νὴ Δία εἰ βούλει τὴν ξανθὴν χολὴν ἅπαντα δὲ τἄλλα κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς ὑπάρχειν θερμὰ τῷ τούτων μετέχειν.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:
